title: A Pastry Chef Unleashed
description: IACOPO FALAI had already made a success of himself. He was just 30, a relative newcomer to the United States, and working as the pastry chef at no less a restaurant than Le Cirque 2000. But nothing about the job felt right - not the volume of orders, the size of the staff, the emphasis on showmanship, the glossy Midtown location. He was wearing marzipan shackles, and he wanted to take longer strides.

title: Hiding the Data on Drug Trials
description: Any Americans gullible enough to believe that the drug industry can be trusted to report fully on what clinical trials it is sponsoring or what results were found must be sorely disappointed by recent developments. A government survey determined that three of the largest drug companies have effectively reneged on their pledges to list trials in a federal database. A report in yesterday's Times by Alex Berenson reveals that this intransigence also extends to a voluntary industry database. It looks as if demands from researchers and the medical profession for full access to clinical trial data will continue to be frustrated.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEALEY, JOHN ANTHONY, ''TONY.''
description: HEALEY -- John Anthony, "Tony." Died on May 28 in New York City at the age of 69 after long suffering from the effects of the neurological disease Multiple Systems Atrophy (MSA). He is survived by his beloved family: wife Louise, daughter Virginia, son John, daughter-inlaw Christina and two lovely grandsons, Jack and Scott, who were the apples of his eyes. He is also survived by his brothers Father Joseph G. Healey, Thomas J. Healey, sister Ann Oglesby and stepbrothers Michael K. Sheehan, Peter C. Sheehan, and predeceased by Barry C. Sheehan. Upon his retirement, Tony was a Managing Director at TCW and prior to that headed up his own private financial services firm specializing in international projects in energy, natural resources and the emerging markets. He also had been a partner at A.W. Jones. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 2, at 11:30 AM, at St. Ignatius Loyola, 84th and Park Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The memory of John A. Healey, The Department of Neurology, Columbia University at 170 West 168th Street, New York 10032.

Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVENSTEIN, DR. PHYLLIS
description: LEVENSTEIN -- Dr. Phyllis. Died in Rome on May 28, 2005 at the age of 88. Beloved wife of the late Sidney, loving mother of Susan and Daniel. A clinical psychologist who continued practicing until the very end, she founded, and directed for over thirty years, The Parent-Child Home Program, a national early literacy, parenting, and school readiness program. In 1965, she identified parent-child interaction as the key to the development of early language skills, and working with her statistician husband created a pioneering model program. The cost-effective Program helps educationally disadvantaged families prepare their children to enter school ready to succeed. There are now over 145 replications of the Program across the country. Tens of thousands of Program families and staff mourn her passing. A memorial service will be held in the Bay Area in July and in New York at a later date. Contributions in her memory may be made to The ParentChild Home Program (www.parent-child.org)

Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Number Of Smokers Falling, Surveys Find
description: The number of smokers in New York State fell again last year, according to two surveys released yesterday by the State Health Department that showed cigarette use to be at its lowest level in decades. One report found that 16.8 percent of adults smoked in 2004; the other said 19.9 percent of adults were smokers. The first survey showed a 1 percent drop from 2003, and the second showed a 6 percent decline. Antismoking advocates said the drop demonstrated the effect of tough new laws and increased cigarette taxes. It is too early to tell if the figures reflect a national trend, because national numbers for 2004 are still being compiled. Marc Santora (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza: Election Rerun Halted
description: Palestinian officials decided to delay a court-ordered rerun of elections in the Gaza Strip after the militant Islamic group Hamas said it would refuse to participate, despite Egyptian mediation. Hamas announced that it would not contest the new voting in three Gaza municipalities and one West Bank village, ordered after the governing Fatah party lodged accusations of voting fraud and a court ordered a revote in several districts of towns narrowly won by Hamas in local elections on May 5. In Ramallah, Jamal Shobaki, chairman of the elections committee, said, "We have decided to delay the elections until further notice in keeping with a request to avoid all problems on the Palestinian street." title: Vintage New York

They were the waving and smiling faded drawings and hand-painted signs of another era, advertisements for millineries and haberdasheries. Where are they now? And where are the dusty brick buildings? Who will we be in a city of glass? We'll be like those generic new buildings: Mirrors reflecting other mirrors, filled with unfulfilled vague longings. Or is that just the human condition?

The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation will pay for the park out of the last $800 million in federal funds earmarked for the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. Mr. Bloomberg said the project, which he predicted would be "one of the most attractive and popular public spaces in the entire city," would be completed within the next few years. The park would be in the district of Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, whose vote on the proposed West Side stadium this week is considered crucial. Paid Notice: Deaths   LAQUERCIA, EVELYN M. (NEE FERNANDEZ)
description: LAQUERCIA -- Evelyn M. (nee Fernandez). Of Brooklyn, NY, on May 29, 2005. Born in Oviedo, Spain, on November 2, 1943, beloved wife of Thomas Michael Laquercia, loving mother of Thomas Peter, Marc Anthony and Justin Gregory, devoted sister, caring and cherished aunt. Evelyn arrived in America on April 22, 1946, with her parents and sister, on the very first birthday of the man she would later marry. She attended Notre Dame School in Manhattan and was graduated from Hunter College with a degree in Economics. She began her career with Federated Department Stores as an assistant buyer and retired from business to raise her family. Twenty-one years ago, Evelyn was stricken with multiple sclerosis but lived a courageous life both as wife and mother, actively participating in her sons' moral formation and education that extended to bachelor degrees for each and a J.D. from Fordham Law School as well for Marc. Though limited to a wheel chair for a dozen years, she was filled with exuberance and the joy of life without complaint till the very end. She will be sorely missed by her family, neighbors and friends. A true fighter to the very end. Mass at Sacred Hearts St. Stephen, Friday, 9:30 A.M. In repose Raccuglia & Son, 321-323 Court Street, Brooklyn, 718-855-7737.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Longtime Head Of Development Bank Stepping Down
description: Enrique V. Iglesias, the long-serving president of the Inter-American Development Bank, which lends billions of dollars each year to governments in Latin America and the Caribbean, announced his resignation, effective Sept. 30. The bank, based in Washington, has had just three presidents since its founding in 1959, and the departure of Mr. Iglesias -- an Uruguayan who has held the top post since 1988 -- nearly three years before the expiration of his fourth term is expected to set off an intensely competitive succession battle in which Brazilian, Colombian, Mexican and Peruvian candidates have already been mentioned and will be competing for the support of the United States, the leading shareholder in the bank. At the Hirshhorn, she helped in acquiring acquire contemporary works and organize exhibitions. She replaces Ned Rifkin, who also served since January 2004 as the Smithsonian's under secretary for art. He will now work full time in that position, overseeing the Smithsonian's eight art organizations. ELIZABETH OLSON

The group announcedthat under a license from the United Statesgovernment it and the Hemingway PreservationFoundation have assembled a team ofarchitects and engineers to travel to Cubathis summer to work with Cuban counterpartson an emergency stabilization plan for the deteriorating property, nearHavana. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REICHMAN, JOAN CANALE
description: REICHMAN--Joan Canale, 76, died Sunday, May 29, 2005 after a long battle with cancer. Joan enjoyed an illustrious 45 years career in production and the arts in New York City. She began at Grey Advertising Agency creating commercials for Good Humor. She moved on to the Kudner Advertising Agency where she worked as production assistant on the Milton Berle Show, and other popular shows at the time. From 1953-1958 she worked as a production assistant with Jackie Gleason Enterprises. She frequently regaled audiences with tales about "Jackie, Art, Audrey and Joyce on and off the set." From 1959 through 1964 Joan assisted in the production and direction of the Robert Q. Lewis show, the Jimmy Rogers show and the Kate Smith show. She was also the managing agent for Art Carney, Mary Martin, James Mason, and others through her work with the McCaffrey Talent Agency. Joan's best work was as Director of Special Projects at the Lincoln Center Library and Museum of the Performing Arts. From Jackie Onassis to Robin Williams, she engaged, and entertained through screenings of all major studios, receptions and galas, and Amsterdam Gallery openings and exhibits. Joan was a vivacious and endearing person whose love and legacy touched multiple generations. From trips to Ireland with her dear friend Maureen O'Hara to St. Patrick's Day parties with her buddies at Neary's she lived life to the fullest. She is survived by her nieces Diane Heller Klein of Pittsburgh and Karen Heller of Las Vegas; her nephew Aaron Heller of Reno, her brother-in-law Daniel B. Heller of Pittsburgh, and her cousins Rita J. Gould of Pittsburgh and Sally Gould of San Francisco. She is also survived by loving grandnieces and nephews. Funeral at Ralph Schugar Chapel, Inc., Pittsburgh, PA 1-888-621-8282, for Wednesday, June 1. In lieu of flowers Joan requested that contributions be made to the organization of the donor's choice.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Woman Charged In Daughter's Rape
description: A 41-year-old Long Island woman was charged yesterday with rape in the second degree for her role in a sexual liaison between two young men and two under-age girls, one of them her daughter. According to the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, the woman, whose name was withheld to protect the victims, took her 13-year-old daughter and two friends, aged 13 and 14, to White Plains last month to shop. The mother later checked into a hotel, where she gave alcohol to the girls and the men, aged 18 and 19, whom they had met that day, Ms. Pirro said. The mother did not intervene as the 19-year-old had sexual intercourse with the 14-year-old friend in a bathroom and the 18-year-old had sex with her daughter in a hallway, Ms. Pirro said. The men and the mother were indicted on statutory rape charges because of the girls' ages. The mother was also charged with several counts of endangering the welfare of a child and unlawfully dealing with a child. Lisa W. Foderaro (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Sinopec Invests in Oil Sands
description: The Sinopec Group, a Chinese oil and gas producer, said its Canadian subsidiary had purchased a 40 percent holding in a proposed oil sands project in Alberta. Through a series of transactions, SinoCanada will pay 149.7 million Canadian dollars ($119.4 million) for the stake in the Northern Lights Project, which was entirely owned by Synenco Energy of Calgary. If developed as planned, the project, which Synenco has been promoting for nearly two years, will produce 100,000 barrels of crude oil a day and cost 4.5 billion Canadian dollars to develop over five years. The companies said that the investment had been approved by both the Chinese and Canadian governments. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: America's DNA
description: New Delhi - A few years ago my youngest daughter participated in the National History Day program for eighth graders. The question that year was "turning points" in history, and schoolchildren across the land were invited to submit a research project that illuminated any turning point in history. My daughter's project was "How Sputnik Led to the Internet." It traced how we reacted to the Russian launch of Sputnik by better networking our scientific research centers and how those early, crude networks spread and eventually were woven into the Internet. The subtext was how our reaction to one turning point unintentionally triggered another decades later.

World Briefing | Americas: Nicaragua: State Of Emergency In Electricity Crisis
description: President Enrique Bolaos declared a 180-day state of emergency over the country's growing energy crisis and raised electricity rates. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOCH, GERTRUDE
description: KOCH--Gertrude. Columbia, SC. Gertrude Brennan Carr Koch, 91, beloved wife of the late Otto Charles Koch, died Sunday, May 22, 2005 in Columbia. Born on July 19, 1913 in Newark, NJ, she was the daughter of the late Arthur and Gertrude Carr. She was a graduate of the College of St. Elizabeth, NJ, where she earned her B.A. degree in English. In 1936, she earned a Master's Degree from the Columbia Pulitzer School of Journalism, New York, NY. Thereafter, she interned at the New York Times and worked as a reporter for the Newark Evening News while working towards her Ph.D. In 1941, Gertrude married O. Charles Koch of Cliffside Park, NJ and served on committees of the American Association of University Women, as well as many local educational and charity organizations. She was also a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution. They moved to Montclair, NJ, where they raised their six children. She returned to Columbia University Teachers College to receive accreditation in teaching and her Ph.D. in Education. Gertrude taught English at Bloomfield High School, NJ for 28 years. Upon retirement, she served tirelessly as a docent for the Montclair Historical Society. In 1985, she moved to Columbia, where she served as a docent at the Art Museum and Governor's Mansions. "Mimi", as everyone in her family lovingly called her, was a passionate gardener, a voracious reader and a lover of opera. Surviving are daughters, Kathleen Ludwigson of Annadale, NJ, Elaine Pierson of Columbia, Gertrude Koch of Secaucus, NJ, Charlene Packham of Newport, RI, and Margaret Koch of Newport, RI; son, Charles Koch of LaJolla, CA; grandchildren, Elizabeth Ludwigson, Susan Ludwigson, John Ludwigson, Lizanne Koch; and great-grandchildren, Daniel and Johnathan Falvo and Benjamin and Eloise Wyatt. A memorial mass will be celebrated in the Holy Family Chapel, College of St. Elizabeth, Convent Station, NJ. She will be buried in Montclair, NJ, beside her beloved husband Charles. Dunbar Funeral Home, Devine Street Chapel is assisting the family locally.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Jackson Trial Nears Deliberations
description: Prosecutors and Michael Jackson's lawyers spent the day haggling over the complex instructions the jury will receive before beginning deliberations. Mr. Jackson and the jury were not present. Mr. Jackson faces 10 felony counts of child molesting, attempted child molesting, giving alcohol to a minor to aid in child sexual abuse and conspiracy. Jurors will receive the case after closing arguments, which are likely to begin on Thursday. Judge Rodney S. Melville of Santa Barbara County Superior Court said he would instruct jurors that they could find Mr. Jackson guilty of a lesser misdemeanor offense, providing alcohol to a minor, if they did not find that he had given his accuser alcohol in an effort to seduce him. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HORWITZ, MARSHALL S., M.D.
description: HORWITZ--Marshall S., M.D. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University notes with immense sadness the sudden passing of our beloved Chair of Microbiology & Immunology. A member of the Einstein faculty for nearly 40 years, Dr. Horwitz also was the Leo and Julia Forchheimer Professor of Microbiology & Immunolgy, as well as Professor of Pediatrics and of Cell Biology. His leadership and devotion to the medical school was evident in the countless roles he undertook, including director of the Pediatric Infectious Disease Program, associate director of the Medical Scientist Training Program and of the Albert Einstein Cancer Center, and helping to establish and maintain the research program in the Department of Pediatrics. As a scientist, Dr. Horwitz was internationally renowned for his study of the biology of adenoviruses, particularly his development of cell-free systems for adenovirus DNA replication. His most current research focused on understanding how the virus causes disease and how it interacts with the immune system. As a colleague, clinician, scientist, and mentor, he touched the lives of countless individuals throughout the Einstein community. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife and longtime member of the Einstein family, Dr. Susan B. Horwitz, cochair of Molecular Pharmacology and Rose C. Falkenstein Professor of Cancer Research; to his sons, Joshua and Bruce, and to the entire Horwitz family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine Richard M. Joel, President Yeshiva University HORWITZ--Dr. Marshall. We mourn the tragic loss of Dr. Marshall Horwitz, a distinguished faculty member and scientist at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, and beloved husband of Dr. Susan Band Horwitz, Director of the Hallenbeck/Kalman Laboratory for Cancer Research. Our deepest condolences to Susan and the entire family. Diane and Bill Hallenbeck Joan and Ernest Kalman

title: Sun to Buy Data Storage Company for $4.1 Billion
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., the maker of computer servers, said today that it would acquire Storage Technology Corp., which specializes in protecting and archiving data, for $4.1 billion in cash. The acquisition is designed to add depth to the data storage options that Sun offers to businesses and institutions that buy its servers. Sun, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has struggled in recent years to take market share from competitors like I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard, which have been more successful in responding to the demand for lower-priced equipment.

He called for more collaboration between law-enforcement agencies and human rights groups and other public organizations. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bridge Repair Is Rescheduled
description: For the second time in a week, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has rescheduled the start of a yearlong project to replace the 65-year-old roadway deck of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge. The project is now set to begin around 10 p.m. tomorrow, and two of the bridge's six lanes will be closed until around 6 a.m. Saturday. After that, one lane will be closed at all times, but a movable median barrier will allow three Bronx-bound traffic lanes during the morning rush and three Queens-bound lanes during the evening rush. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TYLER, HAROLD R.
description: TYLER--Harold R. We are profoundly saddened at the passing on May 25 of our sole surviving name partner, the Honorable Harold R. Tyler. Judge Tyler was a partner with the firm from 1977 to 1991 and Of Counsel from 1992 until his death. Judge Tyler's distinguished career prior to joining the firm included service as an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York from 1953 to 1955 and as U.S. Assistant Attorney General for the Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department from 1960 to 1961. He was appointed as a federal judge in the Southern District of New York by President John F. Kennedy in 1962 and served on the federal bench until 1975, when he was appointed Deputy Attorney General of the United States. When he joined the firm of Patterson, Belknap & Webb in 1977, its name was changed to Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler. Judge Tyler brought distinction to the firm every day, and we will miss his presence sorely. We join his many friends in sending our deepest condolences to his family. All of Us at Patterson Belknap Webb & Tyler

She was a devoted daughter, loving wife, and dedicated mother. Jeanne met George during their undergraduate studies at Northwestern University. They were married for 56 years and, except for the past 11 months, spent the previous 36 years in New Jersey. Jeanne was a devout Roman Catholic. A funeral service will be scheduled shortly. description: A couple of weeks ago my dad pointed out that there is only one major route out of California over the Sierra Nevada if you are north of Bakersfield. That road is Interstate 80. Other roads cross the mountains, but in a tentative, almost exploratory way. Eighty is the way in and the way out. The roadway has been blasted with cold and heat. And if, while you're climbing it, you happen to remember, as I did, that this is the one eastern crossing out of northern California, the route somehow seems unduly fragile, cutting its way through time.

description: BEN-HAIM--Rabbi Baruch. "If not for the Torah, the heavens and earth would not have existed." Our Rabbis teach us that the continuous study of Torah sustains the entire world. The Magen David Yeshivah family mourns the passing of our deeply loved and highly respected Rabbi Baruch Ben-Haim. He was the guiding force of our community for over 50 years, and left an indelible mark on the future generations of our Sephardic Community. His legacy will live on through the many lives he touched with his goodness, wisdom and compassion. He will be missed, but never forgotten. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: One Opponent Fewer For Gotbaum
description: Michael A. Benjamin, an assemblyman from the Bronx, said yesterday that he had decided to withdraw from the race for public advocate, abandoning his challenge of the incumbent, Betsy Gotbaum. Mr. Benjamin, a Democrat, said that he had not raised enough money to run a credible campaign against Ms. Gotbaum and that the stress of his nearly four-month-old bid had caused strain in his personal life. His withdrawal from the race leaves Ms. Gotbaum with two opponents in the Democratic primary on Sept. 13: Norman Siegel, the former executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, who ran for the job in 2001, and Andrew C. Rasiej, an Internet entrepreneur who organizes conferences on digital democracy at the New School for Social Research. Jonathan P. Hicks (NYT)

title: Turtle Feet and Nudes: Eclecticism Made Easy
description: Attention, struggling eclecticists. Christie's New York is having a sale it's calling Dcor on June 15. Previews begin June 10. Dcor is a culling of 17th-, 18th- and 19th-century furnishings, along with 20th-century pieces inspired by them, Christie's said. The inventory reflects the costly, illogical-looking shopping that characterizes the work of interior decorators. Like a snake swallowing its tail, many of the lots were also designed by decorators, a category of 20th-century collecting that has gained expensive ground at modernist galleries as decorators seek the extremes of taste through the dated audaciousness of their peers. A pair of bronze obelisks with turtles for feet and an ormolu nude, left, by Juan Pablo Molyneux and Horacio Cordero (expected to sell for $6,000 to $9,000), might be just the thing to put the edge on your corduroy sofa. WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

title: Classical Music Star Grabs, and Holds, the Imagination of Fickle Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, May 30 - When Esa-Pekka Salonen was a serious-minded student at the Sibelius Academy in Helsinki, studying the horn, composing music intensively and conducting student ensembles in performances of new works, he said he never imagined that he would become the music director of a major orchestra. Let alone the Los Angeles Philharmonic.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Narrows
description: Brazil's trade surplus narrowed in May from the previous month, suggesting that a recent rally in the local currency is beginning to take a toll on export growth. The surplus declined to $3.45 billion in May from a monthly record of $3.88 billion in April, the government said. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Wisdom by the Spadeful

The sand was warm between the perfectly tilled rows of green garlic stalks, mulched with a soft blanket of shredded leaves. Mr. Chaskey calls them "green sail masts," and so they were, all 20,000 of them, sailing down this two-acre field.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Security Cameras In Stations
description: Assemblyman Dov Hikind and the president of New York City Transit, Lawrence G. Reuter, announced yesterday that 120 closed-circuit television cameras were installed last month at nine subway stations along the D, F and N lines in Brooklyn. Mr. Hikind, a Brooklyn Democrat, used $1.2 million in discretionary funds available to Assembly members for the project. The stations are in the Borough Park, Midwood, Kensington and Parkville neighborhoods, which have large Jewish populations, and Mr. Hikind said the project was prompted by "concerns that the Jewish community would be targeted" by terrorists. He added that he was not aware of any current threats. The transit agency does not plan to install cameras as comprehensively in other stations, Mr. Reuter said, but he also said more cameras could aid the police in investigating crimes. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Met Neighbors Lose Appeal
description: A state appeals court rejected on Tuesday a lawsuit by Upper East Side residents who are opposed to the expansion of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Metropolitan Museum Historic District Coalition, a group of neighbors, has been fighting the museum's expansion since 2002, saying it would increase traffic and pollution by drawing more visitors. The museum says the number of visitors will remain unchanged. The group argued that the museum's environmental review process had violated the statute of limitations. ANDREW JACOBS

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Rell Vetoes Drug-Possession Bill
description: Gov. M. Jodi Rell yesterday vetoed a bill that would impose the same criminal penalties for possession of crack or powder cocaine because she said it does not go far enough in criminalizing drug possession. Under current law, those arrested for selling 28 grams of powder cocaine face the same five-year sentence as those selling one-half gram of crack cocaine. Critics have argued that the mandatory minimum sentences are tilted against poor and minority defendants, who are more likely to be arrested for possession of crack cocaine than for the more expensive powdered cocaine favored by wealthier drug users. Mrs. Rell agreed that the penalty should be the same for both, but she proposed legislation that would lower the threshold to 14 grams of either one. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Changes at Dance Center

title: Bringing Fairness to Drug Sentencing
description: Congress spawned a national trend toward discriminatory sentencing when it drew a false distinction between powdered cocaine and crack cocaine for law enforcement purposes during the 1980's. Crack is simply powdered cocaine cooked in baking soda. The theory at the time -- that it was more addictive and generated more violence than powder -- was later proved false. By then, however, Congress had made crack the only drug that mandates a sentence for a first offense and fixed high sentences for people caught with relatively small quantities.

description: LIEBERMAN--William S. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art and its International Council note with sorrow the passing of our longtime friend and colleague Bill Lieberman, who began his career at MoMA in 1943 as a volunteer for Monroe Wheeler in the Department of Exhibitions and Publications. In 1945, he became assistant to Alfred H. Barr, Jr., and in 1949 he became the first curator of the Department of Prints at the time of the opening of the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Print Room. Under Bill's leadership, the department expanded to become the Department of Drawings and Prints, and in 1967 he was concurrently appointed a curator in the Department of Painting and Sculpture. The Museum's curatorial departments were reorganized in 1971, and Bill became the founding director of the Department of Drawings. Bill organized over forty exhibitions at MoMA, including Modern Masters: Manet to Matisse, Max Ernst, Joan Miro, Modigliani, Etchings by Matisse, and Art of the Twenties. He left the Museum in 1979 to become Chairman of the Twentieth Century Art Department at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He also became an Honorary Member of MoMA's International Council that year. Bill had an eye finely attuned to quality and elegance, and his friends formed an expansive network of artists, writers, and colleagues. Collectors with whom he was close forever enhanced the Museum's collections, perhaps most notably Florene May Schoenborn and Joan and Lester Avnet. Bill will be sorely missed, but the immeasurable impact of his thirty-six years at the Museum will be apparent for generations to come. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY Brian Urquhart, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art LIEBERMAN--William S. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn with deep sadness the passing of William S. Lieberman, one of the most brilliant curators in the Museum's history, who leaves a stunning legacy of great modern art acquisitions. At the Met since 1979 (after an illustrious 35 years at the Museum of Modern Art), he served first as Chairman of 20th Century Art here, and later as the Jacques and Natasha Gelman Chairman of Modern Art. In that time, he mounted more than 35 exhibitions, enlarged and enhanced the modern art collection, and oversaw many gallery installations both before the opening of the Lila Acheson Wallace Wing for modern art in 1987, and over the years since. He was often called a "collector of collectors" because of the astonishing number of gifts and bequests to the Met that he inspired, including scores of works by the great icons of 20th-century art, among them Balthus, Braque, Giacometti, Klee, Leger, Matisse, Miro, Picasso, and Pollock. He knew many of these artists personally and, in a life intensely devoted to art, brought their work together for study and for the enjoyment of visitors to the Met for generations to come. After June 2004, as Jacques and Natasha Gelman Special Consultant for Modern Art, he continued to work each day at the Museum. By his many donors, colleagues, and friends, this erudite, witty, profoundly talented man was universally respected and will be just as universally missed. James R. Houghton, Chairman Philippe de Montebello, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President

title: The Listings: June 3 -- June 9; ANTONY GORMLEY: 'CLEARING IV'
description: This installation is art's latest one-room wonder. It belongs on a list with similarly dazzling, implicitly populist sensations like Lucas Samaras's "Mirrored Room" of 1966, Walter De Maria's "Earth Room" or Yayoi Kusama's "Fireflies on Water," which was a hit in the 2004 Whitney Biennial. Works of this sort often present one material in mind-boggling quantity. In Mr. Gormley's case, the material is a single strand of aluminum rod approximately 1 inch square (12.7 mm.) and nearly three miles (6 km.) long. The rod has been coiled into the main gallery at Sean Kelly in Chelsea, creating a new kind of walk-in drawing in space that also resembles a messily coiled Slinky in a very tight box. Moving around in the piece can make you feel like a small child on the loose in a storybook space. Jack's fallen beanstalk; the thorny vines protecting the sleeping Sleeping Beauty and Hansel and Gretel's forest may come to mind. At the same time, the piece relates to Minimalist sculpture, to Richard Serra's torqued and spiraled plates and Fred Sandback's stretched string sculptures. "Clearing IV," above, suggests that the closer Mr. Gormley gets to the abstract, the better. The artist, who won the Tate's Turner Prize in 1994, is best known for life-size cast iron or lead sculptures of male figures -- usually based on his own body -- that convey a lugubrious and conservative humanism. The new figures in this show forsake the monolithic for the cumulative. Two are made of small blocks of mild steel. Another, installed on the gallery's roof, is an open, nearly transparent network of short bars of stainless steel. A fourth, resembling an extremely buff human porcupine, is made of hundreds of thin rods of mild steel. Evoking computer renderings, these works slightly update Mr. Gormley's earlier realism. They enter the realm of Tim Hawkinson's or Tom Friedman's figures, except that they are rendered in enduring materials that Henry Moore would have approved of. (Sean Kelly Gallery, 529 West 29th Street, (212)239-1181, through June 25; free.) ROBERTA SMITH

Said to have weighed more than 17 pounds at birth, the adult Braddock tipped the scales around 190, stood nearly 6-foot-3 and was in the possession of a 75-inch reach. His most famous opponent, the Livermore Larruper, Max Baer, had an 81-inch reach, bringing him dauntingly close to Braddock's lopsided grin.

description: This series has been moving dancers and musicians out into the open places of New York City for 20 years now, burrowing imaginatively into areas whose beauty and history are often largely underappreciated. The organization opens its 2005 summer season with free programs this month in Red Hook, Brooklyn. The neighborhood has certainly not been untouched by open-air arts festivals in recent years. But with gentrification rearing its silken head it may soon be too late to loose oneself in Red Hook's eccentric charms, particularly the old commercial structures of the port area. Some dull and some fantastic, the worn buildings and even the refurbished ones have a mysterious, filmic quality. The series begins tomorrow afternoon from 2:30 to 3 at Red Hook's Beard Street Pier with a master-class workshop with members of Rennie Harris Puremovement, above. The stylish, sizzling hip-hop and modern-dance company returns for a repertory performance from 6 to 7:30 p.m. tomorrow in Coffey Park on Visitation Place between Dwight and Richards Street in Red Hook. Two more Saturday afternoon performances will take place in the park, each with some form of community participation. Battleworks performs next Saturday, followed by three professional companies and one student group on June 18. Dancing in the Streets then moves north to Dag Hammarskjold Plaza opposite the United Nations for afternoon performances by Taylor 2, the vibrant junior Paul Taylor troupe, on July 9 and 10. (Information: (212)625-3505 or www.dancinginthestreets.org.) JENNIFER DUNNING

title: Open Roads: New Italian Cinema
description: Paolo Sorrentino's film "The Consequences of Love" is set mostly in a Swiss luxury hotel where its poker-faced, 50-year-old protagonist and narrator, Tita (Tony Servillo), an accountant for the Mafia, has lived for years. The eeriest scenes of the film, which won five David di Donatello Awards (including best film, best director and best actor), show Tita supervising a room filled with workers grimly counting untold millions of dollars by hand. Why not do it electronically, one asks? Tita says he prefers the human touch. He is a kind of super gambler held virtual prisoner there because of a costly mistake he made years earlier. In the film, he makes one last life-and-death bluff for a woman. What makes "The Consequences of Love" (with Adriano Giannini, above left, and Olivia Magnani) more than a cerebral thriller is the metaphysical weight of Tita's self-knowledge. In a world where money rules more than ever, he is an existential fatalist for the 21st century. "Consequences," which has two screenings today at the Walter Reade Theater, is one of the deeper films in "Open Roads: The New Italian Cinema," the Film Society of Lincoln Center's annual Italian film series, which continues through Thursday. It shares with many of this year's films a visual fascination with the outer limits of modernity. That fascination links it to such Italian films of the 1960's as Michelangelo Antonioni's "Eclipse." In Renato De Maria's "Love Me," Isabella Ferrari plays a beautiful 35-year-old woman, married at 15, who explores her own sexual power after her husband of 20 years leaves her. As she drifts through a world of elegant nightclubs and hotels in one close encounter after another, she suggests a reversal of the alienated neurotic beauty once played by Monica Vitti; she blooms. "Love Me" has screenings tomorrow and Wednesday. (Walter Reade, (212)875-5600.) STEPHEN HOLDEN

title: Arts, Briefly; Court Battle Exposes Wildenstein Art to Auction
description: A French court has directed that part of one of the world's largest private inventories of art be liquidated within weeks to settle an inheritance battle that has split the Wildenstein family. Unless the sons of the art dealer Daniel Wildenstein, Alec and Guy, reach a settlement with Daniel's widow, Sylvia Wildenstein, a significant collection of paintings and drawings will be sold at auction in early July, Mrs. Wildenstein said in an interview. The family's real estate holdings in New York and Paris and a string of thoroughbred racehorses and breeding stock are also under court order to be sold and the proceeds divided among the heirs. Under French inheritance law, Mrs. Wildenstein would get at least 50 percent of the proceeds. In its four generations of art dealing, the Wildenstein family has amassed works by old masters and Impressionists including Renoir, van Gogh, Czanne, and many others. The family has rarely disclosed details of its holdings, but court documents made public during divorce proceedings of Alec Wildenstein in 1999 estimated the value of its collection at as much as $10 billion. Daniel Wildenstein died in Paris in 2001 at 84. According to the decision by the Cour d'Appel in Paris, his sons persuaded Mrs. Wildenstein, now 71, to sign away her inheritance in the days after his death by telling her that she would face huge tax bills and a possible criminal investigation. But according to the court decision, Wildenstein had made provisions for any tax liability. GINA RARICK

title: Arts, Briefly; Taking Broadway's Pulse
description: Despite flat sales overall, Broadway ended the 2004-5 season strong, according to statistics released on Wednesday, with a collection of popular hits like "Monty Python's Spamalot," right, and "Doubt" making up for a weak fall. According to the League of American Theaters and Producers, a trade group, the box office gross for the season was $768.6 million, just short of last year's record $770.9 million. (The Broadway season runs from one year's June Tony Awards to the next.) Paid attendance for the 2004-5 season also dropped slightly, to 11.5 million, the fourth-highest figure on record. But after a fall that brought only three new musicals, none successful, the season's final quarter yielded better sales, with $222.1 million in gross receipts over the last 13 weeks. And in an encouraging sign for producers, both domestic and international tourism continued to recover from the effects of the 2001 terrorist attacks; out-of-town visitors made up 60 percent of the Broadway audience. title: The Listings: June 3 -- June 9; McDONALD'S GOSPELFEST
description: Do fries go with that sermon? Deities may not accept branding, but music sometimes does, and the fast-food giant has latched on to the not-so-secret ingredient in African-American pop. Gospel has always kept up a two-way traffic in ideas with secular music, from blues to hip-hop, shifting idioms while trading pop's worldly joys and woes for Christian certainties. The annual McDonald's Gospelfest is a showcase for established gospel stars -- including, this year, current R&B-influenced singers like Donnie McClurkin and Vickie Winans -- as well as a steppingstone for winners of gospel talent competitions. But the headliner for this year's Gospelfest is a singer who grew far more famous outside the church: Aretha Franklin, above. A preacher's daughter who packed gospel dynamics into her 1960's soul classics, Ms. Franklin grows both fervent and flamboyant on the rare occasions when she drops her secular repertory and returns to gospel songs. There will be plenty of impressive voices onstage, and Ms. Franklin, a fiercely competitive singer when she chooses to be, just may sing rings around all of them. (Tonight and tomorrow at 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 4:30 p.m., Theater at Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue and 33rd Street, Manhattan, (212)465-6741, $56.50 to $96.50.) JON PARELES

Paid Notice: Deaths   LAREDO, RUTH
description: LAREDO--Ruth. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with deep sorrow the untimely passing of the distinguished American pianist Ruth Laredo on May 25 in New York City at the age of 67. A highly valued member of our Steinway Artist family for twenty years, Ms. Laredo was an accomplished soloist and chamber musician, and an indefatigable spirit in the New York music world. A native of Detroit, Ms Laredo studied with Rudolf Serkin at the Curtis Institute of Music. She was drawn to the music of Maurice Ravel, Sergei Rachmaninoff and Alexander Scriabin, and her performances and Grammy-nominated recordings of those composers' works, among others, won her a large and devoted following. Her acclaimed series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, "Concerts with Commentary", was in its seventeenth season at the time of her death. Ms. Laredo was warmly received as a participating artist in Steinway & Sons' 135th anniversary concert at Carnegie Hall on June 2, 1988. We wish to convey our heartfelt condolences to her daughter Jennifer and to her family. She will be sorely missed. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

Paid Notice: Deaths   WOODS, MARY E.
description: WOODS--Mary E. of Clinton, CT, died of lung cancer on May 24, 2005, at the age of 75. She was the daughter of John B.C. Woods and Elizabeth Galloway Woods. A New York City native, she graduated from Cornell University and received her Master's degree from Columbia University School of Social Work. An associate professor of Social Work at Hunter College and the co-author of the classic textbook, "Casework: A Psychosocial Therapy," she was a recognized authority in her field. She had been a staff member of the Family Consultation Service in Eastchester, NY, doing clinical work with individuals and families and operating storefront programs for "hard to reach" youth. While there she also developed an in-service family therapy training program for psychiatrists, psychologists, and social workers at the Montefiore Hospital. She was a licensed social worker and a Fellow of the Society of Clinical Social Workers. She also published numerous journal articles and book chapters on a broad array of topics, ranging from psychopathology and the history of casework, to child abuse and neglect. In addition, she continued individually updating the classic textbook for the fourth and fifth editions. She served on various committees, among them the Fahs-Beck Fund for Research and Experimentation. She was a mentor to, and a role model for countless social workers, as well as a highly regarded teacher. She was commencement speaker to the graduating students at the Hunter College School of Social Work in 1992, and also received the lifetime achievement award from the Westchester Division of the National Association of Social Workers in 1993. She is survived by her brother John Galloway Woods and his wife Merilyn of Philadephia, two nieces, Anne Woods (Sonenklar) of Glen Allen, GA, and Dr. Elizabeth Woods (Lis) of Needham, MA, five grandnieces and grandnephews, and her colleague and companion of many years, Dr. Dorothy Kitchell-Cassidy. At her request, there was no funeral service and contributions in her memory should be made to a favorite charity. For more information Swan Funeral Home.

title: Business Briefing | Build-a-Bear Cuts Forecast and Stock Plummets
description: Build-a-Bear Workshop, a toy retailer that went public in October, announced yesterday that it was cutting its second-quarter profit forecast to 12 cents to 14 cents a share from an April outlook of 23 cents to 25 cents, saying that sales had not met expectations. Its shares fell $5.79, or 21 percent, to close at $22.11 yesterday. Net income will be $2.5 million to $2.9 million in the period ending July 2, compared with the forecast in April of $4.7 million to $5.1 million, the company said. Net income in the same period a year earlier, which included the Easter holiday, was $4.9 million, or 27 cents a share. Build-A-Bear, which is based in St. Louis, operates about 170 stores around the world in which customers can customize their own stuffed animals. The company and franchisees plan to open about 55 new stores in 2005, the company said.

Health officials said the findings would not affect the standing of the cases. Dr. Laposata was criticized in a federal report for her handling of a 2003 nightclub fire in Warwick that killed 100 people. The report said she took hours to arrive at the scene and sent only one investigator despite being told of the fire's magnitude. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; CBS Rules the Night
description: The CBS Thursday lineup was dominant in Nielsen's estimated viewer totals, as it is during the regular season. An all-repeat slate of "Cold Case" (in the 8 p.m. "Survivor" slot), "CSI" and "Without a Trace" drew an average of 11.85 million on Thursday night. Also predictable was the status of "CSI" as the most-watched program of the evening, with an audience of 13.86 million. But NBC, a distant second in total viewers, managed to tie CBS among 18-to-49-year-olds, thanks to the premiere of another summer reality series, "Hit Me Baby One More Time." That show, in which one-hit wonders compete in front of an audience, drew 8.65 million viewers opposite "CSI" but bested it in the 18-to-49 age group. "Without a Trace" was the only CBS offering to win that demographic on Thursday, but its ratings were strong enough to ensure the tie with NBC. KATE AURTHUR

description: Gazprom, the Russian state-controlled gas monopoly, said yesterday that it had bought a 50.19 percent stake in the newspaper Izvestia last week. "For us, as a full-scale media holding, it was a matter of principal importance to purchase such a respected publication as the newspaper Izvestia," Nikolai Senkevich, the general director of Gazprom Media, said in a statement. Gazprom bought the newspaper from Vladimir Potanin, an oligarch who controls Norilsk Nickel, one of the world's largest producers. Media analysts say that he had been trying to sell Izvestia after it became clear that the political risks outweighed the benefits of owning a newspaper that was widely regarded by press critics as Russia's best general readership daily. Gazprom is the world's largest producer of natural gas. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

The authorities said that witnesses bought the supplies, like sinus medicine and antifreeze, after telling the clerks or storeowners they would be used for methamphetamine. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Niger: No Response To U.N. Appeal For Aid
description: Two weeks after the United Nations warned of a "silent crisis" and issued an emergency appeal for food aid for Niger, one of the world's poorest nations, not a single dollar has been pledged, the organization said. The Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs began its effort on May 19, seeking $16.2 million in emergency aid over the next four months, during Niger's lean season. The food crisis has been compounded by drought and by last year's locust invasion, the worst in 15 years. Roughly 3.6 million of the country's 12 million people need food aid, including 800,000 children under the age of 5, the United Nations said. Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Garth Brooks and Capitol Nashville Split
description: The country superstar Garth Brooks and his record company, the Capitol Nashville division of EMI North America, announced yesterday that they had agreed to end their current license agreement, under which Capitol had the exclusive license to Mr. Brooks's recordings. Neither Mr. Brooks, the top-selling artist in country music history, nor EMI requested or was paid any compensation for the license termination. Hazel Smith, the veteran Nashville journalist who has long been a friend of Mr. Brooks, recalled a conversation when, she said, "Garth told me that he would never be on another record label except Capitol, because that's where his mother, Colleen, was." Colleen Carroll Brooks, the singer's mother, recorded with little chart success for Capitol in 1954. Mr. Brooks has been living in Oklahoma for the last few years but made news recently with some performances at benefits, and with his engagement to his fellow country star Trisha Yearwood, above. "For nearly two decades, Capitol Nashville has had an extraordinary and fruitful relationship with Garth," Mike Dungan, the president of Capitol Nashville, said in a statement. "We wish him all the best for the future." PHIL SWEETLAND

Arts, Briefly; WCBS-FM Trades In Golden Oldies for Beastie Boys
description: WCBS-FM (101.1), the New York radio station that for three decades has served as a purveyor of frozen-in-time golden oldies, jumped on radio's latest trend yesterday, dumping its genre for the "Jack format," which runs off a broader list of mainstream hits from the 1970's through the 90's. At 5 p.m. yesterday, the station largely abandoned acts like Tom Jones, the Four Tops and the Supremes in favor of the Beastie Boys, No Doubt, Tom Petty and Duran Duran. Analysts say the change by WCBS's corporate parent, Infinity Broadcasting, reflects demographic shifts and a gradual redefinition of what constitutes oldies for today's radio listeners. The Jack format, devised by a Canadian company, Rogers Media, is playing on a growing number of stations in the United States. Programmers have been adopting the format, which is built from a bigger-than-usual music library and results in odd mixes of songs from various eras and genres, partly as a response to the popularity of iPods and satellite radio, which offer deep playlists with no commercials. WCBS had been playing the oldies format since 1972. Infinity said its program director, Dave Logan, and its morning host, Micky Dolenz, above, of the 1960's made-for-television band the Monkees, had left the station. The company said the oldies format continues at www.wcbsfm.com. Infinity's Chicago oldies station, WJMK-FM, is also changing to the Jack format. JEFF LEEDS

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Ex-President's Indictment Delayed
description: Ignacio Carrillo Prieto, left, the special prosecutor appointed by President Vicente Fox in 2002 to pursue cases against officials accused of rights violations, has delayed an expected indictment against former President Luis Echeverra. Mr. Carrillo had promised to file kidnapping and genocide charges against Mr. Echeverra by the end of May, for an alleged role in the massacre of student protestors in 1968. But this week he said his office was studying new elements that would strengthen his case. Last year, he filed genocide charges against Mr. Echeverra, 83, in the killings of two dozen student protesters in 1971, but a judge ruled that the time limit under the statute of limitations had run out. title: Forget the Founding Fathers
description: THE founding fathers were paranoid hypocrites and ungrateful malcontents. What was their cherished Declaration of Independence but empty political posturing? They groaned about the burden of taxation, but it was the English who were shouldering the real burden, paying taxes on everything from property to beer, from soap to candles, tobacco, paper, leather and beeswax. The notorious tea tax, which had so inflamed the people of Massachusetts, was only one-fourth of what the English paid at home; even Benjamin Franklin labeled the Boston Tea Party an act of piracy. Meanwhile, smugglers, with the full connivance of the colonists, were getting rich at the expense of honest tax-paying citizens. The recent French and Indian War had doubled Britain's national debt, but the Americans, who were the most immediate beneficiaries, were refusing to contribute their fair share.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: EARLY BIRD. By Rodney Rothman. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) Here's hoping that Rothman has overcome his nasty fabrication habit, because if the stories and people in his new book, "Early Bird," are real, he has produced a warm, wry bit of reportage. Rothman earned some ignominy in 2000 when an article he wrote for The New Yorker turned out to have fictions mixed in with its facts, causing the magazine to run an apology. That article involved his posing as an employee at a dot-com company, and in "Early Bird" Rodman poses again, in a way: he retires to Florida, in his late 20's, moving into a Century Village senior citizens' complex. Rothman manages to be both an observer of these strange beings about three times his age and a sad-sack newcomer trying to blend in with them. He is working a bit of a stereotype, but his descriptions of the loneliness, the cliquishness, the slow-motion desperation of the place ring true and bittersweet. Most surprising is that his tales contain not an ounce of mean-spiritedness -- this from someone who once wrote for David Letterman. "Young people often think old people all look the same," he writes in a passage typical of his tone, "but that misconception works both ways. To elderly people, young people merge into one tender pink blob. Elderly people always seem to think I am 18 or 19, which is flattering until I remember that their eyesight is failing and that a certain percentage of them suffer from dementia." Can't wait for the sitcom, which is already in the pilot stage.

"JACQUES-LOUIS DAVID: EMPIRE TO EXILE" traces the last 25 years of David's career, from the mid-1790's, after he was imprisoned for his political activities, until his death in 1825 as an exile in Brussels. The show runs through Sept. 5. At 225 South Street, (413)458-2303.

title: Deirdre Davis and Daniel Hanessian
description: Deirdre Elizabeth Davis, a lawyer, and Daniel Souren Hanessian, an associate professor of theater, were married yesterday at the Maverick Concert Hall in West Hurley, N.Y. The Rev. David D. Cockcroft, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Marc L. Britt, an Episcopal priest, taking part in it.

title: What Are Mergers Good For?
description: The Dark Side of the Deal To most investors, mergers are the stock market's equivalent of catnip. Takeover bids typically provide a nice boost to investors' portfolios and confirm their stock-picking smarts. And to hear the executives orchestrating them tell it, they always produce greater profits at the combined company down the road. Business publications and newspapers, including The Times, celebrate the deals with breathless tales of how they came together, complete with photographs of smiling executives shaking hands in front of a crowd.

title: The Believer

Rick Santorum goes one step further and demonstrates that a politician can be effective without separating self from church. As a lifelong Roman Catholic, I am in awe of how he has developed an agenda that is true to his faith.

Mr. Solomon made no mention of Macerata (population about 50,000), its university (founded 1266), the university in Camerino -- another exquisite town nearby on the Umbria-Marche border -- or the yearly open-air opera festival held in Macerata's 18th-century arena. The opera draws visitors from all over Europe and the United States.

title: The Believer

However, in the very personally painful and sensitive case of his wife's choice to induce labor in a situation that was apparently life-threatening to her and to the 20-week-old fetus with a condition that would make long-term survival impossible, the couple allowed the administration of a drug to speed the labor -- and hasten the certain death of the unviable fetus. I have no disagreement with this decision on moral grounds. But it appears that they were able to make the decision in good conscience as Catholics, despite strict beliefs about abortion, because this case has special dimensions. And that's the point!

title: POP/JAZZ
description: At its top commercial tier, hip-hop can seem monolithic: a nonstop party where guys brag about their money, their women, their old bullet wounds and their new business ventures, all to the crispest beats computers can pump out. That's going to be the bulk of HOT 97'S SUMMER JAM on Sunday at GIANTS STADIUM, East Rutherford, N.J., where this hip-hop station presents its playlist onstage. SNOOP DOGG, THE GAME, LUDACRIS, LIL' JON AND THE EASTSIDE BOYZ, YING YANG TWINS, JADAKISS, CAM'RON and others will drawl, race and grunt through their latest club hits, while CIARA provides the token female flirtation. But even in the platinum zone, there are alternatives to bling-bling; one of Summer Jam's headliners is KANYE WEST, the producer turned rapper who will deliver his calmly articulated soul-sampling songs about ambition, community and achievements in enterprises that are actually legal. For tickets: www.ticketmaster.com.

Appel of New York, was married last evening to Alexander Garrett Loehnis, a son of Jennifer and Anthony Loehnis of Churchill, England. Rabbi Michael Feinberg officiated at the Peter White Studios in New York. The Rev. Chloe Breyer, an Episcopal priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Montana to Krakow, Getaways Without a Big Price Tag
description: WHILE travel costs are rising -- up some 4 percent for hotel rooms this year alone, according to the Travel Industry Association of America -- there are places to visit that can help rein in the costs. All-inclusive deals can offer something for the whole family, and if you know where to go, even the Caribbean and Europe are within reason. High prices don't have to trip up family fun.

title: For the Young and Creative, a Showcase for a First Run
description: MOST artists exhibit too young, and too often, a problem worsened to some extent by well-intentioned exhibitions like "First Look," at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art in Peekskill, N.Y. The exhibition showcases 15 artists enrolled in Master of Fine Arts programs in Westchester, Connecticut and beyond.

title: Inside the List
description: CHUCK'S WAGON: Chuck Palahniuk's seventh novel, "Haunted," is No. 8 on this week's hardcover fiction list. It's an entertainingly gruesome book, and Palahniuk (it is pronounced POL-a-nick) has come up with some entertainingly gruesome ways to promote it. His well-choreographed readings will not remind you of Cynthia Ozick's. At bookstore appearances, Palahniuk likes to read a section of "Haunted" about people who are boiled to death in natural hot springs -- but not before he has handed out teriyaki-scented air fresheners that make the local Barnes & Noble smell like the world's nastiest steakhouse. After that, he said in a telephone interview, "I bring the energy level back up by lobbing fake bloody, severed appendages into the crowd." (The fake-appendage plan went awry on his last tour when some of his bookstore visits nearly overlapped with those by Aron Ralston, the climber who wrote a memoir about how he amputated his own arm after it was pinned by a boulder. "He had a real sense of humor about it," Palahniuk said. "He said he wants them for his paperback tour.") Palahniuk ends his events by handing out, to those who ask him questions, rugs that resemble pieces of meat. His best-known novel is, of course, "Fight Club." There are always a few people who hang around after his readings to ask him how to find a fight club, or to invite him to the ones they've started. "I always say, 'No, thank you,' " Palahniuk said. "But I do sometimes ask them to show me their scars."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LURIE, SANNA KLAVENESS
description: LURIE--Sanna Klaveness. Died Monday, May 30, 2005, after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Dear daughter of Clara Normann Klaveness. Sister of Harda K. Fellows. Devoted aunt and cousin. Beloved wife of the late Iles Brody. She enjoyed her interesting and independent life as a fashion director for B. Altman & Co, and as a fashion editor for Harpers Bazaar. A caring and devoted friend who treasured her friendships. She will be missed and remembered always. Skaal, Sanna!

description: LEON LEE was reluctant to leave San Diego and drive home to Northern California on Friday. "I don't want to go home until you make an out," he told his son.

title: A Rich Past That Now Has a Future

Graffiti cover the outer walls, paint peels off the entryway and, just inside, a radiator lies on the rotting floor, no longer warming the faithful.

description: NEARLY three decades before Danica Patrick became a sensation at the Indianapolis 500, Janet Guthrie made history by becoming the first woman to qualify for the race, in 1977. She drove in the Indy 500 three times; her best finish was ninth, in 1978.

description: Dale Velzy, a master surfboard maker widely considered one of the men responsible for the rise of the California surfer culture in the years after World War II, died on May 26 at a hospital in Mission Viejo, Calif. He was 77 and lived in San Clemente.

About the same time, Chris Terrio was finishing his thesis film at the University of Southern California. Their careers converged the next year, at the offices of Merchant Ivory in New York.

title: Mudslide in Bluebird Canyon
description: It is, of course, an optical illusion, but it does seem that every time you pick up the newspaper or turn on the TV, an entire hillside of Southern California houses is sliding into the highway or gully below. What isn't illusory is the plain fact that people who ought to know better by now -- the homeowners, the builders, the local officials who write the zoning laws -- have yet to learn that nature does not play by man's rules, that unless humans set limits on development, nature will.

The mutual friend lowered her voice and added, "She has a terrific body." With that, my schedule cleared up, and I made a date.

Azaleas bloom half eaten and perennials barely glimpse daylight. The pitched battle between human and deer continues, with the garden as the spoils.

description: RON RIFKIN looked unhappy, which is not exactly unusual. During a rehearsal last month for "The Paris Letter" -- now previewing at the Roundabout's Laura Pels Theater, where it will open next Sunday -- he paced and pawed and scratched at his role like a cat fighting its way out of a bag. Also in the room, scribbling on a script, was the play's author, Jon Robin Baitz. The two men (following standard rehearsal protocol) spoke to each other only through the director, Doug Hughes, but they were nevertheless fidgeting in sync.

In February, demolition began on the adjacent one-story commercial building at the corner of Broadway and 93rd, exposing an old brick party wall, which hinted of a historical neighbor before the commercial building went up. Expect the aroma of jasmine, flavors like strawberry jam and rhubarb, and surprisingly low alcohol (5 percent). Pet Wines, 415 East 91st Street (First Avenue), charges $19. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

Many Starbucks stores have installed what is commonly called WiFi technology, which allows laptop users to connect to the Internet without plugging a cable or a phone line into their computers.

He and other lay missionaries walk through bustling piazzas, noisy nightclubs and cramped apartments on the city's outskirts looking for Latin American immigrants who are sometimes as far from their faith as they are from their homelands.

A nondescript awning reading Casa Hernanz and a pair of smudged display windows are the only signs of commerce -- hardly the enticements you'd expect to draw a crowd from morning to night, every day but Sunday.

title: See a Bubble?
description: It's a good time to be a financial-disaster writer. Disasters abound, and even when they don't, people are eager for your opinion on when the next bubble is going to pop. Scarcely a day goes by without a warning of some dire calamity -- in the dollar, in housing values, in pension funds. The way people crave financial info, we must be the best-informed, most economically literate society ever. But we do not sleep any better for it. Is all the anxiety warranted, or even productive?

title: Seeking Art's Verities In Passaic
description: PASSAIC - TOWARD noon one Saturday, Robert Smithson, carrying just a Kodak Instamatic camera and a science fiction novel by Brian W. Aldiss, boarded an Inter-City Transportation Company bus at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Midtown Manhattan and headed for Passaic. It was September 1967, and the soon-to-be-famous earth artist had a rendezvous with art history.

description: An article last Sunday about local primary elections misstated the Republican Party's goal for the Nassau County Legislature. It wants to regain a majority, not maintain one; the Democrats are the majority party now.

title: Hydie Sumner Wants Her Job Back
description: I like to think of myself as relatively easy to get along with," Hydie Sumner said, bafflement in her voice, her dark eyes scanning my face for affirmation. Sitting pensively in the sun room of her shaded San Antonio home on a glorious spring day, Sumner, 48, did look more like a woman who has been working, successfully, as a broker for Merrill Lynch than a woman who has been challenging the company -- successfully, in the end -- for almost a decade. Her demeanor was as placid as a lake on a windless day. She wore the female financial executive's uniform of good gold jewelry and a good dark suit. Her words were measured; her voice was modulated. Even Sumner's Tudor home was silent and serene: she lives alone, without the muss of husband, children or four-legged friends, unless you count the two stone canines standing guard by the front door. "My only pets," she said.

title: DISCOVERING LE MARCHE
description: To the Editor: Mr. Solomon's deliciously vivid portrait of the lure of Le Marche is both blessing and curse: Blessing for those of us still seeking the pre-"Tuscan Sun" Italy, untrampled by tacky tourism, and a curse for the innocent victims of Le Marche who must now brace themselves for the tourist onslaught to come.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLADSTEIN, JOYCE
description: GLADSTEIN -- Joyce. Life time love of husband Harvey. Incredible and cherished mother of Bruce, Jane and Dale. Loved mother-in-law of Debbie and Lance. Adored, irreverent Gram of Lauren, Danny, Adam and Ethan. Our hero. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to Make a Wish Foundation or The Eye Bank of New York.

title: IN THE REGION/Connecticut; Limiting the Size of Trophy Homes
description: MORE than 16 years ago, on Dec. 18, 1988, 400 angry people showed up at a public hearing in Greenwich to protest a proposal for limiting the size of homes and increasing setbacks from lot lines. The measure was formulated in response to complaints from homeowners distressed by the construction of huge new homes and massive additions to old ones, cutting off the light to smaller older houses and changing the character of the town. The town scaled back its proposed restrictions.

description: BONGIOVANNI--Raymond. June 5th, 1996 Oh how cruelly sweet are the echoes that start when memory plays an old tune on the heart. E. Cook

title: In Providence, Faded Area Finds Fresh Appeal
description: DESPITE having two national historic districts within its borders, the West Side of Providence has long been a run-down area, its crumbling 18th- and 19th-century Victorians and magnificent mill buildings cut off from the rest of downtown by a noisy swath of Interstate 95. But artists from elsewhere in the city have flocked to the neighborhood in recent years looking for the last affordable loft spaces, helping to fuel a community-led revitalization effort that has resulted in brilliantly restored buildings and a crop of hip restaurants, cafes, and boutique shops appealing to new young residents.

title: Ellen Baer and David Lebenstein
description: Ellen K. Baer and David N. Lebenstein were married last evening at the Friends Meeting House in Manhattan. Cantor Cathy Lawrence officiated. Ms. Baer, 50, is keeping her name.

title: If They Gave Nobels for Networking. . .
description: WASHINGTON - WASHINGTON was riveted last week by the unveiling of the 30-year-old secret of Deep Throat, but behind all the talk about the ethics of leaks and the business of journalism was a gem of a parable about how the city really works. Aficionados ferreted it out instantly in the first paragraphs of Bob Woodward's tale, stripped across The Washington Post's front page, of how he first met W.Mark Felt in a chance encounter that Mr. Woodward called one of the most important of his life.

title: Believing (and Believing and Believing) in Bullion
description: On a recent early spring morning, I made my way down to the appropriately poker-faced and austere building that houses the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. In its sub-basement, 80 feet below street level, there is a vault that rests on the granite bedrock of Manhattan. "No man-made floor could hold the weight of all this," Peter Bakstansky, a Fed spokesman, assured me. The vault holds 7,000 tons of gold. This represents the world's largest stash of the precious metal, and it is worth about $100 billion. To view it, you descend to an underground bunker and pass through a narrow passageway cut into a 90-ton steel cylinder. Like most people, I'd seen gold before, though only in small quantities -- a filling here, a vanity wristwatch there. In front of me now, stacked in bricks atop wooden pallets, lay some pretty serious bling.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SEALY, PALMER JR.
description: SEALY--Palmer Jr. Passed away on June 2, 2005, after a courageous four year battle with cancer at his home in Brookville, NY. He was 69 years old. Palmer was a loving and dedicated husband to Polly, his wife of 42 years; to his children Chip, Dave and Jeff; to his daughters-in-law Sheila, Sarah and Cindy, and his grandchildren Palmer, Regan, Matthew, Charlie, Clay, J.P., Lucas, James and Sam. Palmer would certainly describe his family as the crowning achievement in what was a very rich life. Palmer worked as a commercial real estate broker for over 30 years, as a result of his successes as a promotional broker the Uris Buildings Corporation asked the Cross and Brown Company to name he and his partner David Hoffman as rental agents for 300 and 320 Park Ave. Over the years he would serve in that capacity for many buildings, including 3,90, 200, 300, 320 and 410 on Park Ave. alone. Many of the Fortune 500 companies found their headquarters offices through his efforts, the likes of which included National Broadcasting Company (NBC) and International Paper. Palmer was Executive Vice President and served on the Board of Directors for the Cross & Brown Company. Later in his career, he was also a founding member of Sealy, Hoffman & Sheehan, Inc. Palmer graduated from the Millbrook School in 1954, and Brown University in 1958, where he received his BA in history, beginning what would be a lifetime passion for US history. He toured Civil War battle sites with friends, and explored the genealogy which dated back to Walter Palmer, settler of Stonington, CT, in 1652. Following Brown, Palmer served his country as a first lieutenant in the United States Marine Corps for two years. Palmer also pursued a lifelong passion for tennis, something passed to him from his father Palmer Sealy Sr., a USTA doubles finalist. He ran the West Side Tennis Club Junior Program during the 1960's introducing many young, promising players to the game, most notably Vitas Gerulaitis, who later went on to win the Australian Open. A memorial service will he held 11 AM, on Saturday, June 11, 2005, at the Brookville Reformed Church, Brookville, NY. Further information, Whitting Funeral Home, 300 Glen Cove Ave., Glen Head, NY. In lieu of flowers the families wish all donations to go to Camp Joslin Scholarship Fund, Joslin Diabetes Center, 1 Joslin Pl., Boston, MA 02215.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: NATURAL NOVEL. By Georgi Gospodinov. Translated by Zornitsa Hristova. (Dalkey Archive, paper, $12.50.) Gospodinov flits and buzzes among various subjects -- from graffiti in public toilets to the movies of Quentin Tarantino -- in this tale of a young Bulgarian writer who decides to create his own version of a "natural novel" assembled from the bits and pieces of everyday life. At its center is a poignant story about the narrator's divorce and the fact that he isn't "the author" of his soon-to-be-ex-wife's pregnancy. Maybe he's suffering from attention deficit disorder; maybe he's just stuck with a skewed if stoic appreciation of life's messy flux. Whatever the cause, his monologue turns into a quirky, compulsively readable book that deftly hints at the emptiness and sadness at its core.

They were killing him. Moss removed his earplugs, which were made of a specially engineered foam, guaranteed to block out snoring, car alarms. Yet useless. The noise bored right through them, to the root of Moss's brain. His sleep was ruined. He heaved himself up in his bed, pulled open the curtain and saw on the window ledge two plump gray pigeons, the head of one tucked under the other's wing. They appeared to be asleep. Moss tapped the pane, but the lovers didn't move; instead came the flapping and screeching of other birds, exploding from their sanctuaries in the narrow air shaft and falling upward through the canyon of blackened bricks toward daylight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, MARSHALL S., M.D.
description: HOROWITZ -- Marshall S., M.D. All the staff members of the Department of Pediatrics of the Children's Hospital at Montefiore and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine are stunned and saddened by the sudden passing of our beloved colleague of nearly 40 years. The quintessential physician-scientist, Dr. Horowitz, Professor of Pediatrics and Cell Biology and Professor and Chairman of Microbiology and Immunology, was an outstanding clinician, researcher, and teacher, as well as one of the world's leading experts on adenovirus. Marshall stood out for his gentlemanly character, modesty, integrity, warmth, and wisdom; he had the unique ability to bring out the best in every person he trained and with whom he worked. After winning international renown for discovering how genes encoded by adenovirus caused disease, Marshall, in characteristic fashion, converted those disease-causing genes into therapeutic tools to cure diabetes mellitus. Marshall was tirelessly and enthusiastically devoted to mentoring and nurturing the careers of generations of students, pediatric residents, fellows, scientists and faculty members. Marshall will be keenly missed, but his impact as an exemplary role model and his countless contributions to our Department, our Medical School, and the world of Medicine, will endure for generations to come. Gabriel Haddad, Chairman Department of Pediatrics Children's Hospital at Montefiore and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Comings and Goings
description: Recent news reports that the Transportation Security Administration was considering a test of "backscatter" technology machinery at select airports in the United States may be premature. The machinery uses low-level X-ray technology that the American Civil Liberties Union has said amounts to a virtual strip search. "At this time, we do not have any immediate plans, nor do we have a timeline or sites for any type of limited deployment," said Amy Von Walter, assistant deputy director of the transportation administration's Public Affairs Office. "We're still working to address the privacy concerns before we make any sort of decisions regarding any type of limited deployment." Taking on Delta, which has long had a tight grip on the route, American Airlines will begin offering five daily nonstop flights between New York and Atlanta on June 9. The flights, on a mix of American and American Eagle planes, will depart from, and arrive at, the T Concourse, reserved for American, at Hartsfield-Jackson Airport's North Terminal in Atlanta.

title: The Believer
description: I was struck by the cover photograph of Rick Santorum and read Michael Sokolove's article (May 22 ) to see if my initial impression would change. The Bible pictured inside, embossed with Santorum's name and title, appeared pristine, bookmark notwithstanding. Sure enough, he confesses that he is not a "reader of Scripture" - allegedly because he's Catholic. I am Catholic, and I read the Bible. Scriptural ignorance is not "Catholic."

title: Questions for Margaret Spellings
description: As if we needed another demonstration of the intellectual infirmities of contemporary conservatism, Margaret Spellings offers a reductivist example when she equates creationism with Darwinian evolution as "points of view" to be taught in a high-school curriculum (Deborah Solomon, May 22). Thus, evolution, an empirically confirmed scientific concept, is considered to be no more valid than a speculation that is inherently immune to the testable canons of science. That a secretary of education is oblivious to this elementary distinction hardly suggests that she, or the administration she serves, is capable of closing the achievement gap.

title: Hello, My Name Was------------------

Orphaned by the age of 2, he was raised by his maternal grandmother, Esther Kantrowitz, who spoke very little English. When she went to register him at school and was asked, "Name?" she gave her own, which the clerk quickly shortened to Kanter. Little Izzy Itzkowitz became little Izzy Kanter.
