title: Monkey Business
description: Keith Chen's Monkey Research Adam Smith, the founder of classical economics, was certain that humankind's knack for monetary exchange belonged to humankind alone. "Nobody ever saw a dog make a fair and deliberate exchange of one bone for another with another dog," he wrote. "Nobody ever saw one animal by its gestures and natural cries signify to another, this is mine, that yours; I am willing to give this for that." But in a clean and spacious laboratory at Yale-New Haven Hospital, seven capuchin monkeys have been taught to use money, and a comparison of capuchin behavior and human behavior will either surprise you very much or not at all, depending on your view of humans.

I worry, however, about the possible implications regarding the overuse of antibiotics. Bacterial antibiotic resistance is a very real problem that faces our public-health system today. Placing children on prophylactic antibiotic therapy is almost sure to result in the formation of bacterial strains resistant to antibiotics.

title: The Quantitative, Data-Based, Risk-Massaging Road to Riches
description: Clifford Asness is probably going to be annoyed when he sees that this article begins with a discussion about how much money he makes, but there's no way around it. Asness is a very successful hedge-fund manager, and very successful hedge-fund managers make stupendous amounts of money, even by Wall Street's extravagant standards. And in the public mind, their staggering compensation tends to overshadow pretty much everything else. "Filthy Stinking Rich" was New York magazine's unambiguous take on the hedge-fund phenomenon some months ago. Last month, in its survey of the best-paid hedge-fund managers, Institutional Investor's Alpha magazine reported that the average pay for the top 25 hedge-fund managers was an astounding $251 million in 2004. Asness himself has written, in one of his better lines, that hedge funds "are generally run for rich people in Geneva, Switzerland, by rich people in Greenwich, Conn."

title: Offender Phobia
description: A PROPOSAL to close the homeless shelter at the Westchester County Airport and open a bigger one across the county in Valhalla has been on the table for years. But when word got out recently that a handful of men living at the 58-bed airport shelter were convicted Level 3 sex offenders -- i.e., those deemed most dangerous -- mild community grumblings about the proposed shelter turned to organized outrage. Last Wednesday night, several hundred people filled a Mount Pleasant Town Hall meeting room and spilled out into the hallways to protest the construction of the shelter.

title: Trying Not to Get to 'Are We There Yet?'
description: IT'S not an officially recognized syndrome with its own celebrity spokesperson, but you may wish to consider whether your family suffers from travel amnesia. Symptoms include a giddy anticipation of the annual family vacation, typically accompanied by near zero recall of the previous years' travel difficulties that elicited frustrated outbursts and threats. In advanced cases, experienced during yet another back-seat squabble, parents have been known to exchange accusatory comments, culminating with "What were we thinking?"

title: The Word Crunchers
description: In David Lodge's 1984 novel, "Small World," a literature professor fond of computer programming presents a novelist with a fantastic discovery: by entering all the novelist's books into a computer, the professor can determine the novelist's favorite word. The computer knows to ignore the mortar of sentences -- articles, prepositions, pronouns -- to get to "the real nitty-gritty," Lodge writes, "words like love or dark or heart or God." But the computer's conclusion causes the novelist to shrink from ever writing again. His favorite word, it finds, is "greasy."

Eliot wrote that "April is the cruellest month," he wasn't on a fishing trip in Argentina. Although autumn can be equally cruel as spring, "mixing memory with desire," the sentiment is less potent in beautiful fall weather on a trout stream.

title: Paying Attention to That Pain in the Chest: It Could Be Serious

For instance, women don't usually experience the classic chest-clutching symptoms. Their first warning sign may be pain in the jaw or neck, fatigue, shortness of breath, a stomachache or nausea, all of which could be associated with another condition. Even the classic chest pain can be misinterpreted. "A lot of women come to me saying their bras feel too tight," said Dr. Maryann McLaughlin, assistant professor of cardiology at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in Manhattan.

title: Iraqi Tribunal Details Plan to Prosecute Saddam Hussein

title: OFF-SEASON AT HELIGAN
description: To the Editor: Regarding "A 'Lost' Cornwall Garden Regains Its Glory," by R.W. Apple Jr. (May 15): A problem with Heligan is the mob scene, particularly on sunny weekends. title: Is That Bird Using a Cellphone?
description: For the past several years, David Rothenberg, a New Jersey Institute of Technology philosophy professor, has been listening to gray-winged trumpeters and hyacinth macaws, greater flamingos and plain old robins, trying mightily to figure out why they warble, buzz and chant what they do. He has even tried to attract them on his clarinets, on which he is, in his spare time, a jazz virtuoso. Mr. Rothenberg's "Why Birds Sing" (Basic Books, $26) is both a whimsical musing and a detailed technical piece of scholarship. At times it is a difficult read, and at others a fun ride around the bird-listening subculture. In the end, the book's main thesis is that birds sing for reasons not much different from why humans talk.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Now that he has finished the premier performances of his opera "1984" at Covent Garden in London, LORIN MAAZEL returns to the NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC this week to showcase what he really can do: conduct. The program, which opens on Thursday, would seem ideally suited to his musical strengths. Wagner, or, you might say, Wagnerism, is the theme. He begins with Wagner's wistfully tender "SIEGFRIED IDYLL," the most amazing birthday present of all time. Wagner composed the work, an adaptation for strings of music from his opera "Siegfried," as a birthday present for his young wife, Cosima, who had recently given birth to their son, Siegfried. He first performed it with a roster of 15 players assembled on his staircase.

title: MOUNT VERNON ESTATE, MAY 21, 2005
description: Jacob Frederich, 9, a third grader from Pasadena, Md., center, listens to a re-enactor playing George Washington's confidant Col. David Humphreys. "My brother had a field trip to Mount Vernon a couple of months before and said, 'It's really fun there, we should go.' We heard them" -- the re-enactors -- "talking, and I went up to them and asked for their autographs. They were just talking about what they did and how they met George Washington and who he was. I'm thinking that this guy's really smart to know all this about George Washington when really not very many people could have known, like not very many people could have known about dinosaurs if they didn't find the footprints and all the fossils." As told to Seth Kugel

description: This year, once again, our Summer Reading issue coincides with BookExpo America, billed as "the largest book industry event in the United States." This week some 1,500 publishers and 500 authors descended on New York's Jacob Javits Convention Center to take in panel discussions like "Back Office Automation for Bookstores" and "Beyond the Book Cover Medallion," not to mention attending cocktail parties all over town. Doris Kearns Goodwin, Nick Hornby and John Irving -- along with Kim Cattrall, Mike Wallace and Charlie Rose -- were among the authors expected to take part.

title: Make Frills, Not War: A Cozy for a Missile
description: Elizabeth Demaray, a conceptual artist who lives in Brooklyn, has upholstered stones and knitted sweaters for plants, as part of a campaign she calls "inappropriate care-giving activities." Her largest effort: a cozy -- akin to the teapot or cake-mixer covers found at church bazaars -- for a 10-ton Nike Hercules missile.

title: We Mapped Manhattan
description: IN 1857, members of the Philological Society of London proposed the creation of a dictionary built upon quotations contributed by readers. The Book Review's project to make a literary map of Manhattan (see centerfold, next page) was wildly more modest than the Oxford English Dictionary, but our reliance on reader submissions was as great, and our gratitude to participants as genuine. The response to our announcement on May 1 ("We'll Map Manhattan") was both enthusiastic and far flung. Submissions arrived from across the country and around the world (Paris, Tampico, Singapore), from general readers, university departments (English, of course, but also German and forestry), and from the third-grade classes of Ms. Chapnick in Ardsley, N.Y., and Mrs. Rosee and Mrs. Absgarten in Scarsdale.

title: Orderly, Neighborly and Somewhat Timeless
description: STANDING in downtown Wantagh, N.Y., and looking up at the clock tower can be a bit perplexing. Not only is the time different on all three clock faces, but not one of the three tells the correct time. It may be the only incongruity in a town that appears to pride itself on orderliness.

title: Rockin' the Torah
description: "We thought that the highbrow contributions that Jews have made to culture have been amply celebrated," said David Segal, a staff writer for The Washington Post. "We wanted to aim lower." So instead of expending the time, energy and Internet bandwidth to build a Web site dedicated to all the Jews who made their names in the arts, Mr. Segal and the other founders of Jewsrock.org opted for a less ambitious project: a virtual shrine to the sons and daughters of Israel who have practiced rock 'n' roll. Another curator for Jewsrock.org -- coming soon, though a beta version has been running for several weeks -- is Jeffrey Goldberg, a staff writer at The New Yorker, and its manager is Allen Goldberg (no relation), director of branding and communications at XM Satellite Radio. The site pays semi-serious tribute to rockin' Jews both genuine and honorary, from Bob Dylan and Lou Reed to two-thirds of Sleater-Kinney.

title: A Luxe Top On the Loose
description: Adam & Eve, which made its name last year with high-quality T-shirts and underwear, has branched into the world of sportswear. Its new collection includes easy linen pants, sexy tanks and beaded cardigans, but the hottest item is probably the embellished dolman blouse: a streamlined version of this summer's ubiquitous Indian tunic, made of cotton jersey and jeweled lavishly at the neckline ($230). At Bergdorf Goodman, the tops are doing a brisk business. "We've already reordered them three times," said Robert Burke, the store's fashion director. "The only problem is that we can't keep them in stock." LOLA OGUNNAIKE

title: Flute Meets Fruit

That night, to my untrained eye, she was walking a line between Vivienne Westwood, the British punk doyenne, and Jane Avril, Toulouse-Lautrec's famous model. A cancan dancer on acid.

title: Report Presses Easy Ways to Fix Airline Security
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 - Significant gaps in security at the nation's airports could be curtailed even at a time of rising passenger traffic by quickly making a wide range of relatively modest changes in screening people and bags, a confidential report by the Department of Homeland Security has concluded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSSORIO, FREDERIC EUGENE
description: OSSORIO--Frederic Eugene. Died May 27, 2005, in Boulder, CO. He was 85. The son of Miguel Jose Ossorio and Pacita Yanco de Ossorio, he was born July 13, 1919, in Manila, The Philippines. He graduated from Yale University and attended Harvard Business School. He married Siena H. de Roos Ossorio on June 26, 1950, in Greenwich, CT. He worked for The Victorias Milling Company, the family business, from 1946 to 1961. He served on the Board of The Amstar Corporation from 1961 to 1984. He was a patron of the arts, and enjoyed literature, history and foreign culture. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Siena, of Boulder, CO, four daughters, two sons, and 15 grandchildren. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be sent to St. Thomas Aquinas Church, 904 14th St., Boulder, CO 80302. A Memorial Service is planned to be held in Boulder, in August.

title: Just Like Courbet's. Except For a Few Tiny Details.
description: AN artist's life is supposed to be riddled with isolation and despair, but for the multimedia artist Tony Oursler, inspired ideas are sparked by thoughtful collaborations. So, when the Muse d'Orsay in Paris invited him to create a work in response to any painting in its collection last year, Mr. Oursler's wife, Jacqueline Humphries, an accomplished painter in her own right, suggested that he take a look at Courbet's 1855 masterwork, "The Artist's Studio: A Real Allegory of a Seven-Year Phase in My Artistic and Moral Life."

title: If You Can Make It in Silicon Valley, You Can Make It . . . in Silicon Valley Again
description: One evening this spring, Marc Andreessen, the first outsize icon of the Internet era, caught a glimpse of his former life while mingling at the San Francisco launch party for Current, Al Gore's new 24-hour cable station. In 1994, when Andreessen was only 22, he and a high-tech veteran named Jim Clark created the Internet-browser company Netscape Communications. Two years later, there he was on the cover of Time, sitting barefoot on a golden throne, dressed in jeans and a rumpled black polo. The magazine cast him as the king of the "golden geeks," a group that popularized the formerly novel notion of surfing the Web and, not incidentally, helped create a vision of Silicon Valley as a glittering gold field where the young, bright and vigorous could stake a claim and make themselves unimaginably wealthy before they even had the time to put up posters in their barely furnished apartments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSMITH, LEONARD
description: GOLDSMITH--Leonard. 86, formerly of Caldwell, NJ, died peacefully at home in Tacoma, WA, May 28th. Born in Worcester, MA, a graduate of Worcester Polytechnic Institute, he played clarinet and sax in a big band. He served as captain in US Army in WW II, installing radar in Latin America. He raised two sons in Valley Stream, LI, with Marcia, his wife of 58 years, while working as an aerospace engineer. He was a loving husband and an involved and caring father, who passed on to all his love of music, art, physics, tennis, hiking, conservation and the great outdoors. He is survived by his wife Marcia Skeist Goldsmith; his sons, Dr. Martin Goldsmith of Tacoma, WA, and Richard Goldsmith, a filmmaker, of Berkeley, CA; daughters-in-law Jodie Zaricor and Susanna Tadlock; four grandchildren, Toby, Noah, Emma and Jamie; a sister Beatrice Victor of Staten Island; and a brother Albert Goldsmith of Newburgh, NY. Memorial service and celebration of his life, Caldwell Women's Club, Caldwell, NJ, Saturday, June 11, 1-5 pm.

title: Suffolk Takes a Gamble to Revive Shellfish

title: The Spring of Our Discontent
description: A LITTLE more than two weeks ago, when much of the American movie-critic population was in Cannes pushing and shoving our way into four or five movies a day, the news arrived from back home that the general public did not appear to share our zeal. For the third spring in a row, the box-office grosses and the number of tickets sold for first-run theatrical releases had fallen, data that provoked concern and speculation in Hollywood and in the industry trade papers. What could be keeping people away from the movies? Bad weather? Economic uncertainty? The high price of gasoline? The angry and polarized political climate?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, DR. GISELA STEIN
description: GROSS--Dr. Gisela Stein. Professor and author. Dr. Gisela Stein Gross, a former Professor of Modern Languages and Comparative Literature at Brooklyn College who also had taught at Vassar and NYU. Dr. Stein Gross was the author of many scholarly articles and books among them the only comprehensive study in English of the Austrian dramatist Franz Grillparzer. For her book "The Inspiration Motif in the Life and Works of Franz Grillparzer," she received the prestigious Ottendorfer Memorial Award. Other volumes included an anthology of the works of the Nobel prize winner Hermann Hesse and of the short stories of Heinrich Boell. Dr. Stein Gross was born in Vienna and came to this country in 1939 at an early age. She received a Bachelor's Degree from Washington Square College and her doctorate from New York University. On her maternal side, Dr. Stein Gross was a direct descendant of the noted Bible scholar Saul Raphael Landau. She was married to the late Edward A. Gross who was also a graduate of New York University. He was a business leader in the automotive replacement field and president of the Andrew Parts Manufacturing Company and the A. G. Sales Company of New York. Mr. Gross died in 1985. There are no immediate survivors. Graveside services Sunday, Beth David Cemetery, 1 PM.

title: Diamond Rings, Beyond Fingers

title: The Clothing Crusader
description: Growing up in Ireland, Ali Hewson had much of her wardrobe handmade by her mother. Now, even after 23 years of marriage to Bono, the lead singer of U2, Ms. Hewson says her tastes have remained homespun. "I like to feel comfortable and relaxed," she said. Those two concepts are the linchpins of Edun, a clothing line that Ms. Hewson started this spring with her husband and Rogan Gregory, a denim designer. Edun's jeans, blazers, camisoles and embroidered T-shirts are made mostly from organic hemp, cotton and silk. On a stop in New York City, Ms. Hewson, 44, wore an Edun cotton and chenille jacket from the fall 2005 collection ($375, at Barneys New York next month). Other favorites include Helmut Lang and Prada. As for Bono's participation in Edun's designs? "I told him he couldn't," Ms. Hewson said. "The man who brought the world the mullet is not supposed to be involved in fashion." JENNIFER TUNG

Sedaris's latest collection of essays revives the themes that have made him one of America's pre-eminent humorists: his family's gentle dementia; his years spent wandering in obscurity; his life in France with his boyfriend. This volume, like "Naked" (1997) and "Me Talk Pretty One Day" (2000), is often hilarious -- but it is also more introspective. In one essay, "Repeat After Me," Sedaris agonizes over using his family for raw material; he imagines training his sister's parrot to say: "Forgive me. Forgive me. Forgive me."

title: ANOTHER CRASH AT TETERBORO
description: In the third accident in four months at Teterboro Airport, a twin-engine plane arriving from Nantucket, Mass., crashed next to a runway and caught fire Tuesday morning. An airport manager and a police officer rushed to the burning wreck and pulled out the pilot, who was the only person aboard, aviation officials said. The pilot was taken to Hackensack University Medical Center. The pilot warned the control tower that he was having mechanical problems about a minute before the crash, said Anthony R. Coscia, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns and operates the busy airport. Jim Peters, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, said that the pilot reported trouble with both engines and that controllers cleared him to land right away. The F.A.A. is investigating, Mr. Peters said.

A man of strong principles and unparalleled scholarship, Hacham Baruch's advice was sought by rabbis throughout the U.S. and Israel. His passing is a great loss to his family, to the Yeshivah of Flatbush family, whose parents and children looked to him for guidance and inspiration, to his community and to Klal Yisrael. description: IN 1792, John Byng, the delightful if irascible author of "The Torrington Diaries," came across his old acquaintance Humphrey Repton -- "the now noted landscape designer," as Byng puts it -- in the village of Biggleswade. To us, of course, Repton is a name as large as Capability Brown or any of the other great fashioners of the English landscape. But to Byng, Repton was just "a gentleman I have long known, and of so many words that he is not easily shaken off; he asserts so much, and assumes so much, as to make me irritable, for he is one (of the many) who is never wrong; and therefore why debate with him?" Thanks to Byng, it is easy to imagine a landowner glad to have the gardens finished, if only to get Repton out of the house. Such are the imperfections of genius.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVOL, RECTOR THOMSON, M.D. DR. DAVOL
description: DAVOL--Rector Thomson, M.D. Dr. Davol, 90, of Greenwich, CT died in Greenwich May 29, 2005. The cause of death was cardio-respiratory arrest. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on May 21, 1915 and moved to Stamford, CT in 1924. Dr. Davol was a graduate of Yale, Class of 1937 and received his M.D. from Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons in 1941. He interned at Bellevue and completed a residency in otolaryngology at New York Eye and Ear Infirmary. He was a Lieutenant in the Navy Medical Corps during WW II and served in the Pacific. After his discharge in 1946, he was an Instructor in Otology at NYU. He moved to Greenwich to practice otolaryngology. He was Director of the Department of Otolaryngology at Greenwich Hospital, a member of the AMA, President of the Greenwich Medical Society, and President of the Fairfield County Medical Society. He was a Diplomate of the American Board of Otolaryngology. Dr. Davol is predeceased by two sons, John Davol and Peter Davol. His widow Anne survives, as do two daughters, Gaynor Davol Casner of Concord, MA and Dr. Joan Davol Popkin of Ridgewood, NJ, and a son Ward Miller Davol of Greenwich, CT as well as fifteen grandchildren and nine great grandchildren. There will be a memorial service on Thursday, June 9 at 12 noon at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich. title: The Real European Union
description: The Eurovision Song Contest, that venerable multinational forerunner of "American Idol," wrapped up its 50th edition recently, awarding the top prize to Helena Paparizou of Greece and the song "My Number One." (Ms. Paparizou is seen at right in the finale in Kiev, Ukraine, demonstrating skills we haven't seen from Kelly Clarkson or Ruben Studdard.) Both contests involve mass balloting by television viewers and intense debates about voting patterns. But in Eurovision, those patterns are a lot more complicated: this year's contest involved voters from 39 countries, representing multiple languages, cultures and historical animosities. Those relationships drew the attention of Neil F. Johnson, a professor of physics at Oxford University, who, in "How Does Europe Make Its Mind Up?," set out to quantify how geopolitics factors in with lyrics, voice and smile. The paper (online at http://arxiv.org/PS--cache/physics/pdf/0505/0505071.pdf) was written with three other Oxford scholars. "Like so many other systems," Mr. Johnson said, "Eurovision is an economy where things are exchanging information over time." Among his findings, based on voting from 1992 to 2003: (1) While many voting affinities were geographically predictable, some were surprising. For instance: Scandinavian and Estonian voters tended to favor the same songs. Looking deeper, Mr. Johnson found that Estonia's large Finnish population was probably the reason. (2) While Britain is often branded the most Europhobic of European nations, its voters were the most "in tune" with the continent; they gave more points to new Central European countries than voters from other older nations, and they began voting for eventual winners earlier and in greater numbers. (3) France, on the other hand, was "the most out of tune" in its voting; French viewers consistently failed to vote for the countries that were most likely to vote for France. All of this, of course, has wounded various European sensibilities. "You wouldn't believe my e-mail box," Mr. Johnson said. "I open it in fear every morning."

title: Payback Peccadilloes
description: On a recent vacation, our rental-car reservation was not honored because the location had no cars available. I wrote to the company demanding reimbursement for the cost of the occasional car and driver we hired instead. The company agreed to reimburse us upon submission of receipts, which, unfortunately, I neglected to obtain. May I submit "receipts" that accurately reflect my expenses but that I have simply forged? M.E., New York The quirky use of quotation marks in a query ("receipts") is a surprisingly reliable clue to misconduct. While your ends are legitimate -- you're entitled to the reimbursement -- your means are not. Rather than engage in counterfeiting, you should obtain honest documents. Call the company that provided the car and driver and ask it for a receipt, or for something more casual but no less authentic, like a letter describing the service it provided. Or tell your sad story to the car-rental company and ask if it would accept a signed and notarized affidavit in lieu of receipts.

What's adventurous for an adult thrill seeker-cum-orthopedic surgery candidate would be unsuited for a 10-year-old (and bloodcurdling for his parents). But child-friendly adventures don't need to be dull. Pick the right trip and you can camp, bike, kayak, rock climb, hike and even elephant trek en famille. Fox News continued to far outpace CNN in May's Nielsen estimates, as well as all other cable news outlets. Concurrent with its 25th anniversary, CNN's April ratings spike evaporated. Fox News increased its year-over-year ratings during the prime-time hours in total viewers, averaging an audience of 1.4 million for the month, compared with CNN's 610,000, CNN Headline News' 317,000 and MSNBC's 286,000. In the 25-to-54 age group that cable news channels target, though, Fox News and CNN deteriorated during prime time and the total day compared with last year, while CNN Headline News showed dramatic increases in all measurements. Its prime-time hours, featuring the table-pounding Nancy Grace, above, whom the channel shares with Court TV, were up 82 percent in total viewers and 76 percent in adults 25 to 54 in contrast to 2004. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMMONS, WALTER H.
description: SIMMONS--Walter H. Born January 20, 1931, in Columbia, South Carolina. Passed away at home surrounded by his loving children on May 28, 2005. He served his country during the Korean War, Engineering Corps in the US Army. Walter graduated from Clemson College where he received a degree in Architecture. He lived in New York City, where his focus was commercial architecture. He was a partner at Copland, Novak, Israel and Simmons. He owned his own firm for several years. Walter loved sailing, golfing and traveling. He also enjoyed dancing with his loving wife of 44 years, Bobbie Jean, who preceded him in death. He is survived by his son Robert Simmons of New York City, and daughter Jean Simmons of Miami, Florida. He will be missed for his sense of humor, extreme organizational skills and his sound advice. No services will be held at his request. Memorial donations may be made in Walter's name to the American Cancer Society, PO Box 102454, Atlanta, GA 30368-2454.

Amid its comedy repeats, Fox continues to feature original episodes on Sundays of Seth MacFarlane's resuscitated "Family Guy" and his new animated series, "American Dad." description: GARDAM--David J., Jr., 76, of Pinehurst, NC, formerly of Short Hills, NJ died on June 3, 2005. Mr. Gardam spent nearly all of his career with RCA. He worked as a Training Manager in Harrison, NJ as Personnel Manager in Marion, IN, and as Administrator, Labor Relations, on the RCA corporate staff. In 1966, he became Director, Personnel for the National Broadcasting Company, was named Vice President, Personnel there in 1968 and was later promoted to Vice President, Industrial Relations. In 1977, he was elected to the NBC Board of Directors. He left NBC to become a Vice President with RCA Electronics in Princeton, NJ. Mr. Gardam was a member of Rock Spring Country Club. He is survived by his wife Lynn, by sister Betty Nuse, by daughters Marilyn Gotlinger, Donna Perkins and Nancy Picinic, all of NJ, by sons-in-law Jeffrey Gotlinger, Bruce Perkins and Fabio Picnic, and by eight grandchildren. A reception will be held on Thursday, June 9 from 36PM at the Gardam Home in the Country Club in North Carolina. A Celebration of his life will be held at Wyoming Presbyterian Church in Millburn, NJ on Saturday June 11 at 11AM. title: Air Fare Fracas
description: AIR FARE FRACAS -- A new attempt by major airlines to raise fares on most domestic flights has just about collapsed as, one after the other, carriers rescinded price increases begun Thursday night by United Airlines and matched by the other majors on Friday. Most of the attempted increases were $10 to $20 for round-trip tickets, said Terry Trippler, the airline analyst for Cheapseats.com. Except for AirTran, none of the low-cost carriers joined in the latest round of fare increases, he said. On Sunday, American Airlines and Northwest Airlines "decided, no, we're not going to play" and rescinded their increases, Mr. Trippler said. Other major airlines quickly followed, except Delta, which was maintaining fare increases of up to $20 one-way on some long routes as of yesterday. "My gut feeling is this was American and Northwest sending United a message: You're not running the show," said Mr. Trippler, who added that he expected airlines to continue trying to raise fares as peak summer demand looms.

description: DOUGHERTY -- Wilma Eli zabeth Dobie, age 86, devoted wife of 60 years to John W. Born in Reading, PA in 1918, she received a B.A. from the University of Pittsburgh. A resident of Scarsdale, NY for over 30 years, she recently resided at Mangrove Bay in Jupiter, FL. She worked in public relations, most notably for Ben Sonnenberg, Lipton Tea Co. and Phillip MOrris Corp. She was a longtime member of the American Women in Radio and Television and during her years as a publicity consultant worked with many outstanding musicians and entertainers. A founding member of the Overseas Jazz Club of the Overseas Press Club of America her contributions as a reporter and news professional were honored in addition to other honors by metro area organizations devoted to Jazz music. She is survived by her husband, John Dougherty of Jupiter, FL, her daughter, Anne Dougherty Collins of Clinton, NC, her sons, Michael Dougherty of Fairfield, CT and William Dougherty of Queens, NY. She also leaves behind two grandchildren, many cherished friends and colleagues. Memorial donations may be made to Rutgers University Jazz Studies on her behalf.

title: Arts, Briefly; Speaking of Chinese Opera
description: Those who follow what little there is to follow of Chinese opera in New York have been hearing for years about the Contemporary Legend Theater of Taiwan and its adaptations of Western drama: in particular, Shakespeare. The company finally made its American debut in recent weeks with performances of its signature work, "The Kingdom of Desire," a Beijing opera adaptation of "Macbeth," in Davis, Calif., and Charleston, S.C. New York still has to wait. But the company's two principal stars, Wu Hsing-Kuo and Wei Hai-Ming, will give a free lecture-demonstration tomorrow at 3 p.m. at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. In addition to discussing "The Kingdom of Desire," they will demonstrate more traditional styles of Chinese opera. Most enticingly, Ms. Wei will give a sample of her exquisite and delightful interpretation of "The Tipsy Concubine," which she performed memorably in New York a decade or so ago, though not costumed as magnificently as she was then. JAMES R. OESTREICH

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Telecom Stake for Sale
description: France said it would sell as much as 8 percent of France Tlcom, seeking to raise a quick 4.5 billion euros ($5.5 billion) after voters rejected the European Union constitution, which may have jeopardized the government's plans for privatizations later this year. The Finance Ministry said it would sell 152 million to 198 million shares, or 6 percent to 8 percent of the company, cutting the government's stake to 32 percent to 35 percent. After voters rejected the constitution last week, President Jacques Chirac named a new prime minister to energize the country's economy. The government hopes to push ahead with politically sensitive privatizations, like those of lectricit de France and Gaz de France.

Earlier, President Pervez Musharraf had told Al Ittihad, a newspaper in the United Arab Emirates, that Mr. Libbi had been deported. "We don't want people like him in our country," the newspaper quoted General Musharraf as saying. The whereabouts of Mr. Libbi -- arrested in northwestern Pakistan last month and wanted in two failed assassination attempts on Mr. Musharraf in 2003 -- was not disclosed. President Bush had called his arrest a "critical victory in the war on terror," but it is unclear what charges, if any, he might face in the United States. Salman Masood (NYT)

But as he declared in a song on Thursday evening at Au Bar, where he and his trio are performing a tribute to Nat (King) Cole through June 12, "I am not my brother/ I'm me." title: Arts, Briefly; CNN Shuffles the Lineup
description: CNN announced yesterday that one of the anchors of its morning program, Bill Hemmer, was planning to leave the network to pursue what it described as "other opportunities." The announcement of Mr. O'Brien's new assignment, effective June 20, was one of a series of changes, most of them involving off-camera personnel, made yesterday by Jonathan Klein, who has been president of CNN's domestic operations since December. Mr. Klein said he was appointing Victor Neufeld, a former executive producer of "20/20" on ABC who was most recently the second-ranking producer on CBS's "Early Show," as senior executive producer of the prime-time program "Paula Zahn Now." Mr. Klein also announced the hiring of David Doss, a former executive producer of "NBC Nightly News" who was most recently executive producer of "Primetime Live Thursday" on ABC, to be senior executive producer of another prime-time program, "Anderson Cooper 360degrees." The network also said that Jack Cafferty, a commentator on "American Morning," would move to the "The Situation Room," a new program that will be broadcast from 3 to 6 p.m. each weekday, beginning sometime this summer. Paid Notice: Deaths   NADLER, ARCH
description: NADLER--Arch. With great sorrow, we announce the passing of Arch Nadler, on June 4, 2005. Born Aaron Nadler in Montreal, Quebec, Canada on April 11, 1924, to Samuel Nadler (from Bucharest, Romania ) and Clara Rubin (from Iasi, Romania), he came to the United States in 1955. An accomplished graphic artist, his first enterprise was a marketing and publicity firm, Arch Nadler Associates. He then established with Rober Larimer the New York advertising agency, Nadler and Larimer, Inc. It soon established itself as one of the major and innovative firms in the world, with additional offices in London, Paris and Bremen. Its clients included Faberge, Austin Nichols, Lionel Toys, New York State Lottery, and Conde Nast. He was the Chairman of the Board until his retirement in 1983. He married Sarah Shirley Friedmanin 1949, and their daughter Linden (now living in Jerusalem, Israel), was born in 1950. After a divorce, he married Nancy Sharon Hertz in 1957. They had three children: Steven (of Madison, WI); Lauren (of Wilton, CT); and David (of LLoyd Harbor, NY). He also had nine grandchildren: Rose and Ben Nadler (Madison); Cameron Nadler (Wilton); Caroline, Sydney and Savannah Nadler (Lloyd Harbor) and Eliezar Zev, Ariel and Rachel Stromberg (Jerusalem). He is also survived by his brother, Sidney Nadler. He was a loving and deeply beloved husband and father, and a devoted, generous, and doting grandfather. He was blessed with wisdom, a brilliantly dry sense of humor, quiet digity, and (something he tried to impart to his children) an unfailing sense of "menschlicheit". He never forgot his impoverished roots--he lost his father when he was 14, and worked to support his family--and his personal and professional success never clouded his sense of who he was and where he came from. May his memory be for a blessing. With love, from his children

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy Chided for Deficit
description: The European Union accused Italy of breaking the budget rules that govern the euro zone economies and threatened to fine the country if its deficit was not brought under control. The bishop, John B. McCormack, was a top aide to Cardinal Bernard F. Law in the Archdiocese of Boston in the 1980's and 1990's; he has been criticized over his handling of abusive priests and has repeatedly been asked to resign. Students at Trinity High School in Manchester circulated a petition over the past month. They met with Bishop McCormack on Friday, according to the school's principal, Denis Mailloux, and questioned the bishop about the extent of his role in the scandal. Katie Zezima (NYT)

Crumbs for Africa
description: President Bush kept a remarkably straight face yesterday when he strode to the microphones with Britain's prime minister, Tony Blair, and told the world that the United States would now get around to spending $674 million in emergency aid that Congress had already approved for needy countries. That's it. Not a penny more to buy treated mosquito nets to help save the thousands of children in Sierra Leone who die every year of preventable malaria. Nothing more to train and pay teachers so 11-year-old girls in Kenya may go to school. And not a cent more to help Ghana develop the programs it needs to get legions of young boys off the streets.

title: Arts, Briefly; CBS's 'Men' Outmuscle The Competition
description: Two and a half hours of "Two and a Half Men" put CBS in first place in both total viewers and among adults 18 to 49 on Monday in Nielsen's estimates. CBS began the night with a single repeat episode of the retired "Everybody Loves Raymond" (9.39 million), which then led into five reruns of "Men." The marathon drew an average audience of 10.81 million. The 10 p.m. episode of the comedy brought in the most viewers, 11.48 million, of any program on Monday. ABC finished in fourth place for the night in both households and the 18-to-49 demographic. Its series premiere of "The Scholar," in which youngsters compete for scholarships, attracted a mere 4.87 million viewers. In the totals for the week that ended on June 5, NBC, which ended the regular season in fourth place, was No.1 among 18-to-49-year-olds for the first time since January. KATE AURTHUR

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New Power Plant Rules Proposed

If Mr. Pataki's plan is approved by the Legislature, builders of power plants of less than 80 megawatts will receive a decision on permit applications within six months, although proposals for such plants would still be subject to a mandatory environmental review and public comment. The governor said the faster review was needed to encourage construction of small plants that would help meet demands for electricity during peak periods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOWAK, AMRAM
description: NOWAK--Amram. Died suddenly June 6, 2005. Mr. Nowak was President and Creative Director of Amram Nowak Associates, the film production company which he founded in 1965. Mr. Nowak produced, directed or wrote over two hundred documentary and dramatic films on a wide variety of subjects ranging from the breakdown of tribal society in Tanzania to American country music, as well as two feature films and several television specials. His films have won over one hundred awards from virtually every major film festival in the world. His most recent films were the two part documentary: "They Came For Good: A History of The Jews In The United States," completed in collaboration with the help of his late wife, Manya Starr. In 1986, Mr. Nowak directed "Isaac In America," an hour long documentary on Isaac Bashevis Singer for "The American Masters' Series" for PBS. "Isaac In America" was nominated for an Academy Award for best documentary feature in 1986. In 1984 Mr. Nowak directed a one hour dramatization of a Singer short story entitled: "The Cafeteria" for "The American Playhouse Series" for PBS. It was selected by the MacArthur Foundation as one of the fifty best programs of any kind produced by PBS in that decade. Amram Nowak's first feature film was "King Murray," an innovative combination of dramatic and documentary film techniques about an insurance salesman on a gambling junket to Las Vegas. "King Murray" was an official U.S. entry in the Cannes Film Festival. John O'Connor, then, the film critic for The Wall Street Journal selected "King Murray" as one of the ten best features films of 1969. In a totally different vein, Mr. Nowak's second feature film was a documentary called "The Nashville Sound,"starring Johnny Cash, Loretta Lynn, and Dolly Parton. He began his career in the theatre working with several regional companies in the U.S., and The Chamber Theatre of Tel Aviv. He subsequently spent seven years with CBS TV, ABC TV, and NET as a Producer/Director. Mr. Nowak received a BA degree in literature from The City College of New York, and an MA degree in drama from Syracuse University. He was the proud and loving father of Steven, Jeremy, and Mara, and the adoring grandfather to Miranda, Arielle, Cordelia, and Jami. He is also survived by his stepsons, Adam Starr, and Barnaby Starr, and his step grandchildren, Robin, Zachary, Brittany, Thomas, Lucas, by his life partner, Vivian Lowell, and by his former wife, Bernice Novak. Services Thursday June 9, 2005 at 10 A.M. at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Exorcist,' the Aftermath
description: William Peter Blatty, the author of the best-selling novel "The Exorcist" and Academy Award-winning screenwriter of the 1973 film of the book, has sued the producer of two "Exorcist" sequels, Morgan Creek Productions, for breach of contract. The suit, filed in Los Angeles Superior Court on Friday, said that although Mr. Blatty had been paid for one of the sequels, "Exorcist: The Beginning," released in 2004, he had not been paid for last month's release, "Dominion: A Prequel to the Exorcist." The suit said Morgan Creek Productions had been granted the right to make these sequels pursuant to a 1996 settlement agreement, in exchange for which Mr. Blatty would be paid $930,000 for the first theatrically released sequel and $750,000 at the start of principal photography of a subsequent sequel. The suit seeks $750,000 in compensatory damages, as well prejudgment interest and costs of suit. Patty Glaser, a lawyer representing Morgan Creek, said yesterday that the company had just received a copy of the complaint and was reviewing it. CATHERINE BILLEY

Now customers at Carve can carry their food to the open door a few steps down the block, climb the stairs or wait for the elevator to the fourth floor, and spread their lunches, snacks or pretheater suppers out while contemplating the skyscrapers of the West Side. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLE, SYLVAN
description: COLE -- Sylvan, 1918 - 2005. With profound sorrow, the International Fine Print Dealers Association (IFPDA) announces the passing of esteemed member, Sylvan Cole, on Saturday, June 4th, 2005. A highly respected art dealer and author, he was an expert in American prints and printmakers. As director and president of Associated American Artists from 1958-1983 and later as director of the Sylvan Cole Gallery, 1984-2005, he published thousands of prints by American artists and was a leading force in promoting American prints of the 20th century. He was a founding member and past president of the IFPDA, board member of the Art Dealers Association of America and International Graphic Arts Foundation, and advisory member of the Print Council of America. He served his country during WWII until his discharge in 1946 with the rank of Major. With a warm heart and generous spirit, Sylvan shared his expertise freely over the years, both as a mentor to dozens of professionals now occupying positions of note in the art field, and as a trusted advisor to print curators and collectors alike. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Mary; to his three children; and to the entire family.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: LNG Terminal Is Planned
description: Repsol YPF, the Spanish energy company, has agreed with the privately owned Irving Oil to build a liquefied natural gas terminal in St. John, New Brunswick, where Irving is based. When completed in 2008, the terminal could ship one billion cubic feet a day of natural gas to customers in North America. Irving would market the gas in Atlantic Canada. Repsol, based in Madrid, will take the liquefied gas to the terminal by tanker and will handle sales in the United States and the rest of Canada. The plant, which Irving said would cost $600 million, will be owned by a newly formed company, Canaport LNG. Its major regulatory approvals have been issued. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Overturning Of Death Sentence Upheld
description: The State Supreme Court unanimously agreed with a lower court to overturn the death sentence of a man whose lawyers failed to present evidence that he had saved two lives. The man, William M. Gulley, 51, was convicted of killing an 81-year-old woman and raping her 61-year-old daughter in 1994. The court ruled on Monday that Mr. Gulley's trial lawyers did not take "fairly obvious" measures to find witnesses or medical reports that said he saved a man from electrocution and a woman from jumping out of a window in 1992, though they had seen a newspaper article about the acts. Prosecutors said they were considering whether to retry the sentencing. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Salem: Nuclear Plant Reactor Shuts After Leak
description: The Hope Creek nuclear reactor, one of three reactors at the Salem nuclear power plant, shut down yesterday afternoon after operators in the control room detected a water leak inside the reactor building. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said that the leak was detected at 2:13 p.m. and that there was no radiation release or danger to the public. It was the fourth time the reactor has shut because of leaks in the past 12 months, a spokesman for the plant operator said. The cause of the leak was under investigation.

World Business Briefing | Americas: Chile: Pinochet Loses A Round And Wins One
description: An appeals court in Santiago voted to strip Gen. Augusto Pinochet of immunity from prosecution in the investigation of $17 million he is said to have illegally obtained and deposited at scores of financial institutions in the United States during his 17-year rule. The ruling may be appealed to the Supreme Court. The former dictator won a round when another set of appeals judges vacated his indictment on kidnapping and murder charges in a case dealing with Operation Condor, a joint campaign by six South American military dictatorships to kill exiled political opponents in the 1970's. The judges said General Pinochet, 89, was mentally unfit to stand trial. Eduardo Contreras, a lawyer representing victims' relatives, said, "Apparently, the judges don't consider it permissible that Pinochet be a thief, but they don't care if he is a murderer." title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARDAM, DAVID J., JR.
description: GARDAM--David J., Jr., 76, of Pinehurst, NC, formerly of Short Hills, NJ died on June 3, 2005. Mr. Gardam spent nearly all of his career with RCA. He worked as a Training Manager in Harrison, NJ as Personnel Manager in Marion, IN, and as Administrator, Labor Relations, on the RCA corporate staff. In 1966, he became Director, Personnel for the National Broadcasting Company, was named Vice President, Personnel there in 1968 and was later promoted to Vice President, Industrial Relations. In 1977, he was elected to the NBC Board of Directors. He left NBC to become a Vice President with RCA Electronics in Princeton, NJ. Mr. Gardam was a member of Rock Spring Country Club. He is survived by his wife Lynn, by sister Betty Nuse, by daughters Marilyn Gotlinger, Donna Perkins and Nancy Picinic, all of NJ, by sons-in-law Jeffrey Gotlinger, Bruce Perkins and Fabio Picnic, and by eight grandchildren. title: Bangalore: Hot and Hotter
description: BANGALORE, INDIA - Every time I visit India, Indians always ask me to compare India with China. Lately, I have responded like this: If India and China were both highways, the Chinese highway would be a six-lane, perfectly paved road, but with a huge speed bump off in the distance labeled "Political reform: how in the world do we get from Communism to a more open society?" When 1.3 billion people going 80 miles an hour hit a speed bump, one of two things happens: Either the car flies into the air and slams down, and all the parts hold together and it keeps on moving -- or the car flies into the air, slams down and all the wheels fall off. Which it will be with China, I don't know. India, by contrast, is like a highway full of potholes, with no sidewalks and half the streetlamps broken. But off in the distance, the road seems to smooth out, and if it does, this country will be a dynamo. The question is: Is that smoother road in the distance a mirage or the real thing?

description: A 21-year-old woman on her way to her boyfriend's house was raped on a Long Island City subway platform early yesterday, the police said. The attacker fled before the police arrived. The rape occurred shortly after 3 a.m. at the 21st Street stop of the southbound G train, the police said. The attacker first approached the woman on the train, and she argued with him and tried to get away, missing her stop, the police said. At the next stop the woman tried to flee up the stairs, but the man grabbed her and pulled her back down, raping her in front of the token booth, the police said. The clerk hit an alarm button, and a passing motorman also called for help. The woman was taken to a hospital, where she was in stable condition. The attacker was described as a light-skinned black man in his 20's, 5-foot-8 and 160 pounds, with a mustache, brown eyes, short brown hair and wearing a black or gray jacket, khaki cargo pants and a military-style camouflage hat, the police said. title: Devon Cheese, Fresh as an English Meadow
description: On the outside, Sharpham Rustic, an English cheese from Devon, is merely a flattened sphere with a whitish rind. But inside it is pure sunshine, golden yellow, fairly firm and every bit as buttery-tasting as its color suggests. The maker, Debbie Mumford, takes the unusual step of adding extra cream back into the cheese before it coagulates; hence its super-richness. The aroma hints of meadow-fresh grass. What a way to start the day, with a slice of this cheese on fresh, toasted country bread. At Murray's Cheese in Greenwich Village and Grand Central Terminal it is $18.99 a pound.

Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Highway Workers Break Water Main
description: A broken water main snarled traffic and cut off water to some residents in the Todt Hill section of Staten Island yesterday afternoon, city officials said. Highway workers drilled into a 20-inch pipe at 2:45 p.m. near Victory Boulevard and Seneca Avenue, said Ian Michaels, a spokesman for the city's Department of Environmental Protection. Workers shut down the pipe about 4:30 p.m., he said. The pipe is under pressure so it can pump water to high elevations of Staten Island, Mr. Michaels said, making it likely that repairs will take "a little longer" than the usual 12 hours for a water main.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Migrating Shorebirds Endangered
description: Because horseshoe crabs along the Delaware Bay have produced the smallest number of eggs ever, migrating red knots, shorebirds that feed on the eggs, could be extinct by 2010, environmental groups warned yesterday. The groups asked Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey to call an open-ended moratorium on the horseshoe crab season, which is scheduled to begin tomorrow. They also asked that beaches scheduled to reopen today remain closed, while the migrating red knots remain in the bay. Bradley M. Campbell, the commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, said that he and Delaware officials expected to make a decision by the end of this week. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Warhol Foundation to Pursue Pirates
description: In the last two decades, the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts Inc. has filed several lawsuits charging copyright infringement of Warhol's work. Yesterday, it announced the first of what it said it expected would be "a significant number" of lawsuits in the next year saying the Internet is being used for such pirating. "There are probably a dozen sites offering Warhol rip-offs," said Paul Hanly, a partner at the law firm Hanly Conroy Bierstein & Sheridan, which is pursuing the suit with the firm SimmonsCooper. The Warhol foundation, a nonprofit organization that oversees Warhol's estate, filed the lawsuit in federal court in Chicago against Arts-Studio.com, above, a Chicago-based online art gallery that sells reproductions of Warhol's work, as well as that of other leading artists. The online seller could not be reached for comment on the suit, which seeks an injunction to halt the reproduction of 40 works and unspecified monetary damages. FELICIA R.LEE

Mr. Galloway recently appeared before the United States Senate to defend himself against charges that he profited from the United Nations oil-for-food program in Iraq. title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Top Sikh Militant Held In Cinema Blasts
description: The police in Delhi announced the arrests of three Sikh militants in connection with bomb blasts at two movie theaters on May 22 that killed one person and wounded at least 48 others. The theaters were showing a film that some Sikhs consider offensive, but the police said they had not yet pinned down a motive for the attacks. The arrested men include Jagtar Singh Hawara, the head of the Sikh militant group Babbar Khalsa and a suspect in the assassination of the top official of Punjab State in 1995, Beant Singh. Mr. Hawara escaped from prison in 2004. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Bomb At House Of Indonesian Radical
description: A small bomb went off on the outskirts of Jakarta, outside the house of an Indonesian preacher suspected of being a leading member of the radical Islamic organization Jemaah Islamiyah, and the police say they think it may have been planted by disgruntled neighbors. There were no reported injuries. "His neighbors didn't really like him because of some religious activities he's been conducting at the house," said Jakarta's police chief, Firman Gani. The preacher, called Abu Jibril and also known as Mohamad Iqbal Abdul Rahman, has been identified by the Malaysian police as one of Jemaah Islamiyah's top three leaders and by the State Department as its primary recruiter. A Modernist Composition, More About Planes Than Plants
description: The Chase garden, above, was designed by Katherine Spitz Associates, a Los Angeles landscape architecture firm, for the West Hollywood home of John Chase, the official urban designer for that city. The garden was conceived as a Modernist landscape that would "take the edge off a traditional 1920's builder house," Mr. Chase said. "I could afford to do a modernist garden but not a modernist house." In the front yard, shown, Ms. Spitz created an abstract composition of horizontal and vertical planes -- ground surfaces of gravel, wood deck and concrete, and vertical stretches of glass, wood stakes and bamboo hedge. The purple, red and orange panels that dot the garden are made by sandwiching a thin layer of colored plastic film between two layers of glass. Plantings include papyrus, irises, persimmon trees and epidendron orchids, all chosen for striking foliage patterns that "set each other off and have a strong geometric presence," Ms. Spitz said.

title: Arts, Briefly; Bob Costas to Pinch-Hit for Larry King
description: CNN, eager to add star power to its prime-time lineup as it seeks to woo viewers from Fox News and other cable channels, said yesterday that it would be getting a part-time assist from one of the best-known broadcasters in television: Bob Costas, right. Mr. Costas will serve as a lead substitute for Larry King, whose one-hour interview program, "Larry King Live," is the most watched of CNN's prime-time offerings. The president of CNN's domestic operations, Jonathan Klein, said that he expected Mr. Costas to fill in for Mr. King about 20 times in the next year. "Bob perfectly fits what CNN is all about," Mr. Klein said. "He's got intelligence. He's accessible. He speaks plain English." Mr. Klein said the idea of Mr. Costas's pinch-hitting for Mr. King was first broached by someone at HBO. Mr. Costas does an occasional interview program, "Costas Now," for HBO, which like CNN, is owned by Time Warner. Mr. Costas, 53, said he welcomed the opportunity to do "long-form" interviews and was grateful that Mr. King thought the arrangement was "a good idea." Mr. Costas, who continues to work for NBC Sports, said he did not expect his moonlighting for CNN to conflict with his duties covering events like the Winter Olympics next year in Turin, Italy. As for Mr. King, who is 71, Mr. Klein said that he could expect to continue as host of his program "as long as he wants it." JACQUES STEINBERG

description: DANON--Danny died on May 6, 2005, the day after his 34th birthday, at Mount Sinai Hospital in NYC from complications arising during emergency surgery on February 3rd. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOWAK, AMRAM
description: NOWAK--Amram. Died suddenly June 6, 2005. Mr. Nowak was President and Creative Director of Amram Nowak Associates, the film production company which he founded in 1965. Mr. Nowak produced, directed or wrote over two hundred documentary and dramatic films on a wide variety of subjects ranging from the breakdown of tribal society in Tanzania to American country music, as well as two feature films and several television specials. His films have won over one hundred awards from virtually every major film festival in the world. His most recent films were the two part documentary: "They Came For Good: A History of The Jews In The United States," completed in collaboration with the help of his late wife, Manya Starr. In 1986, Mr. Nowak directed "Isaac In America," an hour long documentary on Isaac Bashevis Singer for "The American Masters' Series" for PBS. "Isaac In America" was nominated for an Academy Award for best documentary feature in 1986. In 1984 Mr. Nowak directed a one hour dramatization of a Singer short story entitled: "The Cafeteria" for "The American Playhouse Series" for PBS. It was selected by the MacArthur Foundation as one of the fifty best programs of any kind produced by PBS in that decade. Amram Nowak's first feature film was "King Murray," an innovative combination of dramatic and documentary film techniques about an insurance salesman on a gambling junket to Las Vegas. "King Murray" was an official U.S. entry in the Cannes Film Festival. John O'Connor, then, the film critic for The Wall Street Journal selected "King Murray" as one of the ten best features films of 1969. In a totally different vein, Mr. Nowak's second feature film was a documentary called "The Nashville Sound,"starring Johnny Cash, Loretta Lynn, and Dolly Parton. He began his career in the theatre working with several regional companies in the U.S., and The Chamber Theatre of Tel Aviv. He subsequently spent seven years with CBS TV, ABC TV, and NET as a Producer/Director. Mr. Nowak received a BA degree in literature from The City College of New York, and an MA degree in drama from Syracuse University. He was the proud and loving father of Steven, Jeremy, and Mara, and the adoring grandfather to Miranda, Arielle, Cordelia, and Jami. He is also survived by his stepsons, Adam Starr, and Barnaby Starr, and his step grandchildren, Robin, Zachary, Brittany, Thomas, Lucas, by his life partner, Vivian Lowell, and by his former wife, Bernice Novak. Services Thursday June 9, 2005 at 10 A.M. at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Arts, Briefly; Millions Watch Brad
description: In Tuesday's Nielsen estimates, CBS was No.1 in total viewers but lagged among 18-to-49-year-olds behind Fox and ABC, which tied for first. ABC drew the biggest audience of the night, 11.17 million, to a special edition of "Primetime Live," in which Diane Sawyer interviewed a reticent Brad Pitt, above. HBO, with 28 million subscribers, featured three summer series premieres this week. On Sunday night, "Entourage," back for a second year, drew 1.6 million viewers, down from the 1.9 million who watched last summer's premiere. "The Comeback," the new Lisa Kudrow show, attracted 1.5 million viewers, retaining nearly all of the "Entourage" audience. On Monday, "Six Feet Under" drew 2.6 million viewers. Last June, 4.16 million watched its season premiere. KATE AURTHUR

Sex and Simon & Schuster
description: Seeking to expand its offerings in the fast-growing market for popular fiction by African-American writers, Simon & Schuster said it had acquired Strebor Books, the publishing company founded by Zane, the best-selling author of "Afterburn" and other erotic literary novels. Simon & Schuster, which is part of Viacom, would not disclose the purchase price. Among the assets of Strebor Books being acquired are its backlist of about 50 previously published titles by more than 30 authors and its contracts to publish books by a variety of African-American authors. Previously, Simon & Schuster distributed Strebor's books to retail stores; its Atria Books imprint had signed Zane to a multibook publishing contract. Zane, known publicly only by her one-name pseudonym, will serve as publisher of Strebor, overseeing 15 to 25 new books a year and reporting to Judith Curr, publisher of Atria. EDWARD WYATT

title: Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: Carey Returns
description: Mariah Carey's "Emancipation of Mimi" (Island/Def Jam) reached No.1 on the Billboard album chart when it was released two months ago, and it has remained a strong seller ever since, hovering high in the top five as other albums have come and gone. It returned to the top position this week with 172,000 copies sold, bringing its total sales to 1.7 million. Amid slow sales in a week of few major new releases, several long-brewing hits placed high on the chart. System of a Down's "Mezmerize" (American/Columbia) is at No.2 with 118,000 units sold -- it was the only album besides "Mimi" to break 100,000 -- while Audioslave's "Out of Exile" (Interscope/Epic) is at No.3, Toby Keith's "Honkytonk University" (DreamWorks Nashville) is at No.4, and Gwen Stefani's "Love.Angel.Music.Baby" (Interscope) climbed five spots to No.5. The music industry is gearing up, with some butterflies, for next week's chart, hoping for blockbuster sales of new albums by Coldplay, the Black Eyed Peas, the White Stripes and Shakira. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Charged In Cab Fraud
description: A Brooklyn man posing as the owner of a small taxi fleet has been charged with stealing $1.9 million from a lending company that finances taxi owners, the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday. He said the suspect, Mikhail Fisun, 29, used fake documents to trick the company, Metran Funding of Manhattan, into providing loans against six taxi medallions he claimed to own, each valued at $760,000. Prosecutors said that Mr. Fisun, who used the name Sergiy Bacherikov, spent a year hatching the scheme, which involved creating a shell corporation, forging a driver's license, and filing bogus liens on nonexistent medallions. Mr. Fisun pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges including grand larceny and falsifying business records. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Economy to Slow as Oil Prices Slip
description: Finance Minister Aleksei Kudrin of Russia said the economy would probably expand 5.8 percent this year and 5.6 percent in 2006, making it harder for the government to make good on a 2002 promise to double gross domestic product by 2012. President Vladimir V. Putin has said he wants to double the size of the economy as the country takes advantage of record prices for crude oil, the nation's No.1 export. But with prices expected to fall and the economy overly dependent on oil, growth will be less robust, Mr. Kudrin, left, said. Growth was 7.3 percent last year. The price for Urals crude, Russia's major export oil blend, will drop to an average $35 a barrel in 2006 from $43 a barrel in 2005, Mr. Kudrin said. Despite that, he said, "We expect economic growth will continue."

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Holy Imelda Marcos! China Shoe Imports Soar 681%
description: A survey conducted by the European Commission showed that Chinese imports of six categories of shoes rose on average 681 percent in volume in the first four months of this year compared with the period last year. The prices of the shoes fell 28 percent in the period. The report follows the European Union's decision to take formal steps to counter a surge in imports of T-shirts and linen from China. Peter Mandelson, the European trade commissioner, is considering flying to Beijing to try to defuse the dispute over textiles and nip the surge in shoe imports in the bud, one of his aides said. Unlike the situation with T-shirts and other textiles, there are no special trade rules allowing the union to apply safeguard measures to stem the surge in Chinese shoes. The union could enforce standard antidumping duties, if applicable. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Palestinian Leader Urges Factions to Maintain Calm
description: JERUSALEM, June 9 - The Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas held talks today with 14 factions, including the militant groups Hamas and Islamic Jihad, and secured a pledge that the factions would try to maintain the calm between Palestinians and Israel. title: Back to Where They Came From
description: As America wrestles once more with immigration reform, historical lessons lurk on Ellis Island, beginning with a striking photograph of Emma Goldman, simply described as a "Russian Jewish anarchist" by Augustus Sherman, a registry clerk on the island and a discreet amateur photographer. In his invaluable, generation-long avocation amid the great comings and goings of aliens, Sherman politely asked to take Goldman's picture as she and 248 other accused radicals and Bolsheviks were feverishly deported to Russia in 1919 -- also a time of a domestic terrorism scare. Goldman posed grandly for him and now stares out from a trove of Sherman photos that have been restored and displayed as part of the island's modern role as the national immigration museum.

title: Bouquets for the Nose: Talks and Scented Tours
description: FOR noses that want to know more, the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, N.Y., is offering "Landscape Pleasures," a two-day event consisting of a symposium and a garden tour. Speakers at the symposium, 8:30 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. on Saturday, include Robin Clery, a perfume hunter who tracks down floral fragrances in rain forests and the like; Stephen Lacey, author of "Scent in Your Garden"; and Yves de Chiris, a fragrance expert, who will explain how perfume makers extract scents from plants. On Sunday, from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., participants can take a self-guided tour of six gardens in Bridgehampton, Wainscott, Sagaponack and East Hampton. Tickets to the two-day event are $100 for museum members, $125 for nonmembers. The museum is at 25 Jobs Lane; (631)283-2118, ext. 33.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Rapist Convicted Of 1994 Attack
description: A Queens man was convicted this week of a 1994 rape after investigators matched DNA from the crime with a DNA sample the man gave after another rape conviction. Mohammad Karimzada, 32, was convicted on Monday and faces up to 25 years in state prison, said the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. Mr. Karimzada was convicted of raping a 22-year-old woman in a car in a secluded area of 53rd Street near the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. Prosecutors said he was identified through DNA evidence obtained after his 1997 rape conviction, for which he has been serving a sentence of 8 to 16 years in prison.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Provisional Release For Kosovar
description: Ramush Haradinaj, a former guerrilla fighter who until his surrender to the United Nations war crimes tribunal in March as a war crimes suspect was the prime minister of Kosovo, will be allowed to return to Kosovo immediately until the start of his trial, expected in 2007. Mr. Haradinaj, 36, is a former Kosovo Liberation Army chief and the most senior Kosovar to be indicted by the tribunal. The judges who granted his release forbade him to participate in politics or to make public appearances for the first 90 days after his return. Prosecutors had tried to block his return, arguing that in recent trials held in Kosovo involving former guerrillas, witnesses there have been intimidated, and some killed. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Reliable Voices for Reform
description: The Bush administration likes to talk about how well it is protecting the nation from terrorism, but there is reason to be skeptical. Legislation on security for chemical plants has been blocked by special interests, and there have been unsettling reports recently about vulnerabilities in key areas like air travel and ports. This week, members of the 9/11 commission held the first of a series of hearings to explore the progress that has been made since Sept. 11 in making the nation safe. The commission's new project is a worthy one. There is a real need for outside review of the administration's efforts.

description: Federal prosecutors in Chicago arrested seven people, including two who work for the city's Water Department, and charged them with conspiracy to distribute heroin as part of an investigation into a local cell of a Colombian drug-trafficking organization. The authorities described one of the arrested men, who is a hoisting engineer for the Water Department, as the leader of a local heroin distribution network. Federal authorities have arrested two other people, one in New York on Wednesday and one in Chicago at the end of last month, in the same investigation. The defendants face a maximum sentence of life in prison with a $4 million fine. The investigation is continuing. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 14 Charged In Drug Scheme
description: Six pharmacists and two men prosecutors said were associated with organized crime were among 14 people charged with selling more than 25,000 Vicodin tablets a week to college students and clubgoers in Queens and Nassau County, according to an announcement yesterday by Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. Mr. Kelly said that the pharmacists sold the tablets to Dominick Devito, 45, of Howard Beach, one of the men accused of having organized crime links, for $1 or more each, and that Mr. Devito then resold them to other dealers who charged customers $8 to $12 per tablet. The scheme provided Mr. Devito with $250,000 per month, Mr. Kelly said. The six pharmacists, who worked at Rite Aid, Utopia, Shop Wise and Apex pharmacies in Ozone Park, New Hyde Park, Howard Beach, Woodside and Flushing, each received $50,000 per month from the illegal enterprise, Mr. Kelly said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

Everything Rubens did, Warhol did, and more: portraits, religious paintings, history paintings, still lifes, landscapes (well, cityscapes), mythological subjects (Marilyn, Liza, Mao) and scads of drawings. You will find some of all of this, along with films and photographs, in "Dia's Andy: Through the Lens of Patronage," a scrambled, surveyish exhibition here at Dia:Beacon that is more interesting than it probably should be.

title: Arts, Briefly; Table Topping
description: In a turn of events that seemed to take everyone in the saleroom by surprise, a trestle table (below) created by the Italian designer Carlo Mollino in 1948 and executed in 1949 sold for $3.824 million at Christie's New York yesterday, an explosive record for postwar design and a record at auction for 20th-century furniture. The Mollino table had been estimated to sell for $150,000 to $200,000. The previous postwar record, $680,000, was set last year at Sotheby's for a pair of Jean Prouv doors. The table's buyer, Cristina Grajales, a New York dealer, bid with determination against Lee Mindel, a New York architect, as the table's price crossed the million-dollar mark and kept climbing. At the $2 million mark, Mr. Mindel looked behind him with astonishment to see who was besting his bids. "Wonderful," Ms. Grajales said of her feeling in winning. "It's one of the greatest pieces." Experts said they had not expected the table to realize more than $500,000. "Maybe a million," said Richard Wright, of Wright in Chicago, an auction house specializing in modern design, "if you really want to overspend." WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Abbas Calls On Militants To Maintain Calm
description: The Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas held talks in Gaza City with rival Palestinian factions, including the radical groups Hamas and Islamic Jihad, and secured a pledge that they would try to maintain the calm between Palestinians and Israelis. But the militants said they reserved the right to retaliate for Israeli attacks. "We emphasized our right to respond," said a Hamas spokesman, Sami Abu Zuhri. The meeting took place as a truce declared in February by Mr. Abbas and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel appeared to be fraying. In the latest flare-up, Hamas fired a rocket into the town of Sederot, and Israel sent soldiers into the West Bank town of Karbatiya in pursuit of an Islamic Jihad commander, killing him and two others. Islamic Jihad then fired mortars at Jewish settlements, and two Palestinian workers and a Chinese worker were killed. Christine Hauser (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia: Washington Resuming Aid
description: The United States lifted a five-month-old freeze on a $10 million aid package. The resumed aid follows the Serbian government's improved cooperation with the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague. In recent months, the government has helped send 12 suspects to the court. In announcing the aid resumption, R. Nicholas Burns, the under secretary of state for political affairs, who is on a visit to Belgrade, said he believed that Serbia was seriously working to track down one of the tribunal's most wanted fugitives, Ratko Mladic. General Mladic, the former Bosnian Serb military chief, is wanted on charges of genocide in the killing of more than 7,000 Muslims in Srebrenica in 1995. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: The Listings: June 10 -- June 16; PASCAL RIOULT
description: He kept the original Stravinsky score but otherwise radically re-envisioned "The Firebird" last year. Mr. Rioult, a former Martha Graham principal and now a modern-dance choreographer in his own right, shifted the setting of the exotic ballet classic from a Russian fairytale forest to a grimly empty modern-day world. The magical bird of the original, who saves two courtly young lovers from monsters, became an innocent young girl who attempts to humanize the lost men and women around her. Now Mr. Rioult is at it again, in dances to be performed at the Joyce Theater starting onTuesday. This time he has taken on "Les Noces" (above), a 1914 classic in which the choreographer Bronislava Nijinska evoked a bride's intense fears as she prepares for her wedding. Once again, Mr. Rioult has kept the ballet's Stravinsky score. But his "Noces" explores the anxieties of both women and men as they become equal partners in sexual discovery. Also on the program is a restaging of an earlier Rioult work that took a new look at a classic. "Kansas City Orfeo," a work in progress set to the Gluck opera score and Kansas City jazz, moves Orfeo and Eurydice from the underworld to Kansas City clubs during Prohibition, all recalled by a disillusioned older Orfeo. The Juilliard Jazz Ensemble will perform. Mr. Rioult's "Firebird" completes the program. (The Pascal Rioult Dance Theater performs Tuesday through next Sunday at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212)242-0800 or joyce.org. Tickets: $38.) JENNIFER DUNNING

title: The Listings: June 10 -- June 16; KAY ROSEN
description: No contemporary artist has done more with fewer words than Kay Rosen. Inaugurating a new Chelsea gallery, Ms. Rosen, who lives in Gary, Ind., and teaches at the Art Institute of Chicago, presents word-works on canvas, paper and the wall that refer with sly understatement to the 2004 presidential elections. In one neatly made colored pencil drawing the first three block letters of the word "blurred" are rendered in blue, the last three in red and the "r" in the middle in purple. It is a finely distilled comment on the inane red-state-blue-state formulation. A painted mural, above, is more puzzling. It takes a while to figure out that the letters P N U U M L D E -- alternately painted black and gray and diminishing in height toward the middle -- resolve into the word "pendulum" when you read back and forth one letter at a time from outside to inside. This is typically layered: your gaze swings like a pendulum and, in the context of the show, that reflects the right-left swings of political sentiment in America as exemplified, for example, by the sequence Bush, Clinton, Bush. (Gray Kapernekas Gallery, 526 West 26th Street, (212)462-4150, through June 18.) KEN JOHNSON
