title: An Important Election Safeguard
description: There are many problems with American elections, but none more serious than the rise of paperless electronic voting, whose results cannot be trusted. Grass-roots reformers are in the middle of a two-day lobbying blitz on Capitol Hill in support of a House bill that would require that electronic voting machines in federal elections produce voter-verifiable paper records. It is an important measure that should be passed without delay.

title: The Limits of Aquaculture
description: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration released a draft proposal this week for legislation that would open extensive new territory -- out to the federal limit of 200 miles -- to fish farming. This proposal acknowledges the promise and the sobering limitations of aquaculture. The Commerce Department hopes to quintuple the amount of fish farming in the next 20 years, yet it has barely begun to come to terms with the health and environmental problems caused by the fish farms already operating. It seems all too likely that the temptation to expand fish farming swiftly will overwhelm the need to create rigorous environmental guidelines.

title: 36 Hours in Brandywine Valley
description: ONLY 15 miles from downtown Wilmington, the Brandywine Valley is worlds away from the high-rise towers of the city center. Nestled into the northwest corner of Delaware and the southeast section of Pennsylvania, Brandywine, with its historic stone houses and rolling hills, would still look familiar to George Washington, who commanded the Continental Army there in 1777. Later, titans of industry, most notably the du Pont family, built famous estates like Winterthur, above, which is open to the public. And artists like Andrew Wyeth made the landscape famous. But the Brandywine Valley is perhaps best enjoyed on horseback or by canoe, following the lazy path of the river, with a picnic and a good bottle of wine from one of the many local vineyards.

description: The Hendersonville, Tenn., home (below) that belonged to Johnny and June Carter Cash, who both died in 2003, went up for sale on Monday for an asking price of $2.9 million. The two music personalities lived there for 35 years. The lakeside house, The Nashville Tennessean reported, is 13,880 square feet and sits on a 4.6-acre property. President Jimmy Carter was one of many celebrities who visited there. The home has 18 rooms, including seven bedrooms and five bathrooms, as well as four fireplaces and an outdoor swimming pool. The singer and songwriter Kris Kristofferson once famously landed a helicopter on the home's front lawn to pitch Mr. Cash his bittersweet composition "Sunday Morning Coming Down," which Mr. Cash then made a Billboard No. 1 country hit in 1970. In two subsequent sessions, the Legislature strengthened curriculums and added $700 million to the state's $2.3 billion school budget. A new group of schools contends, however, that the improvements are insufficient to meet the court's mandate. The state attorney general, Mike Beebe, said the state would vigorously contest the accusations. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Suing Steven Seagal
description: The actor Steven Seagal (below) is being sued by Kill Master Productions and Nu Image for breach of contract, interference with contractual relations and unjust enrichment involving two films currently in postproduction, "Today You Die" and "Mercenary." The suit, filed in Los Angeles Superior Court on June 6, maintains that Mr. Seagal consistently failed to arrive on the set on time, rewrote scenes on a "locked" script and made early, unapproved set departures. On the final day of shooting "Today You Die," it says, the actor left the set five hours early to attend a dinner he described as having "national security implications" and as a result, three scenes scheduled for that day could not be completed. Marty Singer, Mr. Seagal's litigation lawyer, said in a telephone interview Wednesday: "This lawsuit is absolutely frivolous, was filed in bad faith and it was only filed by Nu Image as an excuse to try to stop paying monies that are legitimately owed to Mr. Seagal. Evidence of the bad faith is, as of yesterday, they offered to pay $650,000 out of the $830,000 that is currently owed to Mr. Seagal, and they filed the lawsuit as a preemptive strike, knowing that my client was going to file a lawsuit against them concerning his many claims." title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOHERTY, SEAN
description: DOHERTY--Sean of NYC died suddenly at NYU Medical Center on Monday (June 6, 2005). Sean was the loving husband of Meg, the beloved brother of Una, Patrick, Teddy, Noel, Mari Byron and the late Kathleen O'Brien, and the dear uncle of many nieces and nephews. Born in Ireland, Sean has lived in NYC for the past 38 years. Sean attended a Jesuit seminary in Ireland and served as Jesuit missionary in Peru and Bolivia. Sean was the Chief Executive Officer of TML Information Services, Inc. and the Chairman of the Board for the North American Driver Safety Foundation. Sean's passion for driver safety and protecting individual's privacy rights was exemplified in his innovative and creative work using official Department of Motor Vehicle driver records of the various states of the US and several foreign jurisdictions in Mexico and Canada for promoting highway safety both in law enforcement and in the rental and insurance industries. Sean's pioneer work in this field created a large source of revenue for many jurisdictions. Sean was active as an Associate Member of the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators (AAMVA) and a member of AAMVA's Industry Advisory Board. Sean was also a leader in the Insurance Industry Committee for Motor Vehicle Affairs and a member of the Board of the Network of Employers for Traffic Safety. Sean provided his international leadership skills to the US Department of Transporation for implementing a technology transfer that developed commercial driver and motor carrier safety initiatives and a safety information system infrastructure between the US and Mexico. As part of his contributions with the US Department of Transportation on safety data exchange between the US and Mexico, Sean served in the Transportation Consultative Group of the NAFTA Land Transportation Standards Subcommittee. Sean made significant contributions to the US Department of Transportation's Federal Highway Administration's Team/Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration's working group facilitating the opening of the USMexico borders for commercial motor vehicle operators. Sean was a leader in promoting safe driving and was coauthor of the CDL Effectiveness Study for the Department of Transportation's Federal Motor Carrier Services Administration, a Report to Congress that was instrumental in the implementation of updated federal regulations embodied in the Motor Carrier Safety Improvement Act. Sean will be remembered for his brilliant and creative mind, vast depth of knowledge in history, government, mathematics and the technical fields related to computers and information transfers, insatiable curiosity, inquiring mind, generous heart, love for his fellow man, and dedication to his friends, his business partners, and employees, all of whom Sean regarded as his family. Sean loved life which he faced with a sense of adventure and a zest for the joys this world brings; it was said of him that he lived life as a poet would like to record it, with intensity and uncompromising dedication. For Sean there was no other way. Sean's sense of humor and "twinkle in his eyes" will be with us always. Sean will be missed, but what wonderful memories and shared adventures he leaves for his family and friends to remember and cherish. A funeral service will be at Gannon Funeral Home on Friday at 9:00 AM followed by a burial service at The Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The American Diabetes Association, PO Box 1131, Fairfax, VA 22038-1131.

title: Arts, Briefly; Cousin Brucie Heads to Satellite Radio

"I've been watching satellite radio grow," Mr. Morrow said yesterday, "and I realized that this is the way that broadcasting has to go." WCBS, which had been playing oldies in New York since the early 1970's, switched last Friday afternoon to a new format called Jack, which plays a broad variety of pop hits from the last 30 years. Mr. Morrow said he had signed a five-year contract with Sirius to be the host of two oldies shows, on Saturday and Wednesday nights, as well as a call-in talk show on Thursdays. He said he had had offers from other terrestrial stations but that Sirius offered the most freedom. "For the first time in my life I can go on air with a library of 52 years of music," he said. "I'm no longer stuck with the same 280 records to play over and over." A spokesman said the shows were scheduled to begin over the July 4 weekend. BEN SISARIO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIRANI, CONRAD L., M.D.
description: PIRANI--Conrad L., M.D. The Department of Pathology of Columbia University notes with sadness the passing of Conrad Levi Pirani, M.D., an internationally recognized expert in diseases of the kidney, who died of heart failure at age 90 on May 28 in Pittsfield, Mass. Dr. Pirani, who founded Columbia's Renal Pathology Laboratory in 1973, was one of the most influential pathologists of his day. His work forged the transition from autopsy-based studies of the kidney to modern biopsybased pathologic interpretation. The semiquantitative method he developed for evaluating needle biopsies of the kidney is not only essential to establish an accurate diagnosis, but also provides valuable clinical information about disease activity and reversibility that has helped guide optimal therapy. His systematic approach has been instrumental in describing for the first time the defining features of many major renal diseases. Dr. Pirani was born in Pisa, Italy, and attended medical school in Italy. Because of racial laws enacted by the Mussolini government, he immigrated to the United States in 1939. His early career in pathology was at the University of Illinois, and he was appointed chairman of pathology at Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago in 1965. In 1973, he came to Columbia University Medical Center as professor of pathology and director of the newly created Renal Pathology Laboratory. He retired from that position in 1985, becoming professor emeritus of pathology. Dr. Pirani lectured widely and published more than 200 research papers and textbook chapters over a 30year period. He is best known for his seminal observations on the clinical-pathologic features of lupus nephritis, diabetic nephropathy, poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, and myeloma-related renal disease, which helped form the basis of our modern understanding. In 1977, he founded the course "Renal Biopsy in Medical Diseases of the Kidney," which is the longest-running continuing medical education course in the history of Columbia University Medical Center. Lectures in his name are given every year at Columbia and at the Mario Negri Institute for Renal Research in Bergamo, Italy. In 1987, he received the prestigious John Peters Award of the American Society of Nephrology for his lifetime contributions. Dr. Pirani is survived by his wife Luciana of Lenox, Mass.; three children, Barbara Alberts-Pirani of Bolton, Mass., Sylvia of Albany, N.Y., and Robert of Manhattan; and five grandchildren. Michael L. Shelanski, M.D., Ph.D. Vivette D. D'Agati, M.D. Department of Pathology Columbia University

title: 'Au Hasard Balthazar'
description: Forget the Sith, Tom and Katie, the big movie news this summer is the release on DVD on Tuesday of one of the greatest films in history: "Au Hasard Balthazar." Written and directed by Robert Bresson, and shot in limpid black-and-white, this 1966 allegory tracks the journey of two innocents, the teenage Marie (Anna Wiazemsky, above, who later married Jean-Luc Godard) and the soulful donkey of the film's title that's adopted by her family when she and the animal are very young. In the course of Bresson's short tale, both Marie and Balthazar will endure a crucible of suffering -- she at the rough hands of a punk in a black leather jacket, the donkey at the equally rough hands of various vicious masters. The critic J. Hoberman has observed that "Balthazar" is about a donkey in about the same way that "Moby-Dick" is about a whale, but it is also true that this is a story about an animal. Inspired by a passage from Dostoevsky's "Idiot," Bresson makes Balthazar the moral center of his film, perhaps because, unlike Marie and the rest of the men and women in this fallen world, the donkey doesn't need to die to achieve grace. (It's worth noting that Bresson used a Schubert Sonata as "a kind of language for the donkey's soul.") Over the years, some critics have classified Bresson's work as unapproachable, even punishing. For these professional philistines the idea that movies can be serious, more than tricks and trashy entertainment, is apparently anathema. Don't you believe it: "Au Hasard Balthazar" is a masterpiece of the art, but a masterpiece that stirs the heart and soul as much as the mind. Released by the Criterion Collection, the DVD features a pristine print with a new translation and includes a 1966 television program about the film. MANOHLA DARGIS

description: RICHARDSON--Dr. Mary Ann (nee Sanchirico). 67, a research scientist and professor of psychiatry at NYU, who devoted her career to improving the lives of those with schizophrenia, died on June 9, 2005 of breast cancer. Working until the time of her death as director of the Movement Disorders and Molecular Psychiatry Division of the Nathan Kline Institute, Dr. Richardson saw her life's work come to fruition in 2002 with the release of a medical treatment she created for Tardive Dyskinesia, a stigmatizing disorder afflicting some of the most severely ill psychiatric patients. Fiercely intelligent yet quietly patient and warm, she was a source of inspiration for many and of deep and loving comfort for the lucky few with whom she shared her life. She is survived by her husband, John J. Richardson DPM; son, Justin Richardson MD, and his partner, Peter Parnell; daughter, Martine Sacks MD, and granddaughter, Lita Sacks. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a fund established in her memory to support patient care at Rockland Psychiatric Center and NKI. title: The Listings: June 10 -- June 16; LCD SOUNDSYSTEM
description: If you visit lcdsoundsystem.com, you can watch the video for "Disco Infiltrator," the unreasonably propulsive new single from the disco-punk band LCD Soundsystem, above. It's a performance video, although the performance itself unfolds for only a few seconds, in a scene that occurs more than halfway through. The rest of the time, you're watching the band members as they go about their day: they wake up, run errands, stumble down to the venue and then, inevitably, find their way to the after-party. The group's leader is the singer and producer James Murphy (one-half of the team known as DFA), who is credited with "most sounds" on the band's self-titled debut album, released by Capitol Records. By releasing a series of great underground singles (included with the album on a bonus disc), LCD Soundsystem became known as one of the city's most entertaining dance-music acts, and fans were no doubt hoping for an album that included a few more DJ-friendly tracks. That's exactly what the CD provides -- no more but also, more important, no less. Mr. Murphy loves to rifle through the record racks, paying tribute to his favorite finds by dropping names (the first track is called, "Daft Punk Is Playing at My House," after the French house duo) and borrowing beats; among other things, the album is a tribute to the diversity of early-1980's new wave. "Disco Infiltrator" is the moment where everything snaps into place: there's a keyed-up backbeat and a one-note bass line, and Mr. Murphy yelps -- then, near the end, croons -- the lyrics; the only thing wrong is that, at five minutes long, the track is over too soon. Expect an ecstatic version (and, perhaps, a longer one) during a pair of appearances this week. (Tonight at 6:30, with the Juan Maclean, Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212)533-2111, $20. The band is also scheduled to open for the Pixies and Interpol: Tuesday night at 7, Jones Beach, Meadowbrook Parkway South, Wantagh, N.Y., (516) 221-1000, $35 to $40.) KELEFA SANNEH

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Vagina Monologues' in Moscow
description: "Monologi Vaginy," the Russian version of "The Vagina Monologues," by Eve Ensler (right) opens tomorrow for a two-performance run at the Hermitage Theater in Moscow. The play, based on women's stories about the role of their vaginas in their lives and encompassing topics that range from childbirth to rape, is especially difficult to render in Russian: translators often lament that the language for sex is limited to clinical terms or expletives. Vasily Arkanov, the United States correspondent for NTV, a Russian television network, said he was inspired to translate the play after he wrote an article about it for the Russian version of Elle magazine. He told The Moscow Times that for the Russian title he ultimately chose to transliterate the English word "vagina" rather than use the standard Russian equivalent, which he concluded was too vulgar. Joel Lehtonen, the play's director, told The Moscow Times that he had had problems securing financing and finding actresses comfortable enough to speak their explicit lines. SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

title: Hints of Ancient Worlds From Harmonies in Constant Flux
description: You have to admire the Riverside Symphony for its tenacity in the face of hefty competition. Since 1981 this freelance chamber orchestra and its directors, George Rothman and Anthony Korf, have offered programs in which new works, rarities and war horses mingle. Its performances are generally not the highly buffed, supercharged readings that a parade of wealthy major league ensembles present in New York's halls, but when the group is at its best, its playing is polished and vital.

National Briefing | Washington: Editor Of Climate Reports Resigns
description: Philip A. Cooney, chief of staff to President Bush's Council on Environmental Quality, has resigned, White House officials said. Mr. Cooney's resignation came two days after documents revealed that he had edited government climate reports in ways that cast doubt on the link between greenhouse-gas emissions and rising temperatures. Mr. Cooney has no scientific training. Dana Perino, a deputy White House press secretary, said the decision was unrelated to revelations about the documents. Mr. Cooney did not respond to e-mail or phone messages left at his home. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: U.N. To Check On Syrians
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan is sending back to Lebanon this weekend the United Nations verification team that reported last month that all Syrian forces had left the country in compliance with a Security Council resolution. In Washington, President Bush said he was "disturbed" by reports that Syrian intelligence agents were still in Lebanon. He said the need to "not only remove their military, but to remove intelligence officers as well" was "our message to Syria -- and it's not just the message of the United States; the United Nations has said the same thing." Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Court Frees 12 In Rape Case
description: A Lahore High Court panel ordered the release of 12 men behind bars in the case of Mukhtar Mai, also known as Mukhtaran Bibi, the woman who was gang-raped in 2002 on the orders of a village council to punish an act attributed to her brother. The men have been in jail since March, and the panel denied a government request for a three-month extension. It was not clear when they might be released. The move was another in a number of legal twists in the case so far, including convictions and death sentences, acquittals and rearrests. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: Poor Little Rich Country
description: Samaipata, Bolivia - MY taxi is stuck behind Indian roadblocks. Three hundred farmers, many of them Quechua in colorful ponchos, just took control of the only highway near this small town in central Bolivia, right below a jaguar-shaped Inca temple. I can escape neither east to the sweltering boomtown of Santa Cruz nor west toward the windswept Andean capital, La Paz, where tens of thousands of Aymara Indians are on the march. I get through, but only after abandoning my taxi and making my way on foot.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Opposition Leader Staying On
description: Three days after tendering his resignation as chief of the largest opposition party and prompting a crisis of leadership within its ranks, L.K. Advani withdrew his bid to step down. Mr. Advani, left, the chief architect of the Hindu nationalists' rise to power, sparked a war of words within his Bharatiya Janata Party after praising the founder of Pakistan, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, as a "secular" leader during a trip to Karachi last week. Mr. Jinnah has been demonized by India's Hindu nationalists as the man responsible for the partition of the country. Yesterday, party apparatchiks praised Mr. Advani's trip to Pakistan but did not back his comments on Mr. Jinnah. It signaled a compromise between loyalists of Mr. Advani, who has increasingly sought to cast himself as a moderate, and the Hindu hard-liners within the party. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Toward Asbestos Justice
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee's recent vote to create a $140 billion fund to compensate victims of asbestos exposure was undoubtedly a gratifying moment for its Republican chairman, Senator Arlen Specter. Working closely with the committee's senior Democrat, Senator Patrick Leahy, Mr. Specter has devoted countless hours to fine-tuning the bill's myriad details even as he has been undergoing grueling cancer treatment. The result is a promising if necessarily imperfect bipartisan compromise that aims to unclog the nation's courts and provide a measure of justice for sufferers of asbestos-related disease and their families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TSAGARIS, THEODORE
description: TSAGARIS--Theodore, a resident of Scarsdale, NY died Thursday June 9, 2005 at the age of 79. Ted was a beloved father, grandfather, patriarch of his family and patron of the classics and the arts. He was a graduate of New York University with a Master's in Naval Architecture and Nautical Engineering. As an international shipping executive, he was a recognized and respected ship owner and arbitrator. A faithful and passionate supporter of the church and Archon of the Ecemenical Patriarcate of Constantinople Order of St. Andrew. His love for life inspired all those who knew him. He is survived by his sons Evangelos and his wife Marlena, Constantine and his wife Patricia, George and his wife Demetria Tsagaris, and grandchildren Teo, Christopher, Theodore, Zoe, Maro Alexia and Artemis. Funeral services will be conducted Tuesday, 11 AM at the Church of Our Savior 2195 Westchester Avenue East Rye, NY. Interment will follow at Kensico Cemetery Valhalla, NY. The Family will receive friends at the BallardDurand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue at South Broadway, White Plains, NY Monday from 2-9pm. In lieu of flowers, those who wish may send memorial contributions to Metro Athlete Refocus Organization (M.A.R.O.), the family's charity for inner city youths, or the Archbishop Iakovos Library Endowment Fund c/o of Church of Our Savior 2195 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, NY 10580, or the Cancer Research Fund, 675 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017

title: Arts, Briefly; The Ratings Game

That, according to Nielsen's estimates, went to CBS, which featured two 90-minute shows: the series premiere of "The Cut" (6.68 million), a reality show judged by Tommy Hilfiger, and a "CSI" repeat (12.43 million). The previous Thursday, NBC tied for first among adults 18 to 49 on the strength of "Hit Me Baby One More Time," but this week, the ratings for that show slipped slightly, bringing in 7.19 million viewers. NBC took third place in both total viewers and the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

They gather on the steps of the post office or on the Pont de Pedra - the stone bridge that spans the Onyar River at the southern end of Girona's historic district - then spin away in a blur of spandex and spokes. title: Unpersuasive
description: Rather than requiring students to perform a foolish writing exercise that would never be asked of them in any self-respecting college, the SAT ought to test for college readiness by giving a college-caliber test. At the beginning of the year, the College Board could announce the names of six books from which the essay questions would be chosen. The books could be classics from all fields. Students would then be given a passage from one of the books and be required to identify it and discuss its significance in one hour. Essays would be scored on content as well as style. Surely nothing could inspire the actual reading and discussion of books more than the prospect of being tested on their content on the SAT.

title: Interrogating Ourselves
description: I. The Silence After Abu Ghraib In order to get to the nub of the question of what we as citizens really expect and require of American interrogators facing supposed terrorists -- how far we're prepared to allow those asking the questions to venture into the dark realm of brutalization and coercion -- let's for argument's sake put aside the most horrific, shameful cases, those of detainees who died under interrogation: that of Manadel al-Jamadi, for instance, whose body was wrapped in plastic and packed in ice when it was carried out of an Abu Ghraib prison shower room a year and a half ago, where he'd been handcuffed to a wall; or Abed Hamed Mowhoush, who, elsewhere in Iraq, appears to have been thrust headfirst into a sleeping bag, manhandled there and then, finally, suffocated. By anyone's definition of torture -- even that of the Bush administration, which originally propounded (and later withdrew) a strikingly narrow definition holding that torture occurs only when the pain is "of an intensity akin to that which accompanies serious physical injury such as death or organ failure" -- these cases answer the question of whether torture has been committed by our side in what's called the global war on terror. No one steps forward to condone what's plainly illegal under United States and international law. And although we've seen no indication that blame will attach to any official or command officer at any level for these killings, there are small signs that conclusions have been drawn somewhere between the Pentagon and White House, signs of an overdue housecleaning, or maybe just a tidying up. By the coldest cost-benefit calculation, a dead detainee is a disaster: he cannot be a source of "actionable intelligence," only fury. So there's now a new policy, "Procedures for Investigations Into the Death of Detainees in the Custody of the Armed Forces of the U.S.," that was duly conveyed last month to the Committee Against Torture, a United Nations body, in a subsection of a longer report. The subsection's heading even carried a whiff of contrition. It was "Lessons Learned and Policy Reforms." Also, the Pentagon has let it be known that it's preparing a new manual for interrogators that prohibits physical and psychological humiliation of detainees. What interrogation techniques it does allow are listed in a classified annex as, presumably, are any hints of what can happen when those techniques fail to produce the desired results. Can the detainee then be handed over to another agency, like the Central Intelligence Agency, that may not be constrained by the new directives? Or to units of a foreign government like the counterterrorism units now being financed and coordinated in Iraq by the United States?

title: Up Front
description: Julia Reed has been writing for The Book Review for nearly a decade, on subjects ranging from Truman Capote to why air travel is conducive to the intellectual life to the virtues of being a Frenchwoman. In this issue, she explores manners in modern America, what they are and what they aren't. Reed, a writer for Vogue for 16 years, grew up in Greenville, Miss., "a small town in the Delta where manners were important,"+she said in a telephone interview. "I don't remember Mother pulling out Emily Post, but there were definitely rules. You did what you were supposed to do and you knew what that was." Rules have their limits, of course. While "it's incredibily empowering to know all that stuff," Reed observed, "it's definitely a way to brag." As for the people who write about rules -- Reed's review of Judith Martin (a k a Miss Manners) appears on Page 8 -- "people still look to them; even I do." A couple of years ago, she was thrilled to came across the etiquette book the formidable Millicent Fenwick wrote for Vogue in 1948. "The best of them have a strong voice," she said, noting that her own grandmother is "being channeled through these women. There are very few people we don't second-guess." Reed left Greenville for Washington, then New York, and now New Orleans, where she went to cover a governor's election. But she's far from having cut her ties. "I still order my stationery from the local bookstore, " she said. And needs, she adds, to order some more. The Editors

description: LISKOFSKY -- Sidney. The American Jewish Committee mourns the death of Sidney Liskofsky, a distinguished and beloved member of our staff for nearly half a century before his retirement in 1992. Sidney was instrumental in drafting some of the most important international human rights instruments and was engaged in every aspect of developing the U.N.'s human rights program. In 1971, he became the Founding Director of our Jacob Blaustein Institute for the Advancement of Human Rights to help institutionalize universal human rights standards and monitoring. He devoted his professional and personal life to the welfare of the Jewish people and to insuring human rights and dignity for all. He will be sorely missed. We send heartfelt condolences to his family and many friends. E. Robert Goodkind, Pres. David A. Harris, Exec Dir

title: Unpersuasive
description: The headline of Ann Hulbert's article on the SAT's new essay question identifies precisely what's wrong with it (The Way We Live Now, May 29). Any writer who hopes to be read by someone who is not being paid to do so must cultivate the art of persuasion. This means not simply telling the reader what one thinks but also leading the reader to see things from one's point of view. Kaplan's advice -- "Don't panic and write from the opposing point of view" -- dooms all chance of persuasion by forbidding any concession, anything that might make the writer sound thoughtful and balanced, as he or she takes a stand.

description: THE BASICS -- Back in the waning days of the last century, Paul W. Stallings, a developer, decided to erect a hotel amid the tenements of the Lower East Side. In search of hipness, he consulted with Surface Magazine and began bandying about the names of top designers, including the Pritzker prize-winner Zaha Hadid of Britain and Marcel Wanders of the Netherlands. Last October, with Surface no longer involved, the hotel began renting out most of its 109 rooms, despite construction that was still in progress. This soft opening with hard edges is still going on. At present, the lobby bar (a lovely room a floor above the street, designed by Piero Lissoni) is open, but the ground floor (which will include a restaurant by Mr. Wanders) and the penthouse (which Ms. Hadid is no longer designing) are still construction sites. Despite this, the hotel is pretty much sold out -- I heard potential guests being turned away at the front desk. But the construction poses problems. The emergency stairway outside my room had a sign saying, "Wet Paint. Do not enter. Stairwell is closed." A problem that construction won't solve is the lack of a service elevator; customers share two elevators with maids and their equipment.

title: Ethical Hacking?
description: My company produces journal-writing software that includes encryption and password protection. The parents of a customer recently wrote that their daughter had died tragically. They asked me to unencrypt her journal so they "may access her last words." I sympathize, but feel bound to protect a customer's privacy. Do you agree that I should send a gentle note declining to decode the journal? Ruth Folit, Sarasota, Fla. I do agree: you have an obligation to protect the privacy of your customer. Had she wished to let her parents read her journal, she could have told them her password when she was alive or made provisions for disclosing it upon her death -- leaving instructions with friends or in her will, for example. Her not doing so might be an oversight and not an intention, but you can't know that and should presume that she meant both what she said and what she did not say.

title: Spider Hole to Follow
description: When the mannequin makers at Dorfman Museum Figures asked Ceilia Stratton, civilian director of the Fourth Infantry Division Museum at Fort Hood, Tex., what kind of stance she wanted Saddam Hussein to have -- "upright and defiant" or "slumped and defeated" -- she replied, unequivocally, "Slumped and defeated, because that's what he was." The 6-foot-1 mannequin of Mr. Hussein, depicted as he looked at the time of his capture in December 2003, is the focal point of the first of four Operation Iraqi Freedom exhibits the museum has planned to document the division's deployment to Iraq. It went on display two weeks ago and is free to the public, though its main purpose is to educate soldiers. Dressed in brown sandals ("I think we got those from Wal-Mart," Ms. Stratton said) and dark blue shalwar kameez (traditional trousers and tunic), the latex rendering of Mr. Hussein -- bound in plastic handcuffs donated by a local policeman -- took seven months to fabricate. It stands in a glass case next to a date palm tree; directly in front of it, on a floor of sand littered with bricks and rocks, is the actual metal box that held the $750,000, in American $100 bills, that Mr. Hussein had in his possession; to his left is a makeshift prayer rug representing the entrance to the spider hole. Still to come, Ms. Stratton said, is an aboveground replica of the spider hole (6 by 3 by 3 feet) into which children will be able to crawl.

title: At the Top of the Bottom in the Segregated South

"Negro" families of relative position and privilege, as mine was, inculcated the values of education, citizenship and, as one said back then, breeding with a pertinacity that was as anxious as it was authentic. Despite a challenging childhood, he graduated valedictorian from Stuyvesant High School in New York City and then went on to serve his country in World War II. After the war, he put himself through college at Pace University and embarked upon a successful career. He is survived by his loving wife Ronette and their six children, Fred Tedori, Jr. and wife Robin, Monica Tedori, Linda Tedor Whitman and husband Michael, Letetia Tedori Callinan and husband James; Joseph Tedori; and Randy Tedori Sanson and husband Michael. He will be remembered always by his eighteen grandchildren. He is also survived by his brothers and sisters, Anna Gattulo, Frank Tedori, Elizabeth Montane, and Albert Tedori. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HORWITZ, MARSHALL S., M.D.
description: HORWITZ--Marshall S., M.D. All the staff members of the Department of Pediatrics of the Children's Hospital at Montefiore and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine are stunned and saddened by the sudden passing of our beloved colleague of nearly 40 years. The quintessential physician-scientist, Dr. Horwitz, Professor of Pediatrics and Cell Biology and Professor and Chairman of Microbiology and Immunology, was an outstanding clinician, researcher, and teacher, as well as one of the world's leading experts on adenovirus. Marshall stood out for his gentlemanly character, modesty, integrity, warmth, and wisdom; he had the unique ability to bring out the best in every person he trained and with whom he worked. After winning international renown for discovering how genes encoded by adenovirus caused disease, Marshall, in characteristic fashion, converted those disease-causing genes into therapeutic tools to cure diabetes mellitus. Marshall was tirelessly and enthusiastically devoted to mentoring and nurturing the careers of generations of students, pediatric residents, fellows, scientists and faculty members. Marshall will be keenly missed, but his impact as an exemplary role model and his countless contributions to our Department, our Medical School, and the world of Medicine, will endure for generations to come. Gabriel Haddad, Chairman Department of Pediatrics Children's Hospital at Montefiore and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Inside the List
description: DATING GAMES: When a serious writer has a serious new book to sell, he or she tends to drop it on bookstores in the spring or the fall -- the "prestige" seasons, when it's cool enough outside to plausibly wear tweeds at readings. The historian David McCullough cuts against this grain. He likes to publish his books around Memorial Day, just in time for beach readers, and it's a strategy that's been good to him. His new book, "1776," makes its debut on the nonfiction list this week at No. 1. His last book, "John Adams," released in late May of 2001, also entered the list at No. 1, and lingered on the hardcover chart for 60 weeks. McCullough's biography of Harry Truman, published in June of 1992, rose only as high as No. 2, but it too had a long, lazy run on the hardcover list -- 43 weeks. McCullough is not what you would call a trendy writer, but the title "1776" does seem to confirm a new vogue for narratives that trace the arc of one specific, earth-rattling year. Already this spring we've had Winston Groom's "1942: The Year That Tried Men's Souls," as well as Jonathan Mahler's "Ladies and Gentlemen, the Bronx Is Burning," a look at New York City in the bumptious year of 1977. This August will bring Charles Mann's "1491: New Revelations of the Americas Before Columbus." And some readers may still be trying to wade their way through "1421: The Year China Discovered America" (2003) and "1215: The Year of Magna Carta" (2004).

description: LEWIS--John S., M.D. Otolaryngologist and Head and Neck Surgeon Invented Surgical Resection of Temporal Bone, an operation to treat a previously inoperable cancer, while at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Born Medicine Hat, Alberta, Canada; Died Pelham, NY, June 4, 2005, age 85, where he lived for over 50 years. Director of Otolaryngology, Roosevelt Hospital (Roosevelt-St. Luke's Hospital after the merger) for 18 years. Associate Attending Surgeon on Head and Neck Service of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center for many years. Graduated University of Alberta, Edmonton Doctor of Medicine, 1943; Royal Canadian Army Medical Corps, Overseas E.T.O., 1943-1946; Graduate training, Surgery, University of Edinburgh, Scotland, 1946-1947; Pathology, University of Alberta, 1947; Residency, Otolaryngology, Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, 1948-1950; Fellowship, Head and Neck Surgery, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, N.Y., 1950; Diplomate, American Board of Otolaryngology, 1951. Governor, American College of Surgeons 6 years. Past President of the following societies: American Society of Head and Neck Surgery, 1970-1, American Otolaryngological Society, 1983-4 New York Otological Society, New York Laryngological Society, Physician Scientific Society; Vice President, Eastern Section, Triological Society, 1979. Treasurer, American Society of Head and Neck Surgery, 1964-9; Past Secretary and Chairman, Section of Otolaryngology, N.Y. Academy of Medicine. Member, Society Surgical Oncology Head and Neck Surgeons, American Medical Association. University Appointments: Associate Clinical Professor of Otolaryngology, Columbia University School of Medicine. Author of 32 medical papers & 7 book chapters. Awards and Prizes: Newburn Medal for Surgery, University of Alberta; Newcomb Award, American Laryngological Society; Presidential Citation, Triological Society; Ogura Lecture, Triological Society; Distinguished Alumnus Award, University of Alberta; Guest of Honor, American Skull Base Society, American Society for Head and Neck Surgery, and American Laryngological Society. Survived by his wife of 55 years, Marion DeLong, two sons, Harry DeLong Lewis, J.D., of N.Y.C. & John Myers Lewis, M.D.C.M., F.R.C.S.(C), F.A.C.O.G. (wife Katharine), of Middlebury, CT, a daughter, Barbara Logan Buchman (husband John Andrew), of Bethesda, MD, Executive Director of International Lyme and Associated Diseases Society, and two grandchildren, John Lewis Buchman and Sarah Elizabeth Buchman. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Roosevelt Hospital Department of Otolaryngology C/O Development Office, 555 West 57th St., 5th Floor, NY, NY 10019; Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Head and Neck Service, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY, 10021; or Rotary Foundation, P.O. title: Retraction
description: When is an apology not enough? What is the difference between a clarification and a correction or an admission of error? Is a retraction the same as a recantation? To recant is to withdraw or disavow a declared belief, as in renouncing a philosophy or abjuring fealty to a religion. The most famous recantation in history was that made by the Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei, when threatened by the Inquisition in 1633 with dire punishment for advocating the theory of Copernicus that the earth was not the center of the universe but that it moved around the sun: "I abjure, curse and detest the aforesaid errors and heresies," swore the intimidated scientist, legendarily adding under his breath, "eppur si muove" -- "but it moves." (That retraction of his recantation is apocryphal, probably the starry-eyed wish of subsequent astronomers.)

title: Incendiary Device
description: Melissa Mowbray-d'Arbela is an unlikely player in the cigarette business, an incongruous figure in an industry run by Southern tobacco farmers on the production side and secretive capitalists on the retail side. You can see this in her appearance (the tailored suits, the chiseled face, the exotic appearance) and the elite rsum (stints as a lawyer at Skadden Arps and as an investment banker at Lehman Brothers). You can also see it in her personal history and opinions. Born in England, raised in poverty in Australia by a mother who is half-Russian and half-Ugandan, Mowbray-d'Arbela, 38, has never smoked. In her view, no one should. And those who do should quit. Those who have failed to quit should try again. She does not take issue with the World Health Organization's projection that 500 million people now alive will eventually die from smoking-related diseases; when I first met her for breakfast late last winter in Manhattan, she actually pointed me to that very statistic. She then made an impassioned presentation about the toxins in tobacco, a display so granularly detailed and footnoted and cross-indexed that when she began to talk about the 4,000 or so chemicals (including some 60 known carcinogens) released by every burning cigarette, a tally now agreed upon by virtually all tobacco scientists, I feared she might list every one.

"I would be quite surprised if Athol has ever allowed this before," said Samuel Liff, Mr. Fugard's agent at the William Morris Agency. "I have never given anyone permission to do that. description: For two months every spring, Marco Canora, the chef at Hearth in the East Village, serves a remarkably good fava-bean and Pecorino salad. Tiny cubes of the soft cheese and barely cooked favas swim in a pool of olive oil flecked with parsley, oregano and dried chilies. The sweet-bitter beans snap under your teeth, the sheep's milk cheese slips a little tang into the mix and then you soak up the fragrant oil with a piece of sesame-crusted bread from Sullivan Street Bakery -- a delicious aggregate of flavors.

title: Classical Giveback
description: Many of America's top orchestras negotiated new contracts with their musicians over the last year, and many took the occasion to bemoan the effects of shrinking audiences and rising deficits. The Tokyo Metropolitan Symphony, one of Japan's top-tier orchestras, has its own financial challenges, and in its recent negotiations it suggested a radical fix: performance-based contracts, under which musicians' raises and promotions -- or, perhaps, their departures -- would be based on "objective" evaluations by management. It was a first for Japan (and generally remains unknown in the United States, where even merit pay has been anathema to performers' unions). But the Tokyo Metropolitan's musicians, fearing their employer's demise, agreed to accept the new system on a trial basis this fall.

title: A Mothers' War
description: While reading Gorney's heartbreaking article on Memorial Day, I finally understood why this war in Iraq stays under the radar of our national conscience. I am not speaking of being "for" or "against" the war but rather noting that the majority of us just don't care. Aside from the brave young men and women who are fighting and dying and the families of those in harm's way, what effect does Iraq have on any of us? We aren't collecting tin cans, we aren't planting victory gardens, we aren't being drafted. Until we as a nation are involved in this war, there can be no real debate, just right-wing and left-wing rhetoric that echoes without resonance.

She had already admitted that one woman inquired about her religion and rejoiced that she was Muslim. It would be interesting to know if the reaction would have been the same if she were Jewish, Christian or atheist; perhaps it would.

The Fathers' Crusade
description: Reading the letters (May 22) on Susan Dominus's article (May 8) prompted me to describe how my daughter and her husband handled the custody problem when they divorced. Their two boys, in their early teens, remained in the big Vermont farmhouse where they had always lived, and the parents alternated living with them, two weeks at a time. Thus, the boys were not uprooted from their home, separated from friends and school or made to feel their lives were secondary in importance. And the parents were largely freed of feelings of guilt. It worked.

My classmates in parochial school in the center of town near the cathedral came from widely scattered neighborhoods: the middle-class area of two-story brick bungalows east of Cheseman Park; the Five-Points neighborhood near downtown, home to much of Denver's small black population; the Westside, where most Mexican Americans lived; and North Denver, an area heavily represented by working-class Italian-Americans. Since we all wore uniforms - plaid jumpers for the girls and navy blue slacks and white shirts for the boys - it was difficult to know who was rich and who was poor.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: June 12-June 18; POP/JAZZ
description: The 10th annual VISION FESTIVAL, the Little Engine That Could of New York experimental jazz, runs in direct counterpoint to the bigger and better-financed JVC JAZZ FESTIVAL this year. Vision Festival X takes place at the ANGEL ORENSANZ FOUNDATION FOR THE ARTS, the beautiful, crumbling former synagogue that held the Vision Festival in 1997 and 1998; it is by far the best of the festival's many different homes, for the simple reason that the rambling, unvarnished, spiritual qualities of the space reflect the music. The weeklong festival's highlights include a quartet called WARM (Tuesday), which includes two great and utterly different saxophonists of the 1960's: SAM RIVERS and ROSCOE MITCHELL; the influential Chicago tenor saxophonist FRED ANDERSON playing in two different bands (Thursday); and a duet of the German free-jazz saxophonist PETER BRTZMANN and one of the great New York jazz drummers of the last decade, NASHEET WAITS (Saturday). title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SQUITIERI, ALAN
description: SQUITIERI--Alan. Of Gainesville, Florida died Friday morning at his home. He was 92. Mr. Squitieri was born in New York City. He began his career as a violinist for the Columbia Broadcasting System. In 1976, he moved to Gainesville where he developed the Oaks Mall. His career in real estate spanned over 55 years. He was a generous contributor to innumerable charities, including the Center for Performing Arts, the University of Florida and the Children's Home Society. He was a parishioner of St. Patrick's Church. Survivors include his wife, Carol Squitieri, his sister Rose, his sons Dennis, Sandy, Rick and Chip and 11 grandchildren. For further information call Forest Meadows Funeral Home in Gainesville, (352)378-2528. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to St. Patrick's Church Building Fund, 412 NE 16th Ave., Gainesville, FL 32601 or Hospice of North Central Florida, 4200 NW 90th Blvd., Gainesville, FL 32606.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICHARDSON, DR. MARY ANN (NEE SANCHIRICO)
description: RICHARDSON--Dr. Mary Ann (nee Sanchirico). 67, a research scientist and professor of psychiatry at NYU, who devoted her career to improving the lives of those with schizophrenia, died on June 9, 2005 of breast cancer. Working until the time of her death as director of the Movement Disorders and Molecular Psychiatry Division of the Nathan Kline Institute, Dr. Richardson saw her life's work come to fruition in 2002 with the release of a medical treatment she created for Tardive Dyskinesia, a stigmatizing disorder afflicting some of the most severely ill psychiatric patients. Fiercely intelligent yet quietly patient and warm, she was a source of inspiration for many and of deep and loving comfort for the lucky few with whom she shared her life. She is survived by her husband, John J. Richardson DPM; son, Justin Richardson MD, and his partner, Peter Parnell; daughter, Martine Sacks MD, and granddaughter, Lita Sacks. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a fund established in her memory to support patient care at Rockland Psychiatric Center and NKI. Contributions payable to the Research Foundation for Mental Hygiene may be sent to the Mary Ann Richardson Fund, c/o RFMH at NKI, 140 Old Orangeburg Road, Orangeburg, NY 10962. Viewing will be at Frank Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, Friday & Saturday from 2-5 & 7-9 PM & Sunday from 9-11 AM. A memorial service is planned for the fall.

Right in the center here. The cars all pulled around in a circle and they were in the center."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLOSS, RICHARD ARTHUR
description: SLOSS--Richard Arthur, 87, on June 5, 2005. Cherished husband of Rosalyn, beloved father of David, Ginny and Kathy, loved grandfather of Sophie, Sammy, Katharine and Gaby, and special fatherin-law to Elyse, Paul & Itshak; dear brother of Ellie and Jim Schatz and Dick and Joan Steele. He was President of Puro Filter Corporation of America and Chairman of the Board of American Sponge and Chamois Corporation. After his retirement, he became a staff associate in the Department of Ornithology at the American Museum of Natural History and contributed material to numerous ornithological works. He was also a past President and Fellow of the Linneaen Society of New York and a past President of the Federation of New York State Bird Clubs. He was the Chairman of the Willow Pond Commission of Hewlett Harbor and a long-time member of its Zoning Board of Appeals; and also a former Treasurer of the Five Towns Community Chest. He will be deeply missed by those who knew his warmth, wit and wonderful spirit. Private funeral and memorial services. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) or Planned Parenthood of Nassau Co.

title: Remembering Utrecht
description: To the Editor: "Going to Utrecht" by Sunshine Flint (May 29) reminded us of our own stop there in the 1980's. One of us is an alumnus of New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, which is why we wanted to see the original Utrecht. We went down the stairway to lunch at an outdoor restaurant along the canal (reminiscent of San Antonio) enjoying the traveling musicians. On that trip we also made a pilgrimage to nearby Breukelen, taking a picture of the Breukelen Bridge with a horse and wagon traversing its length.

Unlike a furniture designer or jeweler, an artist, making a painting, is free to work without considering function. A chair has to accommodate a sitter in the same way a ring has to fit someone's finger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EWESON, DOROTHY DILLON
description: EWESON -- Dorothy Dillon died at her home in Far Hills, NJ on June 8th at the age of 92. The daughter of the late Clarence and Anne Dillon and the sister of the late C. Douglas Dillon, she is survived by her three children, Christine Allen of NY, Philip Allen of Far Hills, NJ and Douglas Allen of Ames, Iowa. She is survived by eight grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by her husbands, Philip Allen, Sidney Spivack and Eric Eweson as well as by her eldest grandson, David Peipers. She graduated from Barnard College Magna Cum Laude and was a member of the National Honor Society Phi Beta Kappa. She served on the Board of Barnard College for many years and was a past board member of the Newark Museum, the NJ Historical Society, the NJ State Museum, and the Upper Raritan Watershed Association. She was active on the Women's Board of the NJ Performing Arts Center and was involved in the NJ Symphony, the Colonial Symphony, the Morristown Community Theater, the NJ Ballet and Apollo Muses. Through her foundation, she supported education at all levels as well as medical research at Harvard, MIT, and the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Church in Gladstone, NJ on Friday, June 17th at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Visiting Nurse Association of Somerset Hills at 12 Olcott Avenue, Bernardsville, NJ 07924.

The morning light falling into the room put his abs and pecs and nipples into perfect relief. * Brad gasped, as if it was the first time he had seen what was hidden beneath. Troy was a magnificent specimen of manhood. At 33, three years older than Brad, he had the firm, hard stomach of a high-school athlete. His muscles were naturally lean and ropy; he was strong, but he had none of the false bulk of a steroid queen."

title: A Mothers' War
description: I had to read Cynthia Gorney's article bit by bit over a couple of days (May 29). I am a veteran, a former Navy medic; my son has served as a combat medic for the Army in Baghdad for the past seven months. If all goes well, he will come home in November. The support my small town in suburban Connecticut has offered to Philip, to his unit and to me has made this experience almost bearable. It is heartening to see the networks other parents have built locally and over the Internet to weather a disturbing and mostly unexplored facet of parenthood. Our children suffer in the heat of battle, and we suffer from uncertainty half a world away.

title: Finding Nirvana on Two Wheels

title: Try Convincing a Child These Are Real Penguins
description: Children today, reared on a steady diet of lifelike computer-generated imagery, know their animation. It's real life that may trip them up, if reports from screenings of the documentary "The March of the Penguins" are any indication. The film, which opens in New York on June 24, follows emperor penguins on their winter mating journey. The French filmmaker Luc Jacquet and his camera crew spent 13 months following the penguins as they traveled hundreds of miles, single file and in very short steps, into the frosty depths of Antarctica. There, after a courtship involving an intricate ritual dance, the flightless birds pair off. Apparently it's not the bizarre penguin watusi that has the "Madagascar" demographic scratching their heads, but rather shots of the birds waddling in unison in the intensely colorful, foreign environment of the ice shelf and swimming in the ocean. Angie Argabrite, from Clifton, N.J., took her children to a screening and was surprised to learn that all three thought the film had been at least partly animated. Her 10-year-old son, Eli, asked, "'If they wanted to make the film so real, why did they use special effects when the penguins were underwater?"' Jackson Buchanan, 6, of New Rochelle, N.Y., said, "Sometimes at the beginning I thought it was animated, but then I figured it out."

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: THE DEVIL OF NANKING. By Mo Hayder. (Grove, $23). Hayder's wrenching third novel was originally published in Britain last year as "Tokyo" -- a less memorable but more appropriate title for a beautifully controlled thriller about culture clash and especially about a strain of cruelty running through Japanese history. Grey, a young woman from England with some morbid ideas about her sexuality, has been obsessed for years with a particular atrocity committed by Japanese soldiers during the Nanking massacre in 1937. She comes to Tokyo in 1990 to find an elderly Chinese professor who has the only copy of a film depicting it; he agrees to help her if she'll ferret out the secret of a life-prolonging elixir from a yakuza gangster in a wheelchair. (The professor, naturally, is one of the massacre's survivors, and his diary from those days alternates chapters with Grey's narration.) Working at a Marilyn Monroe-themed "hostess club" called Some Like It Hot, Grey flirts with businessmen, overcomes her terror of sex with the help of an American co-worker and tries to figure out how to get past the gangster's terrifying bodyguard, a gigantic, murderous woman called "the Nurse."

description: Two suspects arrested after a shooting Saturday in Midtown that left a tourist from Maryland wounded have been identified as 16-year-old neighbors from the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, the police said yesterday. The shooting, shortly before noon, occurred after the robbery of a vendor selling compact discs and DVD's on a bustling block of Broadway between 29th and 30th Streets, the police said. One of the thieves fired at the vendor and struck a woman from a tour group, Sheria Guster, 25, in the chest, the police said. She was treated at St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan, the police said. The suspects were identified as Christian Campbell, of 345 Thatford Avenue, who was charged with reckless endangerment and weapons possession and whom the police believe to be the gunman, and Devon Carter, of 365 Thatford Avenue, who was charged with robbery. The police said they were seeking others involved in the robbery.

description: Although the box office continues to be in a slump for the 16th weekend in a row, as overall ticket sales trail those of last year, "Mr. and Mrs. Smith" (Fox), the comedic action-romance starring Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie, right, opened surprisingly strong this weekend with just over $51 million in ticket sales, according to studio estimates, earning the No. 1 spot by a wide margin. There was a sharp drop to the next highest-grossing film, "Madagascar" (DreamWorks), which earned $17.1 million, and the numbers trail off from there. "Star Wars: Episode III -- Revenge of the Sith" (Fox) has lost 41 percent of its sales since last week, earning $14.8 million, for total sales of $332 million over four weeks. "The Longest Yard" (Paramount) was at No. 4, with $13.5 million, and "The Adventures of Shark Boy and Lava Girl in 3-D" (Miramax), the only new release in the Top 5 besides "Mr. and Mrs. Smith," took in $12.5 million. But the biggest casualty at the box office this weekend might have been "Cinderella Man" (Universal), the boxing drama starring Russell Crowe and Rene Zellweger. In its second week in theaters, the film was at No. 6, with ticket sales of $9.5 million. CATHERINE BILLEY

title: Arts, Briefly; New Home for Private Art
description: The Museum of Private Collections, an affiliate of the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow, opened its new quarters in an old mansion on Friday. Created in the 1980's to highlight the passion for art that continued in Soviet times, even after the Bolsheviks expropriated pre-Revolutionary holdings, the museum is made up of about 30 private collections, including that of the Russian pianist Sviatoslav Richter, and the world's biggest assemblage of works by Alexander Rodchenko and Varvara Stepanova, his wife. Now hoping to lure a new class of Russian collectors -- many of whom are buying up Russian works that ended up abroad after the Revolution -- the museum has moved from its longtime temporary location nearby to the 18th-century mansion next to the Pushkin, where restoration work had been underway for 15 years. SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Federal Forces Sent To Border City
description: President Vicente Fox deployed hundreds of federal forces to take control of the border city of Nuevo Laredo to contain increasing violence. On Saturday, the local police opened fire on a convoy of federal agents, seriously wounding one, and on Wednesday, gunmen killed the new police chief on his first day on the job. A turf war among rival drug gangs has unleashed a wave of violence in Nuevo Laredo, with more than 50 people killed so far this year. A spokesman for Mr. Fox, Rubn Aguilar, said the federal action was necessary "because there are very clear indications of the relationship of elements of the police of Nuevo Laredo with the drug traffic." After the attack on the federal convoy, 41 local police officers were detained and taken to Mexico City for questioning. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

Last Thursday night, four of the six major carriers, led by Northwest, raised those fares by $50, but retreated when it became clear over the weekend that two carriers, Delta and American, were not participating. By yesterday, the last holdouts, Northwest and Continental, had withdrawn their increases on the fares, which are typically used by business travelers making last-minute plans. In addition, airlines that late last week increased less-expensive advance-purchase fares by $5 to $10 each way dropped those increases over the weekend, said Terry Trippler, the airline analyst at Cheatseats.com.

Metro Briefing | New York: Power Losses Around The City
description: Manhole fires caused power failures in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday, officials from Con Edison and the Fire Department said. The Rossville section of Staten Island also experienced failures, said Joe Petta, a spokesman for the utility. The most serious loss of power occurred last night when a fire in a manhole cut power to 12 buildings in the Turtle Bay neighborhood of Manhattan. Mr. Petta said that the fire, which was reported about 8 p.m., was in a manhole near Second Avenue and 57th Street, and that the affected buildings, all residential, were along 57th Street between First and Second Avenues. The cause of the fire was still under investigation. About 5:30 p.m., power to some 2,100 customers was cut in Rossville in southeastern Staten Island. By 10 p.m., power had been restored to all but 90 customers, Mr. Petta said, adding that he did not know the cause of the failure. In the Bronx, a fire in a manhole on the Grand Concourse at East 167th Street cut power to one block along the street, said Firefighter Charlie Markey, a spokesman for the Fire Department. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COONEY, JOHN M.
description: COONEY--John M. John Mason Cooney succumbed to cancer on June 13, 2005. He was 71 years old. This brought to a close a life devoted to education and community service, including 30 years of distinguished service at Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey. Cooney was born in 1933 and raised in McDowell County, West Virginia, where his father and grandfather were involved in the coal industry. Graduating from Elkhorn High School as class president, he continued his education in 1952 at the McCallie School in Chattanooga, Tennessee, one of the nation's top college preparatory schools. Cooney obtained his bachelor's degree from Marshall University in 1956, studying philosophy and Greek. He then attended Princeton Theological Seminary from 1956-1958 and transferred to Harvard University, where he received his divinity degree (theology) in 1959. In 1962, he completed credits for his doctoral degree in political science at Rutgers University. Cooney's early professional years were spent in the church. He served as minister of the Fairmount Presbyterian Church in Califon, New Jersey, from 1959-1966. He was a member of Newton Presbytery of the Presbyterian Church (honorably retired). Cooney was the organizing chairman of the Northwest New Jersey Community Action Program, the antipoverty agency still serving Hunterdon, Warren, and Sussex counties. He then worked for New Jersey Governors Hughes and Cahill in the Department of Community Affairs, in the areas of education and youth. Among his many duties, he served Governor Cahill as staff director for the White House Conference on Children and Youth (1969-1972), assembling and directing the New Jersey committee that included, among others, future New Jersey Governor and 9/ 11 Commission Chair Thomas Kean. In 1972, Cooney began work representing Rutgers University in the local community and as a liaison to the state government, local government and community organizations, and coordinating visits of national and world dignitaries while serving Rutgers University President Edward J. Bloustein. He continued to serve in that role under Bloustein's successor, Francis L. Lawrence. Cooney retired from that position in 2002. At Rutgers, Cooney administered programs that brought distinguished visitors to the institution: the Victoria Program in Contemporary Issues, the Clifford P. Case Fellowship Program, Senator Bill Bradley student programs, and the Holland Program on Ethics in Government. Among the visitors were former Presidents Gerald Ford and Bill Clinton, former Speaker of the House Thomas Tip-O'Neill, and former Vice President Walter Mondale. He coordinated the royal visits of Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands and the Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko of Japan. Cooney also administered the University's Kirkpatrick Chapel for many years. He established the first day care program for the children of faculty, staff and community residents. The Senior Citizen Audit Program was administered by his office. Cooney held leadership positions in a number of community agencies, including the United Way of Central New Jersey, serving as its President and on its Board of Directors. His office at Rutgers was also responsible for organizing and directing the University's annual drive for its combinedcharities campaign. He served on the boards of: the Raritan-Millstone Heritage Alliance; the Business and Education Partnership of Somerset/Hunterdon counties; the New Jersey Society for the Prevention of Blindness; the New Jersey Teen Arts Festival; New Jersey Special Olympics, the Boonton Hospice; and the Friends of New Jersey Public Television as president from 1968-1972. On his retirement from Rutgers, Cooney was elected to the Board of Trustees of the Family and Community Services program for Somerset County, to the Board of Trustees of Centenary College, and to the Board of Directors for the Harvard Divinity School Alumni Advisory Council. Cooney is survived by his wife of 50 years, Nancy Evans, and by his four children: James M. Cooney (wife Myriam, and his daughter Nancy), Carolyn LaMontagne (husband Robert, daughter Erin, son Evan), Christine Sullivan (husband Kenneth, sons Patrick and Kevin, daughters Kelly and Lauren), and Mark Cooney (wife Lisa, daughters Morgan and Margaret). Funeral arrangements are private and under the direction of the Branchburg Funeral Home, Inc., 910 US Highway 202 South, Branchburg, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made in John's memory to the Sondra Geier Hospice Fund c/o Somerset Hills Hospice, 12 Olcott Ave., Bernardsville, NJ, 07924 or the American Cancer Society, Somerset Unit, 600 1st Ave., Raritan, NJ, 08869. For more information or to send condolences, please visit, www. branchburgfuneralhome .com. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date.

The moves come at one of the more politicized moments in the history of public broadcasting. Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, a Republican who is chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which funnels about $400 million in federal money to public television and radio, has pushed to change what he and other conservatives say is the liberal bias of some public programming, particularly on PBS. Last week, a House Appropriations panel approved a spending bill that would cut the corporation's budget by about a quarter. title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Gay Soldiers Wed At Base

The soldiers were married by a United Church minister after the base chaplain, an Anglican, refused to officiate for religious reasons. The guidelines of the armed forces treat same-sex couples the same as unions between men and women. Paid Notice: Deaths   OVARY, ZOLTAN
description: OVARY--Zoltan. The Department of Pathology of NYU School of Medicine mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Zoltan Ovary, M.D., Professor of Pathology, who died June 12, 2005, after 47 years of service on the faculty. One of the founders and early leaders in the field of immunology, he was internationally recognized for his discoveries and break through methods in the study of allergy, the control of the immune response, and the quantification of antibodies. Dr. Ovary was a consummate man of the 20th Century, his rich life spanning 98 years. Born in Kolozsvar, Transylvania, then part of Hungary, he lived in several countries in Western Europe before coming to the United States as a Fellow at Johns Hopkins University. In 1959 he accepted a position at NYU, where he educated and inspired countless students and colleagues. Convinced that life, science, and art are inseparable, he initiated the NYU School of Medicine Artist-inResidence program, which ran from 1965 to 1976. He was instrumental in putting the Aston Magna Foundation for Music and the Humanities on the cultural map, and at NYU he belonged to a nucleus of renowned immunologists-including Nobel laureate Baruj Benacerraf, Lewis Thomas, and Edward C. Franklin--who were devoted to the arts. He worked in his office until eight days before his death, sharing his passion for science and art. Dr. Ovary exuded an infectious zest for life; he was an extraordinary raconteur with a quick wit capable of reducing his listeners to tears of laughter. Even during recent periods of ill health, he displayed an ability to accept life at whatever cost, finding joy at museums and concerts and in communication with his devoted friends, both nearby and around the world. A memorial service at NYU is being planned. David B. Roth, M.D., Ph.D. Chairman, Dept. of Pathology NYU School of Medicine

description: Canadian auto production will probably stagnate this year, the Conference Board of Canada predicted. Weak demand in the United States, which is the main market for Canadian-made automobiles and auto parts, and a relatively high Canadian dollar will lead to three consecutive quarters of declining production, the report said. The study predicted that by the end of the year the auto sector would increase production by only 0.1 percent. The report was not all bad news, however. The Conference Board, which is based in Ottawa, expects that auto industry profits in Canada would rise sharply because of declining costs for labor and materials. The Conference Board forecast profits of 3.6 billion Canadian dollars ($2.9 billion) in 2005 compared with 1.4 billion last year. Ian Austen (NYT)

Last year at least 125 Kenyans, most of them children, died from eating corn with toxins created by the stem borer.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Power Failure Affects Thousands
description: About 4,800 customers in Queens lost electricity last night, and scattered power failures were reported in all boroughs on a day of nearly record high electricity demand, a Con Edison spokeswoman said. The largest failure was in the area of Howard Beach and South Ozone Park in Queens, said D. Joy Faber, the spokeswoman. In South Jamaica, power was lost at the Rochdale Village housing complex, and fire units searched elevators for trapped occupants, a Fire Department spokesman said. Con Ed does not provide the complex's power, Ms. Faber said. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

That move makes it the second union executive board to give its leaders a green light to secede from the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which has 13 million members. Last Saturday, the executive board of the Service Employees International Union, which has more than 1.7 million members, gave its top leaders the authority to quit the federation. Andrew L. Stern, the service employees' president, has been threatening for months to quit the federation. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: A New Pairing of Conductor and Soloist
description: There's no rest yet for the librarians of the New York Philharmonic as the season winds down. First Lorin Maazel replaced Debussy's "Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun" on this week's subscription program with Sibelius's "Swan of Tuonela." (Goodbye, flute; hello, English horn.) Then Mr. Maazel withdrew from the concerts with what was said to be a mild illness. The hotly touted David Robertson stepped in at the last minute, bearing more substitutions: Dukas's "Sorcerer's Apprentice" for Dvorak's concert overture "Carnival" and Stravinsky's "Firebird" Suite for Roussel's "Bacchus et Ariane" Suite No. 2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARTRAM, MARY ''TEDDY'' SHEPPARD
description: BARTRAM--Mary "Teddy" Sheppard died at her home in Hobe Sound, Florida on Monday, June 13, 2005. Formerly of Greenwich, Connecticut and Edgartown, Massa chusetts, she was born Mary Sesso Sheppard on July 21, 1908 to Josephine and William Sheppard of New Jersey. She married the late J. Burr Bartram on April 16, 1929. An active volunteer, she devoted her time to raising her family and helping the WW II efforts by serving with the Red Cross. She also donated her time to the Greenwich Hospital and Christ Church in Greenwich, Connecticut. Mrs. Bartram was an honorary member of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club and a member of the New York Yacht Club, both of which her husband, J. Burr Bartram served as Commodore. "Teddy", as she was known, is survived by her son, J. Burr Bartram, Jr., (Joe) and her daughter, Nina Griswold. She is also survived by three grandchildren and seven great grandchildren. A kind and loving woman, she will be remembered fondly by all who knew her. Visitation will be held at her residence from 10-5 P.M., on Wednesday, June 15th. A memorial service in her honor will be held at a later date in Hobe Sound and Greenwich, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Jupiter Island Clinic, 1 Estrada Rd., Hobe Sound, FL, 33455 or the Humane Society of the Treasure Coast, Inc., 4100 SW Leighton Farm Ave., Palm City, FL 34990.

Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDLAND, BEATRICE
description: FRIEDLAND--Beatrice. June 12, 2005. Bea, a quintessential New Yorker, was a graduate of Brooklyn College and the Manhattan School of Music. With her beloved husband Bernie, Bea spent many years as an activist, committed to social and economic justice. In the 1960s, she earned a PhD in Musicology from CUNY. A lover of all things French, she wrote her thesis on French music thus ensuring a brief residence in Paris. For many years, Bea was the Editor of Da Capo Press, where she combined her love of music and language. As a columnist for the Berkshire Independent, she wrote each year about the forthcoming Tanglewood season. After retirement she indulged her interest in French culture at the NYU Institute for French Studies, committed energy and resources to the Brooklyn Academy of Music and made it a point to enjoy the varied artistic riches of her city, New York. She leaves a sister, Helen, nieces, nephews and many cousins. The family welcomes visitors on Friday, June 17, at Bea's apartment, One Fifth Avenue, between 3 and 8 P.M. We will all miss her boundless warmth, her rapier wit, incisive humor, outspokenness and erudition.

title: National Briefing | South: Powered Scooters Recalled
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced a recall of about 275,000 electric-powered scooters because of safety problems. The voluntary recall included 246,000 scooters produced by Razor USA, of Cerritos, Calif., and 29,000 by Fisher-Price, of East Aurora, N.Y., a subsidiary of Mattel, the agency said. About 10,000 injuries treated at emergency rooms nationwide from July 2003 through June 2004 were related to electric scooters, the commission said. In addition, commission officials said they had learned of 49 deaths related to motorized scooters from 1998 to 2004. The companies urged people to stop using the recalled scooters, and to call for information: Razor at (866) 664-1409 and Fisher Price at (800) 255-7318. John Files (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; New Orchestra Pacts
description: The New York musicians' union has signed new contracts with nearly a dozen of the city's freelance orchestras, and among the terms is a ban of the Sinfonia synthesizer, a "virtual orchestra" that the union has opposed. The 11 contract extensions, with groups including the New York Pops, the American Composers Orchestra, the Opera Orchestra of New York, the Bronx Arts Ensemble and the Brooklyn Philharmonic, are for three years, ending in 2007, except for that of the Orchestra of St. Luke's, which signed a four-year contract. The agreements cover wage and pension increases, and health benefits. "We are satisfied that these agreements continued our long-established pattern of wage and benefit improvements, as well as uniform terms and conditions, including a commitment to live music by agreeing to ban the use of the virtual orchestra machine," said David Lennon, the president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians.
