title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZAREMBA, SYLVIA
description: ZAREMBA -- Sylvia. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with great sorrow the passing of the American pianist Sylvia Zaremba on June 3 in Columbus, Ohio at the age of 74. A native of Chicopee, Massachusetts, Sylvia Zaremba was a valued member of our Steinway Artist family for 61 years. A child prodigy, Ms. Zaremba gave her first public performance at age five. She debuted with the Cleveland Orchestra under Artur Rodzinski at age ten, and gave her New York recital debut at Town Hall in the same year. In addition to tours of the European music capitals, Ms. Zaremba appeared with most of the major symphony orchestras in this country, working with renowned conductors such as Leonard Bernstein, Eugene Ormandy, and Leopold Stokowski. Ms. Zaremba was trained at the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, and she was an acclaimed teacher herself, serving for a number of years as the chairman of the keyboard department at the Ohio State University School of Music. She will be deeply missed. To her family we extend our heartfelt condolences. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

description: Miami Beach - AS Oribe Canales tells it, the high point of his career as a celebrity hairdresser and his fall from grace very nearly were one and the same. The year was 1993, the scene backstage before a fashion show in New York by Manolo, a Cuban-born designer with an avid cult. Grand enough himself to go by his first name only, Oribe (pronounced OR-bay) was seized by a burst of cocaine-fired inspiration. He scooped up a fistful of his special pomade, a hair cream thickly embedded with pearls, and darted toward the models.

title: Governors' Group Proposes Medicaid Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 - The National Governors Association offered sweeping bipartisan proposals on Wednesday to rein in the growth of Medicaid, saying states should be allowed to charge higher co-payments to beneficiaries and should be entitled to larger discounts from drug companies and pharmacies.

title: The Tuna Fish Can Incident and Other Injustices of Life
description: BOSTON, June 12 - Looking like a pair of cherubs exiled from a baroque blue sky, damned to drift for an eternity through the smudged streets of New York City, Christopher Durang and Debra Monk are wonderfully matched in the Huntington Theater Company's revival of Mr. Durang's "Laughing Wild."

Aceh's strongman for tsunami relief
Paid Notice: Deaths   CAFFREY, PATRICK
description: CAFFREY--Patrick, of Bayonne, NJ, and Venice, FL, former mailer for The New York Times in Carlstadt, New Jersey, passed away on June 3, 2005. He served two tours in Vietnam in the Army 1st Air Cavalry Division. He was one of the most highly decorated soldiers in the Vietnam War, having received the Silver Star, seven Purple Hearts, nine Bronze Stars with Valor, eight U.S. Air Medals, a Vietnam Medal of Honor, and several Commendations. He is survived by his mother, Grace Caffrey, and many aunts, uncles and cousins. He was buried in Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THORNTON, JOHN V.
description: THORNTON--John V. The New York Law School community mourns the passing of John V. Thornton, former chairman of the Board of Trustees who led our school through one of its most transformative periods in the 1970's and 1980's. Mr. Thornton contributed his considerable talents and keen intellect to all areas of our profession as a practitioner, educator, academic administrator, judge, and public servant. He left an indelible mark on the many academic institutions and other non profits which he served. Our community is particularly grateful to have benefited from his wise counsel and guidance for more than 3 decades. We extend our condolences to his wife Edna, his son John, and his daughters Nancy, Sarah, Amy, and Laura. Arthur N. Abbey '59 Chairman of the Board of Trustees Richard A. Matasar Dean and President

title: National Briefing | Science and Health: Fewer Doses Of Flu Vaccine
description: A major supplier of flu vaccine said it would provide fewer doses this year than it had anticipated, tightening the supply somewhat for this winter. The supplier, the Chiron Corporation, said it now anticipated providing 18 million to 26 million doses for the coming flu season, down from the 25 million to 30 million doses it had forecast in late April. Chiron is struggling to resume production after the shutdown of its factory in England last October by British regulators because of sanitary problems. Company executives said it was taking longer than expected to train more than 100 new workers and put into effect dozens of new procedures. Federal officials and industry executives said, however, that there would be enough vaccine to avert another severe shortage, providing other companies also deliver what they anticipate. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: Dr. Gingrich: Wise Prescriptions
description: A bipartisan, Congressionally mandated task force headed by Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, and George Mitchell, the former Senate majority leader, has presented a clear statement of America's national interest in a revived and effective United Nations. Their balanced and thoughtful report, prepared over six months, features an unsparing analysis of the U.N.'s current problems and weaknesses. It also offers constructive recommendations on mobilizing Washington's powerful influence to promote urgent and necessary reforms, including some already proposed by the U.N. itself.

title: A Wobbly Ginbili Is Seeking His Bounce
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., June 15 - Bathing in the glare of the N.B.A. finals can be a perilous pastime. As the television commercials suggest, the spotlight can turn great players into stars. But the bright rays can also burn their subject, and occasionally, the entire spotlight falls with a thud on the newly minted star's head.

title: Lawyers Fought U.S. Move to Curb Tobacco Penalty
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 - Senior Justice Department officials overrode the objections of career lawyers running the government's tobacco racketeering trial and ordered them to reduce the penalties sought at the close of the nine-month trial by $120billion, internal documents and interviews show.

title: Arts, Briefly; Jones Novel Wins Big Prize
description: "The Known World," a novel about free blacks who owned slaves in the antebellum South, has won the world's richest literary prize for its author, Edward P. Jones, right. Mr. Jones is the first American to win the $120,000 purse of the International Impac Dublin Literary Award, founded in 1994 and underwritten by a United States-based management consultancy. "The Known World" (Amistad/HarperCollins), which the author has said took 11 years to write, was nominated for the award by public libraries in Minnesota, Oregon, Virginia and Illinois. The prize's panel of six international judges chose Mr. Jones's first novel, which won the 2004 Pulitzer Prize for fiction, from a long list of 147 and a shortlist of 10, which included novels by authors from South Africa, Canada, the Netherlands and Norway. The only other American title to be shortlisted was Jonathan Lethem's "Fortress of Solitude" (Doubleday). BRIAN LAVERY

title: Senate Panel Approves Nominee to Lead F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 - Dr. Lester Crawford's nomination to become commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration cleared an important Senate panel on Wednesday, but his nomination still faces an uncertain future, with several senators saying that they will prevent the full Senate from voting to confirm him.

title: Hippie flower power as wearable art
Paid Notice: Deaths   KINGKADE, MARY JANE
description: KINGKADE--Mary Jane, 82, died May 26. Dr. Kingkade, former Chair of Chemistry, Hunter College, and Associate Dean of CUNY, administered CUNY's Baccalaureate and Overseas Study Programs. She also developed a public high school program that enabled disadvantaged students to enter and succeed in colleges with pre - medical and other science programs. In recent years she and her husband, Bill, were residents of the Quadrangle, Haverford, PA. She is survived by her son, a grandson, two sisters, and several nieces and nephews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLESH, HENRY
description: FLESH--Henry. Novelist, editor, beloved friend. In New York, June 5, 2005. We will remember his wit, his grace, his strength and generosity of spirit. Geoffrey, Kaalii, Heather

title: People: Sean Penn, The Wayans brothers, Burt Reynolds
Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 13 Charged In Federal Drug Case
description: Thirteen men involved with a violent street gang were charged yesterday with conspiracy to distribute cocaine and crack cocaine, federal prosecutors said. Two of the men were also charged with conspiracy to transfer false identification documents. The men are members of or associated with the gang Mara Salvatrucha, also called MS-13, according to Christopher J. Christie, above, the United States attorney in Newark. MS-13, which originated in Los Angeles, is considered one of the country's most vicious street gangs, Mr. Christie said. The arrests, made by federal agents, state troopers and the local police, singled out an MS-13 crew based in Elizabeth, prosecutors said.

title: Philips Shares Fall on Demand Forecast
description: AMSTERDAM, June 15 - Royal Philips Electronics, the biggest maker of television sets and other appliances in Europe, said Wednesday that consumer demand in the region is slowing this quarter. His remarks led to the biggest decline in the company's share price in two years.

title: Making a Downtown Address A Little Easier to Find
description: At the intersection of architecture, sculpture and signage sits TWO, a project by Gustavo Bonevardi, left, and John Bennett, right, who also work together as Proun Space Studio. The pair, trained as architects but now working across several design fields, were part of the group that conceived the 9/11 Tribute in Light. They hit upon their public sculpture for the plaza of a new apartment building -- 2 Gold Street, in the financial district -- in a eureka moment of graphic clarity. "We went back and forth for days," Mr. Bonevardi said, "until it struck us that every letter in the word 'two' is symmetrical." He and Mr. Bennett stacked welded bronze letters into a 22-foot, six-ton column, with each letter rotated to a different angle so that the word reads from every direction. EVA HAGBERG

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHRENZEL, MILTON
description: SCHRENZEL -- Milton. Be loved husband of Shirley. Loving father of Jeffrey Schrenzel, Philippa Beth Scott and Paul Brophy. Cherished grandfather of Alex, Zach, Ariel, Lily, Nora, Will, Rachel and Benjamin. He died at his home in Delray Beach, FL on June 14, at 90. We already miss his generous spirit. His resilience, humor and courage in the face of his many physical ailments is an inspiration. He dearly loved his wife, his family and life itself. We will always remember him with great love as a mensch among men.

title: Saks, Struggling to File Annual Report, Gets Notice of Default From Debt Holder
description: Saks Inc., the department store owner under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department, said yesterday that a hedge fund holding a portion of its $230 million in convertible notes sent it a notice of default because the company has delayed filing its 2004 annual report.

title: Report Card Says Auditing Still Needs Improvement
description: The state of American accounting is better than it was before the Enron scandal, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday in a report to Congress and President Bush. But, according to the report, accounting still needs much improvement.

World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Industrial Output Up 16.6% to a Record High
description: Industrial production in China increased 16.6 percent in May from a year ago as overseas orders for products like steel, shoes and laptop computers helped drive expansion. Production in China, the world's fastest-growing major economy, climbed to a record 570 billion yuan ($69 billion) after a 16 percent gain in April, the National Statistics Bureau in Beijing said on its Web site. The production growth in May exceeded the forecast of seven economists for 15.8 percent growth and was the fastest in three months. Exports of ferrous metals like steel jumped 74 percent. Exports of shoes, clothing and laptops rose more than 30 percent, the bureau said.

How Some Popular Bills Die Slowly and Quietly in Albany
description: ALBANY, June 15 - For more than a year, consumer groups have been seeking to push through a law to make it easier to lease cars in New York. Last week, it looked as if the measure just might squeak through the little-known Assembly Transportation Committee, despite opposition from trial lawyers, a powerful lobby in the Capitol.

description: WORKING her way through Father's Day cards at a Target store in Silver Spring, Md., Kelley Osmond was uninspired. There were plenty of options for her daughters to give their grandfathers: cute cards with animals and XOXOXO signature lines. But finding one for her husband, Chris, a computer software trainer with a taste for fashionable clothes and golf, was tougher.

title: Chinese City Emerges As Model in AIDS Fight
description: GEJIU, China - The storefront looks like just another downtown shop. But inside, health workers offer tests for H.I.V. and dispense methadone to drug users. Upstairs, a nonprofit group offers counseling and support for anyone with H.I.V. or AIDS.

France and Japan Seek Concorde Alternative
description: TOKYO, June 15 - Since the Concorde was grounded more than a year ago, about the only way to fly faster than the speed of sound was to become an Air Force pilot. But now France and Japan are hoping to develop a commercial jet that could cut the flight time between Tokyo and New York by more than half, to about six hours.

title: DeLay Shown Facing Growing Legal Bills
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 - House Majority Leader Tom DeLay raised more than $439,000 for his legal defense fund last year, and his legal bills climbed as he faced the prospect of ethical inquiries and other investigations, according to disclosure forms released Wednesday in the House.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Court Takes Up Appeal Of New Putin Law
description: The Constitutional Court agreed to hear a legal challenge to President Vladimir V. Putin's decision last year to abolish direct elections of governors and other regional leaders. The court accepted an appeal from a citizen in Tyumen, a sprawling region in western Siberia, who filed a suit after Mr. Putin reappointed the region's governor, Sergei Sobyanin, earlier this year. The court is not expected to rule until the fall. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: One Possible Cure for the Common Criminal
description: WHEN Jonathan M. Klick worked in Washington, he noticed a striking effect every time the terrorism alert level went from its usual yellow ("elevated") to the more urgent orange ("high").

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COMEN, LAURIE B.
description: COMEN--Laurie B., died June 14, 2005, age 46. Laurie was a free spirit. Dearest daughter of Iris Comen Kaplan (Herb Kaplan) and Jerry Comen. Beloved sister of Steven (Sondra) and Robert (Cheryl) Comen. Loving aunt of Melissa, Stephanie, Lindsay, Alex, and Danielle. Beloved niece of Rita Schiller and cousin to Bonnie and Gail. Funeral service Friday 11 AM, Zion Memorial Chapel, Mamaroneck, NY 914-381-1809. Donations in Laurie's name to the American Cancer Society.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Call To Arm Border Agents
description: A Senate report recommended arming Canadian customs officers posted along the 4,000-mile border with the United States. Senator Colin Kenny, the chairman of the Senate Committee on National Security and Defense, which made the report, said that customs officers should be armed with guns for their own security and that the current practice of calling local police forces to respond to threats along the border takes too long, especially at more remote crossings. While United States customs officers and border patrol agents already carry firearms, Canadian border officers are currently armed with just batons and pepper spray. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: G.E. Unit Orders Jets From Two Makers
description: GE Commercial Aviation Service, the aircraft leasing unit of General Electric, placed an order for 30 jets from Airbus of Europe and Embraer of Brazil to meet rising demand from airlines seeking to expand and renew their fleets. The order is for 10 planes from the Airbus A350 family, which can carry up to 300 passengers, and 20 regional jets from the new Embraer 190/195 aircraft family, which have 100 to 118 seats. GE Commercial has a fleet of more than 1,300 aircraft. At list price, the Airbus deal is valued at about $1.6 billion; the purchase from Embraer would be $650 million. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLIN, KAREN SUE
description: SOLIN--Karen Sue. Loving wife to Jerry. Devoted and adored mother to Allison and Jill. Dear sister to Dr. Myron J. Kaplan. A caring, committed and brave woman whose strength and character will be missed by all. Services Friday, 10:30 AM at Temple Israel of New Rochelle. In lieu of flowers, kindly direct contributions to Institute of Breast Diseases, c/o Dr. Reinhard Zachrau, Munger Pavilion, G13, NY Medical Colleage, Valhalla, NY 10595 or Wilderness Society, 1615 M Street, Washington DC 20036.

description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 15 - As the Mets approach the trading deadline, combing the market for the few first basemen available, they have identified one they need.

title: The BassamFellows Line, Now in the United States
description: Craig Bassam, an architect, and Scott Fellows, a former creative director for Salvatore Ferragamo and Bally, are based in New York, but until now their BassamFellows line of handcrafted products has not been shown or sold in the United States. The collection, introduced two years ago, includes midcentury modern-inspired furniture and men's leather bags and shoes; a show at the R 20th Century Gallery in TriBeCa through June 25 features tables, stools and trays in solid walnut and teak, and new pieces like a sofa with thin cushions with rawhide lacing ($9,570 to $12,320, depending on upholstery) and a wingback chair (shown above, supporting Mr. Fellows, $7,150 to $8,580) and ottoman (with Mr. Bassam, $2,420 to $2,750). R 20th Century, 82 Franklin Street; (212)343-7979. ARIC CHEN

title: Verne Meisner, Musician Who Championed the Polka, Dies at 66
description: Verne Meisner, a virtuoso accordionist and bandleader who helped keep the polka alive and swinging into the age of rock and beyond, died on Friday in Milwaukee. He was 66 and lived in Waukesha, Wis.

description: An off-duty police officer died last night after his motorcycle struck another vehicle at a Brooklyn intersection, the police said.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Ex-President Can Be Charged
description: The Supreme Court opened the way for a lower court to consider an indictment against former President Luis Echeverra on genocide charges in the killings of more than 30 student protesters in 1971. Three of the court's five justices voted to overturn a lower-court ruling, saying the 30-year statute of limitations for genocide charges had not expired because Mr. Echeverra enjoyed immunity from prosecution until he left office in 1976. The decision is a major victory for the special prosecutor's office created by President Vicente Fox, Mexico's first opposition president, to investigate the most egregious abuses by the long-governing Institutional Revolutionary Party. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: Pataki Signs Pension Bill for Workers at Ground Zero
description: ALBANY, June 15 - Handing another blow to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in the wake of his defeat on the West Side stadium, Gov. George E. Pataki signed a bill Wednesday that will increase the pensions the city must pay to employees who worked at the World Trade Center site after Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Farm grants face scrutiny

description: Universal Pictures and PublicAffairs have agreed to pay close to $1 million to buy the film and book rights to the life story of W. Mark Felt, people involved in the deal said yesterday.

description: The Times's Mark Landler reports that there's is an optimistic buzz in the air at the aviation industry's biggest gathering. Launch interactive feature.

title: Giambi's Approval Ratings Change in 10th
description: What should have been Jason Giambi's last swing last night looked as if it were taken with a 32-pound bat instead of his customary 32-ounce model. Giambi loaded up against the Pirates' Mike Gonzalez, tried to drill an 86-mile-an-hour slider and did not even come close. The old, menacing Giambi might have destroyed such a pitch.

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 15 - Under pressure from Washington, the Pakistani government on Wednesday lifted its travel restrictions on Mukhtar Mai, whose gang-rape and its aftermath set off worldwide outrage at the treatment of women in Pakistan.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: AstraZeneca Fined 60 Million Euros Over Ulcer Drug
description: The European Commission fined the British-Swedish pharmaceuticals company AstraZeneca 60 million euros ($72.7 million) for improprieties involving the patent on its ulcer drug, Losec, after a six-year investigation. The commission, the European Union's executive body, found that the company gave a wrong date to European patent authorities to gain an unfair extension of Losec's patent. AstraZeneca said it would appeal. Paul Meller (NYT)

description: CORCORAN--Tommy. Dear Tommy, thank you for 35 years of wonderful friendship. A prized visit with you, via whatever, was always hilarious and insightful. You will always be a part of me. With love and gratitude Jim Milford

title: Mr. Hyde: Dangerous Quackery
description: With so many good ideas for reforming the United Nations set for discussion later this year, this is not the time for Congress to be threatening to bludgeon the organization into submission by withholding the United States' legally required dues. Yet that is the thrust of a measure backed by the House of Representatives' Republican leadership and scheduled for a vote today. We hope the Bush administration's newly explicit opposition kills this meat-ax approach.

title: Raise the Price of Fame
description: FEW people are aware that several years ago Congress, in its wisdom, limited to $1 million the amount of a chief executive's pay that a corporation could annually deduct as a business expense when calculating its income tax. The provision of the legislation, imaginatively titled by ebullient accountants as "Section 162(m)" of the Internal Revenue Code, did permit exceptions -- for example, when the pay was "performance-based" and tied to objective goals.

title: State Issues Blistering Audit of NYRA
description: The New York Racing Association has been the "poster child for mismanagement and corruption" because it has cheated taxpayers and not followed state laws, according to the state comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, who released a financial audit yesterday of the troubled agency that runs Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga Race Course.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: No.2 Brewery Raided in Tax Inquiry
description: The federal police raided the offices and factories of Brazil's second-largest brewery, Schincariol, arresting the company's senior executives and dozens more on the suspicion that the beer maker was evading taxes. The raid, called Operation Barley, came after a 14-month investigation into the closely held Schincariol, which in recent years has spent heavily on advertising and a new brand. The police say that Schincariol and some of its distributors evaded millions of dollars in taxes by underreporting sales, buying raw materials illegally and falsifying tax returns. More than 70 people were arrested in 12 states, including Adriano Schincariol, the brewer's 28-year-old chief executive. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: In New Jersey, Child Welfare Is Still Failing
description: After more than a year of efforts to improve the way New Jersey handles child abuse cases, the Division of Youth and Family Services is still saddled with large caseloads, inadequate staff training and weak supervision, among other problems, according to the state's child advocate.

description: TAL AFAR, Iraq, June 15 - Nine months ago the American military laid siege to this city in northwestern Iraq and proclaimed it freed from the grip of insurgents. Last month, the Americans returned in force -- to reclaim it once again.

title: New York, the Hamptons and Los Angeles
description: A HAPPY afternoon of shopping can be spoiled by a trudge home with an armload of bags. But now there's a way to avoid the long walk. Beginning today, Caravan, a boutique on wheels, will bring its fashions to a street near you. The shop (above and at right) is actually a carpeted silver van with a dressing room that has begun to cruise streets in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Hamptons. It's loaded with youthful, Los Angeles-style women's clothes and accessories including Rock & Republic jeans, Twisted Heart tanks, handbags by Kafi D., cardigans by Ekeko (each comes with a Peruvian good luck charm) and handmade tops from Tarsian & Blinkley of Afghanistan. The shop's fashions will change with the seasons, and in the future there will be men's wear, too. You can log on to ShopCaravan.com to see when the van will be parking at a curb near you. Information: (917)902-9691.

description: BOSTON, June 16 - More than a year after gay marriage became legal in Massachusetts, Gov. Mitt Romney said today that he would support a newly proposed constitutional amendment that would overturn that right and make it illegal for same-sex couples to marry.

title: In Senate, Energy Debate Focuses on U.S. Resources
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 - Senate Democrats agreed with President Bush and Senate Republicans on Wednesday on the need to reduce the nation's dependence on imported oil. What they differed on was how to do it.

title: Autopsy on the Schiavo Tragedy
description: The autopsy results released yesterday should embarrass all the opportunistic politicians and agenda-driven agitators who meddled in Terri Schiavo's right-to-die case. There is no evidence that Ms. Schiavo's husband did any of the awful things attributed to him, and no hope that her greatly damaged brain would ever have recovered. The courts were right to conclude that she should be allowed to die after 15 years in what her doctors described as a persistent vegetative state with no hope of recovery.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Settlement In Discrimination Lawsuit
description: Federal regulators said they had reached a $1.05 million settlement with Rivera Vineyards, a grower and packer of table grapes in the Coachella Valley, to resolve a 2003 lawsuit that charged the business with sex discrimination and sexual harassment of female employees. Under the terms of the settlement, announced by the Los Angeles office of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the money would be shared by a group of current and former employees of the company, which also agreed to reinstate workers who said they were wrongfully terminated, to hire an outside consultant to handle harassment complaints and to enact anti-discrimination policies. The women, most of whom are Hispanic, contended that they had been physically harassed, denied higher-paying jobs at the vineyard and retaliated against when they complained. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

Paid Notice: Deaths   DIAMOND, DAVID
description: DIAMOND--David. The Juilliard School mourns the death of David Diamond. One of the most distinguished composers of the 20th century, he helped establish a distinctly American approach to works for orchestra. In addition to his remarkable compositions, David was an active and effective teacher of composition at Juilliard from 1973 to 1997. He recently received an inaugural Juilliard medal at the School's commencement on May 20. His friends, colleagues, and former students will deeply miss him, but his great musical legacy will live forever. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

description: WASHINGTON, June 15 - Kurdish security forces have seized scores of minority Arabs and Turkmens in the restive city of Kirkuk and secretly transferred them in violation of Iraqi law to prisons in Kurdish-controlled areas of northern Iraq, American officials said Wednesday.

description: WHITNEY--David. All of us who were privileged to know you are vastly diminished by the loss of a brilliant talent and a generous friend. Robert A.M. Stern

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Move On Extradition Of Bombing Suspect
description: Venezuela announced that it had delivered to the United States a formal extradition request for a Cuban exile wanted for involvement in an airplane bombing. It wants the United States immediately to hand over the Cuban, Luis Posada Carriles, a former C.I.A. operative who is in American custody, charged with illegally entering the United States this year. Venezuela accuses him of orchestrating the 1976 bombing of a Cuban airliner that killed 73 people, including several Venezuelans. The case has embarrassed the Bush administration, which the government of President Hugo Chvez has accused of being soft on terrorists opposed to Washington's enemies, in this case Cuba. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: A Week of Big Debuts
description: Last week brought the music industry's "super Tuesday," when a handful of highly anticipated new albums were released with the hopes that big sales might carry the business out of this year's slump. Yesterday Billboard released sales figures and chart positions for the week, and it was a big one, if not huge: Coldplay's "X&Y" (Capitol), left, dominated sales, as expected, with 737,000 copies, a figure that puts the album in line to become one of the top sellers of the year. Only 50 Cent's "Massacre" (Interscope) sold more this year in its first week. The Black Eyed Peas' "Monkey Business" (A&M/Interscope) is at No. 2 with 291,000 copies sold, and the White Stripes' "Get Behind Me Satan" (V2) reached No. 3 with 189,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Another new release made history at No. 4: Shakira's "Fijacin Oral Vol. 1" (Epic) is believed to have set a new record for the biggest debut week in the United States for a Spanish-language album, with 157,000 copies, beating Ricky Martin's record of 65,000 for his 2003 album "Almas de Silencio." Meanwhile, Mariah Carey's "Emancipation of Mimi" (Island/Def Jam") is at No. 5 with 151,000 sales, and "The Massacre" has finally left the Top 10 after 14 weeks, landing at No. 11 with about 65,000 sales. It has sold a total of 3.9 million copies. Despite the big numbers this week, sales were still 0.2 percent lower than in the same week last year, and sales for the year so far trail those of last year to this point by 8 percent, Billboard reported. BEN SISARIO

title: Exploring a Maligned Region So Many Think They Know
description: "The Appalachians" is an elegant film about a people and a region that are rarely examined beyond stereotypes. The writer and producer, Phyllis Geller, and the West Virginia-born executive producer, Mari-Lynn C. Evans, want the world to know that the people who live in the Appalachians from West Virginia to Alabama have a proud heritage and have gotten a supremely raw deal from the news media.

title: Corrections

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Donald Tsang Set To Be Leader
description: Donald Tsang effectively won the race to be the next chief executive when his only serious opponent withdrew after gaining only limited support from the pro-Beijing election panel that vets candidates for the top office here. Mr. Tsang, 60, has been the acting chief executive since the resignation of Tung Chee-hwa in March and had been the favorite to keep the job. He is to be declared the winner today, and there will be no vote on July 10, Reuters reported. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Court Rules Against E.P.A.
description: A Clinton-era initiative to require power-plant operators to upgrade pollution equipment as part of any expansion, known as new source review, was undercut when an appeals court rejected the Environmental Protection Agency's claim that the Duke Energy Corporation violated clean air laws by modifying its coal-fired plants without adding proper pollution controls. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, Va., ruled that the E.P.A. had misapplied rules that limit the changes that can be made to a power plant before it becomes subject to tighter regulations under the Clean Air Act. A spokesman for the Southern Environmental Law Center in Chapel Hill, N.C., which supported the E.P.A.'s suit, said it was considering whether to appeal.

title: U.S. pressure lifts ban on travel for rape victim
Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Salem: Leak Prompts Reactor Shutdown
description: The Hope Creek nuclear reactor was shut down on Tuesday afternoon to allow workers to repair a steam leak. It was the second shutdown in a week because of a leak. A spokesman for the reactor's owner, P.S.E.G. Nuclear LLC, said that operators noticed the new leak as they were putting the reactor back on line after earlier repairs. The reactor, one of three at the Salem nuclear station, has shut down five times in the past nine months because of equipment problems.

The raid, which also freed an Iraqi hostage, was a rare case of military action successfully ending one of the scores of hostage-takings that have been a major insurgent tactic in Iraq.

Codey signed an executive order yesterday for 35,000 employees of state authorities, agencies and commissions to take annual ethics classes starting as early as the fall. Earlier, he recommended that 70,000 people who work for the state's executive branch undertake similar training, and called for an independent agency to enforce ethics laws. David W. Chen (NYT)

Mr. Vilar's lawyer, Susan Necheles, said that "logistical difficulties" had kept supporters from signing the documents. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science and Health: Space Shuttle Gets New Fuel Tank
description: The space shuttle Discovery returned to the launching pad at Cape Canaveral, Fla., after technicians replaced its fuel tank with an enhanced model. NASA opted for the tank swap after tests in April and May revealed problems with a pressure-relief valve and with sensors designed to determine the amount of hydrogen inside the tank. At about the same time, a team studying ice formations on the tank expressed concern about frozen debris that might break loose and hit the shuttle's thermal tiles during launching. The enhanced tank carries heaters that should prevent moisture from turning into ice that might damage Discovery as it travels through the atmosphere. Liftoff for a mission to the International Space Station is scheduled for July 13. Stefano Coledan (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Israel Arrests Palestinians In Bomb Plot
description: Israeli security sources said that a number of Palestinian adults and eight teenagers from refugee camps in the Nablus area in the West Bank were arrested in the final stages of planning a suicide attack in Israel. The security sources said they belonged to a cell affiliated with Fatah militants. Some acted as recruiters while others, including youths ages 15 and 16, were prepared to carry out the attack, the sources said. They did not give the number arrested or say when the arrests took place. Christine Hauser (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Central Islip: Indians File Long Island Claim
description: The Shinnecock tribe on Long Island filed a federal lawsuit yesterday claiming ownership of 3,600 acres of prime Hamptons real estate worth billions of dollars. The lawsuit also charged that the builders of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Course, which opened in 1891, had desecrated burial grounds by "digging up and randomly discarding the remains of Shinnecock persons." Gregg Deger, general manager of the golf course, declined to comment. Shinnecock leaders seek at least $1.7 billion in damages, plus billions more in lost rent and interest. Gov. George E. Pataki's offices issued a statement saying that the state would take "whatever steps may be necessary" to protect the interests of Long Island taxpayers and property owners. Anthony Ramirez (NYT)

title: From a Blogger, Rants and Dish About the Architecture World
description: Now that Deep Throat has revealed himself, will the Guttersnipe come forth? The author of a Web log using that pseudonym has been ranting about the architecture world since May 9 at gutter.curbed.com. Favorite targets include architects of the project at the site of the World Trade Center, preservationists trying to save 2 Columbus Circle and The New York Times. Among the profanity-slinging writer's printable recent insults are "derivative yet anodyne," "a crashing bore" and "a complete boondoggle." The blogger seems to have some highly placed moles, alleging financial scandals and hinting at marital infidelities involving celebrities. But who knows so much, yet is willing to risk burning so many bridges? The site's publisher, Lockhart Steele, said it receives up to 4,000 hits a day. He would identify the Guttersnipe only as "an angry young man, raised in darkness." EVE M. KAHN

description: Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the majority leader, who is under pressure from Democrats and some fellow Republicans to schedule a vote on legislation that would expand federal financing for embryonic stem cell research, said he opposed the measure. He said he had not yet decided whether to bring it directly to the Senate for a vote or refer it to a committee. President Bush has threatened to veto the bill, which has passed the House and has broad support in the Senate. Dr. Frist said he would like to see a review of the scientific progress on embryonic stem cell research since Mr. Bush announced his policy four years ago, but he said he believed the policy should not be expanded. title: 36 Hours in Toronto
description: After 40 years of immigration from virtually every country, Toronto has realized its promise as a vibrant picture postcard of world culture. Cafes, clubs, restaurants, theaters, museums and galleries are everywhere, and instead of making a summer exodus to cottage country, Torontonians these days are just as likely to take in their city during the warm, mild weather that prevails this time of year. Which is not to say that the buttoned-up poise coded deep in the town's DNA is completely gone - many places retain the 1950's veneer of Toronto the Good while adding the sound and tempo of T.O. today. You might want to visit before the latter completely consumes the former.

The record-high price for a residence in Litchfield, set in 2001, is $6.3 million, which was paid for a newly built 7,000-square-foot house on 75 acres in Washington, one of the county's 26 towns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'CONNOR, JOHN R.
description: O'CONNOR--John R., born on November 15, 1920 in Loretto, PA died on Thursday June 16, 2005 after a short illness in Franklin Hospital in Valley Steam, NY. He was a graduate of St. Francis University of Loretto, PA at the age of 19 and was honored as "Distinguished Alumnus in Education" in 1990. He began his teaching career in a oneroom schoolhouse in rural Pennsylvania and a retired Junior High School Principal in NYC, and was a co-author of numerous text books including: Exploring American History, Exploring A Changing World, Exploring American Citizenship and many others. Several of his text books were also printed in braille. He was also retired from the Air Force reserves as a Lt. Colonel. He was active in many civil and religious organizations: Trustee of Holy Name of Mary Church for 19 years, member of St. Vincent de Paul Society, Holy Name Society, Knights of Columbus Fr. Thomas Carroll Council, Past President to the Catholic Interracial Council of Long Island and a member of the board of directors for 17 years, a dynamic speaker who was well known for his great sense of humor. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Catherine T. Murray, and the following children: Mary O'Connor Rogers, Kate O'Connor Frohn, Jack, Elizabeth O'Connor Kenny, Loretta O'Connor Strack, Patricia O'Connor Kielawa, Tom, Rich, James, Joseph and Theresa. In addition he leaves 16 granchildren and six great-grandchildren. His brother Col. William S. O'Connor, US Army Ret. also survies him in St. Louis, MO. Reposing at the Edward F. Lieber Funeral Homes Inc, 9 East Valley Stream Blvd. Visitation Saturday and Sunday 2-4 & 7-9. Funeral Mass Monday 9:30AM at Holy Name of Mary RC Church. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the St. Vincent de Paul Society in John's memory.

title: The Listings: June 17 -- June 23; VIJAY IYER
description: He appeared about 10 years ago in the San Francisco Bay Area, a very young jazz pianist bursting with micro- and macro- and meta-theories. He wanted to unite jazz and funk, Indian drone elements and swing; he also seemed to want to synthesize four pianists, related but still diverse: Duke Ellington, Andrew Hill, Thelonious Monk and Cecil Taylor. (There were urgent political themes, too, addressed in liner notes.) His music was usually based in odd meters and played hard and dry; it could be daunting. He wasn't working in a vacuum, though, and kept sanding down his sound. Some of his most important early colleagues, like the alto saxophonist Rudresh Mahanthappa and the guitarist Liberty Ellman, ended up in New York around the same time that he did, in 1998; then the circle expanded again, bringing in the drummer Derrek Phillips and the bassist Stephan Crump. Now Mr. Iyer, above, leads a quartet that includes Mr. Mahanthappa, Mr. Crump and the drummer Marcus Gilmore, who is only 19 but has the potential to become one of the bulldozing presences in New York jazz. The band's most recent album, "Reimagining" (Savoy Jazz), is its best, and Mr. Iyer's gigs are attaining a newly urgent momentum, with some genuine lyricism offsetting the rhythm attack. He's a jazz musician of the moment, and now's the time to hear him. (Tuesday through Thursday at the Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212)576-2232; sets are at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., and the cover charge is $20.) BEN RATLIFF

description: ZAREMBA -- Sylvia. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with great sorrow the passing of the American pianist Sylvia Zaremba on June 3 in Columbus, Ohio at the age of 74. A native of Chicopee, Massachusetts, Sylvia Zaremba was a valued member of our Steinway Artist family for 61 years. A child prodigy, Ms. Zaremba gave her first public performance at age five. She debuted with the Cleveland Orchestra under Artur Rodzinski at age ten, and gave her New York recital debut at Town Hall in the same year. In addition to tours of the European music capitals, Ms. Zaremba appeared with most of the major symphony orchestras in this country, working with renowned conductors such as Leonard Bernstein, Eugene Ormandy, and Leopold Stokowski. Ms. Zaremba was trained at the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, and she was an acclaimed teacher herself, serving for a number of years as the chairman of the keyboard department at the Ohio State University School of Music. She will be deeply missed. To her family we extend our heartfelt condolences. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. title: The Listings: June 17 -- June 23; MARY ANN CURRIER
description: A glance at the illustrated brochure announcing Mary Ann Currier's exhibition could lead you to mistake her for an obscure 19th-century still-life painter. In fact, Ms. Currier, 78, lives in Louisville, Ky., and is known for still-life paintings and oil pastels that give traditional Chardin-like realism a distinctly contemporary resonance. This fall, the Speed Art Museum in Louisville will present a 30-year survey of her career (Oct. 4-Dec. 18). The recent paintings in her current show depict one, two or three dying roses larger than life on 24-inch-wide sheets of paper (above). It is an almost impossibly clichd subject, but Ms. Currier revives it, painting with a satiny, soft-edged touch and an intense, nonphotographic attention to texture, light and detail that gives the deep red or peach-colored blossoms a strange, almost fleshy palpability. Lying on otherwise empty surfaces and still connected to dried and faded stems and leaves, the roses are extravagantly florid and even erotically sensuous. While Romantic and Freudian overtones reverberate, the paintings also evoke the antique tradition of the vanitas -- the still-life that allegorizes the futility of material attachments in a world where no one escapes death. (Gerald Peters Gallery, 24 East 78th Street, (212)628-9760, through July 1.) KEN JOHNSON

Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDSAY, JAMES K., ESQ.
description: LINDSAY--James K., Esq. 85, retired NYC attorney and life long advocate for the disadvantaged died in Amherst, MA on May 30, 2005. He was the son of Sadie Gombrich (the French actress Claudine LeDuc) and Robert Kenneth Lindsay, a salesman, and was born in Winnipeg, Alberta. In spite of an itinerant childhood, and the early loss of his father, Mr. Lindsay distinguished himself academically at a very young age and graduated first in his class from Ridley College in St. Catherines, Ontario at the age of 14. He graduated from Oberlin College at the age of 18, and from the University of Michigan Law School at the age of 21 where he served on the Law Review. Mr. Lindsay married Priscilla Shepherd, a fellow alumna of Oberlin College, in 1942, and raised a family with her. Early in his corporate law career he worked for Republic Aircraft, Hayden Chemical Corp., and the Manhattan law firm of Fulton, Duncan, and Halley. He became vice president of Tenneco, Inc. He then established his own law practice. Mr. Lindsay fought actively for social justice in many arenas. He served on the board of directors of the New York City Mission Society for 12 years and was its president for six years. He was an advocate for low-income housing and served on the Fair Housing Commission of Briarcliff, NY. He was an active Episcopalian who taught Sunday school and served on the vestry of All Saint's Church, Briarcliff, NY. He was an avid crossword puzzle fan, who was famous in his family for completing the daily NY Times puzzle on his commuter train as it traveled nonstop between 125th St and Grand Central Station. After the death of Priscilla in 1972 he married Shirley Blois Brown, a musician and teacher who was embraced by his family. Mr. Lindsay retired to Savannah, Georgia where he initiated a volunteer program at Georgia Legal Services and was a moving force coordinating legal services, domestic violence advocates, and the police in the establishment of a Safe Shelter for battered and abused women and their children. Mr. Lindsay was honored by a 'Jim Lindsay Day' there for his efforts in 2002 when the shelter opened its new facility. After suffering several strokes he moved to Jacksonville, FL where he lived until his wife died in 2004. He is survived by his brother Dennis J. Lindsay, Esq, of Portland, OR; three children from his first marriage: Rev. Susan Tobias of Lower Cabot, VT; R. Kenneth Lindsay of Amherst, MA; Dr. Pippi Ellison of Newton, MA; six grandchildren, one greatgrandchild, and eight nephews and nieces. Contributions in his name may be made to the endowment fund for Safe Shelter at The Savannah Community Foundation, 7393 Hodgson Memorial, suite 204, Savannah, GA. 31406. A memorial gathering in his honor will be held in Amherst, MA. on Monday June 27th at the Lord Jeffery Inn from 12:30-2:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOSKOWITZ, SUNNY
description: MOSKOWITZ--Sunny. The Abraham Joshua Heschel School community mourns the passing of Sunny Moskowitz, beloved wife of the late Herbert Moskowitz, adored mother of Roanna Shorofsky, our esteemed Head of School, and of Miriam Ben-Natan. Sunny was the mother-in-law of Morris and Rafi, beloved grandmother of Karren, Sharon and Keren, cherished greatgrandmother of Rebecca, Julia, Jonathan, Noa and Maya. Sunny's good deeds, dignity and grace is clearly mirrored in her daughter Roanna, whose leadership and dedication over the last fifteen years has lead to our school's growth and flourishing. Under her superb guidance the School has grown to over 700 students, has established a high school division, developed a reputation for academic excellence and instilled a love for Judaism and Israel in its graduates. Of this her mother was justifiably proud. Our community is elevated by Roanna and Morris' outstanding example of honoring one's parent. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Board of Trustees Alisa R. Doctoroff, President

Another reality offering, WB's "Beauty and the Geek," also continued to climb in its ratings: this week's episode brought in an audience of 4.26 million and won the 18-to-34 demographic in the 8 p.m. hour. description: KARLINER -- William, M.D. Age 94, on June 15, 2005. description: WASHINGTON - WHEN it comes to art, few things have the unpredictable resonance of the late work of an accomplished, innovative artist whose place in history is secure. Special may be good, bad or indifferent, but these efforts invariably take us deeper into an artist's psyche and sharpen, sometimes poignantly, our understanding of his gift. We get privileged glimpses of regrets, hard-earned wisdom and eruptions of primal feelings. One way or another, late works are by definition fascinating.

title: The Listings: June 17 -- June 23; TOM WOPAT
description: We have seen Tom Wopat swagger, mosey, stride and strut, but in the revival of "Glengarry Glen Ross," he tries something new. As the mealy-mouthed mark James Lingk, who is torn between the sweet-talking sales pitch of Richard Roma and the orders of his wife, Mr. Wopat shuffles across the stage, self-consciously staring at his feet. You would never know that this unassuming middle-aged actor once played the easygoing heartthrob Luke Duke in the hit television series "The Dukes of Hazzard." Mr. Wopat is one of the great surprises of this acclaimed production, proving with only a few lines, none of which, by the way, include curse words, that he will not be typecast. After "Hazzard" finished its run in the mid-80's, he continued playing robust and ruggedly macho characters in the sitcom "Cybil" and in musicals like "Annie Get Your Gun" and "42nd Street." Mr. Wopat (above left,with Liev Schreiber) uses his history playing confident leading men to his advantage in "Glengarry," fleshing out how his character's weakness makes him such an easy person to manipulate. What comes through so vividly is that what Lingk really wants is to walk with a swagger just like Tom Wopat always did. (Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, 242 West 45th Street, (212)239-6200) JASON ZINOMAN

title: National Briefing | West: California: Two Indicted In Terrorism Case
description: A grand jury in Sacramento indicted a man and his son in a federal terrorism investigation. The suspects, Umer Hayat, 47, and Hamid Hayat, 22, both of Lodi, were charged with making false statements to the F.B.I. by denying that Hamid had attended a terrorist training camp in Pakistan. The two men were arrested on June 7 and are being held without bail. In an affidavit, the F.B.I. said the younger Mr. Hayat had trained in Pakistan to kill Americans and that his father had helped to pay for the training. Lawyers for the men denied the accusations. As the grand jury met, several Muslim leaders and civil rights advocates raised concerns about the way the F.B.I., which is engaged in a broader terrorism investigation in Lodi, had questioned Muslims there. The critics said at least eight residents had complained that they felt intimidated by investigators or had been denied access to a lawyer. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility Sells a Unit
description: The German utility giant E.On said it sold its Ruhrgas Industries unit to a European private equity firm, CVC Capital Partners, for 600 million euros ($726 million). CVC will also assume about 900 million euros ($1.09 billion) in debt and pension liabilities. Ruhrgas Industries, a leading producer of gas, electricity, water meters and industrial furnaces, with headquarters in Essen, Germany, had sales of 1.4 billion euros and about 9,700 employees worldwide last year. The deal, to be completed by the end of August and requiring the approval of antitrust authorities and the parties' supervisory boards, is part of E.On's program to focus on its power and gas business. "By selling Ruhrgas Industries we have almost completed E.On's transformation into a pure-play energy company," the chief executive, Wulf Bernotat, said. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Iran's Sham Democracy
description: Today's presidential election in Iran is an affront to true democracy, just as the past record of the front-running contender, Ali Akhbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, is an affront to true moderation. As President Bush rightly noted, the voting was effectively rigged in advance by the council of unelected clerics that decided who would and who wouldn't be allowed to run. And this is for a presidency, remember, that has no power to do anything the unelected clerical establishment does not want done, as amply demonstrated by the frustrating eight-year tenure of the departing incumbent, Mohammad Khatami.

description: Microsoft gained the support of an international group representing about 1,600 small and medium-size companies in its appeal against a European Union antitrust order. The International Association of Microsoft Certified Partners, representing companies that develop software based on the Windows operating system, asked the European Court of First Instance in Luxembourg for permission to support Microsoft's appeal, said Per Werngren, the group's president. Microsoft, whose software runs more than 90 percent of the world's personal computers, was ordered by European regulators in March 2004 to sell a version of Windows without a music and video player and to license information on the inner workings of the operating system to competitors.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Russia: Tigers Hold Their Ground
description: A survey by almost 1,000 fieldworkers has determined that tigers appear to be holding their own in Siberia. The Wildlife Conservation Society said the workers, who traveled by foot, ski, snowmobile and car to track the tigers' footprints in the snow, estimated that the region now had 334 to 417 adults and 97 to 112 cubs. The numbers are up somewhat from the last winter survey, in 1996, but coordinators attributed the increase to efforts to cover more of the animals' range. Yuri Darman, director of the Russian Far East office of another sponsor, WWF, formerly known as the World Wildlife Fund, said there was heavy tiger poaching in the 1990's, but "we have been able to turn back the tide." And now, a decade after her breakthrough, she has released "Jagged Little Pill Acoustic" (Maverick), a new CD with more of the same: quieter versions of the songs that made her a star.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Shellfishing Disaster
description: Carlos Gutierrez, the federal commerce secretary, has declared a disaster in the Massachusetts shellfishing industry because of a vast area of red tide, an outbreak of toxic algae that has caused officials to close most of the state's shellfish beds. The declaration allows the state's Congressional delegation to seek federal emergency appropriations for the state's shellfishermen. It also lets the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration dispense various grants to help study the root cause of the algae, which has closed shellfish beds from Maine to Cape Cod. The Small Business Administration declared the outbreak a disaster earlier this week, allowing affected businesses to apply for low-interest loans. State officials have also applied for payments from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which has yet to declare the algae an emergency. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: On the Dolores River, Whitewater, Running Deep and Fast
description: AT 3 a.m., I slip out of my tent and make a quiet pilgrimage to the river where the inflatable rafts are tethered. The gear boat's padded bench is the perfect pew from which to worship the moonless, ink-black sky, pierced by innumerable pricks of light. On this first night of our trip down 47 miles of the Lower Dolores River in southwestern Colorado, it's sort of hypnotic to think that the Anasazi, whose 1,000-year-old granaries and pictographs still adorn this isolated red-rock canyon, must have enjoyed the same aperture on the stars.

Job growth around the state, slow and steady over the past 18 months, continued to be led by the education and health services industries. Over the past year, New York State added 74,700 jobs, a 1.1 percent gain. New York City added 34,700 jobs in the same period. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: For an Ever-Changing Program, an Intense Final Result

First Lorin Maazel replaced Debussy's "Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun" on this week's subscription program with Sibelius's "Swan of Tuonela." (Goodbye, flute; hello, English horn.) Then Mr. Maazel withdrew from the concerts with what was said to be a mild illness. The hotly touted David Robertson stepped in at the last minute, bearing more substitutions: Dukas's "Sorcerer's Apprentice" for Dvorak's concert overture "Carnival" and Stravinsky's "Firebird" Suite for Roussel's "Bacchus et Ariane" Suite No. 2.

The explosion, beneath the southeast corner of Houston and Mercer Streets, shook the 12-story building and terrified workers inside. Deputy Chief John Bley of the Fire Department said the unidentified man suffered second-degree burns to his head and neck, and was taken to the burn center at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell. A Con Ed spokesman, Mike Clendenin, said the cause of the fire was under investigation. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: The Listings: June 17 -- June 23; NEW YORK INTERNATIONAL BALLET COMPETITION
description: Move over, "American Idol." The New York International Ballet Competition, now in its eighth year, offers the thrill of watching young dancers from 19 nations -- from Azerbaijan to Ukraine -- compete for gold, silver and bronze medals in this ultimate dance reality show. (Other awards include contracts with the Joffrey Ballet Chicago and American Ballet Theater.) Violette Verdy, above, the great French ballerina and a superb teacher and coach, will be honored in the culminating gala performance next Sunday at 7 p.m. at Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, when medalists and other competition participants will dance on a program whose roster also includes former competition winners. The elimination rounds, all at 8 p.m. at Alice Tully Hall, are just as interesting, as dancers compete in duets from Sir Frederick Ashton's "Fille Mal Garde" (Wednesday and Thursday), Jos Limn's "Choreographic Offering" and individual solos (next Friday) and Petipa's "Satanella" (next Saturday). The competing dancers, from 17 to 24 years old, do not know what choreography they will perform until they arrive in New York, where they learn the dances together in rehearsals at the new Ailey center just south of Lincoln Center. The nine-member international jury includes Dame Merle Park, former principal with the Royal Ballet, and Alexei Ratmansky, artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet. (Information: www.nyibc.org. Reservations: (212)721-6500 or www.lincolncenter.org. Tickets: $27.50; $17.50 for students and 65+ (preliminary rounds); $70 (gala). Subscriptions range from $150 for three rounds and gala to $450 for all performances and gala dinner dance.) JENNIFER DUNNING

Arts, Briefly; French Theater In New York
description: The French Association for Artistic Action, the government's cultural arm abroad, has announced a five-month French theater season in New York called "Act French," starting on July 15. With some 30 shows to be presented on 20 stages, including the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Public Theater, the program will feature works directed by Adriane Mnouchkine, Claude Rgy and Olivier Py and plays by Jean-Claude Grumberg, Koffi Kwahul, Marie N'Diaye and Bernard-Marie Kolts. One highlight will be Isabelle Huppert's performance of Sarah Kane's "4:48 Psychosis," to be presented in French with English surtitles. Several works, though, will be presented in English. (The full program will shortly be available on www.actfrench.org) "Act French" follows two earlier festivals: "France Moves," devoted to French contemporary dance in 2001, and "Sounds French," built around French contemporary music in 2003.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: U.S. Assessing Palestinian Military Aid
description: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said the special American envoy in the Middle East was "very close" to making an assessment of Palestinian military needs that would lead to discussions with Israel soon about arming and equipping Palestinian Authority security forces. Ms. Rice said the envoy, Lt. Gen. William E. Ward, was evaluating the Palestinian military's need for armament and other security equipment in Gaza after Israel's planned withdrawal there. Israel has feared that such equipment would be used against Israelis rather than militants. Ms. Rice, speaking to reporters on the way to Israel and Palestinian areas, said that once the general completed his evaluation, "We will work at all levels with the Israeli government to make sure that the Palestinians have what they need in order to carry out the functions they will have." title: An Artist Working in Despair's Grip
description: Extraordinary in execution and impact, the biographical film "Edvard Munch" relates the true-to-life story of the Norwegian painter whose work held up a mirror to a feverishly anguished life. Written and directed by the British filmmaker Peter Watkins, whose other films include "The War Game" and "La Commune (de Paris, 1871)," this 1973 feature (playing in Manhattan at the Cinema Village) fluidly embraces the personal and the political, moving from Munch's death-darkened childhood to his equally tortured adulthood. In the process, Mr. Watkins creates not just a vivid portrait of an artist, but also a movie that effectively parallels Munch's aesthetic breakthrough with Expressionism.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Man Convicted In Nine Killings
description: After a three-month trial, a Fresno man was found guilty on nine counts of first-degree murder in the deaths of nine of his children and grandchildren, a verdict that could lead to the death penalty. The jury, which took more than two weeks to deliberate, also found the man, Marcus Wesson, guilty on 14 counts of raping and molesting seven of his daughters and nieces. Mr. Wesson, 58, who was described as a controlling patriarch, was arrested at his home in March 2004 when he surrendered to the police after an 80-minute standoff. The police found bodies in a pile inside the home.. The lawyer for Mr. Wesson, Ralph Torres, had argued that the deaths were caused by one of Mr. Wesson's daughters, Sebhrenah, 25, who then killed herself. Mr. Wesson's wife, Elizabeth, below center, who testified at the trial that he did not kill the children, broke down after the verdict. Carolyn Marshall (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia: 20-Year Term In Massacre
description: A Serbian court sentenced a former paramilitary police officer to 20 years in prison on Friday for his part in the killing of 14 Albanians -- seven of them children -- during the 1999 conflict in Kosovo. The officer, Sasa Svejtan, was given the maximum sentence for the shootings, which happened at the beginning with Serbia's conflict with NATO in the province. Dejan Demirovic, another member of the unit, known as the Scorpions, was also accused along with Mr. Svejtan. He is in prison in Canada and is fighting extradition to Serbia. The trial was seen as test of Serbia's ability to try war crimes when it began last year, and the court found Mr. Svejtan guilty. But that verdict was overturned this year by Serbia's Supreme Court over procedural irregularities. The court reconfirmed the original verdict on Friday before sentencing Mr. Svejtan. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Business Briefing | Toys 'R' Us Shareholders Seek Delay in Sale Vote
description: A lawyer for Toys "R" Us Inc. shareholders asked a judge in Delaware Chancery Court yesterday to delay a shareholder vote on the proposed sale of the company to provide additional time for more bidders to emerge. The lawyer argued that the process used by directors to set up a $6.6 billion sale to an investment group was flawed. Judge Leo Strine Jr. of Delaware Chancery Court said he would rule on the request by Wednesday. Shareholders are scheduled to vote on Thursday on the sale to a consortium that includes Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, Bain Capital and Vornado Realty Trust. Martin Tully, a lawyer representing the buyers, urged Judge Strine not to reopen the matter, saying the bid might be withdrawn. The challenge to the bid, which is for $26.75 a share, was filed by the Iron Workers of Western Pennsylvania Pension and Profit Plans and Jolly Roger Fund.

title: Business Briefing | Brazilian Airline Files for Bankruptcy Court Protection
description: Viao Area Rio-Grandense, the Brazilian airline known as Varig, filed for bankruptcy court protection, stopping a creditor from seizing 11 of its planes. The International Lease Finance Corporation, the aircraft leasing unit of the American International Group, had given Varig until yesterday to make payment on the planes. Under Brazil's new bankruptcy law, which took effect this month, Varig will now have 60 days to present a plan to its creditors. Varig, Latin America's largest airline, has about $2.5 billion in debt, with more than 60 percent of it owed to the government. Varig's shareholders have already approved a tentative rescue plan that could involve selling up to a 20 percent stake to TAP Air Portugal. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Business Briefing | Panel Endorses Continuation of Merck Painkiller Test
description: Merck & Company said yesterday that a panel of independent monitors had determined that the company's painkiller Arcoxia, which is in the same class of medicines as the withdrawn Vioxx, is safe enough for continued use in clinical trials. The research is being conducted because the Food and Drug Administration sent the company a so-called approvable letter in October saying that it needed more data about Arcoxia's safety and effectiveness before clearing the drug for sale, Merck said. Arcoxia is part of the group of painkillers that came under fire from government officials and consumer groups after Merck, which is based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., withdrew Vioxx because of its link to heart attacks and strokes. One Merck study includes 23,500 patients with osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis and compares the cardiovascular safety of Arcoxia with the drug diclofenac. A second smaller study compares stomach side effects in Arcoxia against diclofenac in about 4,000 rheumatoid arthritis patients. Both studies are scheduled to end next year.

description: Singapore's High Court gave two executives from the failed fuel trader China Aviation Oil (Singapore) more time to respond to charges against them in connection with the company's failure last November, with $550 million in derivatives trading losses. After lawyers for the suspended chief executive, Chen Jiulin, and the former finance chief, Peter Lim, asked the court for more time to review prosecution documents, the court gave them until July 7 to enter pleas. Mr. Chen has been charged with 15 separate offenses, including forgery and insider trading. Mr. Lim faces five charges, including making misleading statements. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBERTS, GAIL K.
description: ROBERTS--Gail K. Ommerle, who retired from the New York State Court Administration in 2001 after close to 20 years with the state, died at her home in New Mexico on Sunday, May 15, 2005. She was 61. Mrs. Roberts was born in NYC. She was the daughter of Harry G. Ommerle, a former CBS television network vice president and talent agent with the William Morris Agency, and Katherine Murphy Ommerle, a former actress who was one of the founders of the Darien Dinner Theater. After graduating from the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, Mrs. Roberts became a model and actress. She appeared in several television series and off-Broadway plays. She made her movie debut as a bride in the movie "Goodbye Columbus", starring Ali McGraw. In her late twenties she decided to join the Civil Rights Movement and traveled down south to march with Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Afterwards, she worked for Bobby Kennedy and became involved with New York City politics. Later, she worked for Mayor John V. Lindsay and became involved with juvenile delinquent programs in the city. She is survived by her daughter Katherine Elizabeth Roberts, her brothers Stephen Ommerle, Peter Ommerle and her sister Elizabeth Ommerle. A memorial service will be held for Mrs. Roberts this Saturday, June 18, 2005 at 3:00 pm at the St. Regis Hotel in NYC.

title: Business Briefing | Circuit City Posts Loss That Exceeds Expectations
description: Circuit City Stores Inc., the nation's second-largest electronics chain after Best Buy, said its fiscal first-quarter loss more than doubled on costs to revamp stores and a drop in sales of computers and DVD players. The net loss was deeper than analysts expected, widening to $13.1 million, or 7 cents a share, from $5.94 million, or 3 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales in the period, which ended May 31, rose 6.4 percent, to $2.23 billion, the company said. Circuit City, which is based in Richmond, Va., said sales at older stores were unchanged. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call were expecting a loss of 2 cents a share. The company's stock fell 4 percent, to $16.93, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRUCKNER, JACK L.
description: BRUCKNER--Jack L. On Saturday evening June 11, 2005, Jack died peacefully at his home in Upper Brookville, Long Island, New York. He was 86 years old, and fought valiantly with Alzheimer's disease, macular degeneration, and cancer. Beloved and devoted husband of Marion Duke Johnson, his wife of 64 years. Loving and supportive father of Marion Duke "Dukie" Baxter, Laurie Bastis, and the late Betsey Reicherter. Father-in-law to Jason Bastis and the late Bob Reicherter. Loving and inspiring grandfather "Gramps" of Keven and Todd Baxter; Andrew, Michael and John Reicherter; and Matthew Bastis. Jack graduated from Duke University with a BA degree in 1942. A lieutenant in the US Navy, he received three citations for his significant role in the Sicily, Salerno, Anzio, and D-Day invasions of WWII. Lieutenant Bruckner was also cited for being the first US Naval officer to set foot on European soil. Jack was a retired Vice President of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, and served on their Board of Directors from 1974-1977. Upon retirement, he served on the Board of Directors of Countrywide Financial Corporation. Other boards on which he served included North Carolina Outward Bound from 1981-1986, Bucknell University, and Friends Academy. Additionally, in 1978, the Board of Trustees of Duke University designated Jack as President's Associate to Terry Sanford. This title conferred the right and responsibility of representing the President of Duke University to all constituencies. He also served for 12 years on the vestry at Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset. His strength, courage, and determination were unyielding and his great love of family, friends, and life touched and taught us all. A Memorial Service to celebrate Jack's life will be held at Christ Episcopal Church, 1355 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, NY on Wednesday, June 29 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial gifts be made in honor of Jack L. Bruckner to Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd, Woodbury, NY 11797; or Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation, 5 Channel Drive, Port Washington, NY 11050; or American Cancer Society, 6800 Jericho Turnpike Suite 200, West Syosset, NY 11791.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Governor Fined $1,900
description: The State Ethics Commission fined Gov. Sonny Perdue $1,900 for violating campaign finance laws. Under the terms of the commission's order, which were negotiated with Mr. Perdue, a Republican, his campaign has repaid $12,155 from his campaign treasury to a company owned by his wife, Mary, for flights on its airplane during the 2002 campaign for governor, and $6,000 to other donors of excessive campaign contributions. The accusations of violations, and others that were dismissed, were brought by the Democratic Party of Georgia against Mr. Perdue, left, and his campaign. It is the first time the commission has fined a sitting governor. Mr. Perdue's spokesman, Dan McLagan, said that Mrs. Perdue could have donated unlimited resources had she not done so through her company, and that the other violations were "technical reporting errors." Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: LaFayette, We Are Leery
description: The level of trust between the French and Americans is at its lowest in 17 years, according to a poll published by Le Monde. The survey of 1,000 people in each country, carried out by the polling firm TNS Sofres, found that only 31 percent of the French had "sympathy" for Americans, down from 39 percent in September 2002. About 35 percent of American respondents said they liked the French, down from 50 percent in September 2002. The survey also showed that both French and American respondents' views had changed on whether the two countries were partners or adversaries: only 39 percent of the French respondents believe that the United States and France are first and foremost partners, down from 50 percent in September 2002, while 45 percent of Americans see the two countries as partners, a sharp drop from 68 percent in September 2002. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Forest Tent Caterpillars
description: I got used to the permeability of our house long ago. In and out we come all day long, and so do the dogs -- to the pastures and the corral, to visit the ducklings and goslings in the horse trailer, to admire the new gilts in the hog pen, to feed the chickens and gather eggs. We learned early on to leave our boots in the mudroom and to check ourselves for ticks at night. We like the bats that nest in the eaves, and we don't so much mind the chipmunks that sometimes disappear through the cracks in the foundation. We no longer really hear the sound of mice and flying squirrels in the walls at night. We all seem, somehow, to live in each other's margins.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: ONE SOLDIER'S STORY: A Memoir. By Bob Dole. (HarperCollins, $25.95.) Memoirs are generally exercises in revelation. Dole's is a study in reticence. By his studiously self-deprecating account, he was a decent athlete, a below-average student, and -- after joining the Army's fabled 10th Mountain Division in World War II -- a mediocre lieutenant. It is only after he is horrifically wounded on the Italian front that we begin to get a hint of the strength that helped Dole ascend almost to the pinnacle of American politics, or a flash of his bone-dry wit. ("The mere thought of being back on American soil sent electricity through me," he writes of his time in a hospital bed encased in plaster. "At least, I think it did.") It took more than a year of agonizing physical therapy before Dole could even stand again, and months of operations to allow him to so much as hold a pen in his battered right hand. But the moments of intimacy -- as when Dole confesses that to this day he cannot bear to look himself in the mirror, save to shave or comb his hair -- are rare. The politician's opacity in his writing frustrates true revelation.

description: ONCE the small talk about movies, baseball and the Michael Jackson verdict has been exhausted, an awkward hush can descend on a dinner party. Slightly embarrassed by the silence, diners may feign indifference to the lull, nervously play with their utensils or pour themselves another glass of anxiety-reducing wine. A good time is had by none.

title: Crocheted Critters, et al.
description: The newest accessories for city strollers, camp trunks and teenage backpacks are homespun crocheted dolls and animals, just the sort of thing that a prairie mother might have made for her children in another century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELKOWE, VALRIE M.
description: SELKOWE--Valrie M. passed away at age 48 on June 1 after a life long battle with diabetes. Valrie authored three children's books and was a well known and beloved children's book reader at Barnes & Noble for 14 years. A private memorial service was held on June 5. Valrie's memory will forever serve to inspire courage in all who knew her.

description: WASSERMAN--Neil. 42. June 12, 2005. Husband of Donna, Son of Stan (Karen), Brother of Ellyn (Michael), Uncle of Blair and Eric. We love you and miss you.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the airline industry's search for profitability included erroneous calculations from the industry consulting firm of R.W. Mann for the average fare per passenger ticket for each domestic round trip in 2004, and for the revenue increases that would be necessary to break even. The firm now says the average fare was $282, not $143, and says that to break even, the airlines, on average, would now have to increase revenue per domestic passenger ticket by $49 -- not just under $20.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, a review on Page 21 of the Book Review today about "The Ethical Brain," a work on the relations between morality and neuroscience, misspells the author's surname at two points in some copies. He is Michael S. Gazzaniga.

title: Mickey Mouse Looking for Guinea Pigs on New Disney Tours
description: If you thought "Lilo & Stitch" was as close to Hawaii as Disney would ever get, think again. A new enterprise called Adventures by Disney, devoted to high-end guided group vacations, is offering trips to Hawaii and is also taking on the Wild West.

description: I once heard of a formula to determine if it's smarter to buy a ticket or use frequent flier miles based on a per-mile cost. Can you advise? -- Lore Acheson, Southport, N.C.
