description: To the Editor:

title: Master Cylinders
description: HAMILTON - IF drama is your goal, then the dosa is your dish. These wafer-thin breads, brittle along the edges and yielding in the center, are a deep gold and, unfurled, might be the size of a large pizza but with a fraction of the heft. Fillings can be mildly spicy or more so, but with their base of potatoes and onions polka-dotted with black mustard seed, they handle hunger in a hurry.

title: An Unlikely Haven For High-Speed Nature Lovers
description: Correction Appended

title: A Street of Bright Colors, Mixed With Natural Brick
description: NEW YORK'S streetscapes are like beaches, washed by their own special tides -- the fads and fashions of building design. Glass block from the 1940's, Perma-stone from the 1950's, aluminum siding from the 1960's, cheap vinyl windows from the 1970's -- all contribute to the flow of the blocks, which are ever-changing, almost living things.

title: Shad Population in State May Be Lowest in 25 Years
description: The population of American shad in Connecticut's rivers this year could be down by nearly a half-million from what is considered normal, a scientist with the state Department of Environmental Protection said Monday.

description: IF you read only the headlines, the future of globalization may seem scary, indeed.

description: Why are African-American men more likely to wind up in jail, or unemployed or in poorer health than white men? These were just a couple of the questions addressed yesterday at an impassioned conference on the state of the African-American male.

title: The Senate Apologizes, Mostly
description: WASHINGTON - DOES being in Congress mean always having to say you're sorry?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLE, SYLVAN
description: COLE--Sylvan. Devoted member and friend, Sylvan Cole will be dearly missed by all of us at the Appraisers Association of America.

title: U.S. Troops Press Offensive as Baghdad Diner Bombed
'My Very Own, Very Tame Rattlesnake'
description: I LIVE across the street from the Brooklyn Heights playground where my baby sitter used to take me in, I don't know, 1963? Back then it had seesaws, a sandbox and a jungle gym. Now it's paved with rubber, but under the rubber, yellow markings still rule the asphalt. They describe not only hopscotch and shuffleboard but also games unknown even to the elders. One was a numbered spiral that, lacking rules, prompted a song called "Rattlesnake." I can sing it for you now if you like.

title: Now Playing at the D.M.V.: Renata Scotto
description: WHITE PLAINS - YOU might not expect this city to offer much in the way of advanced training for opera singers, and for 11 months of the year, you would be right. But not in June, when the Renata Scotto Opera Academy takes up residence here at the Music Conservatory of Westchester, inside the shell of a renovated building the locals remember as the Department of Motor Vehicles.

title: Looking Long Term? Get Your Glasses
description: MANY investors couldn't care less about the long term and focus instead on what a stock is likely to do over the next quarter -- or just the next week. But even when they do try to consider factors that will affect a company's long-term profitability, they still don't see very far.

title: The Accidental Landlord
description: IN 1980, Robert Peguero, the foreman of a Chelsea printing shop, was looking for a new apartment. Mr. Peguero had outgrown the studio in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, where he lived with his wife and baby, and Williamsburg, where he had been raised, seemed the natural place to move.

title: 'God Bless the Gowanus'
description: I HAVE a deep, stinking, murky affection for the Gowanus Canal, so polluted in the 70's that supposedly a man who jumped into it trying to escape the police died. To this day an eerily empty, wildish stretch of land borders the canal, a roughshod ribbon between two baby-carriageand- smoked-mozzarella neighborhoods where a scrub like me can afford to live. God bless the Gowanus.

title: Fresh Skin? Take a Number
description: The new V-tonic line by Fresh is proving just the thing to rejuvenate hot and tired summer skin judging by the waiting list for its fragrant Life body splash. Made of cranberry seed oil and wild mint (along with a smorgasbord of vitamins and antioxidants), the line consists of a foaming shea butter cleanser, bath beads, a body lotion and a cleansing bar. Although the initial shipment on Memorial Day sold out in four days, a second shipment was to arrive in stores on Friday. Items in the collection range from $12 to $60 and are available at Fresh stores; (800)373-7420.

title: Village Can Shut X-Rated Store
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Manhattan, has ruled that an adult video store in Valley Stream violated an agreement with the village by installing six booths in which customers could view pornographic movies. The decision, filed May 31, will allow the village to shut down the shop, said Stanley Camhi, a lawyer for the village.

title: Health-Conscious
description: Q: The U.S. Supreme Court just ruled to uphold a federal law forbidding patients from using physician-approved marijuana to ease their pain. Do you agree with their decision?

title: $100 Million Commitment For Stem Cell Research
description: Connecticut's biotech and research centers will receive state help in starting stem cell research under a law signed by Gov. M. Jodi Rell on Wednesday. The law commits $100 million in financing for the research over the next 10 years.

title: Rice Says Both Sides Commit to Cooperation on Gaza Pullout
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 19 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice announced today that Israel and the Palestinians had committed themselves to avoiding violence against each other as Israeli settlers leave Gaza this summer, and to cooperating on the demolition of 1,600 settler homes and removal of rubble from the area.

Cirker Esq., Senior Vice Chairman, Board of Directors. His gracious, affable and distinguished presence as well as his devoted dedication to the Hospital Center's mission will be missed by all. Staff & Board of Directors Peninsula Hospital Center

description: I WENT back to Brooklyn to attend a party for Holi, the Hindu celebration of spring. The host was a friend who grew up in Calcutta but now lived in Fort Greene.

title: Introduction
description: Our Money issue drew a potpourri of mail on financial risk, hedge funds and derivatives. Some readers praised Hydie Sumner for her "kamikaze" attack on corporate discrimination. Others weighed in on the Ethicist's advice on the essay contest and its lone student entrant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOEKAWA, ICHIRO
description: SOEKAWA--Ichiro, 72, born in Inada, Japan, passed peacefully on January 31st, 2005 in Raleigh, NC. A longtime New Yorker, avid Yankees fan and owner of Akasaka Restaurant, Ichiro is survived by his children, Michael, Sumiko, Emiko and their mother, Frances, and by his mother, brother and sister in Japan. We love you.

title: War and Weakness
description: In Washington, people in government often communicate with one another and with the public in guarded, even coded statements. The mass media seldom detect, note or explain these messages. Lately one of those messages has been coming from senior American military officials, both on and off the record. Their message, decrypted, is that things in Iraq are not going well and may not do so for a while. Their corollary charge is that the American military has been seriously damaged.

QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I'm not prepared to have someone tell me there is only one view of what Europe is and that's the view expressed by certain people at certain points in time. Europe isn't owned by any of them; Europe is owned by all of us."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARTRAM, MARY ''TEDDY'' SHEPPARD
description: BARTRAM--Mary "Teddy" Sheppard died at her home in Hobe Sound, Florida on Monday, June 13, 2005. Formerly of Greenwich, Connecticut and Edgartown, Massa chusetts, she was born Mary Sesso Sheppard on July 21, 1908 to Josephine and William Sheppard of New Jersey. She married the late J. Burr Bartram on April 16, 1929. An active volunteer, she devoted her time to raising her family and helping the WW II efforts by serving with the Red Cross. She also donated her time to the Greenwich Hospital and Christ Church in Greenwich, Connecticut. Mrs. Bartram was an honorary member of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club and a member of the New York Yacht Club, both of which her husband, J. Burr Bartram served as Commodore. "Teddy", as she was known, is survived by her son, J. Burr Bartram, Jr., (Joe) and her daughter, Nina Griswold. She is also survived by three grandchildren and seven great grandchildren. A kind and loving woman, she will be remembered fondly by all who knew her. Visitation will be held at her residence from 10-5 P.M., on Wednesday, June 15th. A memorial service in her honor will be held at a later date in Hobe Sound and Greenwich, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Jupiter Island Clinic, 1 Estrada Rd., Hobe Sound, FL, 33455 or the Humane Society of the Treasure Coast, Inc., 4100 SW Leighton Farm Avenue, Palm City, FL 34990.

title: In a Co-op, One Apartment, One Vote
description: Q. In our co-op, each apartment is given one vote, regardless of the number of shares allocated to the apartment. When two apartments are combined into one, the resulting apartment gets one vote. Is this normal and legal? ... Rachel Andreyev, Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRONSTEIN, MURRAY
description: BRONSTEIN--Murray, died June 12, 2005. Beloved and loving father of David. Cherished and devoted brother of twin sister Anne. Proud Founder of Murray Bronstein Associates, Personnel Agency. He was a vital life force. His passions included chess, Shakespeare, history, theatre and travel. He demonstrated great compassion and generosity in his many contributions to charity. He fought a ferocious and gallant battle for five years against a cruel, devastating disease. May he find the peace that so eluded him in his last years.

title: I Want My Hyphenated-Identity MTV
description: ON a fine spring day in Manhattan, Reshma Taufiq, 28, was the first to audition for a role on a new MTV channel that will be aimed at second-generation desis, or immigrants from the Indian subcontinent. Her emerald-green bodice fit snugly atop navel-baring jeans, and her long black hair curtained her cheekbones as she sweated under the studio lights, trying sexy, then cheery, then exuberant variations on "Live from Jackson Heights, Queens, it's MTV Desi."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CONWELL, EDWIN
description: CONWELL--Edwin. April 28, 1917--April 16, 1999 We still love you so much. Louise and George

title: A Legacy and a Library
description: THE doctors have told Joelle Pauporte she has a year, if that much, to say her thank-yous and her goodbyes, to hold her husband, and to create a place in her 3-year-old daughter's mind for a memory, even if a fading one, of an adoring mother. How does a mother stricken with terminal breast cancer create a legacy in such a short time?

title: 'The Melancholy, Echoing Call of a Bird'
description: BEFORE Park Slope, I lived in Manhattan, on a street so noisy that people routinely asked me, when I called them, if I was speaking from a phone booth. The sounds I hear in Brooklyn, in contrast, are specific, intermittent, all the more evocative because I am blind to their sources.

description: A majority of Americans are worried about having enough money for retirement and pessimistic that Social Security will pay the benefits they expect when they retire, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. Yet most Americans also say they find it difficult to save.

title: Signs of Style on a Mundane Commercial Strip
description: FOR nearly 90 years, little has changed inside Eddie's Sweet Shop on Metropolitan Avenue in Forest Hills, Queens. Not the long marble countertop, the dark-wood paneling or the spinning stools. The 20 ice cream flavors (including pistachio pineapple and maple walnut), the hot fudge and the whipped cream are still homemade.

title: The Emptiest Cradle
description: HAARLEM, NETHERLANDS - HOW was I to know what fatherly love was? I almost never became a father myself. The books I'd read, the poems, the songs, the movies, they all advised me likewise: stay who you are, stay a son. Go west, young man. Never settle down.

title: The Next Act
description: MY grandparents all landed in Brooklyn shortly before World War I. My mother's parents, who stayed poor, shifted from small apartment to small apartment in Brownsville with their five kids. My dad's family did much better, building a successful garment business in Manhattan and moving to a two-story attached house, complete with backyard, on a tree-lined street in Flatbush.

title: HARRAH'S-CAESARS MERGER FINAL
description: The merger of Harrah's Entertainment and Caesars Entertainment, producing the world's largest gambling company, became official last week. The combined company, now under the Harrah's name, will account for about 40 percent of Atlantic City's gambling revenue, about $4.6 billion a year, in its four Atlantic City casinos: Caesars, Bally's, Harrah's and Showboat. The company divested itself of a fifth Atlantic City casino in September, selling the Atlantic City Hilton to Colony Capital, appeasing casino regulators worried about too much casino control by one company. The new Harrah's will own or manage 40 casinos worldwide, have 100,000 employees and earn nearly $9 billion in annual revenue. Robert Strauss

title: After All These Years...
description: LONG ISLAND diners have sung Chez Noelle's praises for 24 years, calling it a hidden gem, a classic and the most authentically French restaurant on the Island. They still should be doing so, for this Port Washington spot is as beguiling as ever.

title: Bridge to Open Just as Strolling Season Heats Up
description: THE state's only historic covered bridge east of the Connecticut River is expected to reopen in time for the peak summer tourist season after it was closed in early spring for repairs.

title: Slimming Down In the Easy Chair
description: Hard Tail, the active-wear company whose basic roll-top workout pants have become a chic gym staple, has come out with a summer line that offers women the optical illusion of having trimmed off a few pounds -- without exercise. The new collection includes snap-placket baby T's ($62) and tie-dyed V-neck T's ($42) in bright aquas, corals and neutrals, as well as trim short shorts ($48) and slimming miniskirts ($58). The company also sells stretch capris with a roll-down waist ($58), cropped drawstring yoga pants ($64) and corset-front bootleggers ($53, all at the Shop at Equinox in New York, 212-752-5360), in khaki green, aqua and black.

title: A Tale of Two Stadiums
description: There is a lot of good news in the stadium deals announced last week for New York's two Major League Baseball teams. The teams will pay for their new homes themselves. And each transaction holds the promise of more than just a stadium. The city hopes, against the odds, that the new Mets stadium in Queens will help secure the Olympics in 2012. The projected benefits of the new Yankee Stadium appear more certain -- namely the long-awaited revival of that part of the South Bronx, with better parks and waterfront access.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBERTS, GAIL K. OMMERLE
description: ROBERTS--Gail K. Ommerle, who retired from the New York State Court Administration in 2001 after close to 20 years with the state, died at her home in New Mexico on Sunday, May 15, 2005. She was 61. Mrs. Roberts was born in NYC. She was the daughter of Harry G. Ommerle, a former CBS television network vice president and talent agent with the William Morris Agency, and Katherine Murphy Ommerle, a former actress who was one of the founders of the Darien Dinner Theater. After graduating from the American Academy of Dramatic Arts, Mrs. Roberts became a model and actress. She appeared in several television series and off-Broadway plays. She made her movie debut as a bride in the movie "Goodbye Columbus", starring Ali McGraw. In her late twenties she decided to join the Civil Rights Movement and traveled down south to march with Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Afterwards, she worked for Bobby Kennedy and became involved with New York City politics. Later, she worked for Mayor John V. Lindsay and became involved with juvenile delinquent programs in the city. She is survived by her daughter Katherine Elizabeth Roberts, her brothers Stephen Ommerle, Peter Ommerle and her sister Elizabeth Ommerle. A memorial service will be held for Mrs. Roberts this Saturday, June 18, 2005 at 3:00 pm at the St. Regis Hotel in NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOPER, NORMAN
description: COOPER -- Norman. The members of the Department of Pathology of the NYU School of Medicine mourn the loss of Norman Cooper, M.D. After graduating from Columbia University and the University of Rochester Medical School, Norman came to the Department in 1944 as a resident and stayed on as a faculty member. He served as Chief of Pathology at the Manhattan VA for 30 years and made significant contributions to the study of arthritis and understanding of the clinical manifestations and pathogenesis of several autoimmune diseases. His compassionate, generous, and wise leadership was deeply appreciated by students, residents, and colleagues; his thoughtful counsel will be missed by the pathology community at NYU and beyond. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Vittorio Defendi, M.D., Ritter Professor of Oncology and former Chair of Pathology David B. Roth, M.D., Ph.D., Irene Diamond Professor of Immunology and Chair of Pathology, NYU School of Medicine

It will be a mobile kiosk -- stuffed with T-shirts, bumper stickers and other swag -- slated to cover more than 50,000 miles of Texas's nooks and crannies during the next 17 months. It's "It," the writer and musician Kinky Friedman's conduit to the "little fellers" in his quest to become the first independent governor of Texas since Sam Houston.

title: Big Paychecks Are Exhibit A at C.E.O. Trials
description: In the 1990's, they were held up as corporate supermen, executives whose skills and brainpower made them so indispensable to their companies that they were paid on a scale virtually unseen in human history. But in the new millennium, as the story has moved from the boardrooms to the courtrooms, they have portrayed themselves as having been fumblers, sloppy with their paperwork and unaware of crimes in their midst -- yet still deserving of their gargantuan paychecks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOEW, SYLVIA
description: LOEW -- Sylvia. 83 years young of Lake Worth, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY, died June 13, 2005. Beloved wife of Elliott. Mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, and inspiration for the rest of our family. She was the most beautiful woman and spirit and a wonderful friend who brought strength, wisdom, love, humor, and grace to so many people.

description: ZEGUO, China - With his smart clothes, blow-dried hair and speech peppered with references to Rousseau, Voltaire and Montesquieu, Jiang Zhaohua, the young Communist Party secretary for this prosperous township, bears little resemblance to the usual Chinese politician.

title: Kicking the Euro When Europe Is Down
description: ROME - PERHAPS no proposal has been as suggestive of Europe's current disarray as the one made this month by the Italian labor minister, Roberto Maroni: It is time, Mr. Maroni suggested, to scrap the euro and bring back the lira.

title: Finger Painting
description: The dirty little secret in the makeup world, the one insiders know but never reveal to an unsuspecting public, is out. For years we have clung to the mystique of the brush. Every step in the process had to have its own. Even a nothing-special everyday makeup job could require six or seven brushes. And yet, top makeup artists, even the ones with whole battalions of brushes named after them, were sometimes seen, in the throes of creativity, plunging fingers into pots and getting the stuff onto the face with no intermediary tool. Backstage at the fall fashion shows, the practice seemed especially flagrant. Fingers were flying to create natural, seamless looks.

title: Hydie Sumner Wants Her Job Back
description: Your writer says that it's highly unusual for a victim of discrimination to seek reinstatement. In fact, it is not unusual for those fired unlawfully to want to return to their employers. A firing, like a marital breakup, is traumatic, and people react differently. Some say, "Hell, no," but others want to try to reconstruct their careers, especially if, as Sumner believes, "there are lots of people who would love to see me back."

Prayers on Tuesday, June 21, 2005 at 8PM at 9 Fieldstone Lane, Great Neck, New York 11020.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELLMAN, RICHARD VANCE
description: WELLMAN--Richard Vance, 82, a nationally recognized figure in the field of probate law who helped transform the legal landscape in the area of trusts and estates, died on June 3, 2005 in Athens, GA. Robert Cotton Alston Professor of Law at the University of Georgia Law School from 1974 to 1990, Wellman was the principal drafter of the Uniform Probate Code designed to make the probate process cheaper and more efficient. He worked tirelessly to promote the code from the time it was first promulgated by the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws in 1969 until his death. The code has been enacted in 20 states and has influenced probate law in virtually every state. Born on September 10, 1922 in Worthington, Ohio, Professor Wellman received his Juris Doctor degree from the University of Michigan where he served on the law faculty from 1954 to 1974. A life member with the National Conference of Commissioners of Uniform State Laws, he served as a Commissioner for the States of Michigan (1970-1974), and Georgia (1974-2005). Following the death of his first wife, Louise Laylin, Professor Wellman in 1984 married the former Natalie Lancaster Robertson. He is survived by his wife; six children; four step-children; nine grandchildren; seven stepgrandchildren; one greatgranddaughter and nieces and nephews.

title: Quantum Theory And Opera
description: RICHARD FEYNMAN, the brilliant physicist whose work on quantum electrodynamics earned him a Nobel Prize in 1965, also cultivated some unusual musical hobbies, including traveling the world with a set of bongo drums and studying the physics of Tuvan throat singing, a tradition in which the performer produces multiple notes at once.

title: Two Guys From the Hood
description: AS a convert to Brooklyn's charms, I like to think I was ahead of the curve. We were driving back from a camping trip somewhere upstate, my parents, my brother and me, squeezed into my father's pickup truck, the back piled high with tents and sleeping bags. I must have been about 12.

title: Wolfowitz, Ending African Tour, Calls for Changes
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, June 18 - The World Bank needs to streamline its bureaucracy and refocus its lending on rebuilding decaying infrastructures in poor nations, the bank's new president, Paul A. Wolfowitz, said Saturday at the conclusion of his first visit to sub-Saharan Africa.

title: A Life Lived Aloft
description: I WORKED my way through college, working anywhere from 20 hours to 40 or 50 hours a week. When I was 19, my friend and I were working at Riley's, the largest department store in San Luis Obispo, Calif. I was in the junior department, selling clothes.

title: 'I Felt the Cycle of Life Complete Itself'
description: EXCEPT for a few educational sojourns, I've lived in the same Brooklyn brownstone since I was born. I'd intended to set off on my own after college, but an apartment opened up, and the landlords, who happened to be my parents, offered me an irresistible deal. Later, a floor-through with a deck became available, and I took it gladly. Now I'm quite proud of what some might consider my inertia. In 38 years, I've inhabited every floor but one and seen three bodies carried out our front door in vinyl bags. title: Deceiving the Kids
description: My wife and I traveled to the Caribbean with our children, ages 9, 7 and 1. Before the vacation, I went to a local coin dealer and bought several old and strange coins. We buried these coins on the beach so our children could find "buried treasure." Our kids mark it as a highlight of the trip, but now I feel like a fraud. Have we crossed a line? Patrick Filbin, Bloomfield Hills, Mich. It's a fine thing to play with your kids but a dubious thing to lie to them. One way to distinguish between playing and lying is that play occurs with the understanding and consent of all involved. This is a simple enough matter to work out when it involves adult fantasy, from novels to movies to more personal play: consent can be explicit. With kids, it's trickier, a problem every parent grapples with when deciding how to answer a child who asks if there really is a Santa Claus or if the coin under the pillow really comes from the Tooth Fairy. Is the child eager to continue a kind of game, or is he or she requesting honest, if game-ending, information? Such a question requires intimate knowledge of a particular child's thinking, development and desires. To answer it requires all the insight and understanding a parent can muster.

description: WYCKOFF--Barbara Heafey. June 11, 2005 near Washington, DC where she lived with her husband, Edwin Brit and daughter, Dana. Born in Berkeley, CA to Edward and Margaret Murphy Heafey. Loving sister to the late "Teddy". Attended Holy Names College on a full scholarship; moved to New York City, fell in love with Brit, and married in 1954. He remains endlessly fascinated with her beauty, wit, and intelligence. Editor and researcher for Macmillan Publishers, Grolier, trade and specialty magazines. Worked with Raphael Lemkin in the 1950s, to have the United Nations recognize the term and the reality of "genocide". Taught first grade, and was very proud of her work with Head Start. With a strong social consciousness and a sense of community, she served as a Chapter President of the Manhattan League of Woman Voters; taught Catholic Sunday School; served as a Girl Scout Leader; organized Community Days in Chappaqua, NY; volunteered for the Democratic Party; and marched against the Vietnam War. Served on the board of the Chappaqua Drama Group and stage-managed plays; won trophies in ballroom dance competitions; supervised the building of the family homes; and gave marvelous parties. Graced with crackling intelligence, curiosity, intellectual honesty, wit and humor, she was kind, generous, and welcoming. Her approach to life inspired and thrilled people who knew her; she was the best friend to her daughter, and a role model and friend to family and to Dana's friends. "See you in the morning, when the sun gets out of bed. That's right!" Funeral mass and burial in Washington, DC on June 24. title: THE WEEK AHEAD: June 19-25; FILM
description: A highlight of this year's Cannes Film Festival, the delightfully wigged-out "PRINCESS RACCOON," is like nothing you've seen before. This exuberant pastiche from the Japanese auteur SEIJUN SUZUKI stars ZHANG ZIYI as the titular princess, who discovers that her true love may be the very human Prince Amechiyo (JOE ODAGIRI). Best known for eye-popping 1960's yakuza films like "Tokyo Drifter," this 82-year-old director shows no sign of slowing or tamping down. In "Princess Raccoon," he seamlessly samples genres, cinematic and otherwise, including opera, hip-hop, old-school musical numbers and Broadway ballads. Along the way, he provides a master class on perspective that encompasses both traditional painting and up-to-the-minute digital manipulations, and folds in all manner of classic cute. All that's missing is Godzilla. Sunday at 9 p.m. at the New York Asian Film Festival at the Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village, and Saturday at 8:30 p.m. at ImaginAsian, 239 East 59th Street, Manhattan. Tickets: (212)868-4444 or subwaycinema.com.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE DECLINES
description: The New Jersey Department of Labor and Workforce Development announced that the state unemployment rate dropped from 4.2 percent in April to 3.9 percent in May, adding 3,800 new payroll jobs. So far this year the state has added 20,800 new jobs in the private sector. Public employment declined by roughly 18,000 jobs last month. In May the national unemployment rate was 5.1 percent. Joseph J. Seneca, a professor at the Edward Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, said the latest figures are encouraging for the state's work force because its on a pace to create 45,000 new jobs by the end of the year. "The economy is doing remarkably well in New Jersey," Dr. Seneca said. "It's an encouraging picture." The last time the state's unemployment rate was at less than 4 percent was in March 2001. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREBLE, THOMAS C.
description: GREBLE--Thomas C. A respected attorney and partner at Brown Raysman Millstein Felder & Steiner LLP, died Thursday, June 16, 2005 at Westchester Medical Center. He was 55 years old. He is survived by his wife of 31 years, Diane Joan Greble, his daughters, Mrs. Emily Greble Balic and Julia Greble, his son Matthew, and his mother, Jocelyn Sheldon. Tom graduated from Villanova University in 1971 and received his J.D. from Fordham University School of Law in 1974. He began his legal career at the New York City Corporation Counsel's office and went into private practice in 1978. Tom specialized in labor and employment law and litigation representing employers, and had served as an Adjunct Professor of Law at Fordham and New York University. Tom was an acknowledged authority with respect to the laws and rules affecting the staffing industry and the contingent workforce, and served as General Counsel to the New York Staffing Association, Inc., the New Jersey Staffing Alliance, Inc. and Human Resources Outsourcing Association. He also was recognized as one of the top outsourcing attorneys in the United States. A devoted husband and father, a wonderful colleague and mentor to so many, an advocate for the disabled, an accomplished bridge player, masterful storyteller, avid reader and blackjack player, and ardent sports fan -Tom lived his life to the fullest and he will be greatly missed. The wake will be held at Beecher's Funeral Home, Pleasantville on Monday June 20th from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. and from 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. A funeral mass will be held at the Church of St. John and St. Mary's in Chappaqua on Tuesday, June 21, 2005 at 10 a.m. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Center for Discovery, P.O. title: Movement
description: Clive Gillinson transformed himself from musician into manager at a moment of crisis. In 1984, the London Symphony Orchestra was more than $600,000 in debt and sinking. The orchestra moved two years earlier into the Barbican Center, a mazelike modern-arts complex located in the City, the financial district, which in those days shut down after dark. In that confusing and out-of-the-way destination, the orchestra administration programmed unorthodox concerts (a festival of Berlioz and Michael Tippett, for example) in tightly clustered stretches. Each Barbican concert lost an average of $3,000. An orchestra that is governed by its players, the L.S.O. reacted to this desperate plight with an act of desperation. It forced out its managing director and, looking within the ranks, recruited Gillinson, a young cellist whose chief business credential was running an antiques shop with his wife in his spare time. Before accepting, the prudent cellist insisted that his chair in the orchestra be kept open for a year in case the new job didn't work out. Just as characteristically, however, he never looked back.

title: See a Bubble?
description: Roger Lowenstein worries that derivatives increase risk for companies and the financial system (The Way We Live Now, June 5). Since companies are exposed to interest rates, currencies, oil prices and the like when they open for business, executives must make smart decisions about risk from the get-go. Derivatives help in two ways. They help managers to know the value -- and potential changes in value -- of those risk positions, and they make it easier to shed the risks they don't want and take on those they do. Not every decision will be profitable, and some companies will fail, just as they did before the growth of derivatives. But making it easier to shift risk has led to good decisions that strengthen companies and make the financial system more resilient.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRUCKNER, JACK L.
description: BRUCKNER--Jack L. On Saturday evening June 11, 2005, Jack died peacefully at his home in Upper Brookville, Long Island, New York. He was 86 years old, and fought valiantly with Alzheimer's disease, macular degeneration, and cancer. Beloved and devoted husband of Marion Duke Johnson, his wife of 64 years. Loving and supportive father of Marion Duke "Dukie" Baxter, Laurie Bastis, and the late Betsey Reicherter. Father-in-law to Jason Bastis and the late Bob Reicherter. Loving and inspiring grandfather "Gramps" of Kevin and Todd Baxter; Andrew, Michael and John Reicherter; and Matthew Bastis. Jack graduated from Duke University with a BA degree in 1942. A lieutenant in the US Navy, he received three citations for his significant role in the Sicily, Salerno, Anzio, and DDay invasions of WWII. Lieutenant Bruckner was also cited for being the first US Naval officer to set foot on European soil. Jack was a retired Vice President of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, and served on their Board of Directors from 1974-1977. Upon retirement, he served on the Board of Directors of Countrywide Financial Corporation. Other boards on which he served included North Carolina Outward Bound from 1981-1986, Bucknell University, and Friends Academy. Additionally, in 1978, the Board of Trustees of Duke University designated Jack as President's Associate to Terry Sanford. This title conferred the right and responsibility of representing the President of Duke University to all constituencies. He also served for 12 years on the vestry at Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset. His strength, courage, and determination were unyielding and his great love of family, friends, and life touched and taught us all. A Memorial Service to celebrate Jack's life will be held at Christ Episcopal Church, 1355 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, NY on Wednesday, June 29 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial gifts be made in honor of Jack L. Bruckner to Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd, Woodbury, NY 11797; or Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation, 5 Channel Drive, Port Washington, NY 11050; or American Cancer Society, 6800 Jericho Turnpike, Suite 200 West, Syosset, NY 11791.

title: Target Practice
description: There is no set career path for a knife thrower's target. Ekaterina Sknarina's involved the Russian national rhythmic gymnastics team and several years in Cirque du Soleil. Four and a half seconds later, the ball thudded onto a square of freshly sodded grass painted with hash marks, like a swatch from a football field, as a group of neighborhood kids watched in perplexed wonder.

title: In Every Film, a Different Louis Malle
description: OF all the qualities that make an artist great, or even good, simple curiosity must be the most underrated. In the late 1950's, when the young Louis Malle was beginning his filmmaking career, his restless, searching temperament served him well at first: at 23 he was a co-director (with Jacques-Yves Cousteau) of an undersea documentary, "Silent World" (1956), which won an Oscar and the Palme d'Or at Cannes; two years later, his first dramatic features -- a tricky thriller called "Elevator to the Gallows" and an unabashedly romantic tale of provincial adultery called "The Lovers" -- were among the earliest and biggest commercial successes of his generation of French filmmakers, soon to be known as the New Wave. But his curiosity quickly got the better of him: after that promising start, he promptly set about his true life's work, which was to look at the world around him as hard as he could, and to keep his creative identity from becoming too solid, too well defined. "You see the world much better through the camera," he once said, and he wouldn't let anything, even his own personality, block the view.

Survived by his daughter Vivian and her husband Henry, his son John and his wife Deborah, his niece Lisa Levy, and his grandchildren Benjamin Wallace-Wells, David WallaceWells, Michael Wallace and Julia Wallace. Devoted father of Samantha Toogood and husband Richard of Stowe, VT and John W. and wife Carol of New York City. Born March 4, 1916 in Philadelphia, the son of Albert and Adele (Marko) Kner. "Wil" was an Advertising and Marketing Executive with Macy's (Herald Square), Westinghouse Corporation (MA and OH) and D&S Advertising (Mansfield, OH). Wil served overseas in the Army Signal Corps during WW II. He was an active member of First Congregational Church and Westbrook Country Club, Mansfield, OH. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PADILLA, ELIZABETH KASULIS, ESQ.
description: PADILLA--Elizabeth Kasulis, Esq. The Officers, Directors and Members of the Brooklyn Bar Association Volunteer Lawyers Project, Inc. mourn the untimely passing of our beloved Pro Bono Coordinator, Elizabeth Kasulis Padilla, Esq. Liz was a graduate of Cornell Law School, receiving her J.D. and LL.M. in International Law in 2002. Liz had exceptional talents, compassion and wisdom beyond her years and was using her brilliance as an attorney to bring legal services to the poorest residents of Brooklyn. It was an honor and a joy to know and work with her. She will be profoundly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to Telemachus Kasulis, Esq., her husband, and to the Padilla and Kasulis families. James P. title: The First Race-Based Medicine
description: With the unanimous endorsement of an expert advisory committee last week, a heart-failure drug aimed specifically at African-Americans moved a big step closer to regulatory approval. If the Food and Drug Administration gives a favorable nod, the drug, known as BiDil, will become the first medicine ever approved for a single racial group. Its arrival could be a boon to black patients, who die at disproportionate rates from congestive heart failure. But the history of this first racial medicine raises troubling questions about the impact of patent considerations on how drugs are tested.

title: Card Stud
description: The poker player Daniel Negreanu says, "Poker is hot because it's everyone's sport" (Pat Jordan, May 29). I do not doubt that top-flight participants in activities like crossword-puzzle competitions and Scrabble tournaments possess high levels of concentration as well as acute analytical and decision-making skills. And perhaps a bit of extra stamina. However, these activities, like poker, are not sports -- they are games.

title: D. J. Bruce
description: It's a little-remarked part of the concert experience: the music that plays before the star gets onstage. Some bands leave the choice to the sound crew; others put on whatever CD was playing in the bus the night before. And others, slightly more obsessive, create their own compilations to set the appropriate mood. With his current solo tour, which returns to North America next month, Bruce Springsteen is one of the obsessive ones, and for fans who have heard the songs and want to track down his choices, he has listed them on his Web site (www.brucespringsteen.net/live/walkinmusic.html).

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: KICKING BACK IN KENTUCKY -- The Greater Kentucky Convention and Visitors Bureau is offering a handful of quick vacation options. Among them are the Family Adventure Package, starting at $106 for a family of four, including one night's lodging and admission to attractions like the Louisville Slugger Museum. The Berthe Morisot Package includes an overnight stay and two adult admissions to "Berthe Morisot: An Impressionist and Her Circle" at the Speed Art Museum. Seventy-five paintings by Morisot, the 19th-century artist, and others like Degas, Manet, Renoir and Monet, are on their first tour of the United States and will be in Louisville until Sept. 18. Prices are from $46 to $207. Taxes for both packages are 15 percent. Information: (888) 568-4784; www.gotolouisville.com.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: June 19-25; THEATER
description: The Fourth of July is two weeks away, but the theatrical landscape is already littered with patriotic colors (if not themes). The most blatant is "RED, WHITE AND TUNA," the climactic chapter of the satirical Tuna Trilogy, which was perfecting blue-collar comedy before there was such a thing. For the unacquainted, "GREATER TUNA" was an off Broadway hit in 1982 that became a road show war horse (23 years and counting) and spawned a successful sequel, "A TUNA CHRISTMAS." Each was set in mythical Tuna, Tex., a tiny little town where -- to quote the Greater Tuna Corporation's Web site -- "the Lion's Club is too liberal and Patsy Cline never dies." The Tuna plays have made a mint for their apparently incorporated creators -- JOE SEARS, JASTON WILLIAMS and ED HOWARD -- earning more than $6 million a year on tour. As they did in the previous Tunas, Mr. Sears and Mr. Williams star in the final chapter, which lands in the nation's capital this week. Starts Friday at the Eisenhower Theater, the Kennedy Center, 2700 F Street N.W., (202)467-4600.

title: In Bid for Pumping Station, Water Company Warns of Rationing
description: EASTCHESTER - EXECUTIVES at United Water New Rochelle, a regional water-supply company, warn of a dark and dry age if they do not receive permission -- and soon -- to build a large pumping station in a residential neighborhood of Eastchester.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: June 19-25; POP/JAZZ
description: Last month, the great postpunk trio SLEATER-KINNEY released "The Woods" (Sub Pop), album No. 7 in a long career that has been consistent but never quite predictable. The new CD finds the spindly trio bulking up a bit: jagged, interlocking songs give way to digressive guitar solos, and the album ends with a wild 15-minute finale. The group is to play the ROSELAND BALLROOM on Thursday; part of the fun will be hearing the denser old songs collide with the more expansive new ones. Roseland Ballroom, 239 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212)777-6800.

title: An Office and a Gentleman
description: MOREHEAD CITY, N.C. - SHORTLY before the terrorist attacks of 2001, Gen. H. Hugh Shelton, then the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the top military adviser to President Bush, met at an undisclosed location in California with Gen. Richard B. Myers, who later succeeded him in that job, and Gen. Michael E. Ryan, the Air Force chief of staff.

title: In Portugal, Daring Design in a Laid-Back City
description: THE Casa da Msica, a futuristic concert hall in Porto, Portugal, arrived four years later than planned, and not without controversy. Its in-your-face design, by the Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas, is a jarring contrast to the city's gentle, tile-covered buildings. But as a tourist destination -- with appeal to architecture and music lovers alike -- the building can only mean good things for Porto, a city abounding with bargains. Hotel rooms under $80 are common, and delicious meals may cost less than $10. At the Casa da Msica, which has a complete range of classical and jazz events, most events are under $25, and quite a few are free. That includes the chance to offer opinions on such unusual details as the glowing rubber armrests, walls of plywood with gold leaf patterning, and vast windows of corrugated glass beyond the stages.

title: Editors' Choice
Goosen Cracks Whip, and Pinehurst Bends

Over the next year, whole streets were slated to disappear, and did, along with the cast-iron "Bartleby the Scrivener"-era buildings that lined them, housing printing lofts and importers, tanneries and produce stalls. More than 24 city blocks would be razed to allow for a wave of development that included an access ramp for the Brooklyn Bridge, the expansion of Pace University, and office buildings, shops and housing.

title: Young Filmmaker Tells Hollywood It Can Wait
description: WHEN Miranda July's "Me and You and Everyone We Know" was screened for the public at this year's Sundance Film Festival, its writer, director and star was more than a little nervous. Ms. July enjoys an ardent following for her experimental short films and performance pieces. A memorial service will be held on June 26 at noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Just Step on the Gas and Say Om
description: TO many Americans no home is complete without that special suburban red carpet known as the front lawn. Spreading in every direction like a rectangular green lake, showcasing the house like a jewel in a velvet case, the lawn is the American dream, a prize flaunted to the passing world. That its upkeep is a nightmare is a paradox that gave John Cheever a whole field to graze in.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: June 19-25; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Talk about going against the flow. Starting a new concert series in summer, on Monday nights, with doors opening at 6 p.m., in a cabaret/restaurant setting, seems so delightfully to contradict conventional wisdom about programming that it merits attention for its contrarian nature alone. But the ONE-TWO-THREE-GO! series appears to be worth a look for the more substantial -- and traditional -- reason that it presents interesting artists doing interesting things. This Monday's concert features EVE BEGLARIAN and COREY DARGEL, two noted downtown composer-performers, and the flutist MARGARET LANCASTER in a program billed as "electro-cabaret," which features, in part, Ms. Beglarian and Mr. Dargel performing each other's songs. (It turns out this series isn't, strictly speaking, new; but since its previous incarnation was during the regular 2001-2 season, this is a rebirth of sorts.) Opia, 130 East 57th Street, (212)688-3939, $15.

title: Gwen Stone and Elliot Hermann
description: Gwen Lynn Stone and Elliot Bruce Hermann were married last evening by Rabbi Bennett F. Miller at Congregation B'nai Tikvah in North Brunswick, N.J.

The younger Southworth, a minor league standout, had quit baseball and become the first professional ballplayer to enlist in the military. This made him something of a celebrity, especially after Pearl Harbor.

title: Alexandra Pelosi and Michiel Vos
description: Alexandra Pelosi, a daughter of Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, and Paul Pelosi of San Francisco, was married yesterday to Michiel Vos, the son of Pieter Vos of Amsterdam and Geertruida de Boer of Borne, the Netherlands. The Rev. John P. McGuire, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Church in New York.

title: Hikes in Europe, With Your Boots on the Ground and Your Bed Above It
description: WITH all due respect to campfires, cowboy coffee and "roughing it," it's hard to beat ending a good day of hiking with a glass of beer, a comfortable bed and a dinner whose preparation doesn't include the direction "just add boiling water." For those who lean toward a little nurture with their nature, Europe is the answer to a hiker's prayers. In almost every Old World country there are civilized multiday hikes sprinkled with lodges, inns or mountain refuges: treks through France's Alps, walks along Hadrian's Wall in England, trips across glaciers in Switzerland -- you name it.

title: Vomiting, Hypertension, Lethargy
description: 1. Symptoms A wave of nausea swept over the elderly woman as she climbed the stairs of her daughter's home. She hadn't felt well since she left her own tidy studio apartment in Florida the day before. She lowered herself onto the stairs with a quiet moan; her face was pale, her coral pink lipstick faded. "I'm so sorry, darling," she said as her daughter ran into the hallway, "I threw up on your stairs." Embarrassed, she admitted that she hadn't been able to keep anything down since the morning before. She'd thought about not visiting, but at 93, how many more Christmases would she be able to spend with her daughter and grandchildren? "I kept thinking it was going to go away, but it just hasn't," she explained.

title: Inside the List
description: LAW REVIEW: Lisa Scottoline writes tangy legal thrillers that are set in Philadelphia, her hometown, and she is often called "the female Grisham." The comparison is apt enough, though Scottoline's jokey and brittle entertainments make Grisham's books, with their laconic detachment, read like Graham Greene. Scottoline -- "rhymes with fettuccine," she has said -- has published 12 novels, beginning with "Everywhere That Mary Went" (1994). Until now, they have mostly been about the often imperiled employees at an all-female law firm called Rosato & Associates. Her new novel, "Devil's Corner," is a departure of sorts. The book, which enters the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 9, introduces a frisky new heroine -- a prosecutor named Vicki Allegretti. Commercially speaking, it was probably time to give Rosato & Associates a rest. While each of Scottoline's previous five novels made the Times list in hardcover, her last one, "Killer Smile," was her poorest showing in years -- the book entered the list at No. 14 and vanished two weeks later. A former litigator, Scottoline goes to extreme lengths to make sure she gets the details right. According to her Web site, she has, alarmingly, "driven up the front steps of the Art Museum in Philadelphia (the famous Rocky stairs) just to make sure it could be done." Some writers of thrillers like to cultivate a certain air of bristling aloofness. Not Scottoline. "She wants to meet her readers one on one," a note on her Web site says, and "give them all great big bear hugs."

title: OFF LAMU ISLAND, MARCH 14, 2005
description: Sigrid Johansson of Gotene, Sweden, a counselor at a health center. "I went with a friend, a teacher who has been going to Kenya for many years with her students. I hadn't been outside Europe. People on Lamu are mostly Muslims, very friendly, and I think everybody knows each other. Everything is calm, no one hurries. There are no cars; only boats and donkeys for transport. The water is wonderfully warm and salty. We took a sunset cruise on a dhow, a wooden boat with only one mast and one big sail. The crew was three guys, and they talked a lot. They told us about themselves and the boat. They had such a torn and lousy flag -- we said we'd come back and bring them a Swedish one. They said 'Great!"' As told to Seth Kugel

title: Housing Group Sees Bias With a Smile
description: ALMOST four decades after the passage of the federal Fair Housing Act and about 20 years after a federal judge found segregation in the Yonkers schools, the illegal real estate practice of steering minority groups away from nonminority neighborhoods persists, according to a study issued by Westchester Residential Opportunities, a nonprofit housing agency in White Plains.

title: Florida Rooms
description: When David Horvitz and Francie Bishop Good decided that their 10,000-square-foot McMansion in Fort Lauderdale was too big (their four children had all left home), they began looking not only for less space but also for more design. "We wanted something manageable, something pretty, something that wouldn't be ostentatious," said Horvitz, who manages a private investment company.

title: Americans Trade Fire With Insurgents in Western Iraq
description: KARABILA, Iraq, June 18 - American tank fire boomed across this dusty village in western Iraq on Saturday, and insurgents sporadically lobbed mortar shells in return as about 1,000 marines continued a day-old offensive amid a warren of dirt streets in an effort to return the area to Iraqi government control.

title: Corrections

title: Living With Social Security: Small Dreams and Safety Nets
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. - Barbara Amberg used her Social Security checks to fly to New York and see Christo's "Gates" in Central Park. Shirley Malone lives on hers in subsidized public housing, sometimes washing her clothes in dish detergent to save money.

title: Father Knew Best
description: SEVERAL years ago, a naked black woman appeared in our family house. She came to us in a hidden portfolio of drawings done by a quiet Midwestern Jewish man who grew up in Omaha and until his death ran his family's optical business. The drawings were done by my father.

description: HILTZ--Edna, "Bonnie" U. 79, of Weekapaug, RI, formerly of Garden City, NY, died June 8, 2005. Devoted and loving mother and grandmother. Survived by children Stephen Madigan, Dr. Janet Madigan, Catherine Madigan, David Hiltz and nine grandchildren. Mother of the late James D. Madigan III. Memorial service to be held June 25 at 11 AM in Weekapaug Chapel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GORDON, KERMIT
description: GORDON -- Kermit. We mourn and our hearts ache at your passing. Knowing that you are no longer suffering is our only solace. Your legacy lives on in your wonderful wife, your children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Whoever you touched has had their lives brightened ever so much. May we all aspire to your humanitarianism, optimism and gentle ways. Services at Riverside North Chapels, Great Neck, NY, Monday, 10AM. Rest peacefully. Keith and Patti, Karen and David

title: Megan Quigley and Eric Gill

Antonius Jacobse and the Rev. Albert Jacobse, both uncles of the bridegroom and Roman Catholic priests, took part in the ceremony.

title: Choose: More Troops in Iraq Will (Help) (Hurt)
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq - IF, in time, the attempt to implant a pro-Western, democratic political system in Iraq ends up buried in the desert sands, historians will have no shortage of things that went wrong. Equally, if the problems here ultimately recede, supporters of the enterprise will find vindication in the Bush administration's decision to hold course as others lost faith.

title: Accusations by Tories Backfire in Canada
description: TORONTO, June 18 - A month after the Conservative Party tried to exploit a Liberal Party financial scandal to bring down Prime Minister Paul Martins government, the Tories are embroiled in a scandal of their own and are now stumbling in the polls.

title: John Hughes Versus the Vampires: The Dilemma of the Midnight Movie
description: THE IFC Center, which was scheduled to open Friday in the former home of the Waverly Theater in Greenwich Village, is a state-of-the art movie house, consisting of three theaters with plush seating and projection booths capable of showing 35 millimeter film and high-definition video. There is also to be a restaurant offering a full bar and upscale pub food, with menu items like Welsh rarebit, chilled soba noodles and warm baby spinach and oyster-mushroom salad. But one thing remains significantly retro: the midnight movie program.

description: Correction Appended

description: GREENPORT - "DON'T tell anyone," said Kathryn Simos, the publicist for the Icehouse Gallery and Screening Room, as she hid the key to the rough-looking industrial building in downtown Greenport. "We're short of keys."

title: U.S. and Allies Capture More Foreign Fighters
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 - American and Iraqi military forces in Iraq are capturing larger numbers of Saudis, Syrians and other foreign fighters, in a new indication that combatants from outside Iraq are playing a more prominent role in the increasingly violent insurgency, according to figures provided by the Army general in charge of detainee operations there.

title: Corrections; A Correction on School Budgets
description: An editorial last Sunday about school-budget voting misidentified the Hewlett-Woodmere School District as one of the Long Island districts criticized by a state audit over sloppy procedures. The office of the state comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, has investigated several school districts in the wake of the Roslyn financial scandal, but it has not conducted an audit of the Hewlett-Woodmere district or made any suggestion of impropriety or inadequacy in how it handles its budgets. A June 8 article in The Metro Section said otherwise, and the mistake was repeated on this page last week.

title: Go East, Young Man

title: The Quantitative, Data-Based, Risk-Massaging Road to Riches
description: I read with interest Joseph Nocera's article (June 5). I was surprised that the collapse a few years ago of Long-Term Capital Management was not mentioned. The situation precipitated by L.T.C.M. was so dire that some experts felt that the integrity of the entire American financial system was threatened. Clifford Asness's AQR Capital Management and L.T.C.M. share a number of attributes; both are based on quantitative analysis of markets and the underlying historical data spanning decades; both aim for good returns while minimizing risk. What is lost in the discussion of these sophisticated strategies is the basic fact that risk minimization is not risk elimination. If there is any probability at all that an event will happen, then eventually it will.

title: The Day the Music Died
description: DANNY AND THE JUNIORS had it wrong. Rock 'n' roll, the 1950's and 1960's high-charging, gyrating soundtrack to a generation of baby boomers, isn't here to stay. It wore out its welcome, a victim of age discrimination and corporate greed.

description: Michael Jackson avoided a potential prison term last week, but he cannot escape the passage of time, a sentence that befalls all pop stars. Or can he?

title: Steve Case's New Act: You've Got Revolution!
description: WITHOUT a trace of self-consciousness, Stephen M. Case calls his new company Revolution. "It struck me that Revolution might be a good name," he said, "because it does sort of summarize the approach we're trying to bring to bear, which is not an incremental, tweaking kind of thing, but really to take some risks and swing for the fences and to have a transformative impact on society, as well as to build significant businesses in the process."

title: Moon Glass and Magic Children
description: GENRE labels like "science fiction" and "fantasy" are conveniences for publishers, booksellers and readers in a hurry to pick up a reliable entertainment at an airport newsstand. What these labels actually mean is a prickly question. A friend in publishing argues that the distinguishing mark of fantasy is the presence of magic. But what counts as magic? No less an authority than Arthur C. Clarke has observed -- in a dictum known to his legions of fans as Clarke's Third Law -- that any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.

title: Court Backs Condos On Sale Restrictions
description: A SHORT, five-paragraph ruling rendered by a unanimous appellate court last month has taken many of New York's co-op and condominium lawyers by surprise. Indeed, some of those lawyers say, the decision blurs the differences between co-ops and condos and could be used to change the way condominium apartments are sold and leased.

title: PHOTO-OP
How to Sell in a Flash: Hold an Auction
description: LARRY KAGAN'S two-bedroom condominium in Plainview was bustling with activity last Sunday, a week after he sold it in a telephone auction to Chad and Michele Barnattan for $366,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEMAREST, ROSEMARY
description: DEMAREST -- Rosemary. Died June 6, 2005 in NYC age 91. Sister of the late William Demarest and late Daniel A. Demarest. Survived by nephew, David R. Demarest. Services St. James Church, Madison and 71 St, June 21, 3PM.

title: 'Cool Clothes and Marimba Lessons'
description: 1 The ice cream stores advertise happy hour. 2 And every April, a weeping cherry tree showers the house in pink. 3 Signed book galleys and self-help tomes are routinely left out on stoops for the taking. 4 A neighbor imports wine. 5 Another offers to pick up the kids from school. 6 PTA events are produced by ex-TV bigwigs, Washington insiders and Broadway stage managers. 7 Fresh Direct delivery. 8 Grown-ups envy their kids for having cool clothes and marimba lessons. 9 Dogs get their own water fountains. 10 Kids envy their friends for having two moms and six grandparents. 11 Little Mermaid and L.L. Bean snow boots are routinely left out on stoops for the taking. 12 And good thing the food co-op is here in case we ever have five and a half hours to spare. 13 Need a rush? Just try to cross at Grand Army Plaza. 14 Victorian ghosts haunt. 15 The knife sharpener truck also does skates. 16 Improved muscle tone from pushing the double stroller up and down the slope. 17 Spotting the pair of cardinals that hang out on the back fence means luck. 18 The fruit truck and Andy's free plum for the little ones. 19 It's Emma or Josh. No need to tax your memory. 20 There's the neighbor who will size up my spring garden and promptly replant everything. 21 Another who owns four orange cones and police tape. 22 We have soccer mom poets. 23 And soccer mom soccer players. 24 Even a slob like me is probably not the worst-dressed. 25 And I can see clouds, lots of clouds from my bed.

title: The Clowning, Wilding-Out Battle Dancers of South Central L.A.
description: Slabs of bass beat split the air, seeming to warp the walls as the Rice Track Family started dancing at the Silverado Park Teen Center one Sunday in May. Outside, dusk was falling on a mellow evening in Long Beach, Calif., the sort of night when fluke winds swirl in from the desert and ruffle the fronds of the royal palms, rousing the rats from the crowns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOLOWICZ, RUTH
description: JOLOWICZ--Ruth on June 12, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Devoted mother of Kathryn. Visiting at the Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87th St., NYC, Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Religious service at Immanuel Lutheran Church (88th St & Lexington Ave) on Wednesday, 10 AM. Intombment Trinity Mausoleum (Broadway and 153th Street, Manhattan).

While New Rochelle is defending a lawsuit in federal court over a new club in its downtown, Brewster is asking a state court to shut down a club that opened last fall.

The fact that school officials failed to plan for this contingency when announcing the rules does not make their behavior acceptable.

title: Bookshelf
description: THE HAPPY TROLL. By Max Bolliger. Translated by Nina Ignatowicz. Illustrated by Peter Ss. Holt. $16.95. (Ages 4 to 8) A Swiss fable about greed tells of Gus, a nice enough young troll famous for his lovely voice. One day, singing for a raven, he spies and covets a gold ring that leads him to crave other riches. Gaining golden things, he loses his voice and his friends, but finally finds his way back to simple happiness and song. The illustrations are enchanting.

description: George W. Bush may not have carried Newark in the 2004 election, but he has recently become a popular figure with a certain group of 5-, 6- and 7-year-olds there.

title: Aussie Accent in Park Slope
description: Daniel Johnnes, a Brooklynite who is wine director of Montrachet in TriBeCa, owns Jeroboam, which imports and distributes offbeat wines. His luscious 2004 Marquee riesling, with a candied scent and the flavor of stewed peaches, typifies Australia's increasingly popular dry rieslings. It is ideal for weekend meals in brownstone backyards. title: Starring the Redgrave-Burtons
description: Acting families don't get much more royal than the Redgraves and the Burtons. On Broadway alone, five members of the Redgrave clan and two Burtons have received a total of 13 Tony Award nominations and won 4 times. (That's one fewer nomination than Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy amassed between them, but some of the Redgraves and Burtons based their stage careers in Britain. And if you're going to include spouses, then you have to throw in the 10 nominations for Natasha Richardson's husband and former husband, Liam Neeson and the producer Robert Fox, and one for Elizabeth Taylor, Richard Burton's twice-former wife.) There is currently a Redgrave-Burton convergence on New York stages, with Lynn Redgrave and Kate Burton appearing in "The Constant Wife," Vanessa Redgrave in "Hecuba" and Natasha Richardson in "A Streetcar Named Desire." But it's not by any means the first time these two clans have crossed paths. Here's a short guide to intra- and interfamilial projects over the years.

title: 'I Feel Like a Native Son'
description: WHEN I moved to Fort Greene in 1985, you could hear the music of jazz giants like Cecil Taylor float out of brownstone windows and see Lester Bowie walk Willoughby Avenue in a white doctor's jacket. Branford and Wynton Marsalis gave parties near Pratt Institute. The actor Wesley Snipes gave smoky jams at his place off DeKalb. A local named Spike Lee was planning a cinematic revolt out of a tiny apartment off Myrtle, and he shot a color sequence for his mostly black-and-white movie "She's Gotta Have It" in Fort Greene Park.

title: Evocative Music to String Pearls By
description: CHARLES IVES has a well-deserved reputation as the ultimate maverick composer and flinty New England character. Still, in the flinty maverick department, another New England composer, the salty Carl Ruggles, holds his own. Born in 1876 to a whaling family on Cape Cod, Ruggles pursued music, in the words of Virgil Thomson, "without qualms about failure, poverty, disapproval, or what-will-people-say."

title: Many Are Keeping Wary Eyes on the Tide
description: FROM Maine to Massachusetts, a massive outbreak of toxic red tide has shut down the shellfishing industry. Commercial shell fishermen have been unable to work and restaurants are struggling to provide the fried clams, steamers and fresh oysters that tourists expect when visiting the coast. Massachusetts officials are looking for federal disaster aid to help compensate the industry for the worst outbreak in 33 years.

Somehow, in your imaginings of life in New York, the Jay Street/Borough Hall station never played a significant role. You resolve to get back across the bridge the first chance you get.

title: Where's Dad?

An information-technology manager and father of two in Palo Alto, Calif., Mr. De Jongh had a four-mile bicycle ride through the Stanford University campus as his commute. He often spent lunch at home with his wife and children, or even out on the golf course. He usually found himself pedaling up to his apartment at around 5:15 with the evening spread before him like a clean canvas.

title: Taliban Attack Afghan Officials

title: Family Ties
description: ALWAYS wear a tie clip to an autopsy. I learned that the hard way the other day, or nearly did, grabbing hold of the tip before it hit the body on the table, as I leaned in for a closer look. The medical examiner was showing me the dura and arachnoid, protective membranes between the skull and the brain, where blood had pooled after a skull fracture. If I'd gotten bloodstains on the tie, I would have had to throw it out, even though it had been my father's.

description: TREADWAY -- Margaret "Peggy" Hardwick. Died at her home in Vero Beach, FL, on June 11, 2005, after a short illness. title: Hotel Vitale in San Francisco
description: THE BASICS -- Opened in March, the $53 million Hotel Vitale is Joie de Vivre Hospitality's first luxury property and San Francisco's first all-new hotel since 2001. Seven years in the making, the hotel bills itself as "post-boutique chic." It's not just talk. The interior designer Colum McCartan eschews flashy trappings for a focus on natural comforts: muted, soothing blue, green, and cream tones, hallways lit by translucent leaf-patterned glass panels, and sprigs of eucalyptus and lavender bringing the outdoors in. Among Vitale's serene, California-style offerings are free yoga classes daily, kayaking weekends on the bay, and custom bath treatments on the roof. One highlight: outdoor terraces on the fifth and eighth floors, each with sweeping views of the San Francisco waterfront and the nearby Bay Bridge, enabling all guests (not just those with water-view rooms) to take in the city's beauty. The eight-floor brick building also houses Americano, a restaurant and bar serving locally influenced nouveau Italian dishes.

description: The caped crusader returned to theaters with a vengeance: "Batman Begins" (Warner Brothers), directed by Christopher Nolan and starring Christian Bale, right, was No. 1 at the box office over the weekend, with $46.9 million in three-day ticket sales. The film, which opened on Wednesday, made $71 million in its first five days, according to studio estimates. This suggests a strong comeback for the "Batman" franchise, whose luster was tarnished by "Batman and Robin" in 1997 with George Clooney wearing the cape, but the film's numbers were not quite enough to pull Hollywood out of its long box office slump: figures have been down from those of the previous year for several months now. "If these numbers hold," said Paul Dergarabedian, president of the box-office monitoring service Exhibitor Relations, noting that the figures are only estimates, "this will be the 17th down weekend in a row, matching 1985's record -- definitely a box office record that no one wants." This weekend's receipts were off 2 percent compared with last year. "Mr. and Mrs. Smith" (Fox), starring Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie, dropped to No. 2 with $27.3 million in its second week of release, bringing its cumulative sales to $97.9 million. Three holdovers rounded out the Top 5 this weekend: "Madagascar" (DreamWorks) took in $11.1 million, for total sales of $147.2 million; "Star Wars: Episode III -- Revenge of the Sith" (Fox) was No. 4 with $9.7 million, bringing its five-week cumulative sales to $348.8 million; and "The Longest Yard" (Paramount) was No. 5 with $8 million, for total receipts of $131.9 million. CATHERINE BILLEY

Paid Notice: Deaths   ARON, JACQUELINE, RPN
description: ARON--Jacqueline, RPN, age 64, a resident of Woodbridge, Virginia, passed away quietly following a long illness on June 17, 2005. A graduate of the St. Claire's Hospital School of Nursing, New York, Jackie received her Master's Degree in Philosophy from Fordham University in New York. She enjoyed a long and successful career as a professional nurse, specializing in the care of psychiatric patients. She had a lifelong history of helping others, giving generously of her time and compassion. As a youth in New York, she was a member of the Civil Air Patrol and a volunteer at several local hospitals. Later, she served as a couselor at a camp for blind cildren--a position for which she taught herself how to read and write Braille. Jackie was a longtime supporter of organizations assisting individuals with medical disorders, especially Tourette syndrome. She was the founder and President of Sunrise Support, Inc., a charitable organization dedicated to assisting and counseling individuals and families afflicted with Tourette's. At the time of her passing, she was a Director of the J. Aron Charitable Foundation, Inc., in New York. Jackie was the daughter of the late Jane and Jack R. Aron. She is survived by her loving son, Sean Patrick Aron, of Los Angeles, CA, her brothers, Peter A. of New York and Robert of Charlottesville, VA, and her dear friend Nicole "Niki" Hardin, also of Woodbridge, VA. A memorial service will be held 12 noon, Monday, June 20, 2005, at Price Funeral Home, 9609 Center St., Manassas, VA. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Jackie's memory to the Tourette Syndrome Association, Inc., at 42-40 Bell Blvd., Bayside, New York, 11361-2820 would be gratefully appreciated.

title: Corporate Profit vs. Public Safety
description: One of the first steps any sane person would take to guard against terrorism is to stop rail tankers filled with deadly chemicals from passing within a few blocks of the Capitol. If a rail tanker was attacked in downtown Washington, it could put every member of Congress -- and much of the rest of the city -- at risk of instant death. But the railroad industry, concerned with saving money, has blocked reasonable rules for the transport of extremely hazardous materials. Senator Joseph Biden, Democrat of Delaware, has just introduced a bill to fix this disturbing hole in our national defense. Every member of the Senate and House should be supporting it.

description: There's an age gap in daytime viewing. According to Nielsen's estimates for the week that ended June 10, in total viewers, CBS's full daytime lineup (4.22 million) dominated ABC's (3.17 million) and NBC's (2.82 million); the same order applied to the networks' soap opera hierarchy. But among women 18 to 49 -- advertisers' daytime demographic target-- ABC had the edge over the other two networks in both its full list of programming and its soaps. For the season as a whole, ABC's daytime-drama lineup is No. 1 among 18- to 49-year-old women. title: Playing it Fast, Furious and Full of Clarity
description: There are no speed barriers for Michel Camilo, the Dominican pianist who played a JVC Jazz Festival concert on Friday night at the Rose Theater. In solos, duos, trios and quartets, his hands flew across the keyboard. He played quick, clean-lined melodies and elegant two-part counterpoint, shimmering harplike arpeggios and percussive Afro-Cuban montunos. He played limpid ballad lines, splashy runs in block chords and volcanic two-handed tremolos. Sooner or later, even in the most pensive compositions, he found uses for velocity, whether for a filigreed ornament or a rippling backdrop.

The votes by the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee came just 10 days before the Legislature is required, by law, to produce a balanced budget. But the Senate and the Assembly, though both controlled by Democrats, do not agree on how much the rebates should total and whether any new taxes should be imposed. How those negotiations are resolved could have major political implications, and not just for the Assembly members who are facing re-election in November. Property taxes also figure to be a major issue in the race for governor this fall.

title: A House of Cards That Proves a Point
description: Dr. Jeannine Mosely was joking when she first suggested using business cards to build a Menger sponge. The structure, famous among mathematicians, is a three-dimensional fractal. That means, according to Dr. Mosely, who received her doctorate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, that "if you zoom in on a section of a fractal, the close-up view looks just like the bigger view." Fractals are infinite, in theory, so there is no end to zooming in. Dr. Mosely's sponge is not. It has big holes, medium holes and small holes, making it a Level 3 sponge. It is built of 66,048 cards, and she and countless helpers started work on it in 1996. It will be on exhibit this coming weekend in New York City, at the annual Origami U.S.A. convention at the Fashion Institute of Technology. (The convention is open only to members of Origami U.S.A.)

title: Depressed Domestic Fares
description: DEPRESSED DOMESTIC FARES -- Despite small, incremental fare increases imposed half a dozen times so far this year by major domestic carriers, the average domestic one-way air fare paid during the first quarter of 2005 was $202, which is 13 percent lower than the $234 average in the period last year, according to the American Express Business Travel Monitor. The survey, which reflects fares paid by clients of American Express Business Travel, a corporate travel management company, encompasses first-class, unrestricted coach and discount coach tickets. American Express said that fares were depressed because of continuing competitive rate cuts on many routes, as well as aggressive corporate negotiating on fares. The recent rounds of fare increases appear to be having an effect, though. In April, the average domestic one-way fare was $210, up $8 from the first-quarter average, American Express said. By comparison, for all of 2000, the average domestic one-way fare was $259. International fares are going up, meanwhile. On 160 monitored routes, the average fare rose 4 percent in the first quarter of 2005, largely reflecting strong demand for business-class and first-class travel.

Paid Notice: Deaths   REED, J.D.
description: REED--J.D. Of Princeton, NJ. October 7, 1940-June 15, 2005. Poet, novelist and journalist, J.D. Reed died of a heart attack at his home in Princeton, NJ, on June 15, at 64 years old. Mr. Reed who won a Guggenheim Award for his book of poetry, Expressways, in 1970, taught creative writing at the University of Massachusetts in the 1970's. He had two novels published, one made into a major motion picture. His 30 year career in journalism, included 25 years on staff for Sports Illustrated, Time, and People magazines. His writing illustrated his love of American geography, from his early poetry to his most recent book, Stairway to Heaven, being published by Rolling Stone this fall. A native of Michigan, Mr. Reed attended Albion College and Michigan State University and received a M.F.A. from the University of Montana where he studied with poet Dick Hugo. He lived with his family in Princeton NJ since 1977. Mr. Reed is survived by his wife, Christine Reed, and by his three daughters, Phoebe Reed, Alicia Reed, and Gabrielle Reed. A memorial service will be held Saturday, July 9 at 11:00 AM at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation of Princeton, 50 Cherry Hill Road.

"It's alive!" he screams as men in white coats drag him into the back of an ambulance. But Trip isn't crazy.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Zapatista Rebels Go On Alert
description: More than 11 years since the start of its fight against the government, the Zapatista National Liberation Army declared a "red alert" in the predominantly Indian villages it occupies in the southern state of Chiapas, sent its leaders into hiding and urged all others to evacuate those areas. It was an ominous dispatch from the rebels, bringing a burst of national attention to the Indians' all-but-forgotten cause and raising concerns of clashes between the Zapatistas and pro-government paramilitary groups. In another communiqu, the rebels said they had declared the alert to complete a reorganization of their forces and announced that they were preparing to consult with their bases on the future course of the movement. Ginger Thompson (NYT)
