title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: De Niro's Maid Is Accused Of Theft
description: A Queens woman who worked as a maid was arrested on Monday evening and charged with stealing from three of her employers, Manhattan prosecutors said yesterday. They said the maid, Lucyna Turyk-Wawrynowicz, 25, of Maspeth, was held on charges of grand larceny, criminal possession of stolen property, coercion and forgery. Bail was set at $150,000. Prosecutors said she stole over several years from her employers, who, one official said, included Robert De Niro and his wife, Grace Hightower. The official said that Ms. Turyk-Wawrynowicz stole a pair of diamond earrings worth $95,000 that belonged to Ms. Hightower. Prosecutors said that over 10 days in 2001, she used another employer's credit card 16 times at Barneys. The earrings, as well as the jacket of another employer, were recovered from her home on Monday night, prosecutors said. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

description: JACOBSON--Bernice and Sidney. Passed away on June 21, 2005. Beloved wife and husband. Devoted parents of Marjorie and Mark Gershwind, and Mitchell and Kathy Jacobson. We love you with all our hearts and will think of you everyday for the rest of our lives. Love and millions of kisses, Margie and Mark JACOBSON--Bernice and Sidney. Mom and Dad, you can rest in peace knowing that you were great parents, inspirational role models and loved by all your family. You will be in our hearts forever and ever. Love, Mitchell, Kathy and Joshua JACOBSON--Bernice and Sidney. Nanny and Poppa, you were second parents to all of us. Your love, devotion and wisdom was and always will be a constant in our lives. Love, Erik, Stacey and Joshua JACOBSON--Bernice & Sidney. Our hearts are heavy at the loss of our dear friends' parents, Bernice and Sidney. Their devotion, kindness and generosity to all charities is an inspiration to all of us. Our deepest condolences to Margie and Mark, Cathy, Mitchell and Josh, Stacey, Michael, Betsey and Bradley, Jackie, Erick, Jake and Sophie. Our entire family will miss their warmth, wisdom and guidance. May they rest in peace. Lissy and Allen, Lauren and Phil, Meryl, B.J., and Mia, Selma and Millicent. JACOBSON--Bernice and Sid. We are so saddened by the loss of Bernice and Sid. Our hearts go out to Margie, Mitchell and the family. We, too, will miss them. I will miss you. Rest in peace. Love Pat Markowitz JACOBSON--Bernice and Sidney. To the most devoted and loving family, our thoughts and prayers are with you. Diane Lederman and Frank Lederman JACOBSON--Sidney and Bernice, whose endearing love will live on with those who knew them well. The Board of Directors and Associates of The Tiffen Company wish to express their deepest condolences and sorrow to the Gershwin and Jacobson families at the loss of Sid and Bernice Jacobson. The Board of Directors The Tiffen Company JACOBSON--Sidney and Bernice. The Palm Beach Country Club has suffered a grievous and irreparable loss in the sudden passing of our esteemed and beloved former president, Sidney Jacobson and Bernice, his wife, partner, and lover for fifty-nine years. Throughout his long illness, Sidney's kind and gentle demeanor never changed as he gave us a lesson in courage and stoicism, while Bernice taught us the true meaning of love and caring. Now they continue to be one in death as they were in life, leaving us with a void that can never be filled. They left this world together in an embrace that will last through eternity and they have gone to make even Heaven a better place. Michael Stein, President Stephen Fiverson, Secretary JACOBSON--Sidney and Bernice. Dear, dear friends, we have known you over 50 years, during which time you have enriched our lives with your friendship and love. The Jewish community has lost a treasure with your passing away. Your devotion to Israel and Jewish causes here at home and abroad has been outstanding and will always be remembered. You will be deeply missed. Rest in peace. Phyllis and Joseph Gurwin JACOBSON--Sidney. I will always treasure the note you wrote to me extolling our mutual, deep friendship and love for each other. You concluded by saying you always felt secure when I was in the same room with you. Now you are in the hands of God. He will give you your security and appreciate your kindness and humaneness. Rest in peace. Harry Markowitz JACOBSON--Sidney and Bernice. The Tiffen, Cohen and Mendelson families wish to express their deepest condolences and sorrow to the Gershwin and Jacobson families at the loss of Sid and Bernice Jacobson. To Margie, Mark, Mitchell, Kathy, Erik, Jackie, Stacey and Michael, our deepest condolences upon the loss of your parents and grandparents. We know how special they were to you and they will be missed. Love. Paul and Jeannie Karlitz JACOBSON--Sidney and Bernice. In loving memory of Sidney & Bernice Jacobson. You have always been a part of our lives and will forever be in our hearts. The Libshutz and Rosier Families JACOBSON--Sidney and Bernice. A magnificent couple in life. Together always. title: Arts, Briefly; Redesign Approved For Avery Fisher Hall

"I've been in the music business my whole life and recognize there's no better way to reach the music listener than through radio," he said in a statement. title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: 'Iron Lady' Is New Chief Of Staff

Ms. Rousseff, 57, the first woman to hold the powerful post of top aide to the president, is an economist and former guerrilla who was tortured and jailed for three years under the country's military rule. Called the Joan of Arc of Urban Warfare at that time, she is known by other nicknames these days, including Iron Lady of Braslia and The Bulldog. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIDOFF, DEBORAH ELAINE (NEE WEBBER)
description: DAVIDOFF--Deborah Elaine (nee Webber), age 81, died June 15, 2005, in Madison, WI. She was born on October 6, 1923, in Kansas City, Missouri, to Morris and Anna Webber. She graduated from the University of Wisconsin-Madison in 1944 and moved to New York City in 1947. She married her beloved husband, Dr. Leonard Davidoff, in 1951, received her Master's Degree in library science from C.W. Post College and ran the reference desk at the Bellmore Memorial Library for 20 years. She is survived by her children, Judith Davidoff (Kelly) and Andrew Davidoff (Ilyse); her grandchildren, Jordan, Ian and Lauren Davidoff; and her sister, Samene Lesser, and brother-in-law, Joseph Lesser. She is further survived by loving nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends. She was preceded in death by her husband, parents, brothers, Sam and Joseph, and sister, Ronah. Private family services have been held. Contributions in Deborah's memory may be made to the Madison Public Library Foundation.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: 7 Killed, 100 Hurt In Train Crash
description: At least 7 people were killed and more than 150 injured when a passenger train and a truck collided at a dirt-road crossing south of Tel Aviv, rescue officials said. The truck, loaded with coal ash, slammed into the front section of the train, driving two train cars off the tracks and into a field near Kibbutz Revadim, according to rescue workers and railroad officials. Rescue workers climbed into mangled train cars to remove the injured, and helicopters flew them to hospitals. Israeli officials called it one of the worst train disasters in the country's history. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Current-Account Surplus Narrows
description: Brazil's current-account surplus narrowed in May as Brazilian operations of foreign companies took advantage of a strong Brazilian currency to send profits home as remittances and dividends. That trend, along with a rise in imports fostered by the currency, somewhat offset a continuing increase in exports, the central bank said. The current account, the broadest measure of a country's trade in goods and services, was $615 million last month, down from a surplus of $757 million in April and $1.47 billion in May a year earlier. Foreign direct investment also fell, dropping to $711 million from $3.04 billion in April, though it is expected to bounce back slightly in June. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Presidential Plans For 2008?
description: Gov. Mitt Romney made his strongest suggestion to date that he was considering running for president in 2008. Mr. Romney, a Republican who has attended numerous party fund-raisers around the country recently, said outside a health care event that it was a "fair characterization" to say "the governor's testing the national waters," but that at the moment he was planning to run next year for a second term as governor and would make a final decision in the fall. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Smithsonian Renovations
description: The Smithsonian's National Museum of American History is weighing whether its extensive renovation will be done in phases or all at once, forcing it to close temporarily. The project, to be designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, is to include a new gallery for the Star-Spangled Banner and improvements to the 40-year-old museum's infrastructure. Neither a start date nor a long-term timetable has been determined, the museum said yesterday. Valeska Hilbig, a museum spokeswoman, said the project had no firm price tag but would be financed with private and public funds. The institution's Web site says, "The museum hopes to invest $300 million in the revitalization of the building and its exhibitions." Designed by Walker Cain of McKim, Mead & White, the museum opened in 1964 as the Museum of History and Technology. It was renamed in 1980. ROBIN POGREBIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENEDICT, JANE
description: BENEDICT -- Jane. Board Members, staff and volunteers of the Metropolitan Council on Housing were deeply saddened by the death of founder and longtime chair Jane Benedict on Saturday, June 18, 2005, at the age of 93. Jane was unflagging in the fight for tenants' rights and a passionate and persistent advocate for ecomonic and social justice across the board. At Met Council, she was not only an inspirational leader but also our energy, our teacher, our mentor, and our dear friend. Our love for her and her late husband, Peter Hawley, is matched by the dedication to activism and justice she instilled in all of us.

Formerly of South Orange and Deal, N.J. Graduate Newark Academy, 1963; Miami University, 1969. Marketing executive with Benrus, Waltham-Jules Jurgenson Watch Companies.

title: For a Slice Extraordinaire, An Extraordinary Slice Joint
description: Since Beacon opened on West 56th Street six years ago, Waldy Malouf has spent much of his time near a wood-burning oven, shoveling food in and out of it with a long wooden peel. The opening Friday of Waldy's Wood-Fired Pizza and Penne, 800 Avenue of the Americas (27th Street) changes none of this, merely expands it. Mr. Malouf, above, the chef and an owner at Beacon, owns the new place, which he calls a "slice joint," with Rob Dixon. What other slice joint offers 11 different pizzas in two sizes of rectangles and also as a single-serving quarter-pie? In addition to the classic margherita, Mr. Malouf makes a pizza with arugula, garlic, fried egg and cheese, and one topped with braised lamb, roasted lemon and oregano. It may be the only pizza place with pots of fresh basil and oregano for customers to snip and garnish their slices. Wood-fired penne dishes with cheese are also on the menu. Open daily: (212)213-5042.

title: Meals in the Bush, Now With Fine Wines
description: SATARA, South Africa - GUESS what? Some of South Africa's choicest wines and most satisfying food are served far from the bright lights of Cape Town, right in the midst of the wilderness, along a shimmering stream called the N'wanetsi, where hippopotamuses frolic, crocodiles slither and vivid birds of several hundred species fill the air with their trills.

title: Celebrities Working Hard to Seem Light on Their Feet
description: "If you stay in the competition, you have to concentrate on extending your line and holding your posture all the way through," counseled Bruno Tonioli, the riotously expressive Italian judge on ABC's breakout summer hit, "Dancing With the Stars." Mr. Tonioli, pounding the table for emphasis, was critiquing Kelly Monaco of "General Hospital" after her performance of the rumba during the show. To demonstrate proper arm extension and the musically sensitive follow-through that dancers call "articulation," he amusingly used his own wingspan.

description: SHANGHAI, Thursday, June 23 - A Chinese state-controlled oil company made a $18.5 billion unsolicited bid for Unocal today, igniting the first-ever takeover battle between corporations in China and the United States.

title: Mime and Acting and Lavish Sets, and a Back Story, Too
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 - It was probably all to the good that we had to wait so long to see Balanchine's "Don Quixote" again. Forty years after its creation, 27 years after it was last seen at the New York City Ballet, it was finally revived - recreated, reborn - on Wednesday night at the Kennedy Center.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Medical School Settles Suit
description: Weill Medical College of Cornell University agreed yesterday to pay nearly $4.4 million to settle federal charges that it cheated the government by misusing millions of dollars of a National Institutes of Health grant it received to run the Children's Clinical Research Center Under the agreement, the college admitted no wrongdoing in the civil case, which began in 2003 when a whistle-blower at the college told federal prosecutors that she had come across misconduct dating back to 1995 in the college's handling of the federal grant. Court documents identified the whistle-blower as Kyriakie Sarafoglou, an assistant professor of pediatric medicine. In a civil complaint filed last week, the college was accused of defrauding the government and making false statements to the institutes in connection with the grant. In a statement, the college said, "There were no issues about the quality or integrity of the research."

HSBC will acquire the store-card accounts and their outstanding balances, Bon-Ton said. HSBC is based in London. Bon-Ton, which operates department stores in the Northeast and Midwest, said that it would close its corporate credit center, eliminating 84 jobs, on or about Nov. 1. Bon-Ton is based in York, Pa.

Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Motorcyclist Trapped Under Fire Truck
description: A motorcyclist who braked to avoid hitting a fire engine last night was thrown from the cycle and briefly trapped under the engine, fire officials said. The accident happened shortly after 8:30 p.m. at Driggs Avenue and Broadway in Williamsburg. Engine Company 221, heading west on Driggs Avenue to a rubbish fire at a synagogue, had the green light but slowed to enter the intersection, Deputy Chief Michael Marrone said. The motorcyclist, Jens Orrillo, 35, traveling south on Broadway, pitched over the handlebars. He was listed in serious condition at Bellevue Hospital Center.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Floods Kill 51
description: Severe flooding in northern Afghanistan has killed 51 people and affected 4,000 families, said the minister of rural development, Hanif Atmar. The flooding, caused by a sudden rise in the rivers from snow melt, swept away houses, roads and livestock, he said. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Extending Democracy to Ex-Offenders
description: The laws that strip ex-offenders of the right to vote across the United States are the shame of the democratic world. Of an estimated five million Americans who were barred from voting in the last presidential election, a majority would have been able to vote if they had been citizens of countries like Britain, France, Germany or Australia. Many nations take the franchise so seriously that they arrange for people to cast ballots while being held in prison. In the United States, by contrast, inmates can vote only in two states, Maine and Vermont.

title: Queens Muslim Group Says It Opposes Violence, and America
description: The young Muslim men, with beards and bullhorns, work the streets of Jackson Heights on the weekends. They surface at parades and protests around the city, loudly declaring America the enemy and advocating for an Islamic state. Several weeks ago, they publicly tore up an American flag as payback for the reported desecration of the Koran at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. Their own videos of violence against Muslims, one with the title "Muslim Massacres," have recently appeared on Queens Public Television.

title: Pinpointing a Composer in the Act of Metamorphosis
description: Generations of listeners have learned this lesson with just about every composer from Beethoven through Coltrane, but here it is again: Given persistent advocates, even the most difficult music will eventually seem mainstream. For many people, Elliott Carter isn't quite there yet, but the time may not be far off. These days, and certainly since his 95th birthday, in 2003, Mr. Carter's music has been everywhere, and not only in new-music concerts.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Governor Vetoes Wall Around Rio Slums
description: The governor of Rio de Janeiro has revoked a plan approved by the state legislature to build a six-and-a-half-foot wall along some main thoroughfares in Rio to block them off from squatter slums. Lawmakers had endorsed the proposal to shield motorists from the gun battles that often break out between drug trafficking gangs in the slums and to obstruct robbers who assault commuters. But the governor, Rosinha Mateus, said in her veto of the measure that the plan "would be a form of discrimination against good citizens who make up the vast majority of these communities." Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Former Klansman Guilty of Manslaughter in 1964 Deaths
description: PHILADELPHIA, Miss., June 21 - In what is likely to be the final chapter in a story that has troubled a generation, a jury pronounced Edgar Ray Killen guilty of manslaughter on Tuesday in the deaths of three young and idealistic civil rights workers who disappeared on a summer night here exactly 41 years ago.

title: The Reward of Good Weather
description: Weather is not primarily a moral affair. We do not deserve a long, slow patch of hot weather, like the one that sat on the city in early June, any more than we deserve the extraordinarily beautiful evenings that have come with these longest days of the year. Deserving has nothing to do with it. The weather comes, it goes, and sometimes it's occluded. The days of seeing the wrath of God in a prolonged drought or a heavy windstorm -- believing that bad weather chastens our bad actions, in other words -- are pretty much past. One sobering irony of global warming is the thought that it threatens to make weather moral again in a very different way.

title: Jerk Pork to Dim Sum: A Queens Dining Tour
description: "Eating Like Queens" by Suzanne Parker (Jones Books, $16.95) offers a 40-cuisine tour of the city's most ethnically diverse borough. The book, being published this week, is organized by country or region: six Chinese regions are represented, for example, plus categories like Caribbean-Chinese and kosher Chinese. There are descriptions of the food in places like Flushing, Jackson Heights or Corona, and a list of restaurants and food stands for each type of cuisine. Indexes sort the material by neighborhood, cuisine, restaurant and type of dish; maps are included.

title: Taking Chances on Two Sides of a River
description: PENNS GROVE, N.J. - Standing on the east bank of the Delaware River in this depressed town, next to boarded-up commercial buildings and an abandoned ferry pier, it is hard to imagine the time when the waterway was a playground for the rich and famous. But developers on both sides of the river are now hoping to turn back time with new projects that depend, in part, on an expansion of gambling in Delaware.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hammonton: Helicopter Wreckage Found
description: The wreckage of a small helicopter that disappeared over New Jersey last weekend was discovered in a wooded area near the Atlantic City Expressway yesterday, authorities said. title: From the Catskills, a Rakish Italian Visitor
description: Imagine long, green fennel fronds supersized, and you have agretti, an esoteric Italian vegetable that is especially prized around Rome. It's also called barba di frate (monk's beard). Crunchy and a bit grassy when raw, these greens are better braised, when they have a mild flavor suggesting chives, with some of the astringency of spinach. Rick Bishop grows them in the Catskills, and they are sold at Agata & Valentina for $2.99 for 4 ounces, and at Dean & DeLuca for $3.99 for 4 ounces. That is enough to serve two when simply braised, or four when cooked and used as a topping for fish or tossed with pasta. I cut the branches in thirds, tossed them in a skillet with two tablespoons of olive oil, five cloves of sliced garlic, about a cup of thinly sliced sweet onion and a tablespoon of pine nuts, covered the pan and let the agretti cook about 5 minutes. I seasoned the dish with salt and pepper and a splash of balsamic vinegar and sat down to a feast.

title: Verse Film Pits Love Against the Clash of Cultures

It is written in verse (iambic pentameter), one of the few films to use an unusual form of dialogue. (Two others are "Force of Evil," 1948, in blank verse, and "The Umbrellas of Cherbourg," 1964, which is sung through.) "Yes" has two main characters, She (Ms. Allen), an Irish-American, and He (Mr. Abkarian), an Arab from Beirut, who begin an affair in London and end it in Havana. Mr. Neill plays She's husband. On a recent visit to New York, Ms. Potter talked to Annette Grant about making "Yes."

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Growth Forecast Is Lowered
description: France's finance minister, Thierry Breton, reduced his forecast for growth this year to less than 2 percent from a range of 2 percent to 2.5 percent. The reduction was the second in three months. He said that his biggest concern for the French economy was that its rising debt level was not sustainable and that the French need to work more to pay for their social benefits system. "We must have the courage to say that France today lives beyond its means," Mr. Breton said. "Next year, for the first time in our history, revenue from income taxes will be equivalent to the interest payments of France's debt." The costs of social benefits have helped debt rise to a record 66 percent of gross domestic product, Mr. Breton said.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Segregation And Racial Inequality
description: Segregation and inequality between blacks and whites in areas like housing, education, income and employment are persistent problems in Chicago, according to a study by the city's chapter of the Urban League. The study found that 13 of the city's 15 richest neighborhoods were disproportionately white, while 12 of the city's 15 poorest neighborhoods were disproportionately black. The study also found that the city's 22 predominantly black neighborhoods had an unemployment rate almost twice that of the city as a whole. Also, from 1970 to 2000, the median family income in Chicago rose by 2 percent for blacks, compared with 19 percent for whites and 16 percent for Latinos. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

description: All the manly charms of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi were not enough to keep Italy's ambassador to Finland out of trouble. The ambassador was summoned to the Finnish Foreign Ministry after Mr. Berlusconi revealed his techniques for persuading the Finnish president, Tarja Halonen, to give up her country's bid, in favor of Italy, as home of the European Union's food safety office. "I had to use all my playboy tactics, even if they have not been used for some time," Mr. Berlusconi said at the opening of the new office in Parma on Tuesday. In 2001, in the midst of the duel over which country would be assigned the office, Mr. Berlusconi staked a claim to Italian culinary supremacy, saying, "Finns don't even know what prosciutto is." On Tuesday, he disparaged Finnish food again. "I've been to Finland and I had to endure the Finnish diet, so I am in a position to make a comparison," he said. News accounts differed on whether he was most offended by smoked reindeer or smoked herring. Ian Fisher (NYT)

description: On Tuesday, the Detroit Pistons forced a Game 7 in the N.B.A. finals by beating the San Antonio Spurs, and the broadcast put ABC in first place among total viewers and adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen's estimates, ABC's lead in viewers was slim, however, barely beating CBS's three-hour broadcast of "A.F.I.'s 100 Years 100 Movie Quotes," which drew an audience of 9 million. NBC won the 8 p.m. hour with a "Dateline" special (8.56 million) in which Katie Couric interviewed Jennifer Wilbanks, the "runaway bride." That lead failed to benefit the series premiere of "I Want to Be a Hilton." The first episode of the etiquette-lesson reality show, in which 14 contestants learned how to eat escargots and make conversation with Billy Bush of "Access Hollywood," attracted only 6.79 million viewers and finished fourth in the 18-to-49 demographic. title: Back to Nature, and What a Mess

title: Safin Enjoys His Surprisingly Swift Run on the Grass
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 22 - For anyone who was sitting with Marat Safin in a small interview room that seemed much more like a psychiatrist's couch at the All England Club last year, it was easy to rub the eyes Wednesday and wonder whether Safin, the erratic and endearing Russian who swore off grass forevermore in 2004, was really the same erratic and endearing man who was rolling into the third round of this year's Wimbledon without losing a set.

title: The Twinkle of an Eyelash, With a Blink of Mink
description: It is difficult to wear false eyelashes made of red fox fur and have almost everyone fail to notice. Jennifer Lopez achieved this feat at the 2001 Academy Awards, by combining her ostentatious eyelash couture with a dress that was see-through on top.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Lawyer Sentenced For Theft From Clients
description: A disbarred lawyer from Long Island was sentenced yesterday to two to six years in prison for bilking 47 former clients of $4.8 million. Jay Rosen, 62, of Oyster Bay, pleaded guilty in March to second-degree larceny. He was ordered to make restitution to the New York State Lawyers' Fund for Client Protection, which reimburses victims of dishonest lawyers. But a spokesman for the Nassau County district attorney said Mr. Rosen had no assets. and had spent his clients' money on an extravagant lifestyle. Julia C. Mead (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: A Law Backfires, Leaving Romanian Orphans in Limbo To protect children, Romania effectively banned international adoptions, which were popular with American and European applicants. The children may spend their lives in orphanages, like this one in Bucharest. PAGE A6

title: International Donors Pledge to Step Up Their Efforts to Provide Financial Aid for Iraq
description: BRUSSELS, June 22 - Officials at an international conference of more than 80 nations and organizations pledged Wednesday to reinvigorate their lagging efforts to provide financial aid and debt relief for Iraq, and they urged Iraqi leaders to make more efforts to reach out politically to disaffected minorities supporting the insurgency.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Wantagh: 3 Dead And 12 Hurt In Crash
description: Three people were killed and 12 others injured yesterday when the van in which they were riding was struck by a car on the Southern State Parkway and crashed, the state police said. The driver of the car, a BMW, drove away after the accident, which occurred at 6:30 a.m. in the eastbound lanes near the Wantagh Avenue exit, and was being sought last night. The names of the victims were withheld until their families could be notified. The state police asked any witnesses to call 631-756-3300. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

But the price of that storage has been at a level only professional photographers or serious amateurs could afford. Now Seagate has joined the storage competition with an innovative hard drive that holds eight gigabytes for under $300.

Gorgeous Summer (Rachel Bilson) wants to work with Seth and his pal Zach (Michael Cassidy) on their idea for a comic book about their lives. description: Several articles early this year about a Navy submarine that crashed into an undersea mountain in the Pacific Ocean on Jan. 8 misstated the precise location. It was just north of the Equator, not in the South Pacific. The error appeared on Jan. 11, 12, 15 and 23, Feb. 12 and March 13. The location, first classified, was later specified by the Navy as 7 degrees 44.7 minutes north latitude and 147 degrees 11.6 minutes east longitude.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Power Failure Shuts Rail Network
description: The state rail network ground to a halt for four hours because of an electric failure, stranding hundreds of thousands of commuters during the evening rush hour. People were left on platforms or stuck in carriages on a day when temperatures soared to 90 degrees. "Trains are halted across the whole network," Swiss Federal Railways said in a statement. The shutdown was caused by a power failure at 5:45 p.m. local time on part of the track in the southern Italian-speaking part of the country. The trains were back running at 9:30 p.m. but with delays. The system normally runs like clockwork, and the Swiss are among the world's most avid rail travelers. Earlier this year, the state network introduced a timetable to help shave minutes off journeys. Tom Wright (NYT)

The company cleans the banners and attaches simple hanging systems before selling them for home use; their quantity is limited to the number produced for promotional purposes.

title: Bucking a Trend: Theater for $15
description: The Signature Theater Company, the Off Broadway troupe known for devoting entire seasons to a single playwright, has laid out its plans for its 15th-anniversary season. It will include a new play by August Wilson, old plays by August Wilson and a one-man show by August Wilson, starring August Wilson.

title: Grown-Up Boys' Wear for Bar or Barricades

title: European Leaders Intensify Criticism of Blair's Priorities
description: BRUSSELS, June 22 - Jos Manuel Barroso, the leader of the European Union's administrative entity, put himself on a collision course with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain on Wednesday by casting doubt on whether the group could move forward with changes in the budget process or further expansion.

title: From the Ashes
description: SOMETIMES it seems that the most important quality an architect can possess is optimism. For example, it took 12 years for the Jewish Museum I designed in Berlin to finally open to the public. A few hours later it had to close. The date: Tuesday, Sept. 11, 2001. That jarring confluence of events not only predated but also presaged my role in rebuilding ground zero. And the memories of what we went through in Berlin give me confidence that we will succeed in New York as well.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Shellfish Ban Extended
description: Shellfish beds will remain closed for at least another month because of red tide, a toxic algae. The state's shellfish biologist, J. Michael Hickey, said that under ideal conditions the algae would bloom for another two weeks and the shellfish would probably spend a few weeks trying to eliminate the toxins. Officials will reopen the beds if they test below harmful levels three times over two weeks. Mr. Hickey said some toxin levels in shellfish on the North Shore had started to drop, signaling a dying bloom. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Free flow: Concerns about toll of giant span
A Pool Once a Playground for Stars Is Restored in Saratoga Springs
description: The first heated pool in America was not a tycoon's private indulgence but rather a public spa: the Victoria Pool, built by New York State in 1935 at Saratoga Springs. Jean Harlow and Ethel Barrymore were among the celebrities who sunbathed on its limestone deck, surrounded by Georgian Revival pavilions and arcades. The pool reopens July 2 after a three-year, $2 million facelift. Lion-head fountains spout water again, and lilacs and daylilies line the limestone paths. But the water is still chilly, as it has been for some 60 years; the 1930's boilers proved so costly to operate that the state shut them. The New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation says it hopes to install an alternative energy source within a year or two. Victoria Pool, Saratoga Spa State Park, (518)584-2000, saratogaspastatepark.org.

Also survived by grandchildren Alexis and Matthew, his sister and brother-in-law Phyllis and Herbert Kane and companion Brenda Glasberg.

title: Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: Coldplay Holds at No. 1
description: Last week Coldplay's "X&Y" (Capitol) opened big on the Billboard album chart, with well more than double the sales of its nearest competitor. This week it has held on to the No. 1 spot, though with a much narrower margin. "X&Y" had sales of 323,000, and the Foo Fighters' new double album, "In Your Honor" (RCA), is at No. 2 with 311,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The Backstreet Boys' "Never Gone" (Jive) reached No. 3, selling 290,000 copies; that might sound like a lot, but comparing it with its last album, "Black & Blue" -- which sold 1.6 million copies in its first week of release, in November 2000 -- is a sobering reminder that the boy-band era is past its peak. Down the chart, Fat Joe's "All or Nothing" (Atlantic) opened at No. 6 with 106,000 sales. Meanwhile, Alanis Morissette's "Jagged Little Pill Acoustic" (Maverick/Warner Brothers) sold more than 61,000 copies at Starbucks stores, according to that company, which has the exclusive right to sell the album for its first six weeks. But Billboard said it would be ineligible for the magazine's main album chart until its release to other retailers on July 26. BEN SISARIO

description: WASHINGTON, June 22 - The Securities and Exchange Commission will meet next Wednesday to reconsider a rule requiring mutual funds to have an independent chairman, the commssion said Wednesday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Pope To Call Synod On Africa
description: Pope Benedict XVI said he would call a special meeting of bishops to discuss Africa, where Catholicism is growing faster than on any other continent. He did not announce a date for the meeting. The church's efforts to ease poverty and ill health in Africa are widespread and praised, but the Vatican's opposition to condom use to halt the spread of AIDS remains a contentious issue both in and outside the church. Ian Fisher (NYT)

The collection includes sofas and chairs, divided into groups called Eileen (above left), Florence (center) and Charlotte. All are slightly familiar yet completely new. "I stand on the shoulders of these three women," Ms. Barry said. The chairs have maple frames in a choice of 16 finishes; retail prices range from $1,695 to $5,730. For locations of showrooms (to the trade) in Los Angeles, New York, Chicago and elsewhere, go to hbf.com, or call (828)328-2064 for information. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

Babe Ruth's contract, which sent him from the Red Sox to the Yankees in 1919, went for nearly $1 million. A 1913 Liberty Head nickel went for $4.15 million, up from $3 million a year earlier. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Hugo Boss Shifting Focus
description: Bruno E. Slzer, chief executive of Hugo Boss, said he expected the company, Germany's largest clothing maker, to double accessories sales in the next five years to compete with brands like Gucci and Prada. Boss is betting it can increase sales of shoes and accessories for men and women to 15 percent of global turnover by 2010, Mr. Slzer, above, said in Florence, Italy, where he was presenting the company's men's wear collections. "We have already been very active in expanding the accessories business, and it's already very profitable for us," Mr. Slzer said. "In today's market, accessories are important for the style and the identity of the brand." Hugo Boss, based in Metzingen, is expanding its two shoes and accessories factories, in Italy and Poland, Mr. Slzer said. Accessories are more profitable than apparel because they do not have the same sizing and fitting requirements.

Jodi Rell said on Wednesday that she had the "vision" and public approval to run for a full term in 2006. She could announce her plans by Labor Day, she said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Blood Bank Seeks Emergency Donors
description: Blood supplies are so low that the New York Blood Center is rationing certain blood types to local hospitals, center officials said this week. The types being rationed include O positive, O negative, A negative and B negative, the center said. The officials said that donations were 25 percent less than expected, and they were seeking donors to make up the shortfall. The center, the country's largest nonprofit blood bank, serves 200 hospitals in New York and New Jersey.

title: Shell's Chief Reaffirms Goal of 30% More Output by 2015
description: LONDON, June 22 - Jeroen van der Veer, chief of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, said Wednesday that the company would spend more on research, focus on big technology-driven projects and possibly acquire other oil producers and reserves to increase production by 30 percent as planned by 2015.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Sunlight-Powered Spacecraft May Be Lost
description: The first spacecraft designed to be propelled by sunlight has apparently been lost because of the failure of a booster rocket, officials said. The Russian Space Agency said the first stage of the Volna rocket failed 83 seconds after its launching on Tuesday from a submarine in the Barents Sea. Dr. Louis D. Friedman of the Planetary Society, the private American group that sponsored the $4million project, said the Cosmos1 solar sail vessel was probably destroyed. Warren E. Leary (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bombing Report Harshly Critical Of Aznar
description: After a yearlong inquiry, a parliamentary commission investigating the March 11, 2004, train bombings in Madrid that killed 191 people unanimously approved 150 recommendations for protecting Spain from further attacks but split along party lines over whether the attacks could have been prevented. The report's most explosive charges -- that the previous government of the former prime minister, Jos Mara Aznar, ignored signs that the terror attacks were coming and manipulated evidence to blame the separatist group ETA rather than Islamic militants -- were rejected by commission members from his Popular Party. The recommendations include adding more resources to fight illegal immigration, monitoring the movement of explosives more closely and improving cooperation among law-enforcement agencies. Parliament is expected to vote on the findings next week. Renwick McLean (NYT)

Like many adolescent girls she kept a diary. In hers she scribbled the contents of her stomach, not her soul.

title: Obfuscating Intolerance
description: A Pentagon inquiry's finding of no overt religious discrimination at the Air Force Academy strains credibility, considering the academy superintendent has already acknowledged it will take years to undo the damage from evangelical zealots on campus. Indeed, amid its thicket of bureaucratese, the report by an Air Force investigative panel goes on for page after page describing cases of obvious and overt religious bias. But it tosses all of these off as "perceived bias," as if the blame lies with the victims and not the offenders, and throws up a fog of implausible excuses, like "a lack of awareness" of what is impermissible behavior by military officers.

title: Arts, Briefly; Canada's Premier Is Scolded
description: Sir Bob Geldof told Prime Minister Paul Martin, right, of Canada that he was not welcome at the next month's G8 summit in Scotland unless Canada was willing to increase its foreign aid budget. "If he's not prepared, stay at home," Sir Bob said in a taped video message in Toronto during the announcement of the Canadian Live 8 concert. "Just stay at home. Don't come." Mr. Martin responded in Parliament by saying he would not make any promises the government could not keep. The concert itself was also widely criticized for the organizers' decision to present it at a small park, which holds just 35,000, in the tiny city of Barrie, Ontario, at least an hour's drive north of Toronto. A column in The Toronto Star said the concert, featuring aging Canadian musicians like Bryan Adams, Gordon Lightfoot and Burton Cummings, "feels like a lazily programmed, rather halfhearted afterthought." COLIN CAMPBELL

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 23 - Four car bomb blasts struck the central Baghdad commercial district of Karrada early this morning, spewing shattered glass and bits of human skin over the streets while killing at least 17 and raising the combined toll in the capital to at least 43 dead and 100 wounded in a string of similar attacks that began on Wednesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VANDERBILT, CLAIRE FRANCES, NEE CLAIRE FRANCES MCKIERNAN
description: VANDERBILT--Claire Frances, nee Claire Frances McKiernan, died on Sunday, June 19, at her home in Greenwich, CT. She was predeceased by her husband, Hugh B. Vanderbilt, Sr. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Michael's Church in Greenwich on June 28, 2005 at 10AM, followed immediately by a reception at the Greenwich Country Club. Claire is survived by her daughters, Laura Ernst and Linda Allen, her son Hugh B. Vanderbilt, Jr. and her five grandchildren, Thaddeus, Alexander and Nicholas Ernst, and Michael and Tyler Allen. In her life, Claire was tireless in her civic service. She was particularly invested in the activities of the Greenwich Historical Society. For nearly 50 years, she gave of her time and resources, together with her husband to the Bush Holley House and its historic site, as well as to Historic Deerfield, MA. Dressed as Sarah Bush, she would visit Greenwich school classrooms to teach local history. She was the recipient of numerous awards during her lifetime for her outstanding volunteer service. Claire is remembered fondly by friends and family. Inimitable, she will be sorely missed by all who loved and knew her. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Historical Society of the Town of Greenwich, 39 Strickland, Cos Cob, CT 06087.

(The error also appeared in articles on Dec. 14 and Dec. 16, 2004, and Sept. 20, 2004.) Mr. Pickell took office in 1995, not 1994. The error came to light during the editing of a recent article on the case.

title: In London: See Me, Feel Me, Touch Me
description: "Touch Me: Design and Sensation," an exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London through Aug. 29, concerns itself with the tactile. Visitors can touch two-thirds of the 90 objects on display, including Hands On (bottom), a rug made of knitted woolen fingers -- supersize carpet pile -- by Carmel McElroy and Donna Wilson, two British designers. Other pieces include the Embroidered Tablecloth (top right), by the Dutch designer Hella Jongerius, and Green Damask wallpaper (top left), by Linda Florence, a London designer. The paper, which is $320 for a 10-foot-by-20 1/2-inch roll, comes in two layers: a black-on-black William Morris-inspired pattern and, underneath it, an Op Art design in green and turquoise that emerges as the top layer is worn away by touch. Ms. Florence can be reached at linda@lindaflorence.co.uk. For information on the show: 011-44-20-7942-2000 or www.vam.ac.uk. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Sophia? Is That You Behind the Shades?

Most were purchased 30 years ago and bear extinct labels like Anne Klein for Riviera. These days their style-obsessed daughters and granddaughters could be forgiven for wanting to snatch them away. But as it turns out, there is no need.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: U.N. Envoy Cautious Of New Initiative
description: A United Nations envoy returned from a trip to Greece, Turkey and Cyprus and told the Security Council that there was neither a level of mutual confidence nor a disposition to compromise in the region to justify mounting a new attempt to reunite Cyprus, divided since 1974 between Greek and Turkish Cypriots. A reunification plan collapsed last year when Greek Cypriots voted it down and then took their new place in the European Union in the name of the whole island. Recalling that high-profile failure, the envoy, Kieran Prendergast, said that "launching an intensive new process prematurely would be inadvisable." Warren Hoge (NYT)

Visit, and you'll find out how a quarrel over the killing of a farm animal in the 19th century nearly led to war, spot wildlife in a way you've probably never done before and, generally speaking, find yourself drifting onto island time.

Adulterous Romance in a Fractious World
description: The first thing to say about Sally Potter's "Yes" is that it is written in verse -- rhymed iambic pentameter, to be precise. This curious feature may not, however, be the first thing you notice about the movie, given Ms. Potter's knack for enjambment and her cast's impressive ability to make highly artificial language sound like natural speech. The rhythms of their dialogue are at once odd and familiar, and the meter gives the picture a brisk momentum, making it feel like the expression of single, sustained impulse. "Yes" is not just a movie, in other words, it's a poem.

description: Five legislators of the governing party, the African National Congress, resigned from Parliament after striking plea-bargain agreements on charges of fraud stemming from the misuse of their official travel funds. Twenty-one of Parliament's 450 legislators, mostly from the party, have been accused of diverting the money after an investigation by the national prosecutor. A party spokesman said the resignations were an "demonstration of remorse" for wrongdoing and showed the party's zero-tolerance stance on corruption. title: National Briefing | Washington: Payment For Capitol Addition
description: The House has approved a final payment of $37 million for the new Capitol Visitors Center, a major addition to the Capitol projected to cost about $558 million, more than double the original estimate. The money for the project, which lawmakers have contemplated for years, was in a $2.9 billion spending bill that finances the budget of Congress. The center is planned as an underground three-story structure to include a 450-seat theater, a cafeteria and offices. The cost was first estimated to be $265 million, with a scheduled opening of late 2005. In the last two years, the Government Accountability Office revised the estimate first to $454.4 million, then to $558.6 million, while the completion date was pushed to late 2006. John Files (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Repairman Pleads Guilty In Fatal Accident
description: A Queens repairman who struck two boys with his van last year pleaded guilty yesterday to driving under the influence of alcohol, said the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. The repairman, John Wirta, 56, of Fresh Meadows, will be sentenced to 60 days in jail, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Wirta admitted hitting Vasean Alleyne, 11, and Angel Reyes, 12, on 150th Street in Flushing last October. Vasean died and Angel was critically injured.

title: Arts, Briefly; Help for 'Mambo Kings'
description: "The Mambo Kings," the new $12 million musical adaptation of the 1992 film of the same title, is having some work done. Now, according to several online reports, the playwright David Ives, the composer Jason Robert Brown and the choreographer Jerry Mitchell have been brought in to rework much of the musical, which stars Esai Morales. title: 'Paramount Before the Code'
description: This year, Film Forum is devoting its annual extended summer retrospective to one of the great hoards of relatively unseen American films: those frequently astonishing, often impressive and always interesting features produced by Paramount Pictures between the coming of sound and the enforcement of the Production Code in 1934. Now owned by Universal, as are most of the pre-1949 Paramount films, these titles have gone largely unexplored since their television exposure in the 1970's, and there are many that have not been seen at all since their original release. Now, thanks to Bob O'Neil, Universal's vice president for film preservation, many pre-code Paramount films are returning to the scene, most in 35-mm prints. Among the 46 programs that Film Forum will be screening from today through July 21 are a handful of famous titles, such as the double bill of Ernst Lubitsch's "Trouble in Paradise" (1932) and Josef von Sternberg's "Blonde Venus" (above with Marlene Dietrich and Sidney Toler), which opens the series today and tomorrow. Paramount's most celebrated directors, Lubitsch and Sternberg prospered in the freedom that reigned before the censorship crackdown, Lubitsch to create his sensual and suggestive comedies, Sternberg to spin his shadowy erotic fantasies starring Dietrich. While the studio's image was closely associated with Sternberg and Lubitsch's continental sophistication, Paramount also turned out quite a few of the gritty urban melodramas usually associated with Warner Brothers, and this fine series, programmed by Bruce Goldstein, gives pride of place to some surprising rediscoveries from this neglected side of the studio's output. Sylvia Sidney, Paramount's Bronx-accented answer to the innocent ingnues played by Janet Gaynor at Fox, stars in a double bill on July 5 and 6 of "Ladies of the Big House" (1931) and "Pick-Up" (1933), two gruff, working-class dramas directed by Marion Gering, and even Sternberg made his contribution to the genre by casting Sidney in his 1931 adaptation of "An American Tragedy" (July 9), one of his most underrated films. Paramount's confectionary, cosmopolitan side is also much on display, as in the double feature of July 1, Frank Tuttle's droll romantic comedy, "This Is the Night" (1932), and Harlan Thompson's musical ode to plastic surgery (really!), "Kiss and Make-Up" (1934), both featuring a young Cary Grant. In other words, it's pretty hard to go wrong once you plunge into the schedule, available at www.filmforum.org. DAVE KEHR

National Briefing | Washington: Energy Debate Closed
description: The Senate voted to close debate on its energy bill, and leadership aides said they now expected the Senate to vote Tuesday on the legislation. The measure would then head to a conference for reconciliation with the sharply different version passed by the House. The Senate version includes requirements for utilities to use more alternative sources of energy as well as greater subsidies and tax breaks to encourage use of alternative fuels, renewable resources, and energy-efficient cars and appliances. It also includes calls for voluntary reductions in emissions that scientists blame for global climate changes and subsidies for new technology to decrease pollution. The House version includes far more tax breaks for traditional fossil fuels and electric utilities as well as $2 billion to support deep-water drilling for oil. The House also approved a plan to provide makers of the gasoline additive MTBE with some protection from product liability suits arising out of water pollution. Senate opposition to that idea helped derail previous energy bills. David D. Kirkpatrick (NYT)

description: Some 700 militants in the volatile city of Nablus have agreed in principle to join the Palestinian security forces as part of a campaign to transform the gunmen into civil servants, Palestinians officials said. The Palestinian leadership says more than 500 militants in other cities have already signed up to work in the security forces or take civilian jobs in government. The deal in Nablus, a hotbed for militants, is the most comprehensive agreement so far. Most of those joining are from Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, linked to the Fatah movement led by Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian Authority president. The campaign is part of Mr. Abbas's effort to persuade militants to halt attacks against Israel. They are supposed to turn in their weapons as well, though compliance has been spotty, Palestinian officials say. Israeli troops have pulled back from two West Bank towns, and Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, has proposed turning over security to the Palestinians in two more towns. But Israel has given no sign that it is willing to leave the Nablus area. Greg Myre (NYT)

description: When these concerts began back in 1916, summer chamber music in a rural American setting was indeed a more maverick idea. Hervey White founded the series, named it after the arts colony he had established on his farm near Woodstock, N.Y., and built a large barn (above) that served as a concert hall. That barn still stands, and so does at least some of the adventurous spirit in concerts that bridge chamber music favorites with newer or more unusual works. This weekend, Maverick opens its 90th anniversary season with two such programs: tomorrow night, the Contrasts Quartet juxtaposes Beethoven and Schubert with works by Aaron Jay Kernis and Peter Schickele; Sunday, the violinist Charles Libove and the pianist Nina Lugovoy offer a recital of Saint-Saens and Mozart offset by Henry Cowell, Robert Starer and others. Running through Sept. 4, the season features both established ensembles like the Tokyo Quartet (Aug. 14) and younger groups on the rise, like the Mir (July 16) and Pacifica (July 24) Quartets. Alexander Platt, in his third summer as music director, has also woven through the schedule a five-concert tribute to his predecessor, the flutist Georges Barrre, and his fruitful relationship to the early-20th-century American composer Charles Tomlinson Griffes. (Tomorrow night at 6 and Sunday at 3 p.m., the Maverick Concert Hall, Maverick Road, between Routes 28 and 375, West Hurley, N.Y., (845)679-8217, $20, $5 for students, free for children under 12 with an adult.) description: The festival takes over the Joyce Theater this week in an annual event that spills out into the Chelsea Studios, the Hudson River for a waterborne tap jam and the amphitheater at the Fashion Institute of Technology for a young tappers' showcase. Details are to be found at www.atdf.org. The Joyce performances begin on Tuesday at 7 p.m. with a gala and reception that offers a taste of what is to come, with awards presented to Sarah Petronio and the tap historian Delilah Jackson. Sammy Davis Jr. and Peg Leg Bates will be posthumously inducted into the International Tap Dance Hall of Fame. The final program is "Tap Masters, Mentors, Divas and Legends," on Thursday and on July 2 at 8 p.m. and July 3 at 2 p.m. The divas include Brenda Bufalino, Mable Lee, Sarah Petronio and Dianne Walker, with Dr. Jimmy Slyde in a guest appearance. Sandwiched between is "Tap All-Stars/Tap Internationals," which focuses on experimentation by seasoned and upcoming tappers like Ayodele Casel, Kazu Kumagai, Walter (Sundance) Freeman and Max Pollak and Rumba Tap, on Wednesday and next Friday at 8 p.m. and July 3 at 3 p.m. The festival tends to be a happy-go-lucky affair with some surprises every years, with the irrepressible Mr. Waag, above, hovering over it all like a tap-dancing uncle. Wise audience members bring their tap shoes, because jams are often the order of the night. (Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800. Tickets: $40 (all performances); $250 for gala performance and reception; $125, gala performance and reception for students with identification.) JENNIFER DUNNING

World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Kyrgyzstan To Expel More Uzbeks
description: Kyrgyzstan's top prosecutor said his country would return 29 survivors of the deadly crackdown on a short-lived uprising in neighboring Uzbekistan last month despite concerns by the United Nations, the European Union and rights groups that they could face torture. "Among the 29, there are terrorists and religious extremists," Azimbek Beknazarov, the Kyrgyz prosecutor general, said, according to The Associated Press. More than 500 Uzbeks fled to Kyrgyzstan after the revolt was ended by gunfire from the authorities. Survivors have said hundreds died. Kyrgyz authorities forcibly returned four refugees on June 9. Acacia Shields, the Central Asia researcher for Human Rights Watch, said, "It is a violation of international law to return a person to a country that uses torture, and we know that Uzbekistan is such a country." Ethan Wilensky-Lanford (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CITRIN, ESTELLE
description: CITRIN--Estelle. Mom, today was a special day in the life of both of your grandchildren. Ethan, who it seems was born just yesterday, graduated into high school. His intelligence, his warmth and his love of life are proof positive that he is yours. Hunter moved up to sixth grade with your humor and your craziness. Like you, however, he is smart and always looking to the next project. They miss you terribly and would have been blessed had they actually known you in life. It feels like yesterday when we had our last breakfast together near the law School. Our lives will never be the same without you in them. In my thoughts always, Love, Marc

title: The Outtakes of Brando's Large Life
description: A collection of original Times movie reviews and articles, trailers and an audio slide show with additional images from the auction at Christie's: nytimes.com/brando. Hidden in one of the Japanese imitation-lacquer boxes that belonged to Marlon Brando and that will be auctioned at Christie's next week are a few of his little treasures: a plastic bagel that, when lifted, reveals a big plastic cockroach; a fake finger, bloodied at one end; and other pint-size practical jokes. It's not exactly a surprise that one of the greatest actors of our time was also a joker. We might have guessed that from some of his bizarre public appearances, like the television interview, from his bloated and nonsensical later years, in which he kissed Larry King on the mouth. And Johnny Depp, in a brief remembrance written for the Christie's catalog, lovingly recalls his friend's childlike sense of humor, with memories that are largely about whoopee cushions.

description: WASHINGTON, June 23 - The World Customs Organization voted Thursday in Brussels to endorse comprehensive standards intended to fight terrorism, a step that United States officials predict will revolutionize the way goods are tracked as they move around the globe. title: World Briefing | Africa: Malawi: Pandemonium Thwarts Impeachment Bid
description: Leaders of the United Democratic Front in Parliament opened a bid to impeach President Bingu wa Mutharika, left, who quit the party in a bitter feud with his predecessor, Bakili Muluzi, but the move ended in pandemonium when a brawl broke out and the Parliament speaker, trying to restore order, apparently fell from his podium and was taken unconscious to a hospital. Mr. Mutharika is accused of failing to seek approval for a $100 million fund he established to lend money to poor Malawians. description: A group of dance instructors and civil libertarians filed a lawsuit in State Supreme Court yesterday seeking to overturn a city ordinance that forbids dancing in clubs without cabaret licenses. Only 252 city clubs are licensed for dancing by more than three people, and critics say the law barring dancing in the others is outdated and an unconstitutional restriction of free speech. "To be moved by music is a human response," said Norman Siegel, left, a candidate for public advocate, who is one of the lawyers filing the suit. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: How a Renowned Painter Found Inspiration in Cloth
description: "Matisse: The Fabric of Dreams -- His Art and His Textiles," the languidly titled, often patchy, yet vision-altering exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has some great moments, and not all are due to the art of Henri Matisse. Quite a few of the show's visual fireworks are ignited by the splendid assortment of textiles and garments from around the world that Matisse collected and kept close by throughout his long, prolific life. In a phrase evoking gratitude and heavy use, he called his collection "my working library."

title: A Worry-Free Hike, a Contented Family
description: IT'S a bit crowded in the saddle, with my 4-year-old son, Simon, and me sharing a horse. Diamond, our ride, sinks her hooves deep into the thick mud with each step. We peek through the trees, trying to catch a glimpse of the majestic Lake Louise below, one of the Canadian Rockies' most celebrated gems. We are following the rest of our family -- my husband, Rich, and our daughters, Nicole, 11, and Emily, 9 -- on a horseback ascent to the Lake Agnes teahouse, climbing to a 1,320-foot elevation. What Simon doesn't realize yet is that on the way back down the trail, this saddle is all mine.

Never mind that emperor penguins have been doing this for millenniums and that this is their way. The feeling that these creatures are brave, indomitable souls surviving unimaginable physical hardship for the sake of their families is inescapable.

description: When these concerts began back in 1916, summer chamber music in a rural American setting was indeed a more maverick idea. Hervey White founded the series, named it after the arts colony he had established on his farm near Woodstock, N.Y., and built a large barn (above) that served as a concert hall. That barn still stands, and so does at least some of the adventurous spirit in concerts that bridge chamber music favorites with newer or more unusual works. This weekend, Maverick opens its 90th anniversary season with two such programs: tomorrow night, the Contrasts Quartet juxtaposes Beethoven and Schubert with works by Aaron Jay Kernis and Peter Schickele; Sunday, the violinist Charles Libove and the pianist Nina Lugovoy offer a recital of Saint-Sa THE LISTINGS: JUNE 24-JULY 1

Scared and injured with a scraped-up leg, Ms. Read, from Denver, struggled to make it to the top of Edward's Crack, a narrow crevasse in a granite dome rock in Vedauwoo, Wyo. Her 50-foot ascent was a success, and when she reached the summit she thanked Raleigh Coburn and Danika Gilbert, the two instructors who led the climb.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   POST, SHELDON
description: POST--Sheldon. 9/5/36 to 6/25/ 88. Founder, Chelsea Pines Inn. Chair, NYC Gay Men's Chorus. Board, Congregation Beth Simchat Torah. Loving partner, son, brother, uncle, friend, proud gay Jew. 17 years gone: a moment, a lifetime. Please join my spouse Tom Klebba and me as we celebrate Gay Pride this weekend and recall the many loved ones who have gone too soon, especially Peter Monette, Gary Olde and Mark Fuschetti, in the stillraging war against AIDS. Sheldon would have been proud to see how far we have come but would have encouraged us to continue the fight. "Sometimes people leave you halfway through the wood, do not let it grieve you, no one leaves for good." Rest, dear Sheldon, and know that you and all our friends will be remembered and celebrated as long as we live. Jay Lesiger

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BATES, JAMES S.
description: BATES--James S. Longtime resident of Vero Beach, FL. and veteran oil industry executive, died June 18 at the Hospice House in Vero Beach following a prolonged illness. He was 79. Mr. Bates was born in Floral Park, NY on March 26, 1926. He graduated from New York University and went on to obtain an MBA at the University of Pittsburgh. Mr. Bates joined the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey as a mail clerk in 1944 while still attending college, and retired from the same company, which had become Exxon International as a Senior Vice President in 1988. Then, in New York City, he became President and CEO of the Vanderbilt Petroleum Company. He fully retired from business in 1992. During most of his business career, Mr. Bates was a resident of Greenwich, CT, moving to John's Island in Vero Beach upon his retirement. He was an avid sportsman. In his youth, he boxed in the Golden Gloves Tournaments and played baseball in the Cleveland Indians organization as a pitcher. In his later life, with equal enthusiasm, he took up golf, skiing and paddle tennis. He was a member of the John's Island Club of Vero Beach, Burning Tree Country Club of Greenwich, Connecticut and the Morris County Golf Club of Convent Station, New Jersey. Mr. Bates is survived by his wife, Louise; a son, James Bates, Jr.; five daughters, Barbara Blynn, Joan Kelly, Jean Ferrari, Jill Champagne and Joy Vander Wal; and eleven grandchildren. A Mass was celebrated at the Holy Cross Catholic Church on June 21, followed by a reception at the John's Island Clubhouse. In memory of Jim, contributions may be sent to Our Lady of Guadalupe Mission, 12896 County Road #

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Tax Fraud Charges Dropped
description: The Mexican government will drop tax fraud charges against top officials of the steel maker Altos Hornos de Mxico, known as Ahmsa, the company said. Ahmsa, which defaulted on $1.86 billion in debt in 1999, said an agreement reached with the Finance Ministry would ease negotiations with creditors, without elaborating. Ahmsa's vice chairman, Xavier Autrey, was arrested on the tax charges in July in Spain and has been under house arrest there. Ahmsa's chairman, Alonso Ancira, also wanted on tax charges, is thought to be in Israel, which has no extradition treaty with Mexico. The company said the two are now free to return to Mexico. Mr. Ancira and Mr. Autrey own 73 percent of the company. In April, with high world steel prices raising earnings, the company restarted debt negotiations. The Finance Ministry had no comment on why the charges, involving $2 million in payroll taxes, had been dropped, citing tax secrecy laws. Ahmsa is based in Monclova, in northern Mexico. title: ARTHUR SIMMS
description: Some homeless people contrive the illusion of owning property by bundling found and mostly useless material into great aggregates that they load onto shopping carts or other wheeled vehicles. The sculptures of Arthur Simms, a Brooklyn resident who represented his homeland of Jamaica in the 2001 Venice Biennale, call to mind this sort of roving, often mentally eccentric pack rat. The earlier pieces in his show of works dating from 1989 to the present consist of quantities of junk -- rags, old shoes, milk crates, tools, plumbing parts and so on -- wrapped in dense cocoons of rope. These massive, bulging constructions, some standing on wheels, exude an uncanny power in proportion to the urban poverty that they evoke. In recent works, like "Blue Chair" or "Carnival" (above), the found constituents are more discernible: the frames of a blue metal chair and an old wooden one wrapped in a delicate net of copper wire in the one instance; the gold-foil wrapped skateboard, the clear bottle, the wooden shoe form and the bird cage all pulled together by twine webbing and looking a bit like a small dog in the second case. The tradition of the Surrealist assemblage lies behind these works, but they are not so self-congratulatingly witty as such objects can be; Mr. Simms's works are sophisticatedly absurd, but there is a touching pathos about them, too. His is a tender reclamation project; he is a saver of lost souls. (Five Myles, 558 St. Johns Place, Crown Heights, Brooklyn, (718)783-4438, through July 10.) KEN JOHNSON

title: World Briefing | Africa: Africans Reject Call To Condemn Mugabe
description: Days before its fifth annual summit meeting in Libya, the African Union rejected Western demands to condemn mass evictions of poor squatters in Zimbabwe, saying that the forced uprooting of several hundred thousand people was a domestic matter. "If the government that they elected say they are restoring order by their actions, I don't think it would be proper for us to go interfering in their internal legislation," the group's spokesman, Desmond Orjiako, told the BBC. The Group of 8 industrialized nations urged African leaders this week to press President Robert G. Mugabe on observing human rights, saying that "until Africa's leaders as a whole recognize what is going on, take action not just to condemn but to deal with it, we are likely to be in for many more months of this kind of tyranny." Mr. Mugabe says the evictions are an attack on crime and urban decay. Critics say they are, among other things, a campaign to eradicate opposition to his rule. Michael Wines (NYT)

Two-thirds of the CBS lineup, repeats of "CSI" (11.94 million) and "Without a Trace" (10.26 million), held up well against the sports broadcast, putting the network in second place. Business Briefs | Next Windows System to Use a New Internet Link Tool
description: The next version of the Windows operating system will include new tools to link personal computers to information on the Internet, Microsoft announced. The new operating system scheduled to be released in the second half of 2006, will integrate tools for Really Simple Syndication throughout its operating system, allowing users to use and update content from the Web seamlessly in their e-mail messages, word processing, spreadsheet and calendar. Really Simple Syndication has been available for several years as a way to subscribe to feeds from Web sites, but its use has only recently grown. About 5 percent of Internet users obtain information using the system, a Pew Internet and American Life Project report found in January. It is different from e-mail messages because it involves retrieving information selectively from specified Web sites or Web logs. When consumers view their feeds using the system, they typically see the updated Web content all on one screen. Louise Story (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, FRANCES KARO
description: FRIEDMAN--Frances Karo. Of Lauderhill, FL, Stamford, CT, and New York, NY died June 24, 2005, at the age of 84 at her New York home following a short illness. Born in New York, Frances Federman, daughter of Ida and Benjamin Federman; survived by her adoring husband, retired prominent physician Dr. Oscar H. Friedman; daughters Helen Seplowitz of Stamford, CT and Anita Karo of Langhorn, PA; grandsons Kevin and Eric Seplowitz. Predeceasing Frances was her brother Samuel and first husband, Frank Karo, who along with his sisters founded L&B Karo, a leading millinery business that furnished high styled ladies hats to many of America's finest department stores. As a representative of the family business, Frances was always stylishly and immaculately dressed from hat to toe and she enjoyed the pleasures of beautiful clothing, which she wore superbly. The family's artistic genes were passed on to Helen, an artist whose sculpture and photographic works can be found on display in Fairfield and Westchester counties. Eric is also a professional photographer. Kevin has carried on the family entrepreneurial spirit by creating a food and beverage research company to provide a higher standard of living for those suffering with celiac disease. Frances was a generous, sensitive, caring and loving woman, sympathetic to all causes for the underprivileged and needy. She shared generously with a significant number of charities including, Woods School, Langhorn, PA; Rabbi Jacob Joseph School; Cong. Agudath Sholom; Mt. Sinai Medical Center; Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital; Baylor University College of Medicine; UJF. Services will be held at Congregation Agudath Sholom on Sunday, June 26th at 12Noon. Burial will follow at Agudath Sholom Cemetery in Stamford. Shiva will follow the burial at the Seplowitz home, 79 Fawnfield Road, Stamford. Shiva will be observed Monday, June 27th from 3-9PM at 983 Park Avenue, apt 12C, NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions to any charity listed above would be appreciated.

title: Bern
description: WHY GO NOW The long, mild days of summer are ideal for strolling the arcaded streets of Bern, the Swiss capital, with its medieval sandstone buildings and painted 16th-century fountains. This summer it is playing host to several big openings and one-of-a-kind events, including several to honor a famous past resident. To mark the 100 years since Albert Einstein published his theory of relativity in Bern, the city has declared 2005 "Einstein Year," and images of him are plastered on everything from shop windows to streetcars. The Historisches Museum Bern, (1) Helvetiaplatz 5, (41-31) 350 77 11, www.bhm.ch, recently opened an exhibition that traces Einstein's life and explains his theories through interactive displays. Among them is an outdoor physics park and a virtual-reality bike ride through Bern - as you approach the speed of light, the buildings curve and flatten into something out of a Dal painting.

title: Htel du Petit Moulin in Paris
description: THE BASICS There's not much basic about Htel du Petit Moulin, the boutique hostelry designed by Christian Lacroix that opened early this year in the Marais district. The fashion designer, known for his creative exuberance, has had a field day with fabric, furniture, wallpaper, paint, accessories - and that's just the lobby. The lavishly Lacroixian touches continue throughout the 17th-century building. Each of the 17 guest rooms has a different look. Walls might be covered in haute-couture sketches, starry skies or giant carnations. Furniture ranges from antique to pop to zen, sometimes in the same room. It's lodging as theater.

title: Tan Dun's Opera: A Special Delivery From the Spirit World

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: OTHER ELECTRICITIES: Stories. By Ander Monson. (Sarabande, paper, $14.95.) Monson opens with a chart, closes with an index and pocks the intervening text with radio wiring diagrams as he merges metaliterary form with a grim subject (kids falling to their deaths through the ice of a frozen lake) in a poetic, startling, even funny collection of linked stories. As bored locals run laps inside the wintry cage of Upper Michigan and his occasional narrator mourns an ex-flame who went into the water on prom night, Monson turns this lost corner of America into the setting for a unique brand of mudroom Gothic. There's a diver reciting the procedures for recovering the dead, a cop reminding himself of the right way to notify the next of kin, and a catalog of the temperatures at which different items freeze. The funniest list identifies the things a woman must do to lessen her chances of being murdered: "Do not go on dates with men. Do not go on dates with men who drive. . . . Do not spend time with any kind of men at all." The drumbeat of particular words -- snowmobile, sauna, Superior, meth -- roots the reader in a very specific place, and Monson is its loving curator. Sometimes glimpses of a whole new world break through the ice, making you wish for a longer, linear, uninterrupted visit.

title: Bern
description: WHY GO NOW -- The long, mild days of summer are ideal for strolling the arcaded streets of Bern, the Swiss capital, with its medieval sandstone buildings and painted 16th-century fountains. This summer it is playing host to several big openings and one-of-a-kind events, including several to honor a famous past resident. To mark the 100 years since Albert Einstein published his theory of relativity in Bern, the city has declared 2005 "Einstein Year," and images of him are plastered on everything from shop windows to streetcars. The Historisches Museum Bern, Helvetiaplatz 5, (41-31) 350 77 11, www.bhm.ch, recently opened an exhibition that traces Einstein's life and explains his theories through interactive displays. Among them is an outdoor physics park and a virtual-reality bike ride through Bern -- as you approach the speed of light, the buildings curve and flatten into something out of a Dal painting.

title: Up Front
description: Terrence Rafferty's first contribution to the Book Review, a brief review of a biography of David Letterman, appeared in 1987. Known primarily as a film critic -- his reviews for The Nation and The New Yorker were collected in "The Thing Happens: Ten Years of Writing About the Movies" -- Rafferty veered into this field, as he explained in a recent telephone interview, while trying to avoid writing his dissertation in comparative literature at Cornell. He has always, he added, "read a lot of books and gone to a lot of movies" and never considered one form superior to the other -- just as he's always been fond of both popular and literary fiction. This may explain why, over the course of his career, he has worked as an editor of mysteries, westerns, horror novels and science fiction, and has written about popular music, dance, poetry and theater for publications like The Atlantic Monthly, The Threepenny Review and Savvy. At The Times, his appearances have been equally various: notes on Arnold Schwarzenegger's gubernatorial campaign for the Op-Ed page, an article for The Times Magazine on DVD's and Arts & Leisure essays on James Dean, World War I and Federico Fellini. At the Book Review, he has weighed in on Peter Carey, Joyce Carol Oates, John le Carr, John Edgar Wideman and -- this week -- Michael Cunningham. The one distinguishing feature of his work for The Times, Rafferty noted, is that he has yet to appear on any day other than Sunday. The Editors

Almost no one in the audience can see them; once he's left the dressing room, neither can Mr. Stuhlbarg. Still, they're an important part of the process by which he creates the character of Michal: a man in his late 30's who, for seven years as a child, was physically and emotionally tortured by his parents. For Mr. Stuhlbarg, the "shock scars" are physical reminders of the electrodes once attached there -- and an indication of the subtlety of his approach to playing a mentally handicapped person.

title: Interrogating Ourselves

The success of the humane interviewing, in the judgment of the British police, was a result of providing each police officer with 40 hours of training in how to conduct interviews, how to assess a suspect's emotional state, how to build rapport, how to ask productive questions, etc.
