title: Comings and Goings
description: The high-speed Eurostar train, which connects London, Paris and Brussels, is making changes in service classes starting Sept. 1. Replacing first class will be Business Premier and Leisure Select. One-way business class will cost the same as current full-fare first class: $375 for exchangeable and refundable tickets. Leisure class will cost the same as current first-class day trip or leisure tickets -- from $190 for a round-trip, nonrefundable nonexchangeable ticket -- but will be in a separate car. Standard tickets are unchanged, starting at $90 round trip. Information: (800) 387-6782 or www.raileurope.com. Starwood Hotels and Resorts is introducing a less expensive version of their W Hotel chain. The plan for the new hotels, Project XYZ, calls for loftlike guest rooms, signature beds and landscaped outdoor spaces. The first XYZ hotels are expected to open in early 2007 in cities yet to be determined. Continental Airlines began nonstop service from Los Angeles to Durango and Quertaro in Mexico on June 9. The service to Quertaro is daily, while Durango flights operate four times a week but will increase to every day in July and August. Reservations: (800) 231-0856 or www.continental.com. MARJORIE CONNELLY

title: Exit the Iceman
description: DURING the blackout two summers ago, Paul Palmadessa, who was known as Paulie to everyone who lived and worked in Hell's Kitchen, was in his usual spot at his family business, United City Ice Company. As the day pressed on and the air-conditioners sat idle, Mr. Palmadessa sensed a rare business opportunity. "O.K., O.K.!" he yelled to the sweaty crowds gathering in front of his tiny storefront, reveling in the moment. "Single file. Have your cash ready. I got ice!"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LLOYD, MAUREEN B.
description: LLOYD--Maureen B. 62, an officer of the Charles A. and Anne Morrow Lindbergh Foundation, passed away on June 22, in Norwalk, CT. Mrs. Lloyd worked for the law firm of Davis Polk and Wardwell for approximately 40 years and retired in 2001. Mrs. Lloyd was born in NYC, and was the daughter of the late Robert and Sadie Boles and the sister of the late Eileen B. Kenniff. She was married to the late James W. Lloyd and now joins him in eternity. She was a devout member of St. John's R.C. Church in Darien, CT, and has served with the Lindbergh Foundation since 2003. Mrs. Lloyd is survived by her brother, Robert J. Boles, and two nieces, Maureen Godwin and Kathleen Kocur. Also survived by Mrs. Lloyd are three grandnieces, Meegan Daley, Kaitlyn Kocur and Lindsey Godwin, and one grandnephew, Griffin Shelley. A memorial service for Mrs. Lloyd will be held on July 22, 2005, St. John's Church, Darien, CT, at 11 am. In lieu of flowers, Mrs. Lloyd's family requests that contributions be made to the Whittingham Cancer Center of Norwalk Hospital or the American Cancer Society.

title: The Apolitical Israeli
description: Etgar Keret is the most famous young writer in Israel. His four short-story collections -- including "The Nimrod Flipout," which will be published in the United States by Farrar, Straus & Giroux next spring -- have all been best sellers. His fame is surprising, even to himself, since his characters possess none of the qualities on which Israelis usually pride themselves: toughness, decisiveness, physical courage. In a country where "Bulldozer" is one of the prime minister's nicknames, and where the model writer, for decades, has been the strapping kibbutznik and war veteran Amos Oz, Keret writes from some other Israel, populated by weak, confused nobodies. And yet Keret is not just widely read, he is absorbed, above all by the young.

title: Jones's Withdrawal at Nationals Stirs Doubts
description: After two test starts in the 100-meter preliminaries Friday, Marion Jones simply walked away. She withdrew from the United States track and field championships, saying through associates that she had a strained quadriceps in her left leg. The pressing question now is whether the end of this meet will also represent the end of her career as a top international sprinter.

title: Bombs Hurt 8 in a Russian Republic
description: MOSCOW, June 25 - In a sign of the growing instability in the Caucasus region of Russia, four bombs exploded in the southern republic of Dagestan on Saturday. Two of the bombs wounded six police officers in the regional capital, and another derailed a cargo train, injuring two men.

title: A Rapper Renounces His Rocks
description: This year Kanye West has given listeners a chance to witness his political evolution over the course of a single song. First came "Diamonds Are Forever," the first single from Mr. West's hotly anticipated new album, "Late Registration." He is hip-hop's leading rapper-producer, beloved for his wistful beat-making and shameless punchlines; here, over an addictive Shirley Bassey sample, he rhymed, "Now all I need is y'all to pronounce my name/It's Kanye, but some of my plaques, they still say Kayne."

"It turns out I have three very busy daughters," she said, and "five very busy grandchildren. No one ever came up. If they did come up, it was just overnight. It became an obligation."

title: Htel du Petit Moulin in Paris
description: THE BASICS -- There's not much basic about Htel du Petit Moulin, the boutique hostelry designed by Christian Lacroix that opened early this year in the Marais district. The fashion designer, known for his creative exuberance, has had a field day with fabric, furniture, wallpaper, paint, accessories -- and that's just the lobby. The lavishly Lacroixian touches continue throughout the 17th-century building. Each of the 17 guest rooms has a different look. Walls might be covered in haute-couture sketches, starry skies or giant carnations. Furniture ranges from antique to pop to zen, sometimes in the same room. It's lodging as theater.

title: Who Needs Mace? Whip Out That Sonnet
description: IF the only thing between you and the business end of a sawed-off shotgun is a copy of "Immortal Poems of the English Language," then the distinction between art and life is about to become painfully clear. Or is it? To judge from two recent novels, Ian McEwan's "Saturday" and Vendela Vida's "And Now You Can Go," it might be easier to save your bacon with a neatly deployed rondeau than anyone ever suspected. In each book, an impending act of violence is prevented not by the arrival of a SWAT team but by the recitation of a poem -- and not a "spoken word" poem, or a pop lyric masquerading as a poem, but a regular old poem poem. One of the poems is even . . . Victorian. Which leads to the obvious question: should we start outfitting the New York Police Department with pocket editions of "Sonnets From the Portuguese"?

title: Subject to Research
description: I have M.S., for which there is at present no cure. My doctor has invited me to participate in studies of existing and potential treatments. I admire those who volunteer for such research, but I am concerned about the potential long-term health consequences. Is it ethical to benefit from medicines developed through research studies but not participate in them myself? Roberta Osborne, Toronto Volunteering to be a subject for medical research is something we must all admire but may not compel. Such acts of self-sacrifice are termed supererogatory. This is particularly so with actions that involve the sanctity of the body, something most ethical systems respect. Hence we do not require anyone to donate an organ, but we esteem those who do.

title: Who Are Americans to Think That Freedom Is Theirs to Spread?
description: I. As Thomas Jefferson lay dying at his hilltop estate, Monticello, in late June 1826, he wrote a letter telling the citizens of the city of Washington that he was too ill to join them for the 50th-anniversary celebrations of the Declaration of Independence. Wanting his letter to inspire the gathering, he told them that one day the experiment he and the founders started would spread to the whole world. "To some parts sooner, to others later, but finally to all," he wrote, the American form of republican self-government would become every nation's birthright. Democracy's worldwide triumph was assured, he went on to say, because "the unbounded exercise of reason and freedom of opinion" would soon convince all men that they were born not to be ruled but to rule themselves in freedom.

title: How to Get Rid Of a Gun
description: While pondering how to dispose of his friend's guns, neither Mike Kessler nor the guns did any harm. But when Kessler took an ax to the pistols, put the then useless weapons in a trash bag, "poured in some old paint . . . added more . . . and threw it in the trash," he violated well-known environmental regulations. In both Los Angeles (where he was living at the time) and Boulder, Colo. (where he lives now), used paint cannot be disposed of as normal trash because it is classified as hazardous waste.

description: NEE -- David Dawes II. (1976-2005.) David Nee, a much loved member of the class of 2005 from Fordham University School of Law, and a graduate of Princeton University (class of 1998) and The Loomis Chaffee School (class of 1994), died of his own hand on Wednesday, June 22, in New York City. David was born in Hong Kong to his parents, Owen and Amber Nee, on February 24, 1976, and attended the Hong Kong International School, and the Rye Country Day School, before matriculating at Loomis in Windsor, Connecticut. Dave went on to Princeton University, where he was a member of the Ivy Club, and "president" of the Green Room. After graduation, Dave worked as an Associate Producer of "Message in a Bubble," a public television documentary on the rise and fall of internet entrepreneurs, and he also edited an internet magazine called "The Scrivener," which was devoted to contemporary comment and fiction, for several years. While at Fordham, Dave participated in the Jessup International Moot Court Competition both as an advocate and, during the past year, as a coach, and led his team to an eighteenth overall ranking in the world competition, the highest position ever achieved by the school. David leaves his parents, his older sister, Claire Nee Nelson, and younger sister, Alexandra. A memorial service will be held at the Rye Presbyterian Church, 882 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York, on Monday, June 27, 2005, at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be directed to two causes that were very close to David's heart: Legal Education Advocacy Program, Fordham University School of Law, 230 West 55th Street, Apt. 7C, New York, NY 10019; Fordham University School of Law, Attn: Moot Court Competition, in honor of David Nee, Office of the Dean, 140 West 62nd Street, New York, New York 10023.

description: Amid the growing rivalry between the Nasdaq market and the New York Stock Exchange, nothing is being overlooked, not even how to celebrate an I.P.O.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAPHIR, JUDY
description: SAPHIR--Judy. Passed away in New York on June 24 after a long brave struggle against cancer. Beloved wife of Dr. Richard L. Saphir. Super Mom of Steven and his wife Annette. Adoring grandma of Megan and Scotty. Dear sister of Dr. James Schwartz, and loving owner of Missy. Judy was a wonderful, caring human being with keen leadership ability and a sharp sense of humor. She devoted much of her life to philanthropic activities, most notably the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation and the search for a cure to breast cancer. Services will be Sunday, June 26 at 12 noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 91 Street. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of Greater New York, 386 Park Avenue South, 14th Floor, New York, New York 10016, C/O Judy Saphir Research Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DORFMAN, DELLIE
description: DORFMAN--Dellie. I love you Mommy. March 19, 1944-June 23, 2005.

title: Look Smart
description: Moleskine Notebook Armand Frasco bought his first pocket-size Moleskine notebook at a Restoration Hardware store in a mall in Skokie, Ill. The packaging mentioned that this was "the legendary notebook of Hemingway, Picasso, Chatwin." Frasco's basic reaction to that was, Yeah, right. But he liked the notebook's construction and purchased one. Later he went online and did a search for "Moleskine" and "My Moleskine." "And man," he says, "I saw a lot." Modo & Modo, the Italian company that has been producing the notebooks since 1998, sells more than four million a year in about 40 countries. Clearly something not only makes people want to have these notebooks but also makes them want other people to know that they have them. "We know now that it's sort of a symbol," says Samantha Rossini, Modo & Modo's project manager.

title: Metal Menu: This Lamb of God Is Brash and Loud
description: WHEN you like your rock shows loud enough to cause waves in your brain liquid and more aggressive than Lawrence Taylor in his prime -- and a lot of fans of New Jersey's heavy metal scene do -- popular summer festivals like Ozzfest and the Vans Warped Tour can leave you crying in your rubber-banded beard. Bands on those tours are perceived as either too mainstream or too tame, and ticket prices tend to be too expensive for 15-year-olds making do on lawn-mowing money.

title: The Star Maker of the Semipopular
description: Jesca Hoop is a striking, dark-haired 29-year-old from Northern California who writes and sings twisty, sprawling, lyrically abstract songs, featuring strange sonorities and offbeat rhythms. Her music sounds as if it comes from an imaginary country, and she sings in the accented English of someone from that country. In the fall of 2003, Hoop was living in a van in Sonoma County, 35 miles north of San Francisco, when late one morning she was awakened by a call on her cellphone. The voice on the other end belonged to Nic Harcourt, a disc jockey and host of a weekday music program, "Morning Becomes Eclectic," on the Los Angeles public-radio station KCRW. Harcourt had received a copy of some unreleased self-produced "demo" recordings of Hoop's and had begun playing them on the air. Her song "Seed of Wonder" was especially popular: when it spun, the studio's phones lighted up and listeners in their cars pulled over to the side of the road, waiting for Harcourt to announce what it was. It would go on to become one of KCRW's top five requests for eight weeks running, a station record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, FRANCES KARO
description: FRIEDMAN--Frances Karo. Of Lauderhill, FL, Stamford, CT, and New York, NY died June 24, 2005, at the age of 84 at her New York home following a short illness. Born in New York, Frances Federman, daughter of Ida and Benjamin Federman; survived by her adoring husband, retired prominent physician Dr. Oscar H. Friedman; daughters Helen Seplowitz of Stamford, CT and Anita Karo of Langhorn, PA; grandsons Kevin and Eric Seplowitz. Predeceasing Frances was her brother Samuel and first husband, Frank Karo, who along with his sisters founded L&B Karo, a leading millinery business that furnished high styled ladies hats to many of America's finest department stores. As a representative of the family business, Frances was always stylishly and immaculately dressed from hat to toe and she enjoyed the pleasures of beautiful clothing, which she wore superbly. The family's artistic genes were passed on to Helen, an artist whose sculpture and photographic works can be found on display in Fairfield and Westchester counties. Eric is also a professional photographer. Kevin has carried on the family entrepreneurial spirit by creating a food and beverage research company to provide a higher standard of living for those suffering with celiac disease. Frances was a generous, sensitive, caring and loving woman, sympathetic to all causes for the underprivileged and needy. She shared generously with a significant number of charities including, Woods School, Langhorn, PA; Rabbi Jacob Joseph School; Cong. Agudath Sholom; Mt. Sinai Medical Center; Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital; Baylor University College of Medicine; UJF. Services will be held at Congregation Agudath Sholom on Sunday, June 26th at 12Noon. Burial will follow at Agudath Sholom Cemetery in Stamford. Shiva will follow the burial at the Seplowitz home, 79 Fawnfield Road, Stamford. Shiva will be observed Monday, June 27th from 3-9PM at 983 Park Avenue, apt 12C, NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions to any charity listed above would be appreciated.

title: PHOTO-OP
Correction

title: Shortchanged by Good Intentions
description: TO New York State policymakers, a rule tightening the collection of child support must have seemed like a smart way to save money and make fathers responsible for their children. But in fact it is driving many poor children from good, safe, affordable child care centers.

title: New Zealand and Israel Declare End to Dispute
description: JERUSALEM, June 26 - New Zealand and Israel declared today the end of a diplomatic dispute that erupted last year when two Israelis, widely believed to be spies, were arrested for attempting to fraudulently obtain New Zealand passports.

title: Everybody Out?
description: NEARLY two years ago, Alistair and Catherine Economakis became the owners of a six-story tenement building at 47-49 East Third Street, between First and Second Avenues, in the East Village. The building has 15 apartments, with tenants paying rents of $500 to $950 a month.

description: A fight between a 60-year-old Manhattan man and his stepson in May might have contributed to the older man's death a month later, the authorities said.

title: Blacksmith's Son Emphasized His Modest Roots
description: TEHRAN, June 25 - In choosing Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, Iranian voters elevated a blacksmith's son who has made more of his modest background and frugal ways than his revolutionary credentials or political experience.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: June 26-July 2; TELEVISION
description: Et tu, ABC? This year, there will be two big-budget mini-series that illustrate the back-stabbing drama of ancient Rome for viewers to compare. ABC fires the first shot this week with "EMPIRE" (Tuesday at 9 p.m.), which begins with the assassination of Julius Caesar (COLM FEORE). The mini-series, from the executive producers Neil Meron and Craig Zadan ("ANNIE," "THE REAGANS"), will run on Tuesday nights through July 26. HBO'S competing offering, "ROME," will be broadcast in September.

title: Black and White
description: About halfway through Keith A. Beauchamp's documentary "The Untold Story of Emmett Louis Till," the film cuts from Emmett's mother, Mamie Till Mobley, calmly describing her 14-year-old son's mutilation for whistling at a white woman -- his head had been split side to side, and one eye left hanging from its socket -- to a grisly photograph of his corpse. When the movie was shown at the Hamptons International Film Festival last October (it opens at Film Forum in Manhattan on Aug. 17), the sudden appearance of the photograph drew a collective gasp from the audience, followed by audible sobs.

title: Sara Stein and Mark Richman
description: Sara Holland Stein and Mark Howard Richman were married last evening by Rabbi Jonathan E. Blake at Le Chteau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

description: Steve Lonegan may not have won the Republican gubernatorial primary, but he's going places anyway.

description: Some bands are collectives; others are dictatorships. Two bands that dispense with any pretense of democracy are due this week in Manhattan: BILLY CORGAN, performing Monday and Tuesday at WEBSTER HALL, and the EELS, coming to TOWN HALL on Thursday.

title: With Bid for Unocal, U.S. Struggles on China Policies
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 - President Bush's initial response to the proposed takeover of a major American oil company by a Chinese rival has been to duck. It is not hard to see why.

title: Many Are Keeping Wary Eyes on the Tide
description: FROM Maine to Massachusetts, a massive outbreak of toxic red tide has shut down the shellfishing industry. Commercial shell fishermen have been unable to work and restaurants are struggling to provide the fried clams, steamers and fresh oysters that tourists expect when visiting the coast. Massachusetts officials are looking for federal disaster aid to help compensate the industry for the worst outbreak in 33 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VANDERBILT, CLAIRE FRANCES, NEE CLAIRE FRANCES MCKIERNAN
description: VANDERBILT--Claire Frances, nee Claire Frances McKiernan, died on Sunday, June 19, at her home in Greenwich, CT. She was predeceased by her husband, Hugh B. Vanderbilt, Sr. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Michael's Church in Greenwich on June 28, 2005 at 10AM, followed immediately by a reception at the Greenwich Country Club. Claire is survived by her daughters, Laura Ernst and Linda Allen, her son Hugh B. Vanderbilt, Jr. and her five grandchildren, Thaddeus, Alexander and Nicholas Ernst, and Michael and Tyler Allen. In her life, Claire was tireless in her civic service. She was particularly invested in the activities of the Greenwich Historical Society. For nearly 50 years, she gave of her time and resources, together with her husband to the Bush Holley House and its historic site, as well as to Historic Deerfield, MA. Dressed as Sarah Bush, she would visit Greenwich school classrooms to teach local history. She was the recipient of numerous awards during her lifetime for her outstanding volunteer service. Claire is remembered fondly by friends and family. Inimitable, she will be sorely missed by all who loved and knew her. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Historical Society of the Town of Greenwich, 39 Strickland, Cos Cob, CT 06087.

title: Burglaries Decrease in Nassau, but Police Feel Strain
description: A YEAR ago, the Nassau County Police Department reassigned Detective Ron Burk from his job investigating burglaries in a North Shore precinct to a countywide burglary task force. That left the precinct shorthanded, Detective Burk said, but residential burglaries in the county had risen for the first time in more than a decade and the task force needed his 30-plus years of experience.

title: Mean Girls

Laura Lippman, who saturates her Baltimore mysteries in the vivid colorations of that quirky city, takes herself to a much darker and scarier place -- high school -- in TO THE POWER OF THREE (Morrow, $24.95). Unlike her Tess Monaghan series, which rambles freely over the urban landscape, this ambitious suspense story stays tightly focused on Glendale High School, a big school in suburban Maryland rocked by a school shooting.

This compact seaside city -- founded with a somewhat religious fervor in the late 1800's -- has experienced many revivals in the century or so since then.

title: For Bargain Hunters, the Game Grows Scarce
description: As flea markets go, the one held at the Avenue of the Americas and 24th Street every weekend for the past seven years was pretty close to secondhand heaven. Another flea market operated one block north, but admission costs a dollar and the dealers there tend to be pricey. The 24th Street market, with its vinyl records, vintage clothes, midcentury modern furniture and outdated electronic equipment, seemed to have hit upon a perfectly inspired mix of junk and gems.

description: Our headlong love affair with the Internet has clearly progressed from starry-eyed digital passion to a murkier, more tangled dependence. We can't live without it, and we're finding it ever harder to live with it.

title: Interrogating Ourselves
description: As a lifelong Republican and a Christian, I am disgusted with the administration's limp response to the revelations of Abu Ghraib and the interminable incarcerations at Guantnamo. In the past, one of our criticisms of totalitarian regimes was their habit of imprisoning people for months and years without due process. What are we doing in Guantnamo? What will our response be when the next American is thrown in a foreign jail and held indefinitely without being charged? The government involved will just point at Guantnamo.

title: Sailing Through Life On a Sea of Bons Mots
description: Sag Harbor - THE Easterbrooks and the Smiths are terribly sophisticated people. They discuss the most serious matters with a superhuman lightness and respond to disheartening news with brave panache. Things can't possibly be really bad, they seem to say, if you can be clever enough or look good enough while coping.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: June 26-July 2; THEATER
description: Shakespeare comedies in which a retreat to nature figures significantly in the plot go down particularly well at the DELACORTE THEATER. This summer, Central Park doubles as the Forest of Arden, where Rosalind and Orlando enact their teasing games of love in "AS YOU LIKE IT." This Public Theater production, which began performances on Saturday night and runs through July 17, is directed by MARK LAMOS and stars LYNN COLLINS as the most fiercely intelligent of Shakespeare's cross-dressing heroines. Ms. Collins recently received some glowing reviews for her Portia opposite Al Pacino in the movie version of "The Merchant of Venice," and has a history with the Public Theater, too: she played Ophelia to Liev Schreiber's Hamlet in 1999. She will be joined here by BRIAN BEDFORD as the melancholy philosopher Jacques and RICHARD THOMAS as Touchstone, among others. Delacorte Theater, Central Park, free; (212)539-8750.

Paid Notice: Deaths   ARON, JACKIE
description: ARON--Jackie. The national Tourette Syndrome Association Board of Directors, its staff and all its members mourn the passing of our dear friend and true champion of all people with TS, Jacqueline Aron. Diagnosed late in life with TS, Jackie embraced the cause with abiding support for TS research through the J. Aron Foundation, of which she served as a director. Personally she underwrote awareness and educational programs for both people with TS and the public at large. She launched a unique internet program for youngsters and adults with TS through Sunrise Support, Inc. This remarkable network grew exponentially and was her pride and joy, providing critical and individual help to those touched by the severest symptoms of this neurological disorder. Our sincerest condolences are extended to her loving son Sean Patrick Aron of Los Angeles, CA., her brothers, Peter A. Aron of New York and Robert Aron of Charlottesville, VA. and to her dear friend Nicole "Niki" Hardin of Woodbridge, VA.

title: In Buying A Home, You Are What You Do
description: CONSCIOUSLY or not, Manhattanites tend to subscribe to the you-are-what-you-do-for-a-living notion. So perhaps it's not surprising that from the vantage of real estate brokers who shepherd, coax, bully and pander to them, an apartment-hunter's behavior can play out in striking sync with his or her occupation.

He was called a "creative producer," and according to Harold Prince, who produced a couple of shows with titles like "West Side Story," "Fiddler on the Roof," and "Cabaret," he is almost extinct.

We didn't know, so we sought input from an assortment of history buffs, longtime residents and ordinary smart alecks. We asked them to pick a pivotal moment from summers of yore, one that they would have liked to experience or, if they were there for the original, would like to experience again.

This is his first condominium building, not his first building. His commercial projects have included the Whittle Communications headquarters in Knoxville and the Louis Vuitton store in Beverly Hills.

title: Where the Girls Are
description: CATTYSHACK, Park Slope's newest women's lounge, is described by its manager, Shannon Sennott, as "queer-oriented but heterosexual friendly." On a recent Friday night the club was packed with women: women in heels, women with shaved heads and rainbow tattoos, and women in tank tops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, PROF. WILLIAM LEFFERTS IV
description: BROWN--Prof. William Lefferts IV, of the Media Arts Dept., Long Island U. Brooklyn, drowned June 7 in Conn. Preceded in death by his wife, Andrea Gibbs Brown, who passed away eight months ago of cancer. Prof. Brown was a respected electronic music composer, sound designer and installation artist who was an active member of the downtown N.Y. arts and performance community for over 25 years. Prof. Brown pioneered an innovative and highly popular program in digital audio and computerbased sound design at LIU. He is survived by his father, William Lefferts Brown of Jacksonville, FL.; sister, Susan Willis of Olympia, WA.; and nephew, Zachary W. Willis. Memorial service Thursday, June 30, Grace Church, 802 Broadway (10th Street, Manhattan), at 7 PM. Reception following. In lieu of flowers, donations appreciated to Lefferts' favorite charities: environmental groups, nature conservancies, art and performance foundations, or breast and ovarian cancer research funds.

title: Resplendent Goya Ceiling Bringing Visitors to Madrid Chapel
description: After 16 years of restoration on what has been called "Goya's Sistine Chapel," Goya's frescoes in San Antonio de la Florida were formally unveiled in their full splendor during a ceremony on June 10 in Madrid.

title: 'Sands of Empire'
Corrections
description: An article on June 12 about an exhibition of photographs by the father-and-son team of Osvaldo and Roberto Salas gave an incomplete location. The Cuban Art Space gallery is within the Center for Cuban Studies at 124 West 23rd Street in Manhattan.

title: Replacing a Rental's Kitchen Cabinets
description: Q. After we moved into our rent-controlled apartment in the mid-1960's, the landlord installed a new kitchen. We are still paying additional rent for the cost of the kitchen.

description: SOUTH PARK CONSERVATIVES The Revolt Against Liberal Media Bias. By Brian C. Anderson. 191 pp. Regnery Publishing. $24.95.

title: Interrogating Ourselves
description: I commend Joseph Lelyveld's balanced reporting of a very complex issue (June 12). The war on terror is a war of ideas, and as Americans we must occupy the high moral ground if we hope to succeed in this struggle. When we resort to torturing prisoners, we confirm in the minds of Islamic extremists what they already hate about America, thus ensuring a flood of future terrorist acts.

title: Iranian Upset, U.S. Challenge
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 - Even before Iranians went to the polls in their presidential election, the Bush administration declared the process rigged, saying that no matter what the outcome, Iran would be truly ruled by men who "spread terror across the world."

title: Lee Barnum and Erich Grosz
description: Lee Turnier Barnum and Erich Ogden Grosz, both lawyers in New York, were married last evening at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Jamie Orenstein, a magistrate judge of the Eastern District of New York, officiated. The bride and bridegroom are associates in the New York office of Debevoise & Plimpton, the law firm, she in the corporate department and he in the litigation department.

title: Paper Maker Writes It On the Wind
description: WHEN the Nature Conservancy produced its latest annual report, it chose to print it on environmentally sound Mohawk Options paper. General Electric made the same choice, in publishing its first comprehensive "citizenship report." By manufacturing a line of paper created entirely from recycled material with equipment powered by wind-generated electricity, Mohawk Paper Mills has stepped up to satisfy those with ecologic concerns, showing what a big corporation can do to support alternative energy sources.

title: A Merger? Anyone Tell the Board?
description: IN coming weeks, shareholders will vote on merger proposals that, if successful, will retire two of corporate America's biggest icons. On Thursday, owners of AT&T will vote on SBC Communications' offer to buy it for $22 billion, and on July 12, shareholders of Gillette will vote on the proposed $57 billion acquisition of their company by Procter & Gamble.

description: TEHRAN, June 26 - Iran's conservative president-elect, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, said today that he planned to move forward with his nation's nuclear program, insisting it was a matter of national pride. But he also agreed to continue discussions with three European nations which, along with the United States, fear the Islamic Republic is intent on building nuclear weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMELUNG, MARION KENT
description: AMELUNG -- Marion Kent. Resident of Hightstown, NJ, formerly of Montclair, passed away June 22, 2005. Widow of Charles F. Amelung. Survived by her daughters, Karen and Christine, three grandchildren and three great grandchildren.

title: The Rise of the Winner-Take-All Documentary
description: THE title fight, the championship game, the big race -- these events occur with such regularity in certain kinds of movies that you could set your watch by them. For a screenwriter in search of third-act drama, the climactic sports showdown is a surefire winner. And also, of course, a clich. Even in movies based on real-life sports figures and events -- "Cinderella Man," "Friday Night Lights" and "Seabiscuit" are some recent examples -- the big game can feel a bit rigged. And yet, even if we know what's coming -- or, for that matter, what really happened -- we can't help succumbing to the rush of suspense and emotion that the spectacle of high-stakes, winner-take-all competition brings.

title: 'Specimen Days': Manahatta My City

title: Rated S (For Scrubbed)
description: In the emerging industry devoted to scrubbing naughty content from DVD's, ClearPlay has a clear lead. While its competitors flirt with copyright violation by editing and reselling commercial DVD's, ClearPlay, based in Utah (actually, most of them are Utah-based), uses proprietary filtering technology to mute or skip past material without physically altering the DVD. The Family Entertainment and Copyright Act, which President Bush signed in April, explicitly protects this approach from copyright-infringement lawsuits. By downloading "filters" configured for specific movies onto a DVD player equipped with the ClearPlay software, viewers (i.e., parents) can censor 14 types of violent, sexual and linguistic content in some 1,500 films. Joel Topcik put the technology to the test with a selection of famous scenes from films in ClearPlay's catalog. Here are the results:

title: Their Unexpected Adolescence
description: When Dr. Elaine Abrams founded the Family Care Center at Harlem Hospital Center, one of New York's first clinics for the treatment of children with H.I.V. and AIDS, that "treatment" consisted mostly of easing their deaths. Through the early 90's, 10 to 20 babies were dying at F.C.C. every year; at one point, an H.I.V.-infected patient lived to the age of 6, and the doctors considered that child a medical miracle. Today -- thanks to protease inhibitors, combination therapy and other improvements in the treatment of the virus -- the average age of the approximately 135 H.I.V.-infected children being treated at F.C.C. is 13 and rising. It's possible to imagine the day when the clinic itself will be obsolete. "Over the years," Abrams says, "we've turned from a medical program with mental-health support to a mental-health program with medical support. It's the last leg of the journey."

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: June 26-July 2; ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: Is it a building? Is it a sculpture? More to the point, is it (or was it once) alive? These are some of the questions that visitors to P.S.1 in Long Island City, Queens, might be asking themselves today with the opening of "SUR," an architectural/art installation that sprawls through the courtyard of the museum. The piece is the creation of XEFIROTARCH, a Los Angeles-based architecture firm that was chosen, from among five finalists, as the winner of the sixth annual Young Architects Program, conducted by the Museum of Modern Art and P.S.1. The installation, made out of fiberglass, rubber and curvy aluminum ribs covered with latex and spandex, looks a little like a brightly colored intergalactic fossil, but it is also a shelter of sorts, filled with benches that museum officials say are "for listening and respite." Which is a good thing, because the structure will serve as a place to sit and listen during Warm Up, P.S.1's summer weekend music series. (The events are every Saturday from 3 p.m. to 9 p.m., beginning July 2 and running through Sept. 3; the architectural installation will remain up through September.) 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, (718)784-2084.

title: Inside the List
description: SAN FRANCISCO BLUES: Sentence by sentence, the most furiously written book on this week's hardcover best-seller list is almost certainly Sean Wilsey's memoir "Oh the Glory of It All," which clings to the nonfiction list at No. 14. Wilsey's book takes no prisoners. It details the very public implosion of his parent's marriage -- his father was a charming multimillionaire, his mother a pushy and glamorous society columnist -- and his later life under the watchful eyes of a hated (and similarly well-connected) stepmother. "Oh the Glory of It All" is selling particularly well in San Francisco, Wilsey's hometown, where the book landed like a fragmentation bomb aimed at the city's elite. (Even Danielle Steel didn't escape the shrapnel; she was forced to deny Wilsey's claim she had an affair with his father.) The San Francisco Chronicle has treated the book like a major news event, printing a week's worth of excerpts, listing the names of those who dared to attend Wilsey's book party and drawing up lists of actors for the movie. While San Franciscans with long memories are buying Wilsey's memoir for the old-school dirt he dishes, Wilsey has cred with younger readers, too. He's an editor at McSweeney's and an F.O.D. -- a friend of Dave, as in Dave Eggers. Wilsey's book seems unlikely to be the kind of cultural phenomenon Eggers's "Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius" (2000) was; Eggers's book stayed on the hardcover list for more than 3 months, and spent 34 weeks on the list in paperback. But "Oh the Glory of It All" is strong enough to put to rest -- for a while, anyway -- some critics' fears that the worker bees at the McSweeney's word-colony were too coy and insular to introduce many other memorably distinctive writers.

title: The Race to Alaska Before It Melts

title: 'King of the Hill' Democrats?
description: If you watch a lot of cable news, by now you've probably heard someone refer to a bloc of voters known as " 'South Park' conservatives." The term comes from the title of a new book by Brian C. Anderson, a conservative pundit who adapted it from the writer Andrew Sullivan, and it refers to the notion that Comedy Central's obscene spoof of life in small-town America, with its hilarious skewering of liberal snobbery, is somehow the perfect crucible for understanding a new breed of brash and irreverent Republican voters. In truth, aside from its title, Anderson's book has very little to say about "South Park" itself; it's really just a retread of the argument that the mainstream media is losing its grip on world domination, marketed rather cynically to appeal to the same red-state radio hosts and book clubs that make so many right-wing polemics best sellers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BATES, JAMES S.
description: BATES--James S. Longtime resident of Vero Beach, FL. and veteran oil industry executive, died June 18 at the Hospice House in Vero Beach following a prolonged illness. He was 79. Mr. Bates was born in Floral Park, NY on March 26, 1926. He graduated from New York University and went on to obtain an MBA at the University of Pittsburgh. Mr. Bates joined the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey as a mail clerk in 1944 while still attending college, and retired from the same company, which had become Exxon International as a Senior Vice President in 1988. Then, in New York City, he became President and CEO of the Vanderbilt Petroleum Company. He fully retired from business in 1992. During most of his business career, Mr. Bates was a resident of Greenwich, CT, moving to John's Island in Vero Beach upon his retirement. He was an avid sportsman. In his youth, he boxed in the Golden Gloves Tournaments and played baseball in the Cleveland Indians organization as a pitcher. In his later life, with equal enthusiasm, he took up golf, skiing and paddle tennis. He was a member of the John's Island Club of Vero Beach, Burning Tree Country Club of Greenwich, Connecticut and the Morris County Golf Club of Convent Station, New Jersey. Mr. Bates is survived by his wife, Louise; a son, James Bates, Jr.; five daughters, Barbara Blynn, Joan Kelly, Jean Ferrari, Jill Champagne and Joy Vander Wal; and eleven grandchildren. A Mass was celebrated at the Holy Cross Catholic Church on June 21, followed by a reception at the John's Island Clubhouse. In memory of Jim, contributions may be sent to Our Lady of Guadalupe Mission, 12896 County Road #

Paid Notice: Deaths   AHRENS, JOYCE NOLAN
description: AHRENS--Joyce Nolan, Of Indian River Shores, Florida, died June 25, 2005 at Indian River Memorial Hospital, Vero Beach, Florida. Mrs. Ahrens was born in Brooklyn, New York in July 1925. She attended St. Francis Xavier's Academy and received her Bachelor's Degree from Notre Dame College and Master's Degree in Speech from Columbia University. Upon graduation she began her career in speech education and served with the Department of Speech Improvement of the New York City Board of Education. As well, Mrs. Ahrens directed speech education programs at several colleges in the New York area. She married William H. Ahrens in 1951 and resided in Princeton, New Jersey and New York City before departing for Tehran, Iran in 1959, where her husband served as chief architect for an international architectural and engineering firm. In 1962, the Ahrens moved to Rome, Italy where her husband established Ahrens DiGrazia International, a firm of architects, engineers and planners. The Ahrens remained in Rome, Italy for the next 33 years before moving to Indian River Shores in 1995. While in Rome Mrs. Ahrens took an active role in both the Italian and American communities, serving as President of the USO Council of Rome for several terms, President of the American Women's Association of Rome and President of the Santa Susanna Guild. She also served as trustee of the Vincent Palotti Institute. During her stay in Rome she was an English language news broadcaster for Vatican Radio and editor of the "Word in the World" published by the Society of the Divine Word. As an author she is known for her book on her life in Iran, "A Persian Moment". With her husband she received the "Rector's Award" from the Pontifical North American College in Rome. In 1989. Mrs. Ahrens was named a Dame of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta and in 1996 was appointed by Pope John Paul II a Dame of the Pontifical Order of St. Gregory the Great. Mrs. Ahrens was a member of John's Island Club, the Metropolitan Club of New York and of "Aqua Santa," the Golf Club of Rome Visitation will be from 5-8 P.M., Tuesday, June 28, 2005 at the Strunk Funeral Home, Vero Beach, Florida. There will be a prayer vigil at 7:30 P.M., Tuesday. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10 A.M., Wednesday, June 29, 2005 at Holy Cross Catholic Church, Vero Beach, Florida. Interment will be in John's Island Cemetery, Indian River Shores, Florida.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas: Canada: Reviewing Foreign Bids
description: The Canadian government has introduced legislation to include national security as a reason for rejecting foreign acquisitions of Canadian companies. The move follows an unsuccessful bid for Noranda, Canada's largest mining company, by China Minmetals, which is controlled by the Chinese government. While the Canadian government said the proposed legislation, which was presented last week, is not related to any specific case, many Canadian critics of the Minmetals bid argued that it threatened Canada's national security. Other opponents of the deal cited China's human rights record, an issue not addressed by the proposed changes. Under its proposals, the government would also acquire the ability to review takeovers of any size for national security reasons. Under a law passed 20 years ago, takeovers can be challenged for economic reasons if they are worth more than 250 million Canadian dollars. Ian Austen (NYT)

description: On a trip to southern Putumayo State to meet with his military commanders, President lvaro Uribe acknowledged logistical and intelligence errors by the military after Marxist rebels killed 25 soldiers in two separate engagements on Saturday. Across the country, six more soldiers died in combat with rebels in the northeast. The deaths represented the worst single-day loss of life for the armed forces since Mr. Uribe took office nearly three years ago. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: Arroyo Apology For Vote 'Lapse'
description: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo went on national television, acknowledged that she had phoned an election commissioner during voting for president last year and apologized for a "lapse in judgment." But she denied trying to influence the vote count and insisted she would not resign, as some of her opponents have been demanding in a three-week-long political crisis over a secretly recorded telephone conversation between a woman who sounds like Mrs. Arroyo and a man said to be an election commissioner. In the recording, the woman asks if her lead could fall below a million votes and expresses concern about areas in the south. The man tells her, "We will do our best." The final tally gave her more than a million votes over her chief rival. In her address, Mrs. Arroyo said she had spoken to the election commissioner not because she wanted to influence the outcome of the election but because she was anxious to protect her votes. Members of her government said they hoped the apology would put the issue behind her. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

Rarely do the group's members -- Michael Ian Black, Michael Showalter and David Wain -- offer a straight answer. When asked why they're perpetually clad in suits, for example, Mr. Black, 33, said, "They're classy, they're comfortable, they do a really good job of hiding scar tissue." title: That Giant Sucking Sound
description: THAT GIANT SUCKING SOUND -- In a stark reminder of the harsh personal toll of the airline industry's slump, the government released figures showing that employment at the major carriers has fallen 34 percent during the last four years, to 285,800 full-time workers in April from 433,400 in April 2001. The biggest declines were at US Airways, down 49.6 percent, and United Airlines, down 42.4 percent, according to the Bureau of Transportation Statistics at the Transportation Department. But the jobs picture was much brighter at the seven top low-cost carriers, which had a net gain in workers of 12.5 percent in April of this year (71,000) compared with April 2001 (59,600). It was better still at the regional carriers, which had 14.4 percent more employees in April (56,600) than in April 2001 (30,500).

title: Something Old, Something New, Something ... Wacky
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., June 26 - A great deal of work goes into making new things that look old. Take the Harkness Chapel at Connecticut College here, built in 1939 but emulating a Romanesque church with painted wooden beams, massive stone walls and stained glass set into round-arched windows. Because the building is not actually ancient, those windows can be opened, as they were on Sunday night, allowing a breeze to enter from the college's verdant, picture-perfect New England green. In short, bursts of fresh air wafted through a re-creation of something old, making it a good fit for the concert inside, a performance of Handel's "Xerxes" that aspired to do exactly the same thing.

World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Soldier Guilty Of Killing British Activist
description: A military court convicted a former soldier of manslaughter in the 2003 shooting death of a British activist who was working with the Palestinians. The Briton, Tom Hurndall, 21, was shot in the head after helping children move away from the Israeli forces in Rafah, in the Gaza Strip, witnesses said. He never regained consciousness and died nine months later. He belonged to the International Solidarity Movement, a pro-Palestinian group whose members have often placed themselves between the Israeli forces and Palestinians. The court found that the former soldier, Taysir al-Heib, above, an Israeli sergeant at the time, had shot Mr. Hurndall with a sniper rifle using a telescopic sight. He was also convicted of obstruction of justice, submitting false testimony and obtaining false testimony. Sentencing is set for next week. Rights groups and Palestinians say that the Israeli military has killed many unarmed Palestinians, and a number of foreigners, and that the shootings are rarely investigated. Israel says that civilians are not the targets of military action and that it conducts inquiries in cases where soldiers are suspected of wrongdoing. Greg Myre (NYT)

The full Council is expected to vote on the bill tomorrow. The Council voted in 2003 to require a sale of special medallions that could be used only with hybrids or cabs that run on compressed natural gas. The commission, which has said that available hybrid models lack sufficient leg room, said it was progressing toward having hybrid taxis on the road by the fall. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Nathan Lane's Summer Plans
description: Sometimes, things just come together. Nathan Lane, right, who had originally planned to star in Terrence McNally's new play, "Dedication, or the Stuff of Dreams," but was unable to find time in his busy schedule, is now back in the show, pinch-hitting for Peter Frechette, who had to leave "Dedication" because of a scheduling conflict of his own. Mr. Lane, who is to star in the hot-selling revival of Neil Simon's "Odd Couple" this fall, will start rehearsals today for Mr. McNally's new play, which follows the adventures of a couple who run a children's theater in upstate New York. "Dedication," a Primary Stages production, starts previews at the 59E59 Theaters on July 26, and Mr. Lane is to appear in it through Labor Day, after which he starts rehearsals for "The Odd Couple" with Matthew Broderick and -- yep, you guessed it -- Mr. Frechette.

description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain ruled out a halt in the deportation of Zimbabwean asylum seekers who have been refused permission to remain in Britain. Zimbabwean officials said deportees would be safe. Mr. Blair said Britain would not deport people likely to face persecution but did not wish to expose its asylum system to abuse. description: ERDMAN--Barbara Claudia Mason. Of Greenwich, CT, passed away Friday, June 24, at New York Presbyterian Hospital, at age 57. She was predeceased by her husband, William Erdman, and leaves a daughter, Alexandra Marie, 18. Mrs. Erdman was active in the community and enjoyed travel and golf. Besides her daughter, she is survived by a brother, Wayne Winarski of Pennsylvania. A service will be held at Round Hill Community Church, at 395 Round Hill Road, on Tuesday, June 28, at noon. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORGAN, ANDREW ROSS
description: MORGAN--Andrew Ross was born July 25, 1979, in Austin, Texas. He died June 22, 2005, in New York City. Beloved son of Clayton and Cynthia Morgan, of Austin; adored brother of Lillian and Elliot Morgan. Some people wear their spirit on the outside. When you meet them your own light shines brighter. When they're gone, you still have the treasures they gave away every day. Andy gave us the extra light we need to face his sudden passing. Andy was an accomplished photographer, cook, athlete, artist and lover of literature. He graduated from Pacific Lutheran University with a degree in business administration and a minor in jazz studies. He was the manager at Blue Ribbon Bakery in New York at the time of his death, meeting with an accident as he cycled to work. He had traveled to most of the continental U.S., Europe, central Asia, Mexico and South America. Andy taught us all how important every day is. He recently wrote in a letter to his family, "Remember, now is as good a time as ever because we are here on earth together. I know I'll look back on these days with weak legs and a bitter sweet gravity pulling towards my heart because this is all we have, and I have so much love for you. In addition to his immediate family, Andy is survived by many other relatives in Texas. His family thanks his co-workers and the owners of Blue Ribbon Bakery, Eric, Bruce and Michael, also Tom Lowry and Rodean Landeaux, Rex and Ginalola for their support and help. A remembrance will be held at Blue Ribbon Bakery at noon Wednesday.

title: Arts, Briefly; Sunday Ratings
description: So far, this summer's Sunday television schedule has a generation gap. For the third week in a row, CBS's Sunday was No. 1 in total viewers but failed to win the 18-to-49 category. Its lineup, repeats of "60 Minutes," "Cold Case" and the movie "Changing Lanes," drew an average of 7.78 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates. Among 18-to-49-year-olds, however, CBS was No. 4. Fox, which was in fourth place among total viewers, won that age group. Its best performer was a new episode of "Family Guy" at 9 p.m., which drew an audience of 7.29 million. But a repeat of "American Dad," which followed, lost nearly a million of those viewers. It was the only half-hour of the night when Fox failed to place first among adults 18 to 49. "American Dad" was outpaced in that demographic by the last 30 minutes of a particularly tear-jerking, two-part episode of ABC's "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" (7.38 million), in which the team remade both an 8-year-old cancer patient's hospital ward and her family's home. title: Another Terror Attack, but Not by Humans
description: Quiet as the publicity department at Paramount has tried to keep it, the earth is under attack by aliens. I know what you're thinking: what, again? Once upon a time -- for example, in 1938, when Orson Welles scared the bejesus out of America with his "War of the Worlds" radio broadcast -- the pop-cultural spectacle of invasion from outer space could raise some real alarm. Of course, as a thousand think pieces over the next week or so are sure to remind us, Welles's Martians were symbolic displacements of actual threats, a role that marauding space creatures have often been happy to take on, especially during the cold war. But with "Mars Attacks!" and "Men in Black" -- and even "Independence Day" -- the aliens and their minions at the studios began to get a little self-conscious and somewhat less ambitious. The Martians were content to be temporary diversions from our true fears rather than allegorical crystallizations of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLINE, IRVING
description: KLINE--Irving, a longtime Yonkers resident died Monday, June 27, 2005 at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, N.Y. He was 92. He was born on December 31, 1912 in New York City to Morris Kline and Rebecca Norr Kline. He was educated at Evander Childs High School (1930) in New York and graduated from City College in 1934. During the Second World War, he served in the U.S. Army 44th Cavalry Recon as a Staff Sergeant in the U.S., Britain, France and Germany. During W.W. II he served in a U.S. Army tank patrol that liberated two concentration camps in Germany. He gave testimony to the Survivors of the Shoah Visual History Foundation Project. He held memberships in the Jewish War Veterans, Yonkers Post No. 68; the Zionist Organization of America; the Crestwood B'nai B'rith; and the Simon Wiesenthal Center for Holocaust Studies in Vienna. He married Julia Hurwitz of Syracuse in 1946. She died in 1978. His wife Muriel Kline survives him. Irving and Muriel were honored for their commitment to world Jewry at the Midchester Jewish Center for the 1980 UJA-Federation Campaign. He was again honored on October 30, 1988 at the Minyanaires Breakfast at the Midchester Jewish Center. After WWII, Irving was first partner with his uncle, Ben Gold, and then President of the Jacobson Paint Co, Inc. in the Bronx. The funeral will be held in the Weinstein Memorial Chapel in Yonkers, N.Y. on Wednesday at 9:45AM. Burial will be in the Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla. The family requests that donations be made in his memory to Greenburgh Hebrew Center, 515 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. 10922.

Christine Pritchard, a spokeswoman for Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, said the decision established a favorable precedent for the state in several other Indian land-claims cases. It also strengthened the hand of Governor Pataki in stop-and-start negotiations over the Cayugas' proposal to open a casino in the Catskills. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Machine Clobbers Man
description: In chess, is the battle for supremacy between men and machines over? Two matches, pitting humans against computers, ended recently with decidedly mixed results for the humans. On June 21, Rustam Kasimdzhanov of Uzbekistan, the reigning champion of the World Chess Federation, ranked No.32 in the world, played one game against a version of Fritz, a popular commercial chess program. Fritz was running on a tool bar, created by Accoona Corporation, that searches for files on personal computers and on the Web. That game ended in a tie. Another match, six games between Michael Adams, above, of Britain, No.6 in the world, and Hydra, a chess supercomputer developed by Pal Group of the United Arab Emirates, was easily won by Hydra, 5.5 to 0.5. While other people have lost matches to computers, most notably Garry Kasparov, who lost to Deep Blue in 1997, the margin of victory for Hydra stunned some in the chess world. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

title: President Bush's Speech About Iraq
description: President Bush told the nation last night that the war in Iraq was difficult but winnable. Only the first is clearly true. Despite buoyant cheerleading by administration officials, the military situation is at best unimproved. The Iraqi Army, despite Mr. Bush's optimistic descriptions, shows no signs of being able to control the country without American help for years to come. There are not enough American soldiers to carry out the job they have been sent to do, yet the strain of maintaining even this inadequate force is taking a terrible toll on the ability of the United States to defend its security on other fronts around the world.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Ex-Official Admits To Bribes
description: Ludwig-Holger Pfahls, a high-ranking defense official in the government of former Chancellor Helmut Kohl who is accused of bribe-taking and corruption, surprised a court in Augsburg by confessing that in 1990 he had accepted about one million euros, or $1.2 million, for facilitating the sale of armored vehicles to the United States. Mr. Pfahls, who was arrested in Paris last year after five years on the run, is actually on trial over a separate matter: accusations that he accepted bribes of nearly $2.4 million from a weapons lobbyist in an arms sale involving Saudi Arabia in 1991. Mr. Pfahl's lawyers said they would like to invite Mr. Kohl and the former foreign ministers Klaus Kinkel and Hans-Dietrich Genscher to testify about the deal. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Shadows at Home: Living Where B.T.K. Killed
description: WICHITA, Kan., June 28 - There are six of them left, homes of different sizes, different styles, different neighborhoods, but lumped together by the same dark past and known throughout town by the same name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ISAACS, RICHARD M.
description: ISAACS--Richard M. On June 26, 2005. Beloved husband of Maggie (nee Bowes). Devoted father of Lynne and Charles, and father-in-law to Christine. Loving grandfather of Lauren and Brion. Fond stepfather of Paul and stepgrandfather of Paul Jr. and Kenny. Family will receive friends on Tuesday 6 to 8PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street. Funeral services Wednesday 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Little Hill-Alina Lodge, Box G, Blairstown, N.J. 07825 or the Alphonia Isaacs Health Center at the Juilliard School, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, N.Y. 10023.

description: WASHINGTON, June 28 - An American military helicopter transporting Special Operations troops crashed Tuesday in a rugged area of eastern Afghanistan where fighting is going on, military officials said.

title: New York Patrolmen Awarded 10% Raise
description: An arbitration panel yesterday formally awarded a 10 percent raise over two years to New York City's police officers, concluding that they are underpaid compared with police in other cities and nearby suburbs. By giving ammunition to other unions claiming to be underpaid, the panel's ruling could have serious financial consequences for the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVISON, ISABELLE C.
description: LEVISON--Isabelle C. A resident of Florida, died June 25, 2005. A native of Norfolk, Virginia, she also resided in New York City and Detroit, Michigan. She was a founder at Mount Sinai Medical Center and Miami Jewish Home for the Aged, and a patron of the arts. Survived by her children Sally A. Edwards & Edward J. Minskoff, sister Rena Kriegel, four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

title: Lack of information slows bird flu investigation in China
Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Friday listing acquisitions of foreign companies by Chinese companies misidentified one party to a deal. North of England was acquired by Gas Network, a British company that is 70 percent owned by Cheung Kong Infrastructure Holdings of Hong Kong -- not by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority. The chart also referred incorrectly to a deal involving the Hong Kong Monetary Authority. The authority bought 8.9 percent of HSBC Holdings of Britain -- an investment, not an acquisition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, L. HARVEY
description: LEVINE--L. Harvey, age 75, of Port Washington, NY, died Tuesday, June 28, 2005. Beloved husband of Marcia, adored father of Susan and Jim, Roger and Betsy and Robin and David. Exuberant grandfather of Sam, Jake, Nina, Eric, Zach, Eddie and Sarah. Loving brother of Rosalind Miller and Muriel Traubner and the late Phyllis Ruskin. Devoted uncle of John and Michelle, Annato and Lisa. He was our rock. His spirit, energy and love of life and learning are part of us forever. Memorial service to be held Thursday, June 30, at 11:30 AM at the Reconstructionist Synagogue of the North Shore, 1001 Plandome Road, Plandome, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEZZO, RAYMOND M.
description: PEZZO--Raymond M., of Poughkeepsie, NY, 74, accomplished lawyer, author, U.S. Air Force instructor and pilot, passed away on June 20, 2005. A graduate from the University of Buffalo with a Master of Law from New York University, he won the Northeastern Inter-Collegiate All Events Bowling Championship in 1953. Mr. Pezzo is survived by twin sons Matthew & Andrew, sister Gloria, and brothers Albert & Louis.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Self-Injury Prison Protest
description: In a grisly protest with an aim that is not yet publicly clear, hundreds of inmates in a Russian prison camp sliced their wrists, legs and necks in a mass protest against their lot, human rights groups and Russian news media reported. It was not immediately clear who had organized the protest or how seriously injured the prisoners were. Nor was it clear how so many prisoners, all in a camp in the Kursk region, about 300 miles south of Moscow, were able to acquire so many sharp instruments. Russian prisons remain fearsome places, with poor rations, overcrowding and high risks of tuberculosis and H.I.V. infection. They are often criticized by former inmates and human rights organizations. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Saints and sinners walking the long road to Santiago

title: Gay Marriage Is Extended Nationwide in Canada
description: TORONTO, June 28 - The House of Commons voted Tuesday night to extend marriage rights to gay and lesbian couples throughout Canada despite strong opposition from the Conservatives and a splintering of the governing Liberal Party caucus.

title: Milan Mystery: Did Italy Have Role in Kidnapping Case?
description: MILAN, June 28 - At least two of the men who snatched him from the street here spoke Italian, an Egyptian terror suspect told a friend here last year. It is not proof for sure, the friend said, but it fuels a growing suspicion that Italian officials, on some level, were involved in the kidnapping.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Marijuana Bill Gains
description: The legislature passed a bill allowing the use of medical marijuana three weeks after the Supreme Court ruled that federal authorities could prosecute users, even in states with laws allowing medical use. Katie Zezima (NYT)

It made available a version of its iTunes software designed for subscribing to podcasts, audio recordings that can be downloaded to an iPod or other music player for portable listening.

description: A California businessman who boasted that he paid no income taxes because no law required him to do so has pleaded guilty to filing a false refund claim, the latest blow to the tax protest movement.

title: The Case of 2 Columbus Circle
description: So far, Edward Durell Stone is not having a good century. Two years ago, the extraordinary house he built for A. Conger Goodyear in Old Westbury, N.Y., was nearly torn down. Early this month, the board of trustees at the University of Arkansas approved the razing of an apartment complex designed by Stone, an Arkansas native who died in 1978. But the real insult has come from New York City, and specifically from the Landmarks Preservation Commission, which has refused to hold hearings to discuss the fate of Stone's controversial building at 2 Columbus Circle.

An editor at Newsweek has pointed out that the magazine wrote about the document on its Web site on June 19.

title: Arts, Briefly; Another Neil Simon Couple
description: It's looking more and more as if the 2005-6 season will be Neil Simon's year on Broadway. With the Nathan Lane-Matthew Broderick revival of "The Odd Couple" already setting sales records -- it has an advance of more than $16 million, unheard of for a straight play -- now comes word of the cast for a new production of "Barefoot in the Park," the 1963 romantic comedy by Mr. Simon, right. Patrick Wilson (who starred in HBO's "Angels in America") and Amanda Peet (in Neil LaBute's "This Is How It Goes") will fill the roles of the newlyweds Paul and Corie Bratter, originally played by Robert Redford and Elizabeth Ashley. Jill Clayburgh and Tony Roberts will also star. (Mr. Roberts replaced Mr. Redford during the Broadway run.) The new production, to be directed by Scott Elliott, begins rehearsals on Dec. 26, with an eye toward a February 2006 opening at a Broadway theater to be announced. JESSE McKINLEY

title: Arts, Briefly; Twice-Told Tales Win
description: CBS's all-repeat lineup on Mondays continued its winning ways this week. Two reruns of "Still Standing," which will move to Wednesdays in the fall, were followed by "Everybody Loves Raymond," "Two and a Half Men" and "CSI: Miami." According to Nielsen's estimates, the whole package was No.1 in total viewers (averaging 9.21 million) and among adults 18 to 49. The "CSI: Miami" repeat was the night's most-watched show. Among total viewers, CBS had no competition on Monday, but in the 18-to-49 demographic, Fox was a close second with a rerun of "Nanny 911" (5.68 million) and an original episode of "Hell's Kitchen" (6.99 million), which was the night's most popular show among 18- to 49-year-olds. In the ratings for the week that ended on Sunday, ABC won that demographic for the third week in a row, largely because of the N.B.A. finals and "Dancing With the Stars." But CBS was No.1 in total viewers for the fourth consecutive week. KATE AURTHUR

title: Crisp, Complex and Refreshing
description: ON a hot summer night, a beer need only be cold and wet to satisfy. But consider if the standard were set a little higher. Imagine a beer that offered more than the internal equivalent of holding a cold, glistening bottle against a flushed and sweaty forehead. What if that beer did not merely satisfy, but inspired?

title: Arrested Development
description: BERKELEY, CALIF. - LAST month John Miller, director of the State Department's Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons, said that half the victims of human trafficking may be children under 18. Children are "at the center" of the problem of trafficking, which, Mr. Miller noted, is one of the great human rights issues of the 21st century. Yes, children should be at the heart of our concern for human rights. But that concern should start with the children detained in American prisons in Afghanistan, Iraq and Guantnamo Bay.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cancer Drug Approved
description: AstraZeneca, Europe's third-biggest drug maker, said British regulators approved its Arimidex drug to treat postmenopausal women who have undergone surgery for a type of breast cancer fueled by the hormone estrogen. The Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency approved the medicine's use after surgery for postmenopausal breast cancer to prevent the disease's return, AstraZeneca said in an e-mail statement. The approval can be used to enter the market in five other countries, including Spain and Italy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAY, STUART
description: GRAY--Stuart. Beloved husband for 52 years to Lucille; adored dad of Shelley, Lynn and Marcy; cherished Papa to Katie, Jake, Ella and Tal; loved father-in-law to David and Itzik; treasured brother to Pat. A most special and gentle man. Memorial service 10:30 AM, July 1, small chapel at Congregation Kol Ami, White Plains. GRAY--Stuart. We were fortunate to have known and enjoyed the warmth and good humor of Stuart's friendship for more than 50 years. His sincerity, smile and charm made friends everywhere. We join his loving wife, Lucille, & all the devoted family in sadly saying a last goodbye to a special man we loved. Jackie and Harvey Cooper Dolores and Howard Reed GRAY--Stuart. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved longtime member, Stuart Gray. title: U.S. Said to Plan Rackets Lawsuit Over Dockworkers' Union
description: Federal authorities are preparing to file a sweeping civil racketeering lawsuit against the International Longshoremen's Association, officials who were briefed on the case said yesterday. It would be the government's most aggressive attempt ever to wrest the nation's Atlantic and Gulf Coast docks and the union that represents their workers from what prosecutors say is a half-century of control by two powerful New York mob clans.

title: Arts, Briefly; Bush Rattles Ratings
description: There were no big ratings winners on Tuesday, when a speech by President Bush threw a wrench into the networks' schedules. In Nielsen estimates, CBS finished first in both total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. Its numbers were bolstered by "48 Hours Mystery" (7.32 million), which was the night's most-watched show. Though the preliminary ratings suggest that ABC's coverage of the president's speech attracted the most viewers, over all ABC was No.2 in households, and No.4 among 18-to-49-year-olds. Its two-hour premiere of the mini-series "Empire" brought in a mere 6.47 million viewers. On NBC -- third place in households and in the 18-to-49 demographic -- the season premiere of "Average Joe" fared poorly (4.62 million). And "I Want to Be a Hilton" lost more than 2 million viewers after its premiere last week, drawing an audience of only 4.36 million. That drop occurred even though Kathy Hilton brought out her daughters Paris and Nicky Hilton as guest stars, along with Tinkerbell, Paris's chihuahua. KATE AURTHUR

"I'm like the Century 21 of furniture," said Victor DiBlasi, the owner, who offers showroom samples from companies in the building like Henredon, Century and Disegno. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Appeals Court Upholds Judge's Removal
description: The state's highest court upheld yesterday the removal of Judge Michael H. Feinberg, the Brooklyn surrogate judge, for awarding $8.6 million in legal fees to a longtime friend to handle the legal matters of people who died with no wills. The court said the judge had "debased his office and eroded public confidence" in the judiciary. The State Commission on Judicial Conduct recommended the judge's removal in February, and yesterday the appeals court unanimously upheld it, noting that he had demonstrated "a shocking disregard for the very law that imbued him with judicial authority." An intense campaign for succession is likely. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: A Fast Chair for Indoors, Outdoors and Quick Getaways
description: Harald Belker, a Los Angeles designer who once worked for Porsche, specializes in fantasy vehicles for movies, from the Batmobile in "Batman & Robin" and the futuristic cars of "Minority Report" to a wacky three-wheeled contraption in "The Cat in the Hat." Now he has introduced his first piece of furniture. The Maxelle chair, produced by the Swedish company Lyx, has swooping arms and is made of fiberglass, making it suitable for both indoor and outdoor use. "I wanted to take lines from automotive design to make it a more dynamic object," Mr. Belker said of the chair's streamlined shape. At $2,000, it comes in six enameled colors and is available through Space Downtown, 276 West 25th Street; (212)352-9968. ARIC CHEN

title: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: Support From Russia
description: Russia increased its support for Uzbekistan, announcing that it would soon conduct joint military exercises with the Uzbeks, the first of their kind since Uzbekistan broke from the Soviet Union in 1991. The announcement by Sergei B. Ivanov, Russia's defense minister, was broadcast on Russian national television after he met in Moscow with Islam A. Karimov, the Uzbek president. Mr. Karimov, who has resisted Western pressure after Uzbekistan's lethal crackdown on antigovernment demonstrators last month, has been wooed by China and Russia. On Tuesday, he was received by President Vladimir V. Putin, above, and treated as an honored guest. A televised portion of the meeting showed Mr. Karimov hinting to Mr. Putin that the United States was behind the uprising. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

With Vulcan as My Landscaper
description: AHIHI-KINAU NATURAL AREA RESERVE, Hawaii - THE first sign of something suspicious on the lava field was a trail of carpet swatches leading to a cave. On Dec. 10 rangers in this Maui reserve, some of the most stringently protected lands in Hawaii, gingerly approached the concealed lava tube where Karen Mayfield, who is also called Harmony, had been living alone for three years. Deep in the recesses of the tube, a commodious channel with cathedral ceilings through which lava once flowed, they were astonished to find wind chimes, shelves made from Boogie boards and other "unnatural items," including the four-poster that Ms. Mayfield, seeking "spiritual attunement" and a simpler lifestyle, had single-handedly hauled in pieces across the treacherously sharp and slippery lava field.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey's Road To Europe To Be 'Long and Difficult'
description: The European Commission unveiled draft negotiating rules for membership talks with Turkey, setting the toughest conditions yet for a country seeking to join the European Union. "Turkey will not become a member of the union today or tomorrow," Olli Rehn, the commissioner for enlargement, said in Brussels. "It will be a long and difficult journey." The rules must still be approved by the union's national governments for talks on Turkey's membership to open as expected on Oct. 3. They include a requirement that Turkey sign a customs agreement that recognizes Cyprus "within the next few weeks" and a clause to stop the talks if Turkey persistently breached human rights or the rule of law. Even as a member, countries could erect barriers to Turkish migration. Mr. Rehn underlined that talks were likely to last at least until 2014. Graham Bowley (IHT)

title: Backsplashes That Take 50 Million Years To Make
description: Last week, the Green River Stone Company opened its first showroom in New York, where it sells stones bearing the images of fossilized palm fronds, above, and fish like the diplomystus in the backsplash below. The company owns a 13-acre quarry in a part of the Wyoming desert that 50 million years ago was a freshwater lake in a subtropical climate, said Doug Miller, one of the partners in the company. Mr. Miller said that Green River quarries 15,000 to 30,000 square feet of stone a year, turning up hundreds of fossils that range in color from reddish brown to almost black. They are sold in large murals or as smaller stones, for tiles, backsplashes or countertops. Prices start at $200 to $300 per square foot at the store, Fossil Interior, 51 Wooster Street (Broome Street); (212)219-2656. ELAINE LOUIE

National Briefing | Science and Health: Cancer Therapy
description: The drug Xeloda is as effective as intravenous chemotherapy for colon cancer after surgery and has fewer side effects, a study financed by the drug's maker, Roche Holding, found. The company used the results to win regulatory approval of Xeloda this month. Xeloda is an alternative to generic intravenous drugs, allowing at-home care with less severe diarrhea, nausea and drops in white blood-cells. Xeloda or the Sanofi-Aventis drug Eloxatin should be considered for colon cancer patients, said the researchers, led by Chris Twelves of the University of Glasgow. The New England Journal of Medicine published the study.

title: World Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: Leader's Husband To Go Into Exile
description: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, facing increasing pressure to step down amid accusations that she unfairly sought to influence the outcome of the 2004 presidential election, announced that her husband, Jose Miguel Arroyo -- accused of taking bribes from gambling syndicates -- will leave the country and live abroad. She did not say where or when her husband would go into exile, but said he had "volunteered to remove himself from any situation that will cast doubt on my presidency." Barely an hour later, Susan Roces, a movie star and the widow of the man Mrs. Arroyo beat in the election, Fernando Poe Jr., also a movie star, held a press conference to demand that Mrs. Arroyo resign immediately. Oscar V. Cruz, the archbishop of Lingayen-Dagupan, also called for her resignation. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)
