description: A convicted sex offender from Brooklyn who was arrested yesterday on charges of violating the conditions of his release from prison is considered a suspect in three rapes in Upper Manhattan this month, the authorities said yesterday. The man, Franklin Darwin, 58, was arrested on Tuesday at his home on Taaffe Place in Clinton Hill, the police said. Officers first confronted Mr. Darwin on East 90th Street in Manhattan on Monday night. Police patrols in the neighorhood had been stepped up since three women were raped this month on the Upper East Side and Upper West Side. description: KELLY--Sheila (nee Horgan), on June 27. Will be missed by many loving family members and friends. We love you and were blessed to have had you in our lives. Information: Flynn Memorial Home, Yonkers, NY.

title: Judge Warns Reporters They Face Jail in a Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 - With mounting frustration and a hint of anger, a federal judge said at a hearing Wednesday that he would send two reporters to jail in one week if they did not agree to testify before a grand jury about their confidential sources in the meantime.

title: Ali Returns to Where the Gloves Had to Go Away to Jail
description: NO matter where Muhammad Ali travels now, he's usually been there or thereabouts. With or without the heavyweight championship, he was a true world boxer. Most of his bouts were in the United States, but he also fought in Manila, Kinshasa, London, Tokyo, Munich, Frankfurt, Zurich, Dublin, Toronto, Vancouver, Jakarta, San Juan and Nassau as well as Rome, where he won an Olympic gold medal in 1960.

title: Permit Issued for Long-Disputed Work at 2 Columbus Circle
description: A work permit for the reconstruction of 2 Columbus Circle was issued yesterday, effectively defeating the decade-long effort by preservationists to have the building, designed by Edward Durell Stone, designated as a landmark.

title: Minaya a Likely Trading Partner
description: When Mets General Manager Omar Minaya wakes up every morning, he does not bother to check the standings. He says that he simply works the phones as if his team were in first place.

title: Talk Show Washout Tries Again
description: Perhaps the best way to sum up an MSNBC talk show that describes itself as "so fast -- it's changing the pace of news" is by adopting the program's taste for summary judgment: "The Situation," starring Tucker Carlson, a former host of CNN's "Crossfire," is all cross and no fire.

title: Optimism about talks rises in Seoul
Once again, a French finance aide is under fire
New York and Capri
description: ON Friday Helen Wang, the Parson's School of Design alumna whose dresses hang from the racks at Barney's New York and Bergdorf Goodman, plans to open her first stand-alone boutique in SoHo (below). The sleek, minimalist space complements this designer's signature light, summery frocks and provides ample room for her new collections of home furnishings, jewelry, women's eveningwear, men's shirts and children's fashions. At 69 Mercer Street, (212) 997-4180.

title: Online Dating? Thin and Rich Works Here, Too
description: ONLINE dating is one of the most popular paid services on the Internet. A 2003 report by comScore Networks stated that 40 million Americans had visited an online dating site, and JupiterResearch reported early this year that industry revenue will reach $516 million in 2005.

title: The True Cost of War
description: In anger and embarrassment, Congressional Republicans are scrambling to repair a budget shortfall in veterans' medical care now that the Bush administration has admitted it vastly underestimated the number of returning Iraq and Afghanistan personnel needing treatment. The $1 billion-plus gaffe is considerable, with the original budget estimate of 23,553 returned veterans needing care this year now ballooning to 103,000. American taxpayers should be even more furious than Congress.

title: Are Men Ready for the 5-Step, 10-Minute Shave?
description: ANGELO RAGAZA used to shave in less than three minutes, which was all the time he was willing to devote to a chore he considered a nuisance. He washed, applied a dollop of shave gel and with a couple dozen brisk strokes of a disposable razor, scraped his face clean. But that was before a friend gave him a luxurious shaving kit as a gift.

title: On your bike!Sport sprints ahead
A More Perfect Union
description: IT is a time of trial for organized labor. Only 13 percent of nonagricultural workers are unionized. The figure is even lower among immigrants who toil at unskilled jobs in the nation's newest industries. Employers have abandoned the paternalistic job security measures, pensions and fringe benefits of which they boasted only a few years ago. Instead, they are imposing wage cuts and speedups on their workers while the American Federation of Labor stands by helplessly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FITZSIMONS, KIMBERLY ANNE
description: FITZSIMONS -- Kimberly Anne, suddenly on June 28, 2005. Beloved daughter of Richard and Kathleen FitzSimons of Fairfield, CT and very much loved sister of Ryan of Manchester, NH. Also survived by many aunts, uncles and cousins. Kim attended Greens Farms Academy in Greens Farms, CT and George Washington University, Washington, DC majoring in media and TV communications. Kim was an owner of Indigo Media, Inc. and a producer of documentaries for TV, TV commercials and music videos. Family will receive relatives and friends at Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, NYC Friday July 1 from 2-5 & 7-9PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated in her parish at St. Francis Xavier RC Church Saturday July 2nd at 10AM. Burial will follow at Oak Lawn Cemetery, Fairfield, CT. A memorial service will follow at a date to be determined in Fairfield, CT. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Big Sister Program or the Humane Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAGER, SIDNEY
description: TAGER--Sidney on June 27, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy, loving father of Joshua, Nina, Seth and Alexandra. Dear brother of Milton and Florence; adoring grandfather of Samuel, Sophia, Elias, Nathaniel, Dalia and Phineas. He will be missed. Service Thursday 2PM at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: To the Editor:

title: Banned, Saddam Hussein the Literary Lion Roars Again
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 29 - The unpublished novel "Get Out, You Damned One" will not win any literary awards. A forgettable piece of pulp, it features a scheming traitor, an invading army of Zionist-Christian infidels and an Arab liberator. The only thing that sets the novel apart from numerous others like it in Arab bookstores is its author: Saddam Hussein.

title: Chief of TBWA Worldwide declines offer from rival Havas
Paid Notice: Deaths   KING, HELENE F.
description: KING--Helene F., June 28, 2005. Wife of the late Richard M. King. Mother of Nancy Bernstein and Betsy Militello. Mother-in-law of Bob Bernstein and Sam Militello. Grandmother of Daniel and Matthew Bernstein. Aunt of Susan Neitzke, David Feltman and Edward Feltman. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her.

title: Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: Holding Steady
description: This week's Billboard album chart looks a lot like last week's. Coldplay's "X&Y" (Capitol) is at No.1 for the third week in a row, with sales of 186,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan; and, with some shifts, the next several spots are not much changed. Mariah Carey's "Emancipation of Mimi" (Island/Def Jam), which has bumped around the Top 5 for 11 weeks now, is at No.2; the Foo Fighters' "In Your Honor" (Roswell/RCA), falls one spot to No.3, and the Black Eyed Peas' "Monkey Business" (A&M/Interscope) climbs one to No.4. Don't expect those albums to leave the Top 10 anytime soon. This week's chart also has some notable debuts: the rap group Boyz N Da Hood's self-titled first album, on the Bad Boy label, opened at No.5 with sales of 101,000, and "The Way It Is" (A&M/Interscope) by Keyshia Cole, a young R&B singer, is at No.6, with 89,000. BEN SISARIO

title: Whipple: The New Lipton?
description: Whipple: The New Lipton?

title: Rain Floods Westchester, Stranding Travelers
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 29 - Torrential rains caused major flooding across Westchester County on Wednesday, stranding drivers as parkways were closed and forcing commuters off trains long before their stations.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Vote For Felons
description: The State Senate approved a ballot question asking voters to consider a constitutional amendment that would allow felons to vote after they finish their prison terms. The measure, approved 27 to 8, will put the amendment on the ballot in November 2006. Now, as in many other states, former felons in Rhode Island may vote only after completing their probation and parole. Thirteen states and the District of Columbia allow felons to vote while on parole or probation; four others, including New York, allow them to vote while on probation, and Maine and Vermont extend the vote to prisoners as well. Kate Zernike (NYT)

title: High Milosevic official convicted in 4 murders
World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Ex-No. 2 In Court On Graft Charges
description: Jacob Zuma, the former deputy president, appeared in court on two counts of official corruption. He was released on bail, and his case was postponed until Oct. 11. He is accused of accepting bribes from a Durban businessman, apparently in exchange for influencing government contracts. Sharon LaFraniere (NYT)

title: On Way to Life in Britain, With a Year's Airport Layover
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 29 - After nearly 13 months at the Jomo Kenyatta International Airport, Sanjai L. Shah can safely drop his protest and leave. He is not about to, though.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (Bravo) BEING BOBBY BROWN -- Series premiere. Mr. Brown has gotten his name into print for a lot of reasons -- as a solo singer, as a member of New Edition, as Whitney Houston's husband and as a man with legal troubles. This new behind-the-scenes reality show promises at least one courtroom visit. And a lot of family (above, from left: Bobby Jr., Pops, La Princia, Mr. Brown, Ms. Houston, Tommy, Bobbi Kristina).

title: National Briefing | Washington: Senators Seek Inquiry
description: The Senate minority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, and another Democrat, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey, called on the Government Accountability Office to investigate a White House official's editing of reports to Congress on global warming. The two senators want an inquiry into whether the official, Philip Cooney, violated laws on falsification of documents and obstruction of Congress in revising two reports. Mr. Cooney, a former oil industry lobbyist, has left his position at the Council on Environmental Quality to join an oil company. Carl Hulse (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with a rock review about Billy Corgan, at Webster Hall in Manhattan, misidentified the musician at the right. He was Matt Walker. (Brian Liesegang, who also performed with the group, was not shown.)

description: AND now, another episode of gadgetry's long-running corporate soap opera, "As the Palm Turns."

title: World Briefing | Mideast: Gaza: Withdrawal Protests Pick Up
description: Israeli security forces fought with right-wing Jewish protesters who had occupied two abandoned Palestinian houses on the Gaza beachfront for the last three days to protest Israel's planned withdrawal from Gaza in August, journalists on the scene reported. About 40 protesters were arrested. Meanwhile, other opponents of the withdrawal spread oil and spikes across the main highway between Jerusalem and Tel Aviv and later sat down on roads to stop traffic in several places around the country. On the main road in and out of Jerusalem, the police used a water cannon to drive protesters from the street. Greg Myre (NYT)

World Briefing | United Nations: Annan To Submit Council Papers To Volcker Panel
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan summoned Security Council ambassadors to his office to tell them he had received new requests for documents of the oil-for-food program and intended to comply. The staff notes and Secretariat records were sought by the committee led by Paul A. Volcker that is investigating the program and cover the work of the Security Council committee that oversaw contracts awarded under the program. Reid Morden, executive director of the inquiry, said that the panel needed the papers for the next stage of its examination and that "it is not that anyone has refused to give them to us." Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: New Chief in Line at UBS
description: In a sweeping change to its management structure, UBS, the giant Swiss bank, is expected to announce today that Huw Jenkins, the global head of equities, will succeed John P. Costas as chief executive of its global investment banking unit, people briefed on details of the plan said yesterday.

title: A Better Tower
description: In almost every respect, the new design for the so-called Freedom Tower, which was presented to the public yesterday, is better than the one it replaces. Above all, it will be safer, less vulnerable to terrorist attacks from the ground, thereby easing the New York Police Department's basic concerns about security, which sent the architect David Childs back to the drawing board only a few weeks ago. This building -- like the preceding design -- will also set rigorous new standards for protecting its occupants and guaranteeing a safe exit in case of disaster.

title: Knicks Keep Williams in Limbo and in Camp
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., June 29 - Herb Williams was on the podium Wednesday afternoon, sharing a table and a microphone with Isiah Thomas, appearing and speaking as the head coach of the Knicks would.

description: Correction Appended

title: Spain Legalizes Same-Sex Marriage
description: MADRID, June 30 - The Spanish Parliament gave final approval today to a bill legalizing same-sex marriage, making Spain only the second nation to eliminate all legal distinctions between same-sex and heterosexual unions, according to supporters of the bill.

title: INSIDE
description: Judge Warns Reporters They Face Jail in a Week A federal judge said that he would send reporters from The New York Times and Time magazine to jail in a week if they did not agree to testify before a grand jury about their confidential sources. The grand jury is looking into the possibly unlawful disclosure of the name of a covert C.I.A. agent. In his most extensive comments about their case, Robert D. Novak, the columnist who named the agent, expressed disappointment that the two faced jail. PAGE A18

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Caribbean Oil Alliance
description: At a Venezuela summit meeting of 15 Caribbean countries, President Hugo Chvez announced an energy alliance with his neighbors, called Petrocaribe, in which his oil-rich country will offer them cut-rate oil, a strategy aimed at blunting American influence and increasing his own. Caribbean leaders praised the plan. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Briefly: President's husband offers to go into exile
National Briefing | New England: New Hampshire: Drain At School Continues
description: St. Paul's School, the boarding school in Concord that has been criticized for its compensation practices and management, is losing another high-level administrator, Sharon D. Hennessy, the vice rector. Ms. Hennessy wrote in an e-mail message that she would take a one-year sabbatical to complete a degree at Harvard and would begin applying for positions at other schools. "The seemingly unending controversy and unique challenges facing our school weigh heavily on us all," she wrote. Her departure follows that of the rector, Bishop Craig B. Anderson, whose tenure ends today. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: Major Talent Still Stuck Biding Time in the Minors
description: MOOSIC, Pa., June 28 - Ryan Howard is entering his prime on a field where three women are dressed as produce.

title: When the Song Sounds Familiar, but You Can't Place the Singer
description: What is going "hooo" -- or perhaps it's "cooo" -- behind that tree? Song Sleuth probably knows. This device picks up bird songs with a directional microphone array, compares them with digitized songs from the birds of your region in the continental United States and lists the most likely singers on a small display.

title: Traveling a Bumpy Road to Recover Stolen Art
description: A True Story of Art, Thieves and the Hunt for a Missing Masterpiece By Edward Dolnick Illustrated. 270 pages. HarperCollins. $25.95.

description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Google shares' closing above $300 referred incorrectly in some copies to the time that David Edwards, an analyst, had been following publicly traded stocks. It is 7 years, not 20.

title: Rape victim can travel, Musharraf says
Armstrong Sees Familiar Foes as Threats in Tour de France
description: CHALLANS, France, June 30 - Lance Armstrong surprised nobody today when he named his major challengers as he seeks to win a seventh successive Tour de France, starting Saturday.

title: Eco-Friendly and Now Worldly, Too
description: "Green architecture is finally ready for its close-up," according to Alanna Stang and Christopher Hawthorne, the authors of "The Green House: New Directions in Sustainable Architecture" (Princeton Architectural Press, $45). The book documents the rise of high-style, environmentally conscious design, with examples of houses by architects like Shigeru Ban, Rick Joy and Steven Holl, as well as lesser known designers from around the world. Cocks Carmichael's Swart residence in Melbourne, Australia, below, is an example; its semidetached concrete frame creates shade and sound insulation, and photovoltaic roof panels provide power (papress.com). ALAN G. BRAKE CURRENTS: ARCHITECTURE

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Access to Art With a MetroCard Swipe
description: Like all New York City subway riders in the 1970's, Ronay Menschel encountered stations that were decrepit, dimly lighted and covered in graffiti. "The conditions were deplorable," she recalled, "and the environment was unwelcoming and oftentimes threatening."

title: North Korean Diplomat to Meet With U.S. Officials and Their Allies
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 - A senior North Korean official, in New York to attend a private foreign policy conference, will meet Thursday with representatives of the United States, Japan and South Korea, senior Bush administration officials and foreign diplomats said Wednesday. They said they would press him to explain whether North Korea planned to return to nuclear disarmament talks.

title: Serving Up Memories of Dessert and Mother
description: When Laurie Simmons, a photographer, was invited to design for Cerealart, a Philadelphia company that develops artists' products, she recalled her mother's tableware. Dinner at her mother's house was served on traditional floral-printed bone china, but dessert, Ms. Simmons said, "was a different order of business." Thinking of her mother's wildly colorful dessert plates, she designed a set of her own, along with cups and saucers, decorating them with photo collages of cookies, pies and ice cream. A set of four plates is $150, as is a set of four cups and saucers. Sets are made in limited editions of 2,500, and available through Aug. 12 at the Perry Rubenstein Gallery, 526 West 24th Street, which is exhibiting "Cerealart: Feed Your Head," an installation of 25 artist-designed products. Information: (212)627-8000. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Pleads Guilty In Illegal Arms Deal
description: A Yonkers man pleaded guilty yesterday to illegally shipping weapons to the island of Mindanao in the southern Philippines, said David N. Kelley, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Fernando Sero, 35, admitted that he shipped parts of AK-47 and AR-15 assault rifles to the Philippines in March without a federal permit, prosecutors said. They said Mr. Sero, who is to be sentenced in September, was facing up to 10 years in prison.

title: Bank of America to Buy MBNA, Creating Top Credit Card Issuer
description: The Bank of America Corporation said today that it would acquire the MBNA Corporation, a leading issuer of credit cards, in a deal valued at $35 billion in stock and cash.

title: No Need To Match, Just Mix
description: WALKING through a show house can be overwhelming: there are so many rooms filled with high-end furniture. The Hampton Designer Showhouse, which opened Sunday (through Aug. 14) is no different. But if you look carefully -- and understand that decorating is largely in the details -- there are tricks of the trade that anyone can adapt.

title: No Coffee on Subway? M.T.A. Holds That Order
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is still without a five-year capital plan, and billions of dollars worth of building projects may be put on hold, but its chairman found himself contemplating an altogether different matter yesterday: Just how much of a mess can a cup of coffee really make?

title: The Buyouts Versus the Holdouts
description: IN a suburb of Buffalo, a developer wants to knock down more than 300 homes to make way for a traditional-style town that he says he believes will alleviate blight. In Norwood, Ohio, three property owners are the lone holdouts against a developer's plan to build shops and parking garages on the site where some of them have lived for more than 30 years. And in Brooklyn, recently converted lofts are in the path of a proposed basketball arena.

description: The banter, the ostentatious statements and the hype surrounding a fight to determine the world's best middleweight boxer inevitably finds its way back to a single topic: age.

title: In Rhode Island, Uncertainty About Medical Marijuana Law
description: BOSTON, June 29 - Hearing that the Rhode Island legislature approved the use of medical marijuana Tuesday night, Rhonda O'Donnell sat in her Warwick, R.I., living room and giddily thought about legally sauting the drug in some butter and putting it into a cake mix.

title: Case of Mad Cow in Texas Is First to Originate in U.S.
description: The cow that was found last week to have mad cow disease spent its whole life in Texas, making it the first domestic case of the disease, the United States Department of Agriculture said yesterday.

Mayor Agrees to Council's Review of Revenue Source He Uses
description: For years, New York City mayors have had control over a special source of revenue that they could use for projects without review by the City Council.

title: Election in Iran
U.S. Freezes Assets of Syrian Officials Active in Lebanon
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 - The Bush administration took a major step today to put pressure on the Syrian government, ordering a freeze on any bank accounts controlled by two senior Syrian intelligence officials because of their activities in Lebanon, including ties to Hezbollah and threats that preceded the assassination of Lebanon's prime minister.

title: Iran's New President
description: Presidential elections in Iran defy easy categorization. The winner assumes Iran's highest elective office, but no president to date has been able to defy the wishes of the unelected ayatollahs who rule the country. And while the nomination process is very tightly controlled, the eventual winner often comes as a surprise to many Iranians and most outsiders.

title: A Cheating Charge Is Upheld at European Championships
description: The Second European Open Bridge Championships are proceeding in Tenerife, on the Canary Islands. All went smoothly until the diagramed deal on Sunday in the final round of the Swiss qualifying section of the open team event. Massimo Lanzarotti and Andrea Buratti sat North and South representing Italy, which needed a big victory against an Israeli team.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Transit Fare Increase Scheduled
description: New Jersey Transit's second fare increase in three years takes effect tomorrow , increasing the average cost of monthly commuter rail and bus passes 11.5 percent. To avoid paying the higher prices, commuters can buy one-way and off-peak tickets at full fare before midnight tonight for use at any time. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

title: Seeking new Sparx, manager looks beyond Japan for growth
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Critical Mass Bicyclist Acquitted
description: One of 33 bicyclists arrested last October in a monthly Critical Mass bicycle protest was found not guilty on Tuesday of charges of disorderly conduct and parading without a permit. The bicyclist, Liz Shura, an art director at The Wall Street Journal, had been the sole rider to plead not guilty and take her case to trial, said Mark Taylor, a spokesman for Freewheels, a group that defends the Critical Mass riders. The cases of the 32 other bicyclists, arrested for running red lights and other violations, had been adjourned in contemplation of dismissal. Mr. Taylor said that a judge in New York County Supreme Court acquitted Ms. Shura after just 30 minutes of testimony, saying that her lawyer did not have to present a defense. Two dozen bicyclists arrested at a ride in March are to go on trial on Wednesday. Patrick O'Gilfoil Healy (NYT)

title: Rediscovering a Playwright Lost to Time
description: Susan Glaspell was the second woman to win the Pulitzer Prize for drama. She was a founder of the Provincetown Players and is credited with discovering Eugene O'Neill. Her novels were best sellers. So why is she practically unknown in 2005?

title: Appraisal:Fear in a soaring tower
Corrections
description: A report by The Associated Press in the Metro Briefing column on Tuesday about a vote by members of the First Congregational Church in Torrington, Conn., to leave the United Church of Christ referred imprecisely to the denomination's position on same-sex marriage. Although its Connecticut organization has endorsed it, the General Synod, a national convention of church delegates, has not yet considered the issue (it is on the agenda for the session beginning tomorrow).

title: People: Stevie Wonder, Jennifer Tilly, Johnny Carson
Push for autonomy develops in Iraqi south
Wombs on Wheels
description: JOGGING strollers made their debut in 1984, when a company called Baby Jogger developed a revolutionary three-wheel unit and sold 100 of them in the first year, for just $200 each. They cost a lot more these days, but parent-runners also have a broad choice of brands and models, some of which can be used for activities other than running.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Monaco: Prince Wins Case Against Magazine
description: Prince Albert II won 50,000 euros, about $60,000, in damages against the French magazine Paris-Match for invasion of privacy after a feature and photos it ran last month of a Togolese woman and her young son, who she claims is Albert's. Albert became Monaco's ruler in April, after the death of his father, Prince Rainier III. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: The Silver Lining in Iran
description: Stanford, Calif. - THE hottest book in Iran these days is Bill Clinton's "My Life." There are three unauthorized translations on the market and at least two more on the way, Iranian newspapers report. By all accounts, a George W. Bush memoir might do just as well. And that is only the most recent indication of the overwhelmingly favorable disposition of the Iranian population toward the United States.

title: Crowds Gather at Boys' Funeral to Mourn and to Vent
description: CAMDEN, N.J., June 29 - Carl Ramos showed up at the funeral on Wednesday night, a T-shirt down to his knees.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fields Outlines Economic Plan
description: C. Virginia Fields, left, the Manhattan borough president and a Democratic candidate for mayor, proposed yesterday that the city give microloans to small businesses and neighborhood stores in a financial pinch. As part of her economic development plan if she were mayor, Ms. Fields said, the city would grant loans to small businesses in amounts from a few thousands dollars to $250,000. The city now offers technical assistance but not loans. Other parts of her plan included setting aside 20 percent of city contracts for minority-owned businesses and 15 percent for businesses owned by women, and negotiating with landlords to extend commercial leases to at least five years. Patrick D. Healy (NYT)

title: A Nice Guy Finishes First for the Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., June 29 - Anyone who believes Channing Frye is not tough enough for New York has not seen him banging for rebounds while a front tooth dangles by a root from his top gum. Or, at least, has not heard Channing's mother describe the scene.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOKOL, IRENE M.
description: SOKOL--Irene M., of New York City, formerly of Morristown, New Jersey, died quietly on June 28, at SloanKettering Hospital. Loving sister of Helen Lefko and Florentine; dear aunt of Lauren, Janet and Frank; grandaunt of Lindsey, Jeffrey, Christopher and Charles. A graduate of Hunter College, Bryn Mawr and the University of Warsaw, where she received a Doctorate in Eastern European Studies. She taught at Fairleigh Dickinson U., Madison Campus, and was an active member of the Zonta International, serving as Governor of District 3. She will be deeply missed. Funeral Mass will be Saturday, July 2, at 9 AM, at St. Adalbert's R.C. Church, Elmhurst, NY.

title: 'New era' on defense for India and U.S.
WorldCom's Founder to Surrender His Fortune
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, the founder and former chief executive of WorldCom who was found guilty of fraud by a New York jury in March, agreed today to surrender nearly all of his approximately $40 million personal fortune to investors who lost billions of dollars when the telecommunications company spiraled into bankruptcy almost three years ago.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article in Business Day yesterday about the acquittal of the former chief executive of HealthSouth, Richard M. Scrushy, misstated the jurisdiction of the prosecutors in the conviction of two former Tyco officers, L. Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H. Swartz. They were New York State prosecutors, not federal.

description: LEVINE--Harvey. His fellow members of the Yale Class of 1951 note with sadness the passing of our dear friend, Harvey Levine. His intelligence, energy, high spirits and devotion to Yale will be long remembered. We send our heartfelt condolences to Marcia and his children to whom he has left a fine name.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, a front-page article yesterday about President Bush's televised speech on Iraq misstated the writer's characterization of Mr. Bush's tone of voice in some copies. It was uncharacteristically somber -- not "characteristically."

title: Writer in Sources Case Laments Threat to Jail 2 Reporters
description: Robert D. Novak, the columnist whose unmasking of a C.I.A. operative prompted an investigation of who had given her name to him and others, expressed disappointment yesterday that two other reporters faced going to jail for not cooperating in the case.

title: Russia aims to halt sale by Yukos
Are These Parties for Real?
description: IF drinking, driving and college admissions aren't enough for the parents of teenagers to worry about, there's a new specter on the horizon: "rainbow parties."

title: Quantrill and Stanton May Be Let Go Thursday
description: BALTIMORE, June 29 - The veteran relievers Paul Quantrill and Mike Stanton appear to have pitched their last games for the Yankees. Hoping to make their bullpen younger, the Yankees could release or trade both on Thursday.

title: Time Inc. Statement on Handing Over Documents

Playing AIDS Games in New Jersey
description: The New Jersey State Senate is placing politics above public safety -- and tacitly promoting the spread of H.I.V. and AIDS -- by failing to pass a desperately needed needle exchange bill that was approved by the State Assembly last year. Without access to clean needles, or to treatment programs, which are now overcrowded, addicts risk almost certain infection by continuing to share needles with other addicts. They then spread AIDS through sexual contact to their wives, lovers and unborn children, endangering an ever-widening circle of lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VOLK, JESSE
description: VOLK--Jesse. Dearly beloved, our love affair is over but my memories will linger forever. Rest in peace, Iris VOLK--Jesse. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, uncle and friend. Devoted to Iris Gelber and the Gelber family. Burial services private. Donations in Jesse's memory can be made to the New York Weill Cornell Medical Center. Attn: The Jesse Volk Fund for Underserved Child Healthcare, 525 E. 68th Street Box 123 New York, NY 10002.

title: Brazilians Streaming Into U.S. Through Mexican Border
description: BRANAS, Brazil - For years, Jaider de Andrade, a 35-year-old farm worker, talked about going to the United States to look for work, and early in March he finally agreed to a trafficker's offer to fly him to Mexico and have him guided across the border there. By month's end, though, he was back home here again, in a coffin.

title: A Tower of Impregnability, The Sort Politicians Love
description: The darkness at ground zero just got a little darker. If there are people still clinging to the expectation that the Freedom Tower will become a monument to the highest American ideals, the current design should finally shake them out of that delusion. Somber, oppressive and clumsily conceived, the project suggests a monument to a society that has turned its back on any notion of cultural openness. It is exactly the kind of nightmare that government officials repeatedly asserted would never happen here: an impregnable tower braced against the outside world.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Seymour: Powerball Winner Announced
description: A computer parts salesman from Seymour claimed the $59.5 million Powerball Jackpot Prize yesterday, the largest lottery prize ever won in Connecticut. The salesman, Christopher Ewen, 45, and his wife, Lucille, 47, a financial services representative at a bank, will receive an after-tax payment of $34.6 million on July 11. The winning ticket was among three quick picks Mr. Ewen bought on June 24 at the Shop Smart in Seymour. The couple and their children have been living with Mr. Ewen's parents while saving to buy a house. Stacey Stowe (NYT)
